Ordinances that are of a general and permanent nature are codified in the Code Book and are considered "Included." Ordinances that are not of a general and permanent nature are not codified in the Code Book and are considered "Omitted."

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1-1. - Designation, citation and abbreviation of Code. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters, articles and sections shall constitute and be designated as the "Farmington City Code" and may be abbreviated as the "Code," "city Code," or "FCC" and may be so cited. 
(Code 1969, § 1-1-1) 
Sec. 1-1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances of this city, the following rules of construction and definitions shall be observed, unless such construction or definition would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council, unless such construction or definition would be repugnant to the context of the provisions or unless the context clearly requires otherwise: 
    Generally. All words and phrases shall be construed and understood according to the common and approved usage of language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning. 
    City. The term "city" means the City of Farmington, New Mexico. 
    City council or council. The term "city council" or "council" means the city council of the city. 
    Code. The term "Code" means the Farmington City Code designated in section 1-1-1. References to the Code include all additions and amendments to it. 
    Computation of time. Unless otherwise specifically provided, in computing time the first day shall be excluded and the last day included. If the last day falls on a weekend, the time prescribed shall be extended so as to include the whole of the following Monday. If the last day falls on a holiday, the time prescribed shall be extended so as to include the whole of the next workday. 
    County. The term "county" means San Juan County, New Mexico. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears in this Code requiring an officer of the city to do some act or make certain inspections, it is to be construed to authorize such officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or make the required inspection, unless the terms of the provision or section expressly designate otherwise. 
    Easement. The term "easement" means a right, liberty, privilege or advantage without profit which the owner of one parcel of land may have in the lands of another; a right in the owner of one parcel of land, by reason of such ownership, to use the land of another for a special purpose not inconsistent with a general property right in the owner. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships, associations and corporations, as well as to males. 
    In the city. The term "in the city" or "in this city" means any territory within the corporate limits of this city and the police jurisdiction thereof, and any other territory over which regulatory power has been conferred on the city by law, except as otherwise specified. 
    Joint authority. Words purporting to give authority to three or more officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such officers or other persons, unless it is otherwise specifically declared. 
    Law. The term "law" means any statute, ordinance or regulation promulgated by the United States, the state, the county, the city or any agencies thereof, as well as the rules and regulations of other bodies politic that may be appropriate. 
    May. The term "may" is to be construed as being discretionary or permissive. 
    Minor. The term "minor" means the age, with respect to all offenses except those involving alcoholic beverages, of any person under 18 years of age. 
    Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. 
    NMSA 1978. The abbreviation "NMSA 1978" means the New Mexico Statutes Annotated, 1978, as amended. 
    Number. Any word importing the singular number shall include the plural, and any word importing the plural number shall include the singular. 
    Oath. The term "oath" includes an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the terms "swear" and "sworn" are equivalent to the terms "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Official time standard. Whenever certain hours are named in this Code, they shall mean standard time or daylight saving time, as may be in current use in the city. 
    Officials, employees, boards, commissions, etc. Whenever reference is made to officials, employees, boards, commissions or other agencies of the city by title only, i.e., "mayor," "clerk," "manager," "chief of police," etc., it shall be deemed to refer to the officials, employees, boards, commissions or other agencies of this city. 
    Or, and. The term "or" may be read "and," and the term "and" may be read "or," if the context of the provision requires it. 
    Owner. The term "owner," when applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The term "person" includes any firm, partnership, association, corporation, organization, club, society, group acting as a unit, or body politic and corporate, as well as to an individual. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" includes money, goods, chattels, evidences of debt, things in action, and any other species of property, except real property. 
    Preceding, following. The terms "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Property. The term "property" includes real, personal and mixed property. 
    Public place. The term "public place" means any public way, park, cemetery, school yard or open space adjacent thereto; any public lake or stream; and any place or business open to the use of the public in general, open to public view or to which the public has access. 
    Public way. The term "public way" means any street, alley, boulevard, parkway, highway, sidewalk or other public thoroughfare. 
    Real property. The term "real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Reasonable time. In all cases where any section of this Code or a city ordinance shall require any act to be done in a reasonable time or shall require reasonable notice to be given, such reasonable time or notice shall be deemed to mean such time only as may be necessary for the prompt performance of such duty, or compliance with such notice. 
    Residence. The term "residence" means the place adopted by a person as his place of habitation, and to which, whenever he is absent, he has the intention of returning. When a person eats at one place and sleeps at another, the place where such person sleeps shall be deemed his residence. 
    Roadway. The term "roadway" means that portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic. 
    Shall. The term "shall" is to be construed as being mandatory. 
    Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" means any portion of the street between the curb, or the lateral line of the roadway and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    Signature, subscription. The term "signature" or "subscription" includes a mark when the person cannot write, when his name is written near such mark and is witnessed by a person who writes his own name as witness. 
    State. The term "state" means the State of New Mexico. 
    Street. The term "street" includes public streets, avenues, boulevards, highways, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts, bridges, public ways and approaches thereto and other public thoroughfares in the city devoted to public use. 
    Tenant, occupant. The terms "tenant" and "occupant," when applied to a building or land, mean any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense shall include the future, as well as the past or present. 
    Writing, written. The terms "writing" and "written" include typewriting, printing on paper and any other mode of representing words and letters. 
    Year. The term "year" means a calendar year. 
(Code 1969, § 1-2-1) 
Sec. 1-1-3. - Catchlines of sections; history notes; references in Code. 
(a)  The catchlines of the several sections of this Code, set in boldface type, are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections nor as any part of such sections nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(b)  The history or source notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect, but are merely intended to indicate the sources of matter contained in the section. Cross references, editor's notes, and state law references which appear after sections or subsections of this Code or which otherwise appear in footnote form are provided for the convenience of the user of this Code and have no legal effect. 
(c)  All references to chapters, articles, divisions or sections are to the chapters, articles, divisions and sections of this Code, unless otherwise specified. 
(Code 1969, § 1-2-2) 
Sec. 1-1-4. - Continuation of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same in substance as ordinances existing at the effective date of this Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. 
Sec. 1-1-5. - Effect of repeal of ordinance. 
    The repeal of an ordinance or any portion thereof shall not revive any ordinance in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1969, § 1-2-3) 
Sec. 1-1-6. - Police power extended to city property. 
    The police power of the city is extended to include all lands or property owned or leased by the city or any agency of the city, and the general ordinances of the city shall be applicable on such property. 
Sec. 1-1-7. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby; provided that supplementation of this Code by authorized persons shall be permitted. 
Sec. 1-1-8. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
(a)  All ordinances that amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion in this Code. In the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "Section _____ of the Farmington City Code is amended to read as follows:...." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(c)  If new material not heretofore in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "Section (chapter, article, division, etc.) _____ of the Farmington City Code is created to read as follows:...." The new provisions should then be set out in full. 
(d)  All provisions of this Code should be specially repealed by reference to the section, article, etc., of this Code. 
Sec. 1-1-9. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code during the period. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages that have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code that have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ to _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
Sec. 1-1-10. - General penalty; additional fees; additional penalties for certain acts. 
(a)  General penalty. Whenever in this Code or in any other ordinance or resolution of the city or in any rule, regulation or order promulgated by an officer or agency of the city under authority duly vested in him or if any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of such Code or any other ordinance or resolution of the city or such rule, regulation or order shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $500.00 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 90 days or by both such fine and imprisonment. Except where otherwise provided, every day any violation of this Code or any other ordinance or resolution of the city or such rule, regulation or order shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Correction fee assessment. The municipal judge shall collect a correction fee assessment in the sum of $20.00 from any person convicted of violating any ordinance relating to the operation of a motor vehicle or convicted of any ordinance which may be enforced by the imposition of a term of imprisonment. No correction fee will be collected for any violation involving the unlawful parking of a motor vehicle. All money collected pursuant to this subsection shall be deposited in a special fund in the municipal treasury and shall be used for such purposes as provided by state law, as from time to time amended. 
(c)  Penalty for driving while under influence of alcohol or drug. As used in this subsection, the term "conviction" means a finding of guilt of any provision of federal, state or local law forbidding driving while under the influence of any alcohol or drug or driving with a blood alcohol content in excess of a specified minimum. In addition to any provision of the state motor vehicle code or this Code, the following penalties shall apply to violations of sections 25-1-1/66-8-102 and 25-1-1/66-5-39: 
(1)  Upon a first conviction of this offense, the minimum punishment shall be imprisonment for 72 consecutive hours. 
(2)  Upon a second or third conviction of section 25-1-1/66-8-102 or any violation of section 25-1-1/66-5-39, the offender shall be punished by a term of imprisonment of not more than 179 days. 
(3)  Upon a first conviction for aggravated driving while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or drugs, pursuant to sections 25-1-1/66-8-102 or any second or third conviction for driving while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or drugs, the municipal court shall, as a condition of probation, require the offender to have an ignition interlock device installed and operating for a period of at least one year on all motor vehicles driven by the offender, pursuant to rules adopted by the New Mexico Traffic Safety Bureau. Unless determined by the municipal court to be indigent, the offender shall pay all costs associated with having an interlock device installed on the appropriate vehicles. In no event shall the city be responsible for any of the costs associated with the installation or operation of the ignition interlock device. If an offender drives a motor vehicle that does not have an ignition interlock device installed, the offender shall be in violation of the terms and conditions of his probation. 
(4)  In all other cases municipal court may order an interlock device to be installed on all motor vehicles to be driven by the offender upon the same terms as set forth in the preceding section. 
(d)  Maximum imprisonment for more than one offense in single occurrence. Notwithstanding any other section of this Code or state law, when a defendant is charged with more than one offense arising out of a single transaction, act or occurrence, the maximum sentence of imprisonment that may be imposed shall not be greater than 179 days. 
(e)  Fine for violation of wastewater pretreatment ordinances. Notwithstanding the general penalty in subsection (a) of this section, upon conviction of any violation of an ordinance relating to wastewater pretreatment, the municipal court shall impose a fine of not more than $1,000.00 per day for each violation. 
(f)  Court automation fee. In addition to any fine or imprisonment, there is imposed upon any person convicted of violating any municipal ordinance, the penalty for which carries a potential jail term, or any ordinance relating to the operation of a motor vehicle a mandatory court automation fee of $6.00. All court automation fees collected shall be remitted monthly to the state treasurer for credit to the municipal court automation fund and shall be used for the purchase and maintenance of court automation systems in the municipal courts. The court automation systems shall have the capability of providing, on a timely basis, electronic records in a format specified by the judicial information system council. 
(g)  Fee for tests for person convicted of marijuana possession. A person convicted of possession of marijuana in violation of section 18-5-9 shall be assessed, in addition to any other fine or fee, a fee of $75.00 to defray the costs of chemical and other tests utilized. 
(h)  Judicial education fee. Any person convicted of violating any municipal ordinance, the penalty for which carries a potential jail term, or any ordinance relating to the operation of a motor vehicle, shall pay to the municipal court, in addition to any fine or other sentence, a judicial education fee in the amount established by state law. All money collected pursuant to this subsection shall be remitted monthly to the state treasurer for credit to the judicial education fund and shall be used for such purposes as provided by state law, as from time to time amended. 
(Code 1969, § 10-1-1; Ord. No. 98-1072, § 1, 4-28-1998; Ord. No. 02-1137, § 1, 12-10-02; Ord. No. 2003-1143, §§ 1, 2, 6-10-03; Ord. No. 2006-1176, § 1, 10-24-06; Ord. No. 2009-1216, § 1, 7-28-09) 
Sec. 1-1-11. - Severability of parts of Code. 
(a)  It is the intention of the city council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code is declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code, since such would have been enacted by the city council without the incorporation in this Code of any such unconstitutional phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. 
(b)  If any provision of this Code or the application thereof to any person, fact, situation or circumstance is held invalid, the remainder of this Code and the application of such provision to other persons, facts, situations or circumstances shall not be affected thereby. 
(Code 1969, § 1-2-4) 
Sec. 1-1-12. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance: 
(1)  Promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the city. 
(2)  Granting any right or franchise. 
(3)  Dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city. 
(4)  Making any appropriation. 
(5)  Levying or imposing taxes. 
(6)  Establishing or prescribing grades in the city. 
(7)  Providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor. 
(8)  Dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision or prescribing subdivision regulations. 
(9)  Extending or contracting the boundaries of the city. 
(10)  Prescribing the number, classification, benefits or compensation of any city officers or employees, not inconsistent with this Code. 
(11)  Pertaining to zoning map amendments or rezoning. 
(12)  Adopted for purposes that have been consummated. 
(13)  That is temporary, although general in effect. 
(14)  That is special, although permanent in effect. 
(b)  All such ordinances are recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. Such ordinances are on file in the clerk's office. 
Sec. 1-1-13. - Prior offenses, penalties, rights not affected by adoption of Code. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. 
(b)  The adoption of this Code shall not be interpreted as authorizing or permitting any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any ordinance of the city in effect on the date of adoption of this Code. 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1]

ARTICLE 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1-1. - City seal. 
    The impression of the city seal is as follows: In the center the words "Incorporated Seal 1901" and around the outer edge the words "City of Farmington, New Mexico." 
(Code 1969, § 1-4-1) 
ARTICLE 2. - CITY COUNCIL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Disaster succession, § 10-3-1 et seq. 
State Law reference- Governing body of municipalities, NMSA 1978, § 3-12-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-2-1. - Composition. 
    Subject to the provisions of this article pertaining to the implementation of districting, the governing body of the city shall consist of a mayor to be elected at large and four councilors who shall be elected from single-member districts. 
(Code 1969, § 2-2) 
State Law reference- Election of members of governing bodies from single-member districts, NMSA 1978, § 3-12-1.1. 
Sec. 2-2-2. - Salary of mayor and councilors. 
    The mayor shall receive an annual salary of $15,000.00. Councilors shall receive an annual salary of $10,000.00. The salaries of the mayor and the councilors shall be paid periodically to correspond with the usual pay periods of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 2-7) 
State Law reference- Salaries of mayor and councilmen, NMSA 1978, §§ 3-10-3, 4-44-4.1. 
Secs. 2-2-3-2-2-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ELECTION 

Sec. 2-2-31. - Creation of districts. 
(a)  Councilors shall reside in and shall be elected from single-member municipal election districts. 
(b)  The boundaries of each municipal election district are shown on the municipal election district map as adopted or as may be amended as provided in section 2-2-32. 
(Code 1969, § 2-2.1) 
Sec. 2-2-32. - Amendment of district map. 
(a)  Pursuant to the requirements of NMSA 1978, § 3-12-1.1, the city council shall divide the city into four districts, equal to the number of members in the city council. Each district shall be compact and contiguous and composed of populations as nearly equal as possible. 
(b)  Pursuant to the requirements of NMSA 1978, § 3-12-2F, the city council may redistrict the city whenever redistricting is warranted. Upon receipt of a petition signed by qualified electors equal in number to the votes cast for a councilor receiving the greatest number of votes at the last regular municipal election, the city council shall redistrict the city. 
(c)  Pursuant to the requirements of NMSA 1978, § 3-12-1.1, the city council shall redistrict the city following every federal decennial census. 
(d)  The city council may, whenever it may deem districting to be warranted, amend the municipal election district map. 
(e)  Changes in boundaries of the municipal election district map shall be noted on the official municipal election district map kept on file and in the custody of the city clerk. 
(f)  Changes made upon the official municipal election district map shall be commemorated by resolution adopted by the city council and shall be effective immediately upon adoption of the resolution. 
(g)  The city clerk shall give notice of the proposed adoption of a commemorative resolution described in subsection (f) of this section by publication of the proposed resolution or a summary thereof in a newspaper of general circulation in the city not less than ten days prior to the adoption of such resolution, provided that the city council may adopt such resolution as an emergency measure without such publication if it determines that an emergency exists which requires adoption of the resolution without notice and publication. 
(Code 1969, § 2-2.2) 
Sec. 2-2-33. - Candidates. 
(a)  Only persons residing in a particular municipal election district and who otherwise meet all applicable requirements imposed by law or ordinance shall be allowed to be candidates for the position of councilor for that municipal election district. 
(b)  In determining whether the residence of a person is in a particular district, the rules set forth in NMSA 1978, §§ 3-8-3 and 1-1-7, shall apply. 
(c)  In addition to the requirements for a declaration of candidacy set forth in NMSA 1978, § 3-8-27A, the city clerk shall not accept a declaration of candidacy for the position of councilor unless the declaration of candidacy states which district the candidate resides in and is seeking election from. The city clerk shall determine if the candidate's residence is within the district from which the candidate is seeking election. If the candidate does not reside within the district, the city clerk shall determine that the declaration of candidacy is invalid. 
(d)  A write-in candidate shall not be elected to fill the position of councilor unless the write-in candidate resides in the district from which the write-in candidate is elected. 
(Code 1969, § 2-2.4) 
Sec. 2-2-34. - Contents of resolution. 
    In addition to the requirements of NMSA 1978, § 3-8-26, the election resolution calling for the regular municipal election shall set forth which districts of the city will be electing councilors. 
(Code 1969, § 2-2.5) 
Sec. 2-2-35. - Polling places. 
    In addition to the requirements of NMSA 1978, § 3-8-11, the city council shall ensure that each election district has not less than one polling place. 
(Code 1969, § 2-2.6) 
Sec. 2-2-36. - Ballots. 
    In addition to the requirements of NMSA 1978, § 3-8-29, the city clerk shall cause all ballots to separate candidates for the position of councilor by district. The order of the candidates running for office within each district shall be determined by a drawing by lot. There shall be a position for a voter to insert a write-in candidate below the names of the candidates running for legislative office from each district. 
(Code 1969, § 2-2.7) 
Sec. 2-2-37. - Duties of precinct boards. 
    In addition to the requirements of NMSA 1978, § 3-8-20, the precinct board shall ensure that each person who votes is registered in the district, resides in the district, is otherwise a qualified elector and votes only for a candidate for the position of councilor from the district. 
(Code 1969, § 2-2.8) 
Sec. 2-2-38. - Publication of names of candidates. 
    In addition to the requirements of NMSA 1978, § 3-8-30, the city clerk shall ensure that the publication of the names of candidates for the office of councilor shall designate from which election district each such candidate is seeking election. 
(Code 1969, § 2-2.9) 
Sec. 2-2-39. - Election of other municipal officers. 
    Nothing in this division shall be construed to affect the manner in which other municipal officers are elected. 
(Code 1969, § 2-2.10) 
Sec. 2-2-40. - Plurality of votes required for election. 
    In addition to the requirements of NMSA 1978, § 3-8-32, each candidate for the position of councilor shall only receive votes cast for such candidate by the resident qualified electors of the election district from which that candidate is running. The candidate who receives a plurality of votes cast in that district shall be elected to the office for the term designated. 
(Code 1969, § 2-2.11) 
Sec. 2-2-41. - Canvass of returns; certificates. 
    Regarding canvass of returns and issuance of an election certificate, appropriate election officials shall ensure that returns are canvassed and election certificates are issued on a district-by-district basis for the position of councilor. 
(Code 1969, § 2-2.12) 
Sec. 2-2-42. - Adoption and implementation of procedures. 
    The city clerk shall adopt and implement appropriate procedures to ensure that elections conducted under supervision of the clerk are conducted in a fair and impartial manner, that only qualified voters are allowed to vote upon candidates or questions which are at large, and that district voters vote only in the district in which such voters reside and are qualified. 
(Code 1969, § 2-2.13) 
DIVISION 3. - CAMPAIGN FINANCING 

Sec. 2-2-43. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Candidate means an individual seeking election to the position of mayor, councilor or municipal judge at a regular or special election of the city. 
    Contribution means a gift, subscription, loan, advance or deposit of any money or other thing of value which is made for the primary purpose of supporting or opposing a candidate for elective office. This does not include the value of a volunteer's time provided without compensation or unreimbursed personal expenses, such as vehicle use or meals, of individuals who volunteer a portion or all of their time on behalf of a candidate. 
    Election means any regular or special municipal election in the city. 
    Expenditure means a payment, transfer, or distribution, or obligation or promise to pay, transfer or distribute any money or other thing of value for the purpose of influencing the outcome of an election of a candidate, but does not include the candidate's or his immediate family's personal expenses such as vehicle use or meals. 
    General purpose political committee means a political committee other than a special purpose political committee. 
    Political committee means every two or more persons who are selected, appointed, chosen or associated for the purpose of, wholly or in part, supporting or opposing a candidate at any election, and includes political committees or similar organizations composed of employees or members of any corporation, labor organization, trade or professional association or any other similar group which raises, collects, expends or contributes money or any other thing of value for the purpose of supporting or opposing a candidate in a municipal election. 
    Reporting individual means every candidate, every treasurer of every special purpose political committee or treasurer of every general purpose political committee whose purpose is to aid the candidate in the campaign for municipal office. 
    Special purpose political committee means a political committee making contributions to support or oppose one candidate, such contributions being limited to one special or one regular election. 
(Ord. No. 2013-1265, § 1, 7-9-13) 
Sec. 2-2-44. - Applicability of division. 
    This division also applies to any contributions, expenditures, persons, or committees whose purpose is to encourage adoption or defeat of any municipal question submitted to the voters of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2013-1265, § 1, 7-9-13) 
Sec. 2-2-45. - Paid political ads. 
    No candidate or political committee shall pay all or any part of the cost of a political ad endorsing a candidate for an election without disclosing such sponsorship in the ad. 
(Ord. No. 2013-1265, § 1, 7-9-13) 
Sec. 2-2-46. - Reports required. 
    Each candidate and each treasurer of each special purpose political committee and general purpose political committee shall file with the city clerk a report of expenditures and contributions on forms prescribed by the city clerk. When the reporting individual is a candidate, the report shall include the expenditures and contributions of those political committees authorized by the candidate to expend and receive funds on behalf of his candidacy, and when the candidate files a report for the political committee, the treasurer thereof need not file a report of expenditures and contributions for the period of time covered in the candidate's report. 
(Ord. No. 2013-1265, § 1, 7-9-13) 
Sec. 2-2-47. - Forms furnished by city. 
    The city clerk shall furnish upon request to political committees or candidates the form for the reporting of expenditures and contributions. The clerk shall give each candidate, or a designated representative, the prescribed reporting forms at the time of filing the declaration of candidacy. Approximately ten days before any report of expenditures and contributions is required to be filed by this division, the city clerk shall send each candidate, by mail or e-mail, a reminder of the deadline for filing the report. 
(Ord. No. 2013-1265, § 1, 7-9-13) 
Sec. 2-2-48. - Contents. 
    Under this division, each reporting individual shall file a report containing the following information: 
(1)  A report of expenditures and contributions, itemizing each item of expenditure and contribution, including: 
a.  The name and address of the person or business to whom an expenditure was made or from whom a contribution was received; 
b.  The amount of the expenditure or contribution, or value thereof; 
c.  A description of the in-kind services or goods received; and 
d.  The date of the expenditure or contribution. 
(2)  The report shall include all contributions received and expenditures made which have not been previously reported, regardless of when received or made and even if received or made before the candidate filed a declaration of candidacy; and 
(3)  The report of expenditures and contributions shall be subscribed and sworn to by the candidate or treasurer of the political committee, as the case may be. 
(Ord. No. 2013-1265, § 1, 7-9-13) 
Sec. 2-2-49. - Time for filing. 
    All candidates and special purpose political committees and general purpose political committees shall file reports of expenditures and contributions for the following reporting periods: 
(1)  During the year where the candidate is running for election, a report shall be filed by 5:00 p.m. on the following dates: 
a.  The first Monday following candidate filing day; 
b.  The second Monday of February; 
c.  The Thursday before the election; 
d.  The date which is 30 days after an election unless that date is a weekend or a holiday and then on the next regular business day; 
e.  The second Monday of October. 
(2)  During any year in which the candidate did not run in an election, a report shall be filed by 5:00 p.m. on the second Monday of each October, unless the candidate or committee neither received nor expended campaign funds since the last report was filed. 
(Ord. No. 2013-1265, § 1, 7-9-13; Ord. No. 2017-1297, § 1, 4-11-17 ) 
Sec. 2-2-50. - Late filing penalty. 
    If any candidate or treasurer of a political committee files a report of expenditures and contributions after any deadline imposed by the campaign procedures, such person shall be liable and shall pay to the city clerk at the time of late filing the sum of $50.00 per day for each regular working day after the time required by this division for the filing of reports of expenditures and contributions. An incomplete report will be considered as no report; a late filing penalty will apply to the completed report if it is not filed within the prescribed time limits. All sums collected for such penalty shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. If sent by certified mail or registered mail, the report shall be deemed filed on the date three days following the date of the postmark. 
(Ord. No. 2013-1265, § 1, 7-9-13) 
Sec. 2-2-51. - Failure to file report. 
    Any candidate who fails or refuses to file a report of expenditures and contributions in the manner and within the time required by this division shall not be issued a certificate of election until such candidate files the report of expenditures and contributions. 
(Ord. No. 2013-1265, § 1, 7-9-13) 
Sec. 2-2-52. - Political committee treasurer. 
    It is unlawful for the members of any political committee or candidate to make any expenditure or solicit or accept any contribution for the purpose of supporting or opposing a candidate, unless: 
(1)  A treasurer has been appointed and is constantly maintained; however, when a duly appointed treasurer is unable for any reason to continue as treasurer, the candidate may appoint a successor, provided that nothing in this subsection prohibits a candidate from appointing himself treasurer; 
(2)  All disbursements of money and receipts of contributions shall be recorded by and through such treasurer; and 
(3)  Such treasurer, upon disbursing or receiving money or other things of value, shall immediately enter and thereafter keep in a proper book, to be preserved by him, a full, true and itemized statement and account of each sum disbursed or received, the date of such disbursal or receipt, to whom disbursed or from whom received and the object and purpose for which it has been disbursed or received. 
(Ord. No. 2013-1265, § 1, 7-9-13) 
Sec. 2-2-53. - Contribution limitations. 
(a)  Total contributions to any candidate's campaign for any municipal office by any individual or business entity shall not exceed $2,300.00 per election. Total contributions to any candidate's campaign for any municipal office by any political committee shall not exceed $5,000.00 per election. 
(b)  Anonymous contributions are prohibited and a candidate may not knowingly accept or use a contribution without disclosing the source of the contribution on the candidate's reports. If a candidate comes into possession of an attempted anonymous contribution it shall not be used for campaign purposes, but shall be contributed to a charitable organization of the candidate's choice. 
(c)  A candidate may contribute to the candidate's own campaign without regard to the limitations in paragraph (a) of this section as long as those contributions and the expenses they are used to pay for are reported on the reports required in sections 2-2-46 through 2-2-51 of this division. 
(Ord. No. 2013-1265, § 1, 7-9-13) 
Sec. 2-2-54. - Election financial records. 
(a)  Candidates for elective office or treasurers for political committees shall keep financial records for a period of six months following the date of election, in order that the records will be available if a complaint is filed or inquiry is made. Such financial records shall include cancelled checks, invoices, receipts, bank statements, bills of sale, statements of account, and all other financial records pertinent to the campaign. 
(b)  In preparing and maintaining financial records such as ledgers and journals and recording contributions and expenditures on the disclosure statement of campaign financing, the candidates or treasurers of political committees shall: 
(1)  Record in-kind contributions as both contributions and expenditures with a description of such in-kind services or goods received; 
(2)  Record campaign loans as contributions, with subsequent repayment of loans credited against contributions; and 
(3)  Record returned contributions as credits against contributors. 
(c)  The services of a person who is performing the duties of treasurer pursuant to this division shall not be considered a campaign contribution as defined in this section. 
(d)  The gross receipts of a fundraising activity on behalf of a candidate for elective office are considered to be campaign contributions, and all expenditures associated with such a fundraising activity are considered to be campaign expenditures. As used in this interpretation, the term "gross receipts" includes all monies and donations of any kind which are received as part of the fundraising activity. 
(Ord. No. 2013-1265, § 1, 7-9-13) 
Sec. 2-2-55. - Committee statement. 
    The city clerk, upon being advised of the formation and existence of a special political committee, as defined in this division, shall furnish by mail or e-mail to the chairman, moderator, or head, however designated, of such committee, and also the fundraising member thereof, however designated, if known, a copy of this division and shall call attention to the requirements for reporting contributions and expenditures by the political committee as provided for in this division. Within ten days from receipt of the notification from the city, the political committee shall prepare and file with the office of the city clerk a statement, signed by the head of the committee or by the finance chairman thereof, setting forth the following: 
(1)  The exact name of the committee; 
(2)  Its official address and phone number, if available; 
(3)  Its membership and officials thereof; and 
(4)  Acknowledgment of receipt of a copy of this division and of the requirements regarding filing of reports. 
    It is recognized that an affirmative duty rests on the candidates and officials of political committees to be aware of the provisions of this division, and accordingly, such candidates and officials are enjoined to prepare and file the required statements without a request from the office of the city clerk. City officials are encouraged, but not required, to inform candidates and committees of their duties pursuant to this division. 
(Ord. No. 2013-1265, § 1, 7-9-13) 
ARTICLE 3. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance prescribing the number, classification, benefits or compensation of any city officers or employees, not inconsistent with this Code saved from repeal, § 1-1-12(10); appointment and authority of airport manager, § 3-1-2; enforcement of animal regulations by park rangers and animal control officers, § 6-1-1; electrical inspector, § 7-3-4; fire chief designated as local coordinator for civil emergencies, § 10-1-1; municipal judge, § 11-2-1 et seq.; fire emergency services department, § 13-2-1 et seq.; designation of floodplain administrator, § 14-2-1; police department, § 15-2-1 et seq.; special police officers, § 15-3-1 et seq.; park rangers and animal control officers, § 15-6-1 et seq.; personnel, ch. 21; traffic engineer, § 25-2-4. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-3-1. - Enumeration of city officers. 
    The mayor, members of the city council, the city manager, the city attorney, the city clerk, the city treasurer and the municipal judge are declared to be officers of the city. All other persons who receive compensation from the city are declared to be employees of the city in the performance of the duties assigned to them. 
(Code 1969, § 2-3) 
Sec. 2-3-2. - Compensation. 
    The city council shall determine and cause to be recorded in the city records the compensation to be paid all officers and employees of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 2-4) 
Sec. 2-3-3. - Terms of appointive officers. 
    Every appointive officer shall hold his position for an indefinite term, unless sooner removed for cause in the manner provided by law or unless the city council has specified a lesser term at the time of appointment of the officer. 
(Code 1969, § 2-5) 
Sec. 2-3-4. - Removal of appointive officers. 
    By the concurrent vote of three members of the city council, any appointive officer may be removed from office. However, no such removal shall be made without a charge in writing and an opportunity of hearing being given unless the officer against whom the charge is made shall have moved out of the limits of the city. When an officer has moved out of the city limits, he may be removed without a hearing. 
(Code 1969, § 2-6) 
Secs. 2-3-5-2-3-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY MANAGER[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to provide for a manager, NMSA 1978, § 3-13-3. 

Sec. 2-3-31. - Creation of office; appointment; powers and duties generally; qualifications. 
(a)  The office of city manager is created pursuant to NMSA 1978, § 3-13-3. 
(b)  The city manager shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the city council. The manager shall be selected on the basis of his training, experience and other administrative qualifications for the office. 
(c)  The city manager shall have all of the powers and duties as set out in NMSA 1978, § 3-13-3. 
(Code 1969, § 2-8) 
Sec. 2-3-32. - Oath and bond. 
    The city manager, prior to entering into or performing his duties, shall take an oath or affirmation complying with the provisions of the oath or affirmation set forth in NMSA 1978, § 3-10-2. The city manager, within ten days after his appointment, shall furnish a surety bond approved by the city council, with such bond to be conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties. The premium of the bond shall be paid by the city. 
(Code 1969, § 2-9) 
Sec. 2-3-33. - Acting manager. 
    The city manager may appoint an acting city manager who shall serve during the absence or disability of the city manager. 
(Code 1969, § 2-10) 
Sec. 2-3-34. - Removal. 
    By the concurring vote of three members of the city council, the city manager may be removed from office, and he shall not be subject to the rules and regulations of the personnel board, but shall be under the direct control of the city council. 
(Code 1969, § 2-11) 
Sec. 2-3-35. - Relationship between manager and council generally. 
    The city manager shall be responsible to the mayor and council for the administration of all units of the city government. The manager shall attend all meetings of the city council and committees thereof and take part in the discussion of matters coming before the council, but shall not have the right to vote. Except for the purpose of inquiry, the mayor and council shall deal with employees solely through the manager. The mayor and council shall establish policy, and the city manager shall execute and administer such policy. 
(Code 1969, § 2-12) 
Sec. 2-3-36. - Administrative duties; reports to council. 
    The city manager shall supervise and be responsible for the effective management of the administrative affairs of the city. The city manager shall give general direction to the programs and activities of all city departments and shall be responsible for the proper execution of the policies set by the mayor and council and the enforcement of all laws and ordinances. He shall keep the mayor and council informed of the conditions and needs of the city and shall make such reports and recommendations as he may deem desirable or as may be requested by the mayor or council. 
(Code 1969, § 2-13) 
Sec. 2-3-37. - General control of departments. 
    All department directors shall have supervision and control of their respective departments, subject to the general control and direction of the city manager. The city manager may, upon the appointment by the mayor and approval of the council, serve as the director of one or more departments. 
(Code 1969, § 2-14) 
Sec. 2-3-38. - Authority over employees; recommendations for appointments. 
    The city manager shall have full authority to hire and discharge all city employees, pursuant to the authority of and subject to the requirements of Chapter 21 pertaining to personnel. The city manager may make recommendations to the mayor and council concerning the employment, discharge, promotion or transfer of city officers appointed by the mayor, and such recommendations shall be given due weight by the city council. 
(Code 1969, § 2-15) 
Sec. 2-3-39. - Interest in city contracts or transactions. 
    The city manager shall have no financial interest in any contract or financial transaction with the city. 
(Code 1969, § 2-16) 
Secs. 2-3-40-2-3-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CITY ATTORNEY[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to provide for a city attorney, NMSA 1978, § 3-12-4(B). 

Sec. 2-3-66. - Appointment; qualifications. 
    The city attorney shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city council. He shall be admitted to the practice of law by the supreme court of the state, and he shall be in good standing in the State Bar of New Mexico. 
(Code 1969, § 2-17) 
Sec. 2-3-67. - Duties. 
(a)  The city attorney shall be the legal adviser to the city council. He shall attend all regular meetings of the council and such other meetings of the council as he shall be requested to attend by the mayor. He shall have the right to be heard at any meeting of the council at which matters involving questions of law are being discussed. He shall render to the council his opinion upon any question of law involving the interests of the city at all times when requested by the council to do so. He shall draft and prepare all contracts to be entered into by the city and shall submit the contracts to the council for its approval, whenever requested by the council to do so. He shall draft and prepare all city ordinances and shall submit the ordinances to the council for its approval, whenever requested by the council to do so. 
(b)  The city attorney shall draft and prepare all process and papers for the use of police officers in the carrying out by them of the duties of their office, whenever requested by the police chief to do so. He shall prosecute all actions brought in the municipal court on behalf of the city, whenever requested by the municipal judge to do so or whenever in his judgment it is for the general welfare of the city that any such action should be so prosecuted. 
(c)  The city attorney shall supervise and pass upon the legality as to the manner and form of all bonds to be given by any city officer or by any person entering into such a contractual relationship with the city as requires the giving of a bond to the city. 
(Code 1969, § 2-18) 
Secs. 2-3-68-2-3-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CITY CLERK[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Duties of city clerk, NMSA 1978, § 3-13-1. 

Sec. 2-3-96. - Appointment; general duties for council; deputies. 
(a)  The city clerk shall be appointed by the mayor, with the approval of the city council. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the city clerk to attend all meetings of the council, keep the minutes of all its proceedings and record the minutes in the book to be provided by the council, which books are to be kept in the office of the city clerk. 
(c)  The city council may appoint one or more deputy clerks pursuant to NMSA 1978, § 3-12-4. 
(Code 1969, § 2-19; Ord. No. 2011-1252, § 1, 12-13-11) 
Sec. 2-3-97. - Oath and bond. 
    The city clerk shall, prior to entering into or performing the duties of the office of clerk, take an oath or affirmation complying with the provisions of the oath or affirmation set forth in NMSA 1978, § 3-10-2. The city clerk shall, within ten days after entering upon the duties of office, furnish a surety bond in an amount and in such form as is set and approved by the city council, conditioned upon the faithful discharge of the duties of such office. The premium of the bond shall be paid by the city. 
(Code 1969, § 2-22) 
Sec. 2-3-98. - Custodian of city seal, documents, records. 
    The city seal shall be kept in the office of the city clerk and shall be affixed to all instruments and papers which by law or ordinance are required to be attested by the city seal. The city clerk shall have custody of and shall safely keep all public records, documents, ordinances, resolutions and orders of the city council and such other papers and documents as may be delivered into the custody of the city clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 2-20) 
Sec. 2-3-99. - Licensing duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the city clerk to issue all licenses upon receipt of proof of payment of any license fee from the city administrative services department and compliance with other ordinances. All licenses shall be signed by the city clerk or by an authorized person on behalf of the city clerk. All licenses shall have affixed thereto the city seal. Upon the face of the license shall be designated the purpose for which such license is granted and the length of time the license shall run. The city clerk shall keep and maintain in his office a record, to be known as the license record, which shall be a list of all licenses issued, the purpose of the license, the expiration date thereof, and the amount of money paid therefor. 
(Code 1969, § 2-21) 
Secs. 2-3-100-2-3-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - CITY TREASURER[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal finances and duties of treasurer, NMSA 1978, § 3-37-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-3-126. - Appointment; deputies. 
(a)  The city treasurer shall be appointed by the mayor, with the approval of the city council, and shall act under the supervision of the city manager. 
(b)  The city council may appoint one or more deputy treasurers pursuant to NMSA 1978, § 3-12-4. 
(Code 1969, § 2-23) 
Sec. 2-3-127. - Oath and bond. 
    The city treasurer, prior to entering into or performing the duties of office, shall take an oath or affirmation complying with the provisions of the oath or affirmation set forth in NMSA 1978, § 3-10-2. The city treasurer, within ten days after entering the duties of office, shall furnish a surety bond in an amount and in such form as is set and approved by the city council, conditioned upon the faithful discharge of the duties of such office and the proper care and disposition of city funds. The premium of the bond shall be paid by the city. 
(Code 1969, § 2-25) 
Sec. 2-3-128. - Payment of city funds. 
    The city treasurer shall pay from the treasury such sums of money as may be ordered by the city council. The vouchers, warrants, or authorizations therefor shall be signed by the mayor and by the treasurer. No check or bank draft shall be drawn upon city funds except pursuant to a voucher or warrant or authorization which complies with this section. However, this section will not prohibit the refund of deposits, bonds or utility overpayments; the payment of bonds and coupons; or the lawful purchase of investments by cash or by check when properly recorded. 
(Code 1969, § 2-24) 
Sec. 2-3-129. - Investment of funds. 
    The city treasurer shall be responsible for the prudent investment of city funds in the manner specified in state law. 
(Code 1969, § 2-26) 
Sec. 2-3-130. - Bond issues. 
    The city treasurer shall be responsible for maintaining good and sufficient records of all of the city bond issues; shall coordinate city bond issues with fiscal agents and bond counsel; and shall act as adviser to the city manager, the mayor, and the city council with reference to all matters which in any way pertain to city bonds. 
(Code 1969, § 2-27) 
Sec. 2-3-131. - Budget preparation. 
    The city treasurer shall assist the city manager, the mayor, the city council and the city administrative services department in the preparation of the annual city budget required by the administrative services department and shall assist in the preparation of financial reports and shall render such advice upon these matters as may be requested by the appropriate city officials. 
(Code 1969, § 2-27.1) 
Sec. 2-3-132. - Financial archives. 
    The city treasurer shall be responsible for maintaining financial archives for the city and shall advise the city manager, the mayor and the council upon such matters. 
(Code 1969, § 2-27.2) 
Secs. 2-3-133-2-3-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - CODE COMPLIANCE OFFICER 

Sec. 2-3-161. - Establishment of office. 
(a)  The office of code compliance is created. The city manager, subject to the approval of the city council, may hire and appoint a chief code compliance officer and as many other code compliance officers as may be required to effect the duties set forth in this division. 
(b)  The chief code compliance officer and his officers shall report to and be under the supervision of such department of the city as the city manager may direct. 
(Code 1969, § 2-120) 
Sec. 2-3-162. - Duties. 
(a)  The primary duties of the code compliance officers shall be the enforcement of various provisions of the sanitation code, the building code, the Unified Development Code, the nuisance ordinance, and the business registration and license ordinances, which relate to cleanliness, appearance, aesthetics, miscellaneous revenues and the sanitation, health and welfare of the city. The code compliance officers shall work in cooperation with other departments and city officials to carry out the responsibilities of such office. 
(b)  The duties of the code compliance officers shall include, but shall not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Enforcement of the sections of the motor vehicle code relating to junked and abandoned vehicles. 
(2)  Enforcement of the sections of this Code relating to the removal of weeds, debris and noxious substances from properties within the city, and enforcement of sections of this Code which relate to public nuisances. 
(3)  Enforcement of the sections of the sanitation code pertaining to trash, debris and garbage, both on private property and in the public streets and alleys. 
(4)  Enforcement of the sections of this Code pertaining to litter. 
(5)  Enforcement of the sections of the Unified Development Code relating to setbacks and open space. 
(6)  Enforcement of the sections of this Code relating to compliance with the conditions which have been established by the city council for special use permits, including provisions relating to requirements for mobile homes, outside storage, outside display and recreation vehicles. 
(7)  Enforcement of the sections of this Code relating to rundown and dilapidated buildings and property. 
(8)  Inspection and enforcement to ensure compliance with the business registration and license sections of this Code, including compliance with home business licenses. 
(9)  Enforcement of the sections of this Code relating to noxious odors and noxious substances. 
(10)  Enforcement of the sections of this Code relating to excessive noise. 
(11)  Receipt and processing of complaints of residents of the city which pertain to the duties of the code compliance officers. 
(12)  Performance of such other duties as may be assigned to the code compliance officers by the city manager. 
(Code 1969, § 2-121; Ord. No. 2007-1184, 9-8-10) 
Sec. 2-3-163. - Interpretation of Code; procedures. 
(a)  The authority of the chief code compliance officer shall be subordinate and secondary to the primary authority and responsibility of his department head, unless specifically otherwise designated by the city manager. 
(b)  If differences of opinion arise in the interpretation of the sections of this Code by the code compliance officers or with reference to the scope of their authority as between other city departments, these differences shall be resolved by and between the director or chief of that other department and the chief code compliance officer's immediate supervisor, subject to final determination by the city manager. 
(c)  Procedures to be followed by the code compliance officers in enforcement, issuing of compliance notices and orders and processing citizens' complaints shall be established by the chief code compliance officer, subject to the approval of the city manager. 
(Code 1969, § 2-122) 
ARTICLE 4. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Electrical code advisory committee, § 7-3-5; board of appeals for swimming pools, § 7-5-2; lodgers tax advisory board, § 8-12-4; cable and communications commission, § 9-1-2; citizen advisory committee, § 15-4-1 et seq.; public library board, § 16-2-1 et seq.; oil and gas and geologic and engineering hazards advisory commission, § 19-2-31 et seq.; parks, recreation and cultural affairs commission, § 20-2-56 et seq.; employee council, § 21-11-1 et seq.; traffic violations bureau, § 25-2-36 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-4-1. - Appointment of advisory committees, boards and commissions; appointment of alternate members at large. 
(a)  The mayor, subject to the approval of the city council, may appoint advisory committees, boards and commissions, whose purpose and function shall be to make recommendations to the mayor and the council and to provide technical, responsible and expert advice in such fields, skills or areas as the mayor may designate. 
(b)  All such committees, boards or commissions shall function in an advisory capacity only and shall have no decision-making authority. 
(c)  The members of any such committee, board or commission shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor, unless otherwise provided by law or ordinance, and shall meet as directed by the mayor or as such body may deem necessary, if not specifically instructed by the mayor. 
(d)  The mayor may either appoint one member of the committee, board or commission to act as chair or may leave the selection of the chair to the committee, commission or board, unless otherwise provided by ordinance. 
(e)  The mayor, as a matter of discretion and subject to the approval of the city council, may also appoint one or more persons, but no more than one-third of the number of the membership of any committee, board or commission, to act as alternate members at large to any such advisory committee, board or commission. Such alternate member at large may sit in discussion and deliberation of matters brought before the advisory committee, board or commission and may vote if any regular member is absent. Any such alternate member at large shall have no authority to vote if all regular members are present. If more alternate members at large have been appointed and are present to vote than there are regular members absent, the chairman of the advisory committee, board or commission shall decide which alternate members at large shall be entitled to vote in place of the regular members absent. 
(f)  Subsection (e) of this section pertaining to appointment of alternate members at large shall apply to all advisory committees, commissions and boards, including sections of this Code which provide for advisory committees, boards or commissions to the city council, unless otherwise provided by ordinance. 
(g)  This section shall apply only to advisory bodies, committees, boards and commissions and shall not apply to committees, boards or commissions which are vested with specific decision-making authority. 
(Code 1969, § 2-7.2) 
Secs. 2-4-2-2-4-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW BOARD 

Sec. 2-4-31. - Established; terms; organization; purpose. 
(a)  The administrative review board is established, which shall consist of five members, each of whom shall be a resident of the city, appointed by the mayor, subject to the approval of the city council. 
(b)  Members of the administrative review board may be appointed from professional and occupational groups within the city, which will provide administrative, legal and technical expertise in the areas that fall within the jurisdiction of the administrative review board. 
(c)  Members of the administrative review board shall serve staggered terms of two years each. 
(d)  Members shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor and may be removed at the pleasure of the mayor, subject to the approval of the city council. 
(e)  A vacancy occurring in the membership of the administrative review board shall be filled as soon as is reasonably possible by appointment by the mayor and confirmation by the city council for the remainder of the unexpired term of such member. 
(f)  Staff support services for the administrative review board shall be provided by the community development department and by such other departments as may be designated by the city manager. 
(g)  The purpose of the administrative review board shall be to administratively determine certain matters of city business which are of a factfinding rather than a legislative nature. 
(Code 1969, § 2-101) 
Sec. 2-4-32. - Chair. 
    The administrative review board shall elect a chair from its members to serve for a term of one year, with eligibility for reelection. 
(Code 1969, § 2-105) 
Sec. 2-4-33. - Meetings generally; rules of procedure; records. 
    The administrative review board shall hold at least one regular meeting a month; shall adopt rules for transaction of its business; and shall record its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which shall be a matter of public record. All meetings of the administrative review board shall be open to the public, and notice thereof shall be given in the manner provided by law. 
(Code 1969, § 2-106) 
Sec. 2-4-34. - Quorum. 
(a)  The administrative review board may conduct an official meeting with a quorum of three members present. A majority vote of such quorum shall suffice for transaction of business. 
(b)  Since decision-making authority is delegated to the administrative review board, alternate members at large shall not be appointed pursuant to section 2-4-1. 
(Code 1969, § 2-107) 
Sec. 2-4-35. - Technical assistance. 
    The administrative review board may, in its discretion, seek any technical assistance it may require in the performance of its duties. It may, subject to the administrative supervisory control of the city manager, request the assistance of any city department or official, including the code compliance officer or any department head, upon any matter brought before it or may, in its discretion, request the advice and assistance of members of the community who are qualified by experience and training with reference to any particular matter before it. However, the board shall incur no expense for such assistance unless such expense is approved by the city council. 
(Code 1969, § 2-113) 
Sec. 2-4-36. - Authority. 
    The administrative review board is delegated authority to carry out the functions and duties delegated to it and, to the extent of such duty, is designated as a planning authority pursuant to NMSA 1978, § 3-21-1 et seq.; a zoning authority to hear appeals under NMSA 1978, § 3-21-1 et seq.; a board of appeals under the provisions of the Uniform Fire Code; and a board of appeals as defined in the Uniform Building Code. 
(Code 1969, § 2-109) 
Sec. 2-4-37. - Findings and determination of council. 
    For the purpose of this division, the city council does find and determine that: 
(1)  Due to the rapid expansion and development of the city, there is an ever increasing number of requests for variances from this Code and an increasing number of appeals from decisions of various city inspectors and officials rendered in the enforcement or interpretation of various sections of this Code or rendered in the determination of the manner in which various Code sections should be applied. 
(2)  An inordinate amount of the time is being spent by the fire prevention bureau, the planning and zoning commission and the city council in the factfinding process which is necessary to resolve requests for variances and to determine appeals from the decisions of various city officials. 
(3)  It is desirable, economically sound, efficient and otherwise in the best interests of the city for the city to establish the administrative review board to hear and determine such variances and appeals subject to the right of appeal to the city council. 
(4)  It is further determined that time and energy of members of the planning and zoning commission and the fire prevention bureau should not be spent in the determination of variances and administrative review, but that the time of such members should be spent in advising the city council upon policy and legislative matters. 
(Code 1969, § 2-102) 
Sec. 2-4-38. - Jurisdiction. 
    The administrative review board shall, subject to the right of appeal to the city council, have jurisdiction to determine variances and to hear and decide appeals which pertain to: 
(1)  The Uniform Fire Code and the Life Safety Code; 
(2)  The city building code; 
(3)  The city plumbing code; 
(4)  The garbage and sanitation ordinances; 
(5)  The zoning ordinances; 
(6)  Denial or revocation of business licenses or business registrations; 
(7)  The flood damage prevention ordinance; and 
(8)  Any other matter which may be referred to it by the city council. 
(Code 1969, § 2-103) 
Sec. 2-4-39. - Duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the administrative review board to: 
(1)  Hear and determine all requests for variances within its jurisdiction. 
(2)  Hear and determine, subject to appeal to the city council, the complaint of any person aggrieved by any decision of the building inspector or an administrative officer, commission, committee or bureau in the enforcement or the interpretation of the codes, ordinances, rules or regulations within the board's jurisdiction. 
(3)  Investigate and return findings and recommendations upon any other issue the city council may refer to it for decision. 
(Code 1969, § 2-104) 
Sec. 2-4-40. - Procedures. 
(a)  Any person aggrieved, including any city officer, department, board or official affected by any decision of the building inspector or an administrative officer, commission, committee or bureau, in the enforcement or interpretation of the provisions of this Code, an ordinance, a rule or a regulation within the jurisdiction of the administrative review board, may appeal to the administrative review board. 
(b)  Any such appeal shall be taken within 30 days after the decision of the building inspector, code compliance officer, building official, fire prevention enforcement officer, sanitation officer or other administrative officer has been rendered, and the appeal shall be in such form as may be prescribed by the rules of the board. Failure to appeal within such 30-day period shall bar an appeal unless such requirement shall be waived by the administrative review board or by the city council. 
(c)  The appeal shall be filed with the community development department or with such other department as may be designated by the city manager, shall contain a notice of appeal and shall specify the grounds of the appeal. 
(d)  A copy of the appeal and the notice shall be sent to the building inspector, code compliance officer or other official who has rendered such decision, and a copy shall also be sent to the city attorney and the particular city department involved in the decision. The community development department or the department designated by the city manager to furnish staff support for the appeal shall consult with the legal department and, upon the advice and instruction of the legal department, give notice to other persons or property owners who may be interested parties as determined by the legal department. Notice of any request for a variance from any section of this Code within the jurisdiction of the administrative review board or any appeal related to a section of the Unified Development Code shall be sent to the owners of adjoining property pursuant to the procedure outlined in the Unified Development Code. 
(e)  Upon receipt of a notice of appeal, the building inspector, code compliance officer or other official enforcing or interpreting the appropriate Code section shall forthwith transmit to the community development department or the department designated by the city manager to furnish staff support for the appeal all papers pertaining to the cause, together with a summary of all pertinent facts which constitute the record upon which the action appealed from is taken. 
(f)  An appeal stays all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from unless the appropriate city official charged with the enforcement of the particular Code section certifies to the administrative review board, after the notice of appeal has been sent to him, that, because of the facts stated in the certificate, a stay would, in his opinion, cause imminent peril to life or property. In such a case, proceedings shall not be stayed otherwise than by a restraining order, which may be granted by the city council or a court of record on application or notice to the particular official involved and on due cause shown. 
(g)  The community development department or the department designated by the city manager to furnish staff support for the appeal, in cooperation with the administrative review board and the parties affected, upon receipt of all papers constituting the record upon which the action taken was appealed from, shall fix a time for hearing within 30 days of receipt of such record and shall give due notice thereof. 
(h)  The administrative review board shall conduct a hearing upon the matter and, within ten days after such hearing, render its decision, which shall be supported by a statement of the issues presented by the appeal and which shall include findings of fact and reasons in support of such decision. 
(i)  Each member of the administrative review board may separately state his views or objections upon the subject before the administrative review board and may make findings and issue reasons in support thereof. 
(j)  Copies of the written decision of the administrative review board shall forthwith be sent to the party filing the appeal, the appropriate city officials, the office of the city attorney, the department head of the department which is involved, the city manager, the mayor and each of the city councilors. The decision of the administrative review board shall be final unless, within 15 days from the date such decision is rendered, the party shall appeal such decision in writing to the city council or unless not less than two members of the city council issue instructions in writing to the administrative review board directing that such matter be forwarded to the city council for further review. 
(k)  Any person may appear in person or by attorney before the administrative review board to be heard and to present evidence bearing upon such appeal. 
(Code 1969, § 2-108; Ord. No. 2007-1184, 9-8-10) 
Sec. 2-4-41. - Schedule of fees. 
    The city council may, by resolution, provide for a schedule of reasonable fees to be paid for filing and pursuing an appeal to the administrative review board and to the city council. All such fees shall bear a reasonable relation to the expense involved for processing such appeal. The resolution may also, in the discretion of the city council, allow for a refund of such fee if an appellant is successful, if the city is or its officers or employees are found to be at fault, or for other equitable reasons. 
(Code 1969, § 2-110) 
Sec. 2-4-42. - Appeal to city council. 
    If any appeal is presented to or brought forth to the city council as provided in this division, the city council shall hear the appeal as part of regular city business and shall render its decision, which shall include findings of fact and reasons in support thereof, which shall be reflected in the official city minutes. The decision of the administrative review board shall not be reversed, modified, amended or otherwise decided except by a vote of three councilors. Any councilor may separately state his views or objections to the findings of the council, which shall also be incorporated in the official city minutes. 
(Code 1969, § 2-111) 
Sec. 2-4-43. - Appeal to district court. 
    Any person aggrieved by a decision of the city council pursuant to this division may appeal to the district court within 30 days of the date of the decision rendered by the city council. 
(Code 1969, § 2-112) 
Sec. 2-4-44. - Jurisdiction of courts not affected. 
    This division shall not be construed as any limitation upon the power of the courts or as a limitation upon the right of any person to file a complaint for violation of any section of this Code or any city ordinance in the municipal court or as any limitation upon the authority of the court to impose a fine or jail sentence upon conviction in the municipal court for violation of this Code or any applicable city ordinance. 
(Code 1969, § 2-114) 
Secs. 2-4-45-2-4-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - AIRPORT ADVISORY COMMISSION[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference- Airport, ch. 3. 

Sec. 2-4-71. - Created. 
    The airport advisory commission is created.
