(Code 1969, § 2-33) 
Sec. 2-4-72. - Membership; term of office. 
    The airport advisory commission shall consist of five members and one alternate member, all of whom shall serve staggered three-year terms. The alternate member shall be appointed and shall serve pursuant to section 2-4-1. Members and alternates shall not be permitted to serve more than three consecutive terms. 
(Code 1969, § 2-36) 
Sec. 2-4-73. - Officers. 
    The airport advisory commission shall elect a chair, chair pro tem and, unless the city manager has designated a city employee to serve in such capacity, shall elect one member to serve as secretary to record the minutes of the meetings of the commission. 
(Code 1969, § 2-37) 
Sec. 2-4-74. - Meetings. 
    The airport advisory commission shall meet regularly, as determined by the commission, but at least quarterly. All meetings of the commission shall be open to the public and shall be conducted pursuant to the Open Meetings Act. 
(Code 1969, § 2-38; Ord. No. 2009-1213, § 1, 5-26-09) 
Sec. 2-4-75. - Quorum. 
    The airport advisory commission may conduct an official meeting with three members present. In the absence of a regular member, the alternate member may count as a member of the quorum. A majority vote of such quorum shall suffice for the transaction of business. The chair or chair pro tem shall vote unless disqualified due to conflict of interest. 
(Code 1969, § 2-39) 
Sec. 2-4-76. - Compensation. 
    The members of the airport advisory commission shall be paid no salary for their service as members of the commission; however, the members shall be entitled to per diem and mileage authorized by law and allowed to other city boards and commissions. 
(Code 1969, § 2-40) 
Sec. 2-4-77. - Removal. 
    Members of the airport advisory commission serve at the will of the mayor and the city council and may be removed at any time by the mayor, subject to the vote of a majority of members of the city council. 
(Code 1969, § 2-41) 
Sec. 2-4-78. - Vacancies. 
    A vacancy occurring in the membership of the airport advisory commission shall be filled by appointment by the mayor and confirmation by the city council for the remainder of the unexpired term of such member. 
(Code 1969, § 2-42) 
Sec. 2-4-79. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the airport advisory commission shall be to advise the mayor and city council upon all phases of the operation and maintenance of the Four Corners Regional Airport, including but not necessarily limited to: 
(1)  The budgeting and expenditure of capital funds for the Four Corners Regional Airport; 
(2)  The conduct of business and leasing of airport property; 
(3)  Rules and regulations for the conduct of business and affairs at the airport; 
(4)  Fees to be charged for leases, hangars, and business operations at the airport; 
(5)  Coordination with the Federal Aviation Administration, the county, and other entities; and 
(6)  Other matters which pertain to operations at the airport. 
(Code 1969, § 2-34) 
Sec. 2-4-80. - Duties. 
    The airport advisory commission is an advisory commission only, whose recommendations shall not be binding upon the city. The airport advisory commission shall make careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of existing conditions and probable future growth of the Four Corners Regional Airport, which shall be considered in recommendations made to the city council. 
(Code 1969, § 2-35) 
Secs. 2-4-81-2-4-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - BOARD OF PUBLIC UTILITY COMMISSIONERS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 26. 

Sec. 2-4-106. - Establishment; composition; qualifications. 
(a)  There is established an advisory board of public utility commissioners, consisting of ten members, not including the mayor or councilor referenced in subsection (b) of this section, who shall be competent persons in residence in the district they represent. 
(b)  The mayor shall either act as an ex officio nonvoting member of the board or shall designate a member of the city council as alternate to the mayor to so act. Such ex officio member shall attend all meetings of the board to monitor the activities of the board and to ensure that there is appropriate communication between the city council and the board. 
(c)  The municipal electric utility service area shall be divided into ten districts as set forth in this paragraph and as shown on the board of public utility commissioners district map, the original of which shall be on file in the office of the city clerk. As of July 1, 1999, the ten districts will be designated as follows: 
(1)  Commissioner districts one through four shall consist of the same area as city council districts one through four as shown on the council election district map referenced in section 2-2-32 of this Code. 
(2)  Commissioner districts five and six shall consist of the area within the municipal boundaries of the City of Farmington and shall be filled by persons having experience or technical training in the management of utilities. 
(3)  Commissioner district seven shall consist of all of the area within the Municipal School District No. 5 (Farmington) which is not within the City of Farmington, and the area within the electric utility service area which is also within the Municipal School District No. 22 (Central Consolidated). 
(4)  Commissioner district eight shall consist of the area within the City of Bloomfield. 
(5)  Commissioner district nine shall consist of all of the area within the electric utility service area which is also within the Municipal School District No. 6 (Bloomfield) and not within the City of Bloomfield. 
(6)  Commissioner district ten shall consist of the area within the electric utility service area which is also within the Municipal School District No. 2 (Aztec) and outside the service area of the City of Aztec Electric Utility, and the area within the electric utility service area which is also within the Municipal School District No. 21 (Rio Arriba County). 
(d)  On or before July 1, 2001, the board of public utility commissioners district map shall be revised, using year 2000 census data as may be available, to establish ten new districts each representing approximately the same number of consumers within the electric utility service area. Revisions to the district map shall be accomplished using the procedures set forth in paragraph (e) below. Once the revised map is approved, the mayor and city council will, within a reasonable time, take the necessary steps to appoint and confirm new members to the board so as to re-establish representation of each of the ten commissioner districts as shown on the revised board of public utility commissioners district map. 
(e)  The city council may, whenever it may deem it to be warranted, amend the board of utility commissioners district map. Changes in boundaries shall be noted on the official board of utility commissioners district map kept on file and in the custody of the city clerk. Changes made upon the official board of public utility commissioners district map shall be commemorated by resolution of the city council and shall be effective immediately upon adoption of the resolution authorizing such changes. 
(Code 1969, § 2-76; Ord. No. 99-1098, § 1, 6-8-99) 
Sec. 2-4-107. - Appointment; terms of office. 
    The members of the board of public utility commissioners shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to the approval of the city council. Members shall be appointed to serve for three-year terms, except that the appointments made to fill a vacancy in office shall expire upon the expiration date of the original office holder. 
(Code 1969, § 2-77; Ord. No. 99-1098, § 1, 6-8-99) 
Sec. 2-4-108. - Vacancies; absences. 
    A vacancy shall be deemed to exist upon the resignation of any member of the board of public utility commissioners, upon his death or inability to act, or upon removal of any member by a majority vote of the city council. Any member who fails to attend three consecutive regular meetings of the board without excuse shall be deemed to have resigned his office. 
(Code 1969, § 2-78) 
Sec. 2-4-109. - Compensation. 
    The members of the board of public utility commissioners shall serve without compensation, except that nothing in this section shall prevent the mayor and council from authorizing unusual travel expenses and per diem for taking care of city utility business away from home. 
(Code 1969, § 2-79) 
Sec. 2-4-110. - Officers. 
    The board of public utility commissioners shall annually elect a chair and vice-chair. The chair will preside at all meetings of the board of public utility commissioners unless the chair is unable to attend. The vice-chair will preside in the chair's absence. 
(Code 1969, § 2-80; Ord. No. 99-1098, § 1, 6-8-99) 
Sec. 2-4-111. - Quorum. 
    The presence of five members of the board of public utility commissioners shall constitute a quorum for conducting the business for the board. The ex officio member serving under subsection 2-4-106(b) shall not be counted in determining the number of members present for a quorum. 
(Code 1969, § 2-80.1; Ord. No. 99-1098, § 1, 6-8-99) 
Sec. 2-4-112. - Rules of procedure; meetings. 
    The board of public utility commissioners shall, subject to approval of the city council, adopt rules and regulations governing its proceedings, including the time and place of meetings and the call of special meetings; provided, however, at least one regular meeting shall be held each month. 
(Code 1969, § 2-81) 
Sec. 2-4-113. - Appearance of persons before the board. 
    The mayor, members of the city council, city manager, city attorney, city clerk, city treasurer, city engineer and consulting engineer may appear before the board of public utility commissioners at any regular or special meeting, to discuss and advise on any matters pertaining to their particular offices. The general utility director and such other city officers and employees as the board shall designate, including consultants, shall attend all regular meetings of the board when available. 
(Code 1969, § 2-82) 
Sec. 2-4-114. - Powers and duties generally. 
    Subject to the control and direction of the mayor and city council, the board of public utility commissioners shall advise the city council upon the proper administration of the affairs of the municipal electric water and sewer utility system. The city council may, by resolution, remove from the consideration of the board matters pertaining specifically to the operation of the water and sewer utility system. However, nothing in this section shall empower the board to deal directly in the affairs of management, but it shall confine its action to recommendations of policy to the city council, the mayor and the city manager. 
(Code 1969, § 2-83) 
Sec. 2-4-115. - Particular duties. 
    The board of public utility commissioners shall have the following particular duties: 
(1)  Rules and regulations of electric utility system. Subject to the approval and adoption of such rules and regulations by the city council, the board shall recommend general rules and policies of the municipal electric utility system. In making any such recommendations for the municipal electric utility system, the board shall recommend uniform rules and regulations for the entire municipal electric utility system, which shall conform to the state laws relating to the jurisdiction of the state public service commission under the Public Utility Act of New Mexico, insofar as the jurisdiction of the state public service commission under such Public Utility Act attaches to the operation of the municipal electric utility system in the area of operations beyond a distance of five miles from the corporate limits of the city. 
(2)  Rules and regulations of water utility system. Subject to the approval of the city council, the board shall recommend general rules and policies of the municipal water utility system. 
(3)  Rules and regulations of sewer utility system. Subject to the approval of the city council, the board shall recommend general rules and policies of the municipal sewer utility system. 
(4)  Rates and conditions of service. Subject to the approval and adoption of such rates and service conditions by the city council, the board shall recommend rates and charges for electric power and energy, water or sewer utility service furnished by the municipal electric, water and sewer utility systems and shall recommend conditions of service applicable to the furnishing of such electric power and energy, water or sewer service. In making any such recommendations for the municipal electric utility system, the board shall recommend uniform rates and service conditions for the entire municipal electric utility system which conform to the state laws relating to the jurisdiction of the state public service commission, under the Public Utility Act of New Mexico, insofar as the jurisdiction of the state public service commission under such Public Utility Act attaches to the operation of the municipal electric utility system in the area of operations beyond a distance of five miles from the corporate limits of the city. 
(5)  Line extension policies. Subject to the approval and adoption of such line extension policy by the city council, the board shall recommend line extension policies to be followed by the municipal electric utility system and extension policies for municipal water and sewer utility services. In making any such recommendations for the municipal electric utility system, the board shall recommend uniform line extension policies which shall conform to the requirements of the state laws relating to the jurisdiction of the state public service commission under the Public Utility Act of New Mexico, insofar as the jurisdiction of the state public service commission under such Public Utility Act attaches to the operation of the municipal electric utility system in the area of operations beyond a distance of five miles from the corporate limits of the city. 
(6)  Changes in rules, regulations, conditions of service and line extension policies. No rule or regulation, rate or condition of service or line extension policy having been adopted and approved by the city council shall be amended, modified, abrogated, repealed or otherwise changed by the board without the approval of the city council and in conformity with law. 
(7)  Contracts for service generally. Subject to the supervening power of the city council to authorize the execution of all contracts by the city, which power is specifically reserved by law and by this division to the city council, whenever the city council shall determine that any contract relating to service to be provided by the municipal electric, water or sewer utility systems or otherwise shall be executed by the city, the board shall recommend all forms of contracts relating to service to be provided by the municipal electric, water and sewer utility systems or any special contracts relating to service to be furnished by the municipal electric, water and sewer utility systems at special contract rates or relating to line extensions when good cause exists for the execution of such contracts by the city, upon terms or conditions other than as provided by any rules and regulations adopted by the city council, or as provided by rates and conditions of service adopted by the council or as provided in any line extension policies adopted by the city council, when service can be provided under such special contracts at rates or under service conditions which are not preferential as to any customer served by the municipal electric, water and sewer utility systems or unreasonably discriminatory as to any such customers. 
(8)  Execution of contracts. Whenever standard forms of contracts recommended by the board have been adopted by the city council relating to service to be provided by the municipal electric, water or sewer utility systems, under rules and regulations and under rates and conditions of service and in conformity with line extension policies approved by the city, whenever any special contracts recommended by the board have been approved by the city council, as provided in this division, or otherwise, the proper agents of the municipal electric, water and sewer utility systems may execute such contracts on behalf of the city, and the execution thereof by such proper agents shall be deemed to be the ministerial act of the city council, insofar as such contracts provide for service to be furnished by the municipal electric utility, water and sewer utility systems. 
(9)  Annual budgets. The board may, and when so directed by the council shall, prepare and recommend an annual budget for the municipal electric utility system, for the municipal water utility system, and for the municipal sewer utility system conforming to the requirements of the city ordinances authorizing issuance of electric, water and sewer revenue bonds. Upon adoption of such budget by the board, the budget shall be submitted to the city for consideration and approval of the city council or for such action as may be taken with respect thereto by the city council. 
(10)  Review of rates. The board shall review from time to time all of the rates and charges for electric, water and sewer utility services furnished by the municipal utility systems and shall submit the results of such review to the city council. 
(11)  Capital improvements. The board shall recommend to the city council any major extensions and improvements not otherwise provided for by the city council that are required to be made to or in connection with the municipal electric, water or sewer utility systems and not otherwise provided for in the annual budget and shall include in such recommendation any engineering studies and other data obtained or prepared in connection with such proposed extensions and improvements. 
(12)  Contracts for improvements; purchases. The board, in conformity with any procedures established by the city council and in conformity with all laws relating to public purchases, after approval by the city council of the proposed purchases of materials required for the municipal electric, water or sewer utility systems, or of any contract authorized by the city council for the construction of any facilities related to the municipal electric, water or sewer system shall advise the city council upon the taking of all steps to be accomplished by the general director of the particular utility system placed in his charge to comply with the requirements of law relating to public purchases and to comply with the procedures established from time to time by the city with respect to the purchase of materials and supplies through the office of the city purchasing agent. 
(13)  Responsibility for construction. Whenever specific methods of financing any program for major extensions and improvements to the municipal electric, water or utility systems have been made and adopted by the city council, the board shall advise the city council upon the construction thereof from the funds made available for such work and shall keep fully informed as to the progress thereof and report such to the city council. 
(14)  Appeals from utility customer service regulations. The board shall have jurisdiction to hear appeals from and grant variances to any and all customer service rules or regulations pertaining to the city's electric, water or wastewater utilities. Any decision as to such appeals and variances shall be final. 
(15)  Additional duties. The board shall perform such further specific duties as may from time to time be lawfully delegated to it with respect to such municipal electric, water and sewer utility systems by the city council. 
(Code 1969, § 2-84) 
Sec. 2-4-116. - Recommendations for employment of general director. 
    The board of public utility commissioners may make recommendations concerning the employment of a director of the municipal electric utility system or a combined general director of all utility operations. However, the employment and appointment of any such director shall be made by the city manager in accordance with section 2-3-38, subject to Chapter 21 pertaining to the personnel merit system. Any such director shall be subject to the direction of the city manager in matters of administration but shall appear before the board or before the city council when requested to do so respecting the matters set forth in this division. Nothing in this section shall prevent the city manager from acting in his capacity as city manager and as director of any or all of the utilities specified in this division. 
(Code 1969, § 2-85) 
Sec. 2-4-117. - Powers reserved to city council. 
    Nothing contained in this division pertaining to the board of public utility commissioners shall be construed as a requirement that any matter be submitted to the board of public utility commissioners for action prior to action upon such matter by the city council; the city council expressly reserving unto itself the power to act upon any matter pertaining to the city or its utility system at any time without advice or recommendation from the board of public utility commissioners. 
(Code 1969, § 2-85.1) 
Secs. 2-4-118-2-4-145. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS ADVISORY COMMITTEE[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Cross reference- Finance, § 2-5-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-4-146. - Created. 
    The capital improvements advisory committee is created pursuant to NMSA 1978, § 5-8-37. 
(Code 1969, § 2-151) 
Sec. 2-4-147. - Membership; terms of office. 
    The capital improvements advisory committee shall be composed of five members who shall be appointed by a majority vote of the city council. Two members of the advisory committee must be representatives of the real estate, development or building industries. No member shall be an employee or official of a municipality or county or other governmental entity. The members of the committee shall serve staggered three-year terms. Committee members shall not be permitted to serve more than three consecutive terms. 
(Code 1969, § 2-152) 
Sec. 2-4-148. - Officers. 
    The capital improvements advisory committee shall elect a chair, a chair pro tem and, unless the city manager has designated a city employee to serve in such capacity, shall elect one member to serve as secretary to record the minutes of meetings of the committee. 
(Code 1969, § 2-154) 
Sec. 2-4-149. - Meetings. 
    The capital improvements advisory committee shall meet as needed and shall keep minutes of its meetings, which shall be a matter of public record subject to the provisions of the Open Meetings Act. All meetings of the committee shall be open to the public and shall be conducted pursuant to the Open Meetings Act. 
(Code 1969, § 2-155) 
Sec. 2-4-150. - Quorum. 
    The capital improvements advisory committee may conduct an official meeting with three members present. A majority vote of such quorum shall suffice for the transaction of business. The chair or chair pro tem shall vote unless disqualified due to a conflict of interest. 
(Code 1969, § 2-156) 
Sec. 2-4-151. - Compensation. 
    The members of the capital improvements advisory committee shall be paid no salary for their service as members of the committee; however, the members shall be entitled to per diem and mileage authorized by law and allowed to other city boards, commissions and committees. 
(Code 1969, § 2-157) 
Sec. 2-4-152. - Removal. 
    Members of the capital improvements advisory committee serve at the pleasure of the city council and may be removed at any time by a majority vote of the city council. 
(Code 1969, § 2-158) 
Sec. 2-4-153. - Vacancies. 
    A vacancy occurring in the membership of the capital improvements advisory committee shall be filled by appointment of a majority vote of the city council for the remainder of the unexpired term of a member who has resigned or is otherwise unable to serve. 
(Code 1969, § 2-159) 
Sec. 2-4-154. - Duties and purpose. 
    The capital improvements advisory committee is an advisory committee only, whose recommendations shall not be binding upon the city. The committee shall perform duties as provided in NMSA 1978, § 5-8-37. 
(Code 1969, § 2-153) 
DIVISION 6. - COMMUNITY RELATIONS COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-4-155. - Creation. 
    The community relations commission of the City of Farmington is hereby created. 
(Ord. No. 2007-1195, § 1, 12-8-07) 
Sec. 2-4-156. - Mission. 
    The mission statement of the community relations commission is to promote ways in which our community can value and safeguard equal opportunity for all. 
(Ord. No. 2007-1195, § 1, 12-8-07) 
Sec. 2-4-157. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the community relations commission shall be to set standards for positive community relations dealing with cultural diversity, fairness, integrity and respect to all people. The commission will encourage and promote mutual self respect and understanding of each other by all citizens and groups in the city. The commission will function with integrity, fairness and respect to all. 
(Ord. No. 2007-1195, § 1, 12-8-07) 
Sec. 2-4-158. - Duties. 
    The community relations commission is an advisory commission only whose recommendations shall not be binding upon the city. It shall be the duty and responsibility of the community relations commission to: 
(1)  Establish a procedure for receiving and reviewing complaints, compliments and feedback that includes fact gathering, seeking legal guidance, acquiring information for investigation of an issue and providing bilingual resources as necessary. 
(2)  Provide and conduct mediation or to offer referrals if necessary. 
(3)  Advise the city council and city administration on problems of local interest group relations and to assist, advise and inform the citizens of important related issues and projects. 
(4)  Act as liaison between the city and other professional, business, government and civic organizations in order to improve communication and cooperate and coordinate efforts to improve working relationships with such groups in the area of cultural diversity, fairness, mutual respect and understanding. 
(5)  Manage statistical data related to the commission's duties. 
(6)  Develop and provide educational programs, orientation and training, including but not limited to, ways to improve communication, understanding and cooperation between all citizens and groups throughout the area. 
(7)  Assist with and provide marketing to express the commission's mission and purpose to the public. 
(8)  Sponsorship of events. 
(9)  Provide information to the media as necessary. 
(10)  Dissemination of brochures, pamphlets, publications, reports and statistical data as in its judgment will tend to promote the Commission's mission statement and eliminate group tensions and prejudices. 
(11)  Implementation of award and incentive programs. 
(12)  Foster mutual understanding and respect among all groups and organizations of the city regardless of race, religion or beliefs. 
(13)  Advise the community on methods to promote mutual understanding and respect among all citizens. 
(14)  Work to assure equal opportunities for all within the community and to develop ways to relieve community tensions arising from cultural or group differences. 
(Ord. No. 2007-1195, § 1, 12-8-07) 
Sec. 2-4-159. - Membership; term of office. 
    The community relations commission shall consist of nine voting members and six ex officio (non-voting) members, all of whom shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the council. Every effort will be made to include representatives from each council district and a majority of all of the members (both voting and non voting) should live within the city limits of Farmington. The membership will be diversified based on ethnicity, age, disability, gender and occupation. The nine voting members will serve staggered terms with five of the members being appointed initially to three-year terms and four of the members being appointed to two-year terms. Thereafter, members shall serve two-year terms. A member's term is limited to four consecutive terms. 
(Ord. No. 2007-1195, § 1, 12-8-07) 
Sec. 2-4-160. - Officers. 
    The community relations commission shall elect a chairperson, a chairperson pro tem; and unless the city manager has designated a city employee to serve in such capacity, shall elect one member to serve as secretary to record the minutes of the meeting of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 2007-1195, § 1, 12-8-07) 
Sec. 2-4-161. - Meetings. 
    The community relations commission shall hold a regular meeting once per month and special meetings, as needed. Notice of meetings should be published and advertised to the public and media as provided in the city's open meetings policy. Agendas will be available to the public in advance of the meeting as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 2007-1195, § 1, 12-8-07) 
Sec. 2-4-162. - Quorum. 
    A quorum for a meeting of the community relations commission shall consist of five voting members. A majority vote of such quorum shall suffice for the transaction of business. 
(Ord. No. 2007-1195, § 1, 12-8-07) 
Sec. 2-4-163. - Compensation. 
    The members of the community relations commission shall be paid no salary for their services as members of the commission; however, the members shall be entitled to per diem and mileage authorized by law when out of town on city business. 
(Ord. No. 2007-1195, § 1, 12-8-07) 
Sec. 2-4-164. - Removal. 
    Members serve at the will of the mayor and the city council and may be removed at any time by the mayor, subject to the confirmation of the city council. Unless extenuating circumstances are presented to the mayor in advance for approval, any member who misses three consecutive meetings or more than 50 percent of the meetings in any running twelve-month period shall be removed from the commission and replaced according to the procedures set out in section 2-4-165. 
(Ord. No. 2007-1195, § 1, 12-8-07) 
Sec. 2-4-165. - Vacancies. 
    Vacancies occurring in membership of the commission shall be filled by appointment of the mayor and confirmed by the city council for the remainder of the unexpired term of such member. 
(Ord. No. 2007-1195, § 1, 12-8-07) 
Sec. 2-4-166. - Recommendations and reports. 
    The commission may consider such matters and issues as requested by the city manager or city council, and may report back their findings and recommendations to the city manager. Upon receiving a recommendation from the commission, the city manager will promptly schedule such recommendation on an upcoming agenda to be heard by the city council. The commission shall submit annually a written report of its activities and an evaluation of the effectiveness of the commission to the city council and mayor with recommendations for changes. 
(Ord. No. 2007-1195, § 1, 12-8-07) 
Secs. 2-4-167-2-4-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2007-1195, § 2, adopted December 8, 2007, renumbered division 6, regarding planning and zoning commission, as division 7. 
Cross reference- Planning and development, ch. 22. 

Sec. 2-4-181. - Created. 
    The planning and zoning commission is created. 
(Code 1969, § 2-46) 
Sec. 2-4-182. - Composition; terms; removal; vacancies. 
(a)  The planning and zoning commission shall consist of nine members, to be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council. 
(b)  Each member of the commission appointed shall be appointed for a term of two years or less, so that there will be an overlapping of tenure of a majority of the members of the commission. 
(c)  Members shall be removable for cause in the manner specified in NMSA 1978, § 3-19-2. 
(d)  A vacancy occurring in the membership of the commission shall be filled by appointment by the mayor and confirmation by the city council for the remainder of the unexpired term of such member. 
(Code 1969, § 2-50) 
Sec. 2-4-183. - Chair. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall elect a chair from its members to serve for a term of one year with eligibility for reelection. The commission may fill such other of its offices as it may create in a manner prescribed by rules, which may be adopted by the commission and approved by the city council. 
(Code 1969, § 2-51) 
Sec. 2-4-184. - Meetings; rules of procedure; records generally. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall hold at least one regular meeting each month; shall adopt rules for transaction of its business; and shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which shall be a matter of public record. All meetings of the commission shall be open to the public, and notice thereof shall be given in the manner provided by law. 
(Code 1969, § 2-52) 
Sec. 2-4-185. - Quorum. 
    The planning and zoning commission may conduct an official meeting with a quorum of as few as five members present. A majority vote of such quorum shall suffice for transaction of business. The chair or chair pro tem shall vote unless disqualified due to conflict of interest. 
(Code 1969, § 2-53) 
Sec. 2-4-186. - Permanent records; hearings before city council. 
(a)  Permanent records of all proceedings of the planning and zoning commission shall be kept and a transcript thereof shall be submitted to the city council within ten days of the date of any meeting of the commission. 
(b)  The city shall schedule all petitions and matters which have been considered by the planning and zoning commission for hearing on the agenda of the next ensuing regular meeting of the city council, unless otherwise directed by the city council. 
(c)  When publication of notice is required, publication of notice of the hearing to be held before the city council shall not be required, provided publication of notice has been given and the matter has been presented to the planning and zoning commission for consideration as provided in this division. 
(Code 1969, § 2-54) 
Sec. 2-4-187. - Jurisdiction. 
    The territorial jurisdiction of the planning and zoning commission shall be the planning jurisdiction authorized by NMSA 1978, § 3-20-5 and the zoning regulations. 
(Code 1969, § 2-48) 
Sec. 2-4-188. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the planning and zoning commission shall be to: 
(1)  Recommend the orderly development of the city. 
(2)  Serve as an advisory commission to the city council with reference to: 
a.  Planning as provided in Article 3 of Chapter 22, pertaining to the master plan. 
b.  Platting and land subdivision as provided in the Unified Development Code. 
c.  Zoning as provided in the Unified Development Code. 
(Code 1969, § 2-47; Ord. No. 2007-1184, 9-8-10) 
Sec. 2-4-189. - Powers and duties. 
    The planning and zoning commission is an advisory commission to the city council; provided, however, that final decisions upon planning, platting and zoning shall be made by the city council. The planning and zoning commission shall make careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of existing conditions and the probable future growth of the city and its environs, which shall be considered in recommendations made to the city council. 
(Code 1969, § 2-49) 
ARTICLE 5. - FINANCE[13] 
Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the city saved from repeal, § 1-1-12(a)(1); any ordinance making any appropriation saved from repeal, § 1-1-12(a)(4); any ordinance levying or imposing taxes saved from repeal, § 1-1-12(a)(5); any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor saved from repeal, § 1-1-12(a)(7); capital improvements advisory committee, § 2-4-146 et seq.; lodgers tax, § 8-12-1 et seq.; fire protection fund, § 13-1-1; recovery of expenses incurred in emergency actions, § 13-4-1 et seq.; parks, recreation and cultural affairs fund, § 20-1-2; rates and charges for utilities, § 26-4-1 et seq.; fees for water and sewer extensions, § 26-5-1 et seq. 
State Law reference- Municipal finances, NMSA 1978, § 3-37-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-5-1. - Additional taxes. 
    The state governmental gross receipts tax and other city, county, state and federal taxes, where applicable, shall be added to sales of services or property and to rates, tariffs, fees, or charges, made, assessed, charged, levied or imposed by the city, including but not necessarily limited to admissions to public performances and charges made by the city for city utility services. 
(Code 1969, § 30-1-1) 
Sec. 2-5-2. - Claims against city. 
(a)  Form; itemization. All accounts, claims and demands against the city shall be in writing and shall be fully and completely itemized, with the date and character of each item and by whose order, at whose instance, and upon what contract the supplies were furnished, labor performed, or services rendered. 
(b)  Presentation; filing. All claims against the city shall be addressed to the mayor or the city manager, shall be filed with the city clerk, and the date of receipt of such claim shall be noted thereon by the city clerk. 
(c)  Time limitation. Any person having a claim for damages against the city shall present such claim in writing to the city clerk in the manner specified in subsection (b) of this section within 90 days after such claim shall have accrued. Failure to so present such claim shall be a bar to any recovery thereon. 
(Code 1969, §§ 1-3-1-1-3-3) 
State Law reference- Claims against a municipality, NMSA 1978, § 41-4-16. 
Secs. 2-5-3-2-5-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PURCHASING[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
State Law reference- Procurement Code, NMSA 1978, § 13-1-28 et seq. 

Sec. 2-5-31. - Central purchasing agency. 
    There is created a central purchasing agency, the duties of which shall be performed by a person designated by the city manager. All city purchases, except as provided in this division, shall be made through such office, in accordance with the applicable provisions of the Procurement Code, NMSA 1978, § 13-1-28 et seq. 
(Code 1969, § 28A-1) 
Sec. 2-5-32. - Promulgation of additional rules and regulations. 
    The city manager may make additional rules and regulations supplementing the Procurement Code, NMSA 1978, § 13-1-28 et seq.; provided, that such regulations are more restrictive than those contained in the Procurement Code. 
(Code 1969, § 28A-5) 
Sec. 2-5-33. - Performance of duties in absence of city manager. 
    If the absence of the city manager occurs, the city manager may appoint a city officer or employee to act in his absence in carrying out the duties and obligations specified in this division. 
(Code 1969, § 28A-6) 
Sec. 2-5-34. - Direct purchase of certain items under $100.00. 
    The city manager may, by rules and regulations, provide for the direct purchase by the supervisor or head of the department or other personnel designated by him of repairs of disabled equipment or machinery, perishable food products and other services and materials, where ordering through the central purchasing office would entail unnecessary and detrimental delay, provided the cost of such items shall not exceed $100.00. 
(Code 1969, § 28A-2) 
Sec. 2-5-35. - Certain direct purchases authorized. 
    The city manager is authorized to make direct purchases, as specified in NMSA 1978, § 13-1-28 et seq., without prior authorization from the council, when the situation requires that immediate action be taken. 
(Code 1969, § 28A-4) 
Sec. 2-5-36. - Emergency purchases. 
    The city manager is delegated the authority to declare an emergency under NMSA 1978, § 13-1-127, where immediate action is necessary to preserve the peace, health or safety of the people or property within the city. If an emergency is declared, the city manager shall be authorized to purchase directly by order, without bids, provided the situation requires immediate action, prior to the designated meeting date of the city council. 
(Code 1969, § 28A-3) 
Secs. 2-5-37-2-5-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - INDUSTRIAL AND POLLUTION CONTROL REVENUE BONDS[15] 

Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2007-1189, adopted Sept. 25, 2007, amended div. 3, §§ 2-5-66-2-5-69, in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former div. 3, §§ 2-5-66-2-5-69 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from §§ 2-141-2-143, 2-150 of the 1969 Code. 
State Law reference- Industrial Revenue Bond Act, NMSA 1978, § 3-32-1 et seq., Pollution Control Revenue Bond Act, NMSA 1978, § 3-59-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-5-66. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Act means the Industrial Revenue Bond Act, §§ 3-32-1-3-32-16, NMSA 1978, as amended, or the Pollution Control Revenue Bond Act, §§ 3-59-1-3-59-14, NMSA 1978, as amended. When used in the plural, "Acts" means both of these Acts. 
    Bond means any bond, debenture, note, refunding or renewal bond or note, warrant or other security evidencing an obligation the proceeds of which, or a major portion thereof, are to be used to finance a project and which are authorized to be issued by the city pursuant to the Acts. 
    Project means any land, building, structure, facility, equipment or combination thereof, which qualifies as a project under the terms of either the Industrial Revenue Bond Act or the Pollution Control Revenue Bond Act. 
    Property means any land, improvements thereon, buildings and any improvements thereto, machinery and equipment of any and all kinds necessary to the project, operating capital and any other personal properties deemed necessary in connection with the project. 
    User means any person, corporation, partnership or other public or private entity described in either of the Acts for which projects may be financed by the issuance of bonds issued by the city as authorized by the Acts. 
(Ord. No. 2007-1189, § 1, 9-25-07) 
Sec. 2-5-67. - Fee. 
    As a condition to the issuance of any bonds by the city under either of the Acts, the user of the project so financed shall pay to the city a fee equal to one-tenth of one percent of the principal amount of such bonds or $25,000.00, whichever is greater. Such fee shall be paid in funds acceptable to the city at or prior to the delivery of the bonds and shall be in addition to, not in lieu of, the reimbursement of the city's expenses of issuing and maintaining such bonds as required by section 2-5-69 herein. 
(Ord. No. 2007-1189, § 1, 9-25-07) 
Sec. 2-5-68. - Payment in lieu of taxes. 
    Prior to the issuance of any bonds pursuant to either of the Acts, the user must contact the Farmington Municipal School District and San Juan College and enter into negotiations with the district and the college in regard to an agreement providing for a payment in lieu of taxes. The user must then report to the city as to whether an agreement for such payment has been reached with the district and the college before the city takes any final action on any instrument which authorizes the issuance of the bonds. 
(Ord. No. 2007-1189, § 1, 9-25-07) 
Sec. 2-5-69. - Indemnification. 
    In addition to the other sections of this division, the ordinances, resolutions or related documents adopted or executed by the city in connection with the issuance of any bonds under the Acts or any other bonds issued by the city shall require the user of the project so financed or refinanced to reimburse the city for or otherwise to indemnify the city against any and all losses, liabilities, claims, damages and expenses incurred by the city as a result of the issuance of such bonds, including, without limitation, reimbursement to the city of all costs incurred by it in connection with the issuance of the bonds and in connection with the performance or attainment by the city of its obligations and rights under the bonds and related documents. 
(Ord. No. 2007-1189, § 1, 9-25-07) 
Chapter 3 - AIRPORT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Airport advisory commission, § 2-4-71 et seq.; noise at airport and aircraft operations, § 12-5-14. 
State Law reference- Municipal Airport Law, NMSA 1978, § 3-39-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 3-1-1. - Purpose of airport. 
    The Four Corners Regional Airport-Farmington (FMN) shall be conducted as a terminal facility for the promotion and accommodation of air commerce and shall be operated as a public air terminal without discrimination against any person because of race, color, creed, age, sex, religious or political affiliation or national origin. 
(Code 1969, § 20-1) 
State Law reference- Authority to purchase, establish, construct, maintain and operate an airport, NMSA 1978, § 3-39-4. 
Sec. 3-1-2. - Appointment and authority of airport manager. 
(a)  The operation of the airport shall be under the direction of the airport manager who shall be appointed by the city manager and who shall be a person professionally competent by experience and training to manage the airport. 
(b)  The airport manager is delegated authority to take reasonable steps for handling, policing and protecting the public while present at the airport, subject to review by the city manager. 
(Code 1969, § 20-4) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-3-1 et seq. 
Sec. 3-1-3. - Penalty for violation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate this chapter. Any person convicted of violating this chapter shall be punished in the manner specified in section 1-1-10. 
(Code 1969, § 20-16) 
Sec. 3-1-4. - Hours of use. 
    The airport shall be open for public use at all hours of the day, subject to reasonable restrictions for security, inclement weather, conditions of the landing area and other reasonable restraints. 
(Code 1969, § 20-2) 
Sec. 3-1-5. - Obedience to regulations. 
    The use or occupancy of the airport or any of its facilities in any manner creates an obligation on the part of the user to obey all lawful regulations promulgated with reference thereto. 
(Code 1969, § 20-3) 
Sec. 3-1-6. - Airport rules generally. 
    At the airport, no person shall: 
(1)  Solicit funds, alms or fares at the airport for any purpose unless a permit has been issued by the city manager. 
(2)  Post, distribute or display signs, advertising circulars, printed or written matter on the airport unless a permit has been received from the city manager. 
(3)  Take any still, motion or sound pictures on the airport for commercial purposes unless a permit has been received from the city manager. 
(4)  Commence any construction, improvement or remodeling activity at or upon the airport without prior approval of the city manager. 
(5)  Fail to report as soon as possible any damage, injury or destruction caused by any such person to any property on the airport, including real property, personal property, improvements, fixtures or equipment owned or controlled by the city or owned or controlled by any other person or governmental agency and used in connection with the landing, takeoff, control or safety of aircraft. 
(Code 1969, § 20-12) 
Sec. 3-1-7. - Sanitation. 
    At the airport, no person shall: 
(1)  Release, deposit, blow or spread any bodily discharge on the floor, wall, partition, furniture or any part of a public toilet, comfort station, terminal building, hangar or other building or place on the airport, other than directly into a fixture provided for that purpose. 
(2)  Place any foreign object in any plumbing fixture of a public toilet, comfort station, terminal building, hangar or other building on the airport. 
(3)  Dispose of any sewage, garbage, refuse, paper or other material at the airport, except in a container provided for such purpose. 
(Code 1969, § 20-13) 
Cross reference- Solid waste management, ch. 23; utilities, ch. 26. 
Sec. 3-1-8. - Unauthorized use of property. 
    No person shall take or use any aircraft or any part or accessory thereof or any tools or other equipment owned or controlled by any other person or stored or otherwise left at the airport without the consent of the owner or operator thereof or other satisfactory evidence of his right to do so. 
(Code 1969, § 20-14) 
Sec. 3-1-9. - Unauthorized entrance into restricted areas. 
    No person shall enter upon the field area, the control tower area, the airline service area, the airport utilities service area, the fire department control area or any other area of the airport which has been designated and posted as restricted to the public unless such person has been duly authorized to enter such area or place. 
(Code 1969, § 20-15) 
ARTICLE 2. - BUSINESS OPERATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses and sales, ch. 8. 

Sec. 3-2-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business or commercial activity includes but is not limited to airport operators, commercial operations of every kind and nature, commercial aircraft service, charter operations, flight instruction, fixed base operators, restaurant and lounge operations, rental car agencies, aircraft sales, airplane and power plant repair facilities, aircraft rental, flight training, line services, specialized aircraft repair services, aircraft charter and air taxi, specialized commercial flying services, motel business, telephone solicitation and any other business or commercial activity. 
(Code 1969, § 20-6(a)) 
Sec. 3-2-2. - Conducting or soliciting business or commercial activity; contract or lease. 
    No person shall conduct any business or commercial activity of any kind or nature whatsoever from airport property or from the Four Corners Regional Airport, nor shall any person solicit business or advertise for business or any commercial activity from airport property or from the Four Corners Regional Airport unless such person shall first have entered into a written contract or lease agreement with the city upon terms and conditions approved by the city council. 
(Code 1969, § 20-5) 
Sec. 3-2-3. - Contract and lease terms; minimum standards; lease payment. 
(a)  The provisions of any agreement, contract or lease issued pursuant to section 3-2-2 shall neither be unreasonably discriminatory nor preferential. Any such lease, agreement or contract shall conform to minimum standards, which shall be established and approved by the city council from time to time upon recommendation of the airport advisory committee. 
(b)  The minimum standards referred to in subsection (a) of this section shall be periodically updated and reviewed. Such standards shall be adopted by resolution of the city council and shall provide standards for the conduct of business and commercial operations at the airport which will foster, encourage and ensure the economic health and orderly development of the Four Corners Regional Airport, general aviation and related activities by ensuring adequate commercial services and facilities to users of the airport. The standards shall take into consideration, among other things, the intended scope of the activities, the services to be offered, the amount of land to be leased, the building space to be constructed or leased, the type of services to be provided, the number of aircraft to be provided, the number of persons to be employed, hours of proposed operations, types of insurance coverage to be maintained, the reasonably expected market and financial capability of the lessee or contractor to provide the proposed services and facilities and periodic revision for inflationary or deflationary factors. 
(c)  Any lease payment which provides for payment of a percentage of gross receipts of the lessee to the city shall be in lieu of and shall constitute payment of any occupational license fee required under Chapter 8. 
(Code 1969, § 20-6) 
ARTICLE 3. - AIRCRAFT 

Sec. 3-3-1. - Operator's conduct when tower in operation. 
    No person shall, while the federal aviation tower located at the Four Corners Regional Airport is in operation: 
(1)  Navigate any aircraft over, land upon, take off from or service, repair or maintain any aircraft other than in conformity with the rules and regulations of the Federal Aviation Administration of the United States. 
(2)  Fail to taxi while under full control and at reasonable speeds while the aircraft is being operated. Following a landing or prior to takeoff and while taxiing, every pilot shall ensure that there is no danger of collision with other aircraft. 
(3)  Taxi any aircraft not equipped with adequate brakes on any ramp or apron at any speed unless an attendant is at all times beside one wing. 
(4)  Taxi any aircraft on any apron or ramp so as to endanger any passengers entering or leaving any aircraft. 
(5)  Taxi any aircraft upon a runway, except: 
a.  As a necessary part of taking off or landing; 
b.  When given permission by the tower; and 
c.  When crossing a runway or runway intersection. 
(6)  Taxi any aircraft at night or after sunset unless the navigation lights and at least one landing light, if the aircraft is equipped with landing lights, are turned on and burning. 
(7)  Leave any aircraft standing or parked outside of an area designated for parking of aircraft at night or after sunset unless the navigation lights and at least one landing light, if the aircraft is equipped with landing lights, are turned on and burning. If such aircraft lighting is not possible, proper warning lights must immediately be lit and placed near the aircraft. 
(8)  Take off or land any aircraft, except in an emergency or accident when directed by the tower, on any apron, ramp, taxiway or any other place other than a runway. This subsection shall not apply to the takeoff and landing of a helicopter or other aircraft that takes off or lands vertically. 
(9)  Take off or land any helicopter or other aircraft that takes off or lands vertically except at places designated for such takeoffs or landings by the airport manager or the tower. 
(10)  Leave any disabled or wrecked aircraft on any taxiway, runway or other place, other than a designated parking area, overnight or for any unreasonable period of time, unless specific prior authority has been granted by the airport manager and the aircraft is guarded and warning lights are placed around it. 
(11)  Park any aircraft or vehicle within 25 feet of any fire hydrant. 
(12)  Leave any aircraft unattended on any ramp, apron, taxiway, runway or area other than a designated aircraft parking area. 
(13)  Fail to securely tie down any unattended aircraft. 
(14)  Run up or operate at high revolutions per minute (rpm's) any aircraft engine near any passenger terminal building, hangar or other building, other than in areas designated by the airport manager and only with appropriate brakes, chocks or safety devices in use. 
(15)  Park any aircraft on any apron or part thereof which is not designated for the parking of aircraft. 
(16)  Park any aircraft in any fire lane where fire lanes have been so designated. 
(17)  Take off or land any aircraft at the airport when such airport is not equipped with two-way radio equipment consisting of a functioning radio transmitter and receiver capable of conducting two-way communications with the airport within a five-mile radius of the tower on radio frequencies used by the control tower with such equipment in use and appropriately monitored, unless permission to do so has been obtained by the airport tower when such tower is in operation or from the airport manager if the tower is not in operation. 
(18)  Take off or land any aircraft at the airport having a gross weight exceeding that as follows: 
Runway Single 
Wheel 
(pounds) Dual 
Wheels 
(pounds) Twin 
Tandem 
(pounds) 7/25 57,000 80,000 125,000 5/23 40,000 60,000 100,000  
(19)  Fail to follow directions or procedures given or required by the tower or the airport manager in an aircraft emergency or accident, a bomb threat, a fire or other calamity or emergency. 
(20)  Act as a crew member of any aircraft while: 
a.  Under the influence of intoxicating liquor or beverage. 
b.  Using any drug that affects such person's faculties in any way contrary to safety. 
(21)  Allow any person, who is obviously under the influence of intoxicating beverages or drugs, to board or be carried onto any aircraft except in an emergency or when such person is a medical patient under proper care. 
(22)  Move or operate any aircraft in a careless or reckless manner. 
(23)  Run the engine of a parked aircraft in a manner that damages any other property or aircraft or that blows paper, dirt or other material across taxiways or runways so as to endanger the safety of persons or property. 
(24)  Take off over any hangar or other building. 
(25)  Start or taxi any aircraft in any place where the exhaust or engine blast is likely to cause injury to persons or property. If the aircraft cannot be started or taxied without violating this subsection, the operator shall have it towed to a location where such operations can be done safely. 
(26)  Operate an aircraft so as to use any passenger gate other than that assigned by the airport manager. 
(27)  Park any aircraft in such a manner or place as to block or prevent any other parked aircraft from free and unobstructed movement if it becomes necessary to move any one parked aircraft due to any emergency. The intent of this subsection is to ensure that only one parked aircraft may be easily moved away from its position without first moving other parked aircraft. This subsection shall not apply to the parking of aircraft in an aircraft hangar building. 
(Code 1969, § 20-7) 
Sec. 3-3-2. - Operator's conduct when tower not in operation. 
(a)  All aircraft operated from or upon the Four Corners Regional Airport when the tower is not in operation at the airport shall be operated in accordance with the rules of section 3-3-1, except as follows: 
(1)  The appropriate radio tower frequency shall be monitored at all times by two-way radio to determine the location of other airport traffic. Aircraft operators shall announce, on the tower frequency or appropriate frequency designated by the airport manager, aircraft position at takeoff, position downwind and position of final approach to landing, even though the tower is not in operation to alert other aircraft to traffic. 
(2)  Aircraft awaiting takeoff shall park so as to have a direct view of aircraft approaching for landing and shall park at least 100 feet from the runway in use or short of markings placed upon the runway to indicate the area to be used for awaiting takeoff. 
(b)  Taxiing shall conform to taxi charts that are on file in the office of the airport manager and the city clerk. 
(c)  All aircraft takeoffs and landings by the pilot shall be in the direction indicated by the airport wind direction indicator. 
(d)  No turns shall be made after takeoff until the airport boundary has been reached and the aircraft has attained an altitude of at least 400 feet and it has been ascertained that there will be no danger of collision with other aircraft. 
(e)  Aircraft intending to remain in the traffic pattern shall continue to climb to traffic pattern altitude after the first 90-degree turn. The direction of aerial traffic, when the tower is not operating, around the outside of the Four Corners Regional Airport shall be counterclockwise while at or below 1,500 feet above the surface of the airport and within a three-mile radius of the airport. 
(f)  The pilot of any transport category aircraft and other aircraft of similar size shall enter the traffic pattern, when the airport tower is not operating, at 1,500 feet above the surface of the airport or at such higher altitude appropriate for high speed aircraft and shall maintain that altitude until in position to begin descent for landing. 
(g)  Any pilot of smaller aircraft, when the tower is not operating, shall enter the traffic pattern at an altitude of 1,000 feet above the surface when at least three miles from the airport and shall maintain that altitude until in position to begin descent for landing. 
(Code 1969, § 20-8) 
ARTICLE 4. - MOTOR VEHICLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 25. 

Sec. 3-4-1. - Operation generally. 
    At the airport, no person shall: 
(1)  Operate any motor vehicle or mobile equipment, other than aircraft, on any airport apron, ramp, taxiway, runway or any other part of the landing field: 
a.  Except upon authority of the airport manager; and 
b.  Unless the operator of such vehicle or equipment has airport business thereon or, for a city employee, has been assigned to duty by his employer in such areas with approval of the airport manager; 
c.  Unless the vehicle or equipment is covered by insurance in an amount equal to that specified for city vehicles. 
(2)  Operate any motor vehicle or mobile equipment on the landing area unless the required two-way radio equipment is turned on and monitored, is in good working order and is capable of communicating with the airport control tower at all times unless specific permission of the airport manager or of the tower to operate on the landing area without such equipment has been obtained. 
(3)  Fail to yield the right-of-way to any aircraft or pedestrian when operating any motor vehicle or mobile equipment on, including entering or leaving, any ramp, apron, taxiway or landing area or other place on the airport. Aircraft moving or being moved on an apron, ramp, taxiway or the landing area shall always have right-of-way over all motor vehicles or mobile equipment. 
(4)  At night, operate any motor vehicle or motorized ground equipment on any apron, ramp, taxiway or the landing area unless such vehicle or equipment has lights turned on which are clearly visible from the front and rear. 
(5)  Drive or operate any motor vehicle or mobile equipment in such a manner that it is not under complete and safe control at all times. 
(6)  Drive any vehicle or walk or be carried to or be present on any apron, taxiway, runway or any part of the landing field for the purpose of being a spectator, sightseer or for the purpose of taking pictures unless specific permission has been obtained from the airport manager. Permission shall not be granted unless such activities can be conducted in a manner which will not lessen or impair the safety of aircraft or the operator or occupants thereof. 
(7)  Park any motor vehicle for any purpose in any place on the airport which has not been specifically established for motor vehicle parking and which has not been marked or posted by signs, lines or other means identified for parking. 
(8)  Abandon any motor vehicle on the airport; fail to pay any lawfully established motor vehicle parking fee; or park any motor vehicle so as to obstruct any airport driveway, roadway, parking area, pedestrian way or grassed area. 
(9)  Fail to effectively brake any motor vehicle or motorized or nonmotorized equipment when such vehicle or equipment is unattended or an operator is not at the controls, if any. 
(Code 1969, § 20-9) 
Sec. 3-4-2. - Traffic and parking. 
(a)  The airport manager shall designate airport areas generally open to motor vehicle traffic and shall designate areas for vehicular parking. Unless otherwise posted, the traffic rules and regulations set forth in Chapter 25 pertaining to motor vehicles shall apply to areas designated for motor vehicular traffic and parking by the airport manager and, if not in conflict with this chapter, shall also apply to operation of motor vehicles on the airport. 
(b)  All authorized vehicles traversing traffic movement areas, other than service areas (i.e. ramps, fueling areas, passenger loading areas, etc.) of the air operations area proper without two-way radio shall display and fly on the rear of the vehicle a checkered flag of a size not less than three feet square. Two-way radio communications between the tower and all ground vehicles operating on usable runways and taxiways will be maintained at all times. Escort vehicles with two-way communications capability with the tower are to accompany maintenance or service vehicles without two-way radio communications capability, when operating on traffic movement areas. Before crossing any runway, all vehicles will first obtain permission to cross such runway from the control tower by radio. Upon receiving clearance, the driver will ensure by personal observation that no aircraft is approaching his position. Vehicles that do not obtain proper clearance will be reported to the airport manager by the control tower. 
(c)  During the hours of darkness, no vehicle shall cross a lighted runway unless specific clearance is obtained from the control tower, either by radio communications or light-gun signal. The operator of a vehicle without a radio will first call the control tower by phone. To obtain recognition by the tower while at a taxiway holding line, the driver will flash the vehicle headlights toward the tower and proceed across only upon a light signal from the tower. 
(d)  Emergency conditions existing at any time on the airport will not mitigate or cancel the regulations of this section. During such conditions, the driver of any vehicle will make certain that he does not move his vehicle in any direction unless specifically cleared by the control tower to do so. 
(e)  All vehicles operating in the airport operations area must be equipped with two-way radios and be in continuous communication with the control tower, with the exception of the following equipment, which will be accompanied by an escort vehicle when operating or working on usable runways or taxiways: 
(1)  Crash equipment while attending an accident. 
(2)  Refueling vehicles and towing tugs must cross aircraft areas for loading purposes only. Prior to crossing, the operator must obtain clearance from the control tower. 
(3)  Operational, agricultural and maintenance equipment operators not engaged in working on runway property will keep the control tower informed of the general area in which the equipment is working. 
(4)  Any vehicle crossing any taxiway or runway and not equipped with a two-way radio and in direct contact with the control tower shall not be operated within the landing area until prior permission is received from the tower, and then the operator must observe all light signals from the tower. 
(f)  The installation of two-way radios does not permit the operation of vehicles on the airport without prior permission from the airport manager and the control tower. 
(g)  Any vehicle that has been permitted to operate on the airport will not proceed closer than 200 feet from the edge of the runways or across any of the runways prior to being cleared by the tower. It is the responsibility of all vehicle operators to be familiar with the standard airport light signals, regardless of whether or not the vehicle is radio equipped. 
(Code 1969, § 20-10) 
Sec. 3-4-3. - Limitations of article. 
    No action taken under the authority of this article shall be interpreted as dedicating land at the airport as a public street, road or highway. 
(Code 1969, § 20-11) 
ARTICLE 5. - AIRPORT ZONING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Adoption of airport zoning regulations, NMSA 1978, § 3-39-20. 

Sec. 3-5-1. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as "Four Corners Regional Airport Zoning Ordinance." 
(Code 1969, app. II, § 1) 
Sec. 3-5-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Airport means the Four Corners Regional Airport. 
    Airport elevation means the established elevation of the highest point on the usable landing area, which is 5,502 feet, mean sea level. 
    Airport hazard means any structure, tree or use of land which obstructs the airspace required for or which is otherwise hazardous to the flight of aircraft in landing or taking off at the airport. 
    Airport reference point means the point established as the approximate geographic center of the airport landing area and is established at a location described as follows: longitude 108 degrees 13 minutes and 54 seconds, latitude 36 degrees 44 minutes and 30 seconds. 
    Board of appeals means a board consisting of three members as provided for in Ordinance No. 417. 
    Height, for the purpose of determining the height limits in all zones set forth in this article and shown on the zoning map, means the datum which shall be mean sea level, unless otherwise specified. 
    Landing area means the area of the airport used for the landing, takeoff or taxiing of aircraft. 
    Nonconforming use means any structure, tree, or use of land which is lawfully in existence at the time the regulation as prescribed in this article or an amendment thereto becomes effective and does not then meet the requirements of such regulation. 
    Noninstrument runway means a runway other than instrument runway. 
    Runway means the paved surface of an airport landing strip. 
    Structure means an object constructed or installed by man, including but without limitation buildings, towers, smokestacks and overhead transmission lines. 
    Tree means an object of natural growth. 
(Code 1969, app. II, § 2) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-1-2. 
Sec. 3-5-3. - Zones. 
    In order to carry out this article, there are created and established certain zones which include all of the land lying within the noninstrument approach zones, transition zones, horizontal zone and conical zone. Such areas and zones are shown on the Four Corners Regional Airport Zoning Map consisting of one sheet prepared by C. C. Cash, City Engineer, and dated, May 9, 1966, which is made a part of this article. The various zones are established and defined as follows: 
(1)  Noninstrument approach zones. A noninstrument approach zone is established at each end of all noninstrument runways on the airport for noninstrument landing and takeoff. The noninstrument approach zone shall have a width of 500 feet at a distance of 200 feet beyond each end of the runway, widening thereafter uniformly to a width of 2,500 feet at a distance of 10,200 feet beyond each end of the runway, its centerline being the continuation of a centerline of the runway. 
(2)  Instrument approach zone. An instrument approach zone is established at each end of all instrument runways on the airport for instrument landings and takeoffs. The instrument approach zone shall have a width of 1,000 feet a distance of 200 feet beyond each end of the runway, widening thereafter uniformly to a width of 16,000 feet at a distance of 50,200 feet beyond each end of the runway, its centerline being the continuation of the centerline of the runway. 
(3)  Transition zones. Transition zones are established to each instrument and noninstrument runway and approach zone as indicated on the zoning map. Transition zones symmetrically located on either side of runways have variable width as shown on the zoning map. Transition zones extend outward from a line 250 feet (noninstrument) and 500 feet (instrument) on either side of the centerline of the noninstrument or instrument runway for the length of such runway plus 200 feet on each end and are parallel and level with such runway centerlines. The transition zones along such runways slope upward and outward one foot vertically for each seven feet horizontally to the point where they intersect the surface of the horizontal zone. Further, transition zones are established adjacent to noninstrument approach zones for the entire length of the approach zones. These transition zones have variable widths, as shown on the zoning map. Such transition zones flare symmetrically with either side of the runway approach zones from the base of such zones and slope upward and outward at the rate of one foot vertically for each seven feet horizontally to the points where they intersect the surfaces of the horizontal and conical zones. 
(4)  Horizontal zone. A horizontal zone is established as the area within a circle with its center at the airport reference point and having a radius of 1,000 feet. The horizontal zone does not include the noninstrument or instrument approach zones and the transition zones. 
(5)  Conical zone. A conical zone is established as the area that commences at the periphery of the horizontal zone and extends outward therefrom a distance of 5,000 feet. The conical zone does not include the noninstrument approach zones and transition zones. 
(Code 1969, app. II, § 3) 
Sec. 3-5-4. - Height limitations. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, no structure or tree shall be erected, altered, allowed to grow or maintained in any zone created by this article to a height in excess of the height limit established in this section for such zone. Such height limitations are established for each of the zones as follows: 
(1)  Noninstrument approach zones. One foot in height for each 40 feet in horizontal distance beginning at a point 200 feet from and at the elevation of the end of the noninstrument runway and extending to a point 10,200 feet from the end of the runway. 
(2)  Instrument approach zones. One foot in height for each 50 feet in horizontal distance beginning at a point 200 feet from and at the elevation of the end of the instrument runway and extending to a point 10,200 feet from the end of the runway; thence one foot in height for each 40 feet in horizontal distance, beginning at a point 10,200 feet from the end of the runway at an elevation of 200 feet above the end of the instrument runway and extending to a point 50,200 feet from the end of the runway. 
(3)  Transition zones. One foot in height for each seven feet in horizontal distance beginning at any point 250 feet (noninstrument) and 500 feet (instrument) normal to and at the elevation of the centerline of the instrument and noninstrument runways extending 200 feet beyond each end thereof, extending to a height of 150 feet above the airport elevation which is 5,652 feet above the mean sea level. In addition, there are established height limits of one foot vertical height for each seven feet horizontal distance measured from the edges of all approach zones for the entire length of the approach zones and extending upward and outward to the points where they intersect the horizontal or conical surfaces. 
(4)  Horizontal zone. One hundred fifty feet above the airport elevation or a height of 5,652 feet above mean sea level. 
(5)  Conical zone. One foot in height for each 20 feet of horizontal distance beginning at the periphery of the horizontal zone, extending to a height of 400 feet above the airport elevation. 
(b)  Where an area is covered by more than one height limitation, the more restrictive limitations shall prevail. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall be construed as prohibiting the growth, construction or maintenance of any tree or structure to a height up to 40 feet above the surface of the land. 
(Code 1969, app. II, § 4) 
Sec. 3-5-5. - Use restrictions. 
    Notwithstanding any other section of this article, no use may be made of land within any zone established by this article in such a manner as to create electrical interference with radio communications between the airport and the aircraft, to make it difficult for flyers to distinguish between airport lights and others, to result in glare in the eyes of flyers using the airport, to impair visibility in the vicinity of the airport or to otherwise endanger the landing, taking off or maneuvering of aircraft. 
(Code 1969, app. II, § 5) 
Sec. 3-5-6. - Nonconforming uses. 
(a)  Continuation. This article shall not be construed to require the removal, lowering or other changes or alteration of any structure or tree not conforming to this as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives or otherwise interfere with the continuance of any nonconforming use. Nothing in this article shall require any change in the construction, alteration or intended use of any structure, the construction or alteration of which was begun prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives and is diligently prosecuted. 
(b)  Marking and lighting. Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, the owner of any nonconforming structure or tree is required to permit the installation, operation and maintenance thereon of such markers and lights as shall be deemed necessary by the administrative agency to indicate to the operators of aircraft in the vicinity of the airport the presence of such hazards. Such markers and lights shall be installed, operated and maintained at the expense of the city. 
(Code 1969, app. II, § 6) 
Sec. 3-5-7. - Permits. 
(a)  Future uses. Except as specifically provided in subsections (a)(1), (2), and (3) of this section, no material change shall be made in the use of the land and no structure or tree shall be erected, altered, planted or otherwise established in any zone created by this article unless a permit therefor shall have been applied for and granted. Each application for a permit shall indicate the purpose for which the permit is desired, with sufficient particularity to permit it to be determined whether the resulting use, structure or tree would conform to the regulations prescribed in this article. If such determination is in the affirmative, the permit shall be granted. 
(1)  In the area lying within the limits of the horizontal zone and the conical zone but not within the limits of an instrument or noninstrument approach zone or transition zone, no permit shall be required for any tree or structure less than 75 feet of vertical height above the ground, except when because of terrain, land contour or topographic features such tree or structure would extend above the height limits prescribed for such zone. 
(2)  In the areas lying within the limits of the instrument and noninstrument approach zones but at a horizontal distance of not less than 4,200 feet from each end of the runways, no permit shall be required for any tree or structure less than 75 feet of vertical height above the established airport elevation, except when such tree or structure would extend above the height limit prescribed for such instrument or noninstrument approach zone. 
(3)  In the areas lying within the limits of the transition zones beyond the perimeter of the horizontal zone, no permit shall be required for any tree or structure less than 50 feet of vertical height above the ground, except when such tree or structure, because of terrain, land contour or topographic features would extend above the height limit prescribed for such transition zones.
