(2)  A dog which has on at least one prior occasion, attacked or bitten another animal or a person without provocation or without legal justification, such as the protection of a person or property; or 
(3)  An incident where a dog attacks, maims or kills a domestic animal. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 1, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-1-3. - Violations. 
    Penalties. Every violation of this chapter shall be a petty misdemeanor, punishable as outlined in the following table or, if not shown in the table, punishable pursuant to section 1-1-10. None of the following fines may be suspended, deferred or taken under advisement: 
Name and Section of Offense First 
Offense Second 
Offense Third and Subsequent Offenses Abandonment of animal, section 6-4-1(1) $300.00 $400.00 $500.00 Animal running at large, section 6-4-1(2) 25.00 75.00 100.00 No vaccination, section 6-4-1(3) 50.00 75.00 100.00 No tags, section 6-4-1(4) 25.00 50.00 75.00 Barking dog, section 6-4-1(5) 25.00 100.00 150.00 Nuisance animal, section 6-4-1(6) 25.00 75.00 100.00 Vicious animal, section 6-5-1 200.00 300.00 500.00 Animal neglect, section 6-4-3 300.00 400.00 500.00 Malicious treatment, section 6-4-4 300.00 400.00 500.00 Animal biting while at large, section 6-4-1(8) 50.00 100.00 150.00 Failure to obtain a kennel license, section 6-3-1 150.00 200.00 250.00 Failure to obtain a guard dog permit, section 6-3-2 150.00 200.00 250.00  
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 1, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-1-4. - Use of revenues. 
    All money collected as a result of fines and fees imposed by this chapter shall be placed in a fund to be utilized exclusively for the operation of the Farmington Regional Animal Shelter. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 1, 12-9-14) 
ARTICLE 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND PROCEDURES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 2, adopted Dec. 9, 2014, repealed art. 2 in its entirety, and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former art. 2 pertained to animal shelter, impoundment and disposition, and derived from the 1969 Code, §§ 4-2-1-4-2-7, 4-2-9. 

Sec. 6-2-1. - Enforcement by park rangers-animal control officers. 
(a)  Park rangers-animal control supervisors and officers, as established in section 15-6-1, are responsible for the administration and enforcement of this chapter. 
(b)  In addition, the director of parks, recreation and cultural affairs and the animal welfare director may appoint animal attendants and other personnel as authorized and necessary to assist in carrying out the duties required under this chapter. 
(c)  Park rangers-animal control officers shall have the authority to enter onto privately owned property within the city as needed to carry out the provisions of this chapter or to protect the life or health of an animal that is in immediate danger if neither the owner nor the occupant of the property are present on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 2, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-2-2. - Animal shelter created; services. 
    There is created a municipal animal shelter which shall provide the following services and facilities: 
(1)  Impoundment of all stray, ownerless, owner surrendered and at-large animals, cruelly treated animals, vicious animals and animals otherwise in violation of this chapter. 
(2)  Individual isolation facilities for sick, vicious, rabid and suspected rabid animals. 
(3)  Facilities for the humane destruction of unclaimed animals, rabid animals and animals that are so ill or injured as to be beyond reasonable medical assistance. 
(4)  Records and facilities for adoption and other disposition of animals. 
(5)  Adequate facilities and personnel for the proper housing, feeding, watering and other care of animals. 
(6)  Veterinary services as provided in section 6-2-10. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 2, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-2-3. - Impoundment. 
    The park ranger-animal control supervisor, park ranger-animal control officers or police officer shall pick up and impound every animal found running at large, suspected of rabies, obviously injured or diseased, believed to have been cruelly treated or known to be vicious. The park ranger-animal control officer may, in their discretion, return an animal found running at large, may give a warning or may cite the owner for allowing his animal to run at large, rather than impounding the animal. Diseased animals may be humanely and immediately destroyed if, in the discretion of the park ranger-animal control supervisor or animal welfare director, the animal's condition is a threat to other animals or the public welfare. Domestic cats are expressly excluded from the prohibition against animals running at large, but are included in other categories stated in this section and may be impounded if suspected of rabies, if believed to have been cruelly treated or if known to be vicious. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 2, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-2-4. - Notice to owner of impounded animal. 
    Upon the impounding of any animal, it shall be the duty of the park ranger-animal control supervisor or other park ranger-animal control personnel to notify the owner of the animal impounded if the owner is known or can be identified from a vaccination tag or other identification. Such notice shall be by telephone, by certified mail or by any means provided by law to serve process in a civil action. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 2, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-2-5. - Period of impoundment; disposal. 
(a)  Unless sooner redeemed by the owner, all impounded animals shall be kept for a minimum period of three days. A fraction of a day shall be computed as being a full day for the purposes of this section. An animal that bears a tag or whose owner is otherwise known shall be kept for a period of five working days from notification of the owner. If notification is by mail, an additional three days, not including holidays, Saturdays or Sundays, will be added to the required five-day period. 
(b)  After the period of impoundment has been completed as described in subsection (a) of this section, any impounded animal may be sold, adopted or humanely destroyed in the discretion of the animal welfare director. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 2, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-2-6. - Redemption of impounded animal. 
    It is the duty of the animal welfare director or designee and animal shelter staff to release any animal from the city animal shelter to the owner thereof upon receipt of satisfactory proof of ownership and payment of the required fees and deposits as set forth in this article. Any citation issued must also be signed by the owner. However, an impounded animal shall not be released to its owner if the animal has been impounded because it is vicious or because the animal welfare director, animal shelter staff or park ranger-animal control officer believes the animal has been cruelly treated until the matter has been heard by the municipal court and the court has ordered such release or any other disposition, including euthanasia, if the court finds such disposition to be in the best interests and welfare of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 2, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-2-7. - Fees and deposits. 
    The owner of an animal impounded pursuant to this chapter or an approved adoptive owner shall pay the fees and costs established by regulations issued by the animal welfare director. Such regulations and changes or amendments thereto shall be reviewed by the city council and shall be binding and valid only after approval by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 2, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-2-8. - Injured animals. 
    Animals injured while running at large on public property may be impounded and given medical treatment pending notification of the owner. If the animal is treated or impounded, the owner of the animal shall be liable for all expenses of the treatment and/or impoundment. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 2, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-2-9. - Disposal of dead animals. 
(a)  When any animal lies dead upon private property within the city, it shall be primarily the duty of the animal's owner or, if the owner is unknown, the occupant or person in charge of such property to forthwith remove or cause to be removed the dead animal from such property to the landfill or other appropriate place of disposal. No person shall deposit or otherwise place any dead animal or portion of any dead animal for collection by sanitation personnel. 
(b)  If any dead animal is found upon the city streets or other public places within the city, the city, acting through its employees or through contract with private individuals, shall cause the dead animal to be removed and disposed of in a proper manner. However, park ranger-animal control personnel are not required to remove horses, cows or other large animals. 
(c)  The owner or occupant of private property wherein a dead animal is found shall place such animal in a plastic bag or similar container, which is securely fastened shut. Upon request, the secured plastic bag or container may be disposed of by park ranger-animal control personnel. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 2, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-2-10. - Scope of veterinary services. 
    Veterinary services shall include: 
(1)  Serving the medical needs of the Farmington Regional Animal Shelter animals to: 
a.  Reduce their pain and suffering; 
b.  Maintain their health and well-being while being sheltered; and 
c.  Provide follow-up medical care as determined by the veterinarian or animal welfare director. 
(2)  Spaying, neutering and vaccinating of shelter animals and animals owned by the public at the time of spay and neutering who qualify under financial means testing based on adjusted gross household income. 
a.  Provide follow-up medical care arising from the spay/neuter procedure performed as determined by the veterinarian or animal welfare director. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 2, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-2-11. - Judicial disposition upon finding of cruel treatment. 
    If a municipal or district court finds that an animal has been cruelly treated and further finds that such treatment is likely to continue, the court may order that the animal has been forfeited by the owner; the court may cause the animal to be placed with an adoptive agency or humane society, if such agency or society is willing to accept custody of the animal and has adequate facilities therefor; or the court may order such other disposition as is appropriate under the circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 2, 12-9-14) 
ARTICLE 3. - LICENSE AND PERMIT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 3, adopted Dec. 9, 2014, repealed art. 3 in its entirety, and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former art. 3 pertained to rabies control, and derived from the 1969 Code, §§ 4-1-1-4-1-7. 

Sec. 6-3-1. - Kennel license required. 
(a)  Any person who keeps or operates or proposes to establish a kennel shall apply to the city clerk for a business license pursuant to article 3 of chapter 8. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a kennel in the city without obtaining a license as provided in this section. Additionally, any person obtaining a kennel license must pay a $20.00 permit/inspection fee annually. 
(b)  The park ranger-animal control supervisor shall inspect each kennel within the city, licensed as required in this section, at least annually, in order to determine if the kennel is being kept in a clean condition and all animals are being treated humanely. Based on these inspections, the park ranger-animal control supervisor shall recommend to the city clerk whether the license shall be renewed. If the park ranger-animal control supervisor shall recommend to the city clerk that such license should be suspended, revoked or that it should not be renewed, the licensee shall have the right to appeal this decision to the administrative review board, which is granted jurisdiction to hear such appeal pursuant to subsection 2-4-38(8). 
(c)  Hospitals, clinics and other premises operated by licensed veterinarians for the care and treatment of animals are exempt from this section. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 3, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-3-2. - Guard dog permit. 
(a)  Before a person may use or house a guard dog, the person must obtain a permit for the property. 
(b)  The permittee shall display a permit issued under this article at the approved property. 
(c)  Permit application. 
(1)  An application for a permit under this article must include: 
a.  The name, address and telephone number of the property where a guard dog is to be used; 
b.  The name, address and telephone number of a handler who will be available for contact 24 hours a day; 
c.  The number of dogs to be used and a general description of their use; 
d.  The location where a guard dog is to be housed; and 
e.  The owner must pay a $50.00 permit fee. 
(d)  Permit term and renewal. 
(1)  The city clerk may issue a permit under this article for a one-year term. 
(2)  A person may apply for a renewal permit and pay the renewal fee established by ordinance not later than the 30th day after the expiration of a permit. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 3, 12-9-14) 
ARTICLE 4. - PROHIBITED ACTIONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 4, adopted Dec. 9, 2014, repealed art. 4 in its entirety, and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former art. 4 pertained to animal services advisory commission, and derived from Ord. No. 2011-1244, § 1, adopted May 24, 2011. 

Sec. 6-4-1. - Unlawful acts. 
    It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person to do any of the following: 
(1)  Willfully abandon an animal within the city limits. 
(2)  Allow a dog or other animal, except cats, to run at large within the city. Any person owning or having charge, custody, care or control of any animal shall keep such animal within his premises. Unless in a designated city dog park, no animal shall be at large in or on any street, alley, sidewalk, vacant lot, public property, other unenclosed space in the city or private property. Any animal found running at large in violation of this section is declared to be a nuisance, a menace to the public health and safety, and if observed by an animal control officer shall be taken up and impounded as provided for in section 6-4-5. It shall be the duty of any city law enforcement officer to report any animals running at large to the city's animal control officers. 
(3)  Own a dog or cat over the age of three months that has not been vaccinated as required by state law. 
a.  It is the duty of every person keeping a dog or cat over the age of three months to have such animal vaccinated against rabies. 
b.  Every veterinarian who vaccinates or supervises the vaccination of a dog or cat hereunder shall issue to the owner or keeper of such animal a numbered vaccination certificate and tag. The certificate shall contain the name and address of the owner or keeper of the animal, a description of the animal vaccinated, the type of vaccine used, the date of vaccination and the expiration date of the period of immunity. 
(4)  Own a dog that does not have a tag affixed to a collar or harness indicating the date of the most recent rabies vaccination of that animal. An owner of an animal without a rabies vaccination shall have ten days from the date of the violation to provide proof to the court of a rabies vaccination and the citation shall be dismissed. 
(5)  Own or harbor a dog that annoys others by constant or consistent bark, howl or by making noise common to its species, or otherwise to disturb the peace and quiet of the inhabitants of the city, or to keep or maintain in such a manner as to disturb by noxious or offensive odors, or otherwise endanger the health, safety or welfare of the inhabitants of the city. 
(6)  Own, harbor or maintain an animal that is a nuisance. For purpose of this subsection, an animal nuisance shall be an animal that: 
a.  Scratches or digs about any flower bed, garden, tilled soil, shrubbery or small plants; 
b.  Habitually prowls around, on or through premises which do not belong to its owner; 
c.  Overturns refuse container or scatters the contents of refuse container; 
d.  Chases or kills any domesticated animals or domesticated birds; or 
e.  Habitually chases motor vehicles, bicycles or other vehicles. 
(7)  Own, harbor or maintain a female dog in heat (estrus) that is not confined in a building or secure enclosure in such manner as to avoid contact with a male dog, except for intentional breeding purposes. 
(8)  Allow a dog or other animal, except cats, to run at large and while at large to attack or bite any animal or person without provocation or legal justification. 
(9)  a.  No owner or caretaker of any dog shall cause or allow such dog to defecate on any public property or upon any street, sidewalk, public way, school yard, play area or upon private property other than that of the owner or caretaker, unless such owner or caretaker immediately removes and disposes of all feces deposited by such dog by the following methods: 
1.  Collection of the feces by appropriate implement and placement in a paper or plastic bag or other container; and 
2.  Removal of such bag or container to the property of the dog owner or caretaker and disposition thereafter in a manner as otherwise may be permitted by law. 
b.  Animal excrement shall not be placed in storm sewers or street gutters, but shall be disposed of in a sanitary manner as provided in subparagraph a. above. 
c.  A sightless person who has the charge or control of a guide dog, a police dog in the performance of law enforcement duties or a service animal shall be exempt from the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 4, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-4-2. - General cleanliness of premises where animals are kept; spraying of enclosures. 
(a)  No person who is the owner, tenant or person in possession and control of any stable, corral, lot, pasture, stall, shed, apartment, yard or premises in the city in which any animal, including but not limited to horses, cows, livestock, domestic fowl, dogs, cats and all other animals, is kept or maintained shall allow the accumulation of manure, water, moisture, animal droppings or liquid discharges of such animal which create a stench or emit offensive odors or which are otherwise injurious to the public health and safety. However, nothing in this section shall be construed to include temporary manure deposits upon any private property for the purpose of fertilizing or composting. 
(b)  Stalls or stables, corrals, lots or pastures shall be kept sprayed with disinfectant to kill germs and to prevent the premises from becoming a breeding place for flies, mosquitoes or other insects. 
(c)  The park ranger-animal control supervisor and all park ranger-animal control officers are authorized to go into or upon and inspect the premises of kennels and pet stores, during regular business hours, to determine compliance with this section. Failure to comply is a petty misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 4, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-4-3. - Animal neglect. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fail, refuse or neglect to provide any animal in his charge or custody, as owner or otherwise, with proper food and drink, adequate shade and shelter and necessary medical care. 
(b)  If temperatures and conditions exist which cause unnecessary suffering by the animal, at the discretion of the park-ranger animal control supervisor or park-ranger animal control officers, a violation of this section may result in the immediate impoundment of the animal pursuant to sections 6-1-3 and 6-2-3 of the Farmington City Code. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 4, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-4-4. - Malicious treatment. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if, either through the person's actions or omissions, the person: 
(1)  Docks the tail or removes the dew claws of an animal, or crops the ears of an animal of any age, unless the individual is licensed to practice veterinary medicine in the state of New Mexico; 
(2)  Transfers ownership or otherwise physically removes from its mother any dog, cat, ferret or rabbit less than eight weeks old, or any other animal that is not yet weaned, except as advised by a licensed veterinarian; 
(3)  Abandons any animal that the person has possession of at any business, on public property or with any other person that has not agreed to be responsible for the care of the pet; 
(4)  Fails to reclaim any animal that the person owns from the person who had temporary possession of the animal; 
(5)  Places or allows an animal to be placed or confined, in a motor vehicle or trailer under conditions which may endanger the health of the animal due to temperature, lack of food or water or under other circumstances which may cause bodily injury, serious bodily injury or death of the animal; 
(6)  Causes, allows or permits any animal to remain in its own filth; 
(7)  Owns any animal having an infestation of ticks, fleas or other parasites which has not been treated by a veterinarian or with appropriate commercially available treatments; 
(8)  Mutilates any dead animal for reasons other than food preparation or taxidermy. Dissection in compliance with medical or veterinary research, medical or veterinary necropsy and bona fide educational use of dead animals shall not be considered mutilation; 
(9)  Attaches a collar or harness to an animal that is of an inadequate size so that it restricts the animal's growth or causes damage to the animal's skin; 
(10)  Teases or taunts any animal and provokes an aggressive reaction from an animal; 
(11)  Willfully or maliciously maims, disfigures, kicks, beats with a stick, chain, club or other object, mutilates, burns or scalds with any substance or kills any animal. Reasonable force may be used to drive off vicious or trespassing animals on private property; or 
(12)  Overrides, overworks, overloads, tortures, ill-treats, abandons willfully, inflicts inhumane injury or pain not connected with bona fide scientific medical experimentation or cruelly or unnecessarily beats, maims or kills an animal whether the animal belongs to them or another. 
(b)  The use of traps other than live traps are prohibited with the exception of an individual issued a trapper's license by the New Mexico Department of Game and Fish. 
(c)  Animals seized pursuant to this section may be impounded and the animal control officer and/or police officer may petition the municipal court for a hearing to determine whether the animal was inhumanely treated and to determine the disposition of the animal. The petition shall be filed within 48 hours of the seizure. If the court is not open during this 48-hour period, the petition shall be filed the next day the court is open for business. If a hearing is not requested, then the animal shall be returned to the owner upon request of the owner. 
(d)  This section shall not be interpreted to restrict the legal activities and legitimate operations of Rodeos, 4H Clubs or FFA Clubs. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 4, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-4-5. - Detaining animals at large. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to hold, for resale purposes, any animal running at large that such person has detained, believing such animal to be lost. 
(b)  Any person detaining an animal running at large that such person believes to be lost shall either surrender such animal to park ranger-animal control personnel or else shall contact the animal control office, giving a description of the animal, where the animal is being detained and when contact may be made concerning inquiries on the animal. 
(c)  Park ranger-animal control officers shall remove and impound animals running at large when such animals have been trapped in traps or devices approved by the park ranger-animal control supervisor. Park ranger-animal control officers may but are not required to remove animals in nonapproved traps. 
(d)  For purposes of this chapter, an animal is at large if it is free of physical restraint and control anywhere within the city, except as provided in subsections (e), (f) and (g) of this section. An animal is not at large if it is confined to the owner or caretaker's property within a secure fenced area, building or enclosure, or is securely restrained and confined to the owner or caretaker's property by means of a chain, cord, harness, leash, rope or other similar restraining device. 
(e)  A dog is not at large if it is in the immediate presence and close proximity of the owner or caretaker, remains at all times on the owner or caretaker's property and is under the direct control of the owner or caretaker. 
(f)  A dog will not be considered to be at large if it is being used by law enforcement personnel for law enforcement purposes. 
(g)  A dog will not be considered to be at large if it is participating in a city designated off-leash event or is in a city designated off-leash area. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 4, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-4-6. - Sale or gift of an animal. 
(a)  Public property. No person shall display, sell, deliver, offer for sale, barter, auction, give away or otherwise dispose of an animal upon a street, sidewalk, public park, public right-of-way or other public property. Adoption events held by a rescue group, rescue individual or the City of Farmington are exempt. 
(b)  Commercial property. No person shall display, sell, deliver, offer for sale, barter, auction, give away or otherwise dispose of any animal upon commercial property including parking lots, with or without the property owner's permission. Licensed pet stores shall be exempt from this provision. 
(c)  Sales incentives. No person shall offer an animal as an incentive to purchase merchandise or as a premium, prize, award or novelty in a raffle or otherwise. 
(d)  Advertising. No person shall advertise any animal for sale in the City of Farmington in a public right-of-way or on public property. 
(e)  Penalty. The penalty for violating this section shall be a mandatory fine of $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 4, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-4-7. - Hit and run prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use a motor vehicle to strike or collide with, knowingly or with criminal negligence, a domestic animal and then to leave the scene. Any person driving a motor vehicle which strikes and collides with a domestic animal shall stop at the scene, if safe to do so, and shall immediately report the incident to the police department. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 4, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-4-8. - Display or sale of premature and unweaned animals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to display, sell, barter or give away premature animals. A premature animal is an animal that is less than eight weeks old. The selling or giving away of a premature animal who is a rescued animal or whose mother has been killed shall not be considered a violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 4, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-4-9. - Poisoning of animals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person by any means to make accessible to any animal, with the intent to cause harm or death, any substance which has in any manner been treated or prepared with any harmful or poisonous substances. It is not the intent of this section to prohibit the use of poisonous substances for the control of rodents or vermin constituting a danger to the public health or a nuisance to the owners and/or occupants of private property. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 4, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-4-10. - False and stolen documents. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to transfer any license or rabies tag from one animal to another or to make use of a stolen, counterfeit or forged license, certificate or tag, bill of sale or pedigree. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 4, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-4-11. - Chaining or tethering of animals. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if the person chains or tethers an animal to a stationary object for any length of time except as allowed by subsection (b). 
(b)  Restraint of an animal on the owner's property or for a lawful animal event, veterinary treatment, grooming, training, law enforcement activity or when needed to protect the safety or welfare of a person or animal shall be allowed provided that all of the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The chain or tether is attached to a properly fitting collar or harness and is not wrapped around the animal's neck. Choke or prong-type collars shall not be used; 
(2)  Chain collars shall not be used; 
(3)  The chain or tether is designed and placed in a manner to prevent entanglement or injury; and 
(4)  The chain or tether does not allow the animal to move outside the person's property or come within ten feet of public property if chained or tethered outside a fenced area. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 4, 12-9-14) 
ARTICLE 5. - DANGEROUS ANIMALS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 5, adopted Dec. 9, 2014, repealed art. 5 in its entirety, and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former art. 5 pertained to pigeon control, and derived from Ord. No. 2012-1255, adopted March 13, 2012. 

Sec. 6-5-1. - Vicious dogs. 
(a)  The owner or caretaker of every vicious dog shall: 
(1)  Confine such dog within a building, secure fenced yard or secure enclosure; and 
(2)  Not allow the dog to exit such confinement unless the dog is: 
a.  Securely muzzled; 
b.  Harnessed; and 
c.  Restrained with a leash with a maximum length of six feet. 
(b)  If the animal is determined to be dangerous by the court, the court shall order that the owner comply with one of the following conditions: 
(1)  Euthanasia of the dangerous animal: 
a.  Shall be ordered if the court determines the animal caused the death or serious bodily injury of a person; 
b.  May be ordered if the court determines the animal caused bodily injury to a person; 
c.  May be ordered if the court determines the animal was outside its enclosure or yard and caused death to another animal; 
d.  May be ordered if the court determines the animal was outside its enclosure or yard and caused serious bodily injury to another animal and has made at least one unprovoked attack against an animal or person on a previous occasion; 
e.  Can be elected by the owner of the animal; 
f.  Euthanasia is not allowed if the attack, bite or mauling occurred while the dog was being used by a peace officer for law enforcement purposes. 
(2)  If an animal is declared dangerous by the court, the dog shall be spayed or neutered. 
(c)  An incident where a dog attacks, maims or kills a domestic animal must be reported to a park ranger-animal control officer within 24 hours. 
(d)  No domestic animal may be declared a dangerous animal if: 
(1)  The threat, injury or damage was sustained by a person who at the time was committing a willful trespass or other tort upon the premises occupied by the owner of the animal; 
(2)  The person attacked was teasing, tormenting, abusing or assaulting the animal or has in the past been observed to have teased, tormented, abused or assaulted the animal; 
(3)  The person attacked was committing or attempting to commit a crime; 
(4)  The animal attacked was at large at the time of the incident, unless the attacking animal was also at large at the time of the incident and: 
a.  The attacking animal has committed an unprovoked attack on another person or animal on at least one previous occasion; or 
b.  The animal attacked suffered serious bodily injury or died as a result of the injuries it sustained during the attack; 
(5)  The animal attacked or killed at the time of the incident was teasing, tormenting, abusing or attacking the alleged dangerous animal or if the animal attacked was not a domestic animal; 
(6)  The animal was protecting or defending a person within the immediate vicinity of the animal from an unjustified attack or assault; 
(7)  The animal was injured and responding to pain; or 
(8)  The complaint filed against it is solely based on the animal's breed, size or physical appearance. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 5, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-5-2. - Guard dogs. 
(a)  Nothing contained in this article shall prevent a person from owning or harboring a guard dog which has been trained to protect persons or property. The owner or user of such guard dog shall prominently post at least two written warnings of the presence of such guard dog. 
(b)  Safety requirements for use of a guard dog. 
(1)  A person that keeps a guard dog must comply with the safety requirements prescribed by this section. 
(2)  A guard dog must be kept in housing completely surrounded by an anti-escape fence or in an anti-escape building. 
(3)  The gate or entrance to an area where a guard dog is housed, used or trained must be locked unless a person is in direct control of the guard dog. 
(4)  The area outside a building patrolled by a guard dog must be enclosed with anti-escape devices, and either have: 
a.  A fence not less than six feet tall constructed out of secure fencing material; or 
b.  A wall at least six feet tall. 
(5)  Exterior glass must be installed in a building patrolled by a guard dog that is strong enough to prevent the guard dog from breaking through the glass and any additional protective measures required to protect the general health, safety and welfare of the public. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 5, 12-9-14) 
ARTICLE 6. - PIGEON CONTROL 

Sec. 6-6-1. - Feeding of feral pigeons a violation. 
(a)  It is a violation of this article for any person to intentionally feed feral pigeons on any public or private property within the Farmington city limits. 
(b)  It is a violation of this article for any person to permit or allow the placement or discard of food, food by-products, vegetable, garbage or animal food of any kind in a manner that such person knows will reasonably result in the lingering, roosting and/or congregating of feral pigeons. 
(c)  This prohibition does not extend to domesticated pigeons used for show or for racing or to injured pigeons that are kept at all times in cages or are prevented from creating pigeon nuisance conditions on nearby properties. 
(d)  This prohibition does not extend to bird seed set out in bird feeders or otherwise provided to birds other than pigeons, provided that the seed does not attract significant numbers of pigeons or create conditions that constitute a pigeon nuisance. 
(e)  Each act in violation of this article shall constitute a public nuisance and a separate violation. Any person who violates this article shall be subject to: 
(1)  The first violation of this section shall result in a written warning. This warning will provide the details of the violation and will specify corrective action. 
(2)  The second violation and subsequent violations of this section shall result in a fine not to exceed $50.00 for each violation or each day of a continuing violation. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 6, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-6-2. - Procedure for abatement of pigeon nuisance. 
(a)  There shall be an investigation of any complaint made to the supervisor to determine if there is a pigeon nuisance. 
(b)  The supervisor shall determine if a pigeon nuisance exists. 
(c)  The supervisor shall attempt to meet with the property owner and any person on the property who appears to be a responsible party to notify them that a pigeon nuisance has been determined to exist. The goal of the meeting shall be to enter into a written abatement agreement with the City of Farmington wherein the responsible party agrees to take specific steps to pigeon-proof the property. 
(d)  An abatement agreement may provide for the use of any pigeon-proofing method agreed upon by the supervisor and the responsible party. If pigeon-proofing involves the removal of accumulations of pigeon excrement, nesting materials, pigeon carcasses or other pigeon related debris, the method selected for such removal shall protect human health and ensure that ground water, surface water and real property are not contaminated by the waste. 
(e)  If the supervisor determines that the responsible party is in violation of section 6-6-1 of this article, and is unwilling to comply with this article, or if the responsible party fails to act on or complete the terms and conditions agreed to in an abatement agreement by the time set forth in the agreement, the supervisor may proceed to issue a citation for violation of this section for failure to abate the pigeon nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 6, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-6-3. - Inspection of buildings, premises and vacant lots. 
    The supervisor is authorized, by obtaining consent of the owner or occupant, and at reasonable times, to make such inspections of real property as is necessary to investigate and abate a pigeon nuisance. For the purpose of making such inspections, the supervisor is authorized to enter onto premises to examine or survey property only after reasonable notice to the owner and any person occupying the property. Such entry shall be made in a manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the person in control. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 6, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-6-4. - Additional remedies. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to preclude the city from seeking any other remedy available in law or equity. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 6, 12-9-14) 
ARTICLE 7. - RABIES CONTROL 

Sec. 6-7-1. - Disposition of animal bitten by rabid animal. 
    Unvaccinated dogs, cats or other animals bitten by a known rabid animal should be destroyed immediately. If the owner is unwilling to have this done, the unvaccinated animal shall be vaccinated immediately with an approved rabies vaccine and placed in strict confinement and isolation at the owner's expense, in a manner directed by the park ranger-animal control supervisor or the park ranger-animal control officer and in accordance with regulations of the state health and environment department for a six-month period. It shall be revaccinated with an approved rabies vaccine one month before being released. If the animal has been previously vaccinated with an approved rabies vaccine and is within the recognized period of immunity for the vaccine, it shall be revaccinated immediately and confined and isolated at the owner's expense for at least 60 days in a manner directed by the park ranger-animal control supervisor or park ranger-animal control officer and approved by the district health officer. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 7, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-7-2. - Notice of affected animal or of animal bitten by rabid animal. 
    Whenever a dog, cat or other animal is affected by rabies or is suspected of being affected by rabies or has been bitten by an animal known or suspected to be affected by rabies, the owner of the animal or any person having knowledge thereof shall forthwith notify the park ranger-animal control supervisor or district health director or other person designated by regulations of the state health and environment department, giving a description of the animal and stating precisely where the animal may be found. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 7, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-7-3. - Confinement of dog or cat after biting person. 
    The city shall serve notice upon the owner of a dog or cat that has bitten a person so as to cause penetration of the skin to confine the dog or cat at the owner's home or, upon orders of the park ranger-animal control supervisor, at the city animal shelter, a veterinary hospital, or at some other place designated in the order for at least ten days after the animal has bitten a person. The costs of such confinement, regardless of location, shall be borne by the owner under all circumstances, and no animal shall be released from confinement until such costs are paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 7, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-7-4. - Examination of dog or cat after biting person. 
(a)  The park ranger-animal control supervisor or other duly authorized agent of the city shall be permitted, by the owner of a dog or cat that has bitten a person, to examine the dog or cat at any time during the ten-day confinement period to determine whether the animal shows signs of rabies. 
(b)  No person shall refuse, obstruct or interfere with the park ranger-animal control supervisor or his duly authorized agent in making the examination. 
(c)  Any dog or cat that has bitten a person shall be examined by the park ranger-animal control supervisor or their duly authorized agent at least twice, once at the beginning and once at the end of the ten-day observation. At the end of the mandatory ten-day observation period, the owner shall have the animal examined by a licensed veterinarian, who will issue written documentation that the animal does not have signs of rabies. The owner of the animal shall provide the written documentation to the Farmington Regional Animal Shelter within two business days of receiving the document. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 7, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-7-5. - Euthanasia of suspected rabid animal; submission of animal specimen to laboratory. 
    During the ten-day confinement period as provided in this article, the owner may elect to have the animal euthanized. If the animal is euthanized or dies while confined, the animal welfare director or designee shall immediately send a specimen from the animal, under suitable refrigeration, to the scientific laboratory division of the state health and environment department in Albuquerque for pathological examination and shall notify the district health office of the diagnosis made of the suspected animal. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 7, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-7-6. - Certificate of release after confinement. 
    As provided in this article, an animal confined for observation under order of the city shall not be released until a certificate of release has been issued by a licensed veterinarian or by the order of the court. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 7, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-7-7. - Quarantine. 
    When a rabies quarantine order has been issued by the district health officer or park ranger-animal control supervisor or designee and an animal continues to run at large, uncontrolled by the owner or person responsible for its control, any law enforcement officer shall have the right, after reasonable effort has been made on the part of the park ranger-animal control supervisor or his agents to apprehend and impound a dog running at large, to euthanize such animal and properly dispose of its body. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 7, 12-9-14) 
ARTICLE 8. - ANIMAL SERVICES ADVISORY COMMISSION 

Sec. 6-8-1. - Created. 
    The animal services advisory commission of the City of Farmington is hereby created. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 8, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-8-2. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the animal services advisory commission shall be to advise the mayor, city council, director of parks, recreation and cultural affairs (PRCA) and animal welfare director upon all phases of the operation and maintenance of City of Farmington animal services, including the animal shelter and animal control. The commission may also recommend to and advise the parks, recreation and cultural affairs commission on animal matters and the budgeting and expenditure of operational and capital funds for the animal shelter and animal control services. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 8, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-8-3. - Duties. 
    The animal services advisory commission is an advisory commission only whose recommendations shall not be binding upon the city. The commission shall review and recommend procedures and protocol related to animal welfare, animal cruelty and neglect, education and outreach regarding animal issues, adoptions and establishing foster care homes for animals, animal population control policies including spay and neuter, and shall coordinate and develop partnerships between the city and other animal organizations. The commission shall keep itself educated and informed on animal issues, including recent studies and developments concerning animal control, care and treatment, and adoption. It shall also be the duty of the commission to help the city maintain good communication with the public on animal issues, to educate the public, and to receive comments from the public, particularly comments on city provided animal shelter or animal control services. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 8, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-8-4. - Membership. 
    The animal services advisory commission shall consist of seven members, all of whom shall serve staggered three-year terms. Appointments to the commission will be made by the mayor, with confirmation by the council. One member shall represent the San Juan Animal League, one member shall represent the humane society of the four corners and one member shall be a veterinary professional. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 8, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-8-5. - Officers. 
    The animal services advisory commission shall annually elect a chairperson and a chairperson pro tem from among its membership. The chairperson or chairperson pro tem shall vote unless disqualified due to conflict of interest. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 8, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-8-6. - Meetings. 
    The animal services advisory commission shall meet regularly, as determined by the commission, but at least quarterly, shall keep meeting minutes and operate in accordance with the Open Meetings Act. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 8, 12-9-14; Ord. No. 2016-1288 , § 1, 5-24-16) 
Sec. 6-8-7. - Quorum. 
    The animal services advisory commission may conduct an official meeting with four members present. A majority vote of such quorum shall suffice for the transaction of business. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 8, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-8-8. - Compensation. 
    The members of the animal services advisory commission shall be paid no salary for their service as members of the commission, however, members shall be entitled to per diem and mileage for authorized travel as allowed to other city boards and commissions. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 8, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-8-9. - Removal. 
    Members serve at the pleasure of the mayor and may be removed at any time by the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 8, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 6-8-10. - Vacancies. 
    Vacancies occurring in membership of the commission shall be filled by appointment of the mayor and confirmed by the city council for the remainder of the unexpired term of such member. 
(Ord. No. 2014-1273, § 8, 12-9-14) 
Chapter 7 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Powers relative to public buildings, NMSA 1978, § 3-18-4; building construction and restrictions, NMSA 1978, § 3-18-96. 

ARTICLE 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-1-1. - Recreation space or fees. 
(a)  When a person proposes to build or locate any residential building, including mobile housing units as defined in the Unified Development Code, upon any lot in the city, such person shall dedicate land to the city for park and recreational purposes, shall pay to the city a fee in lieu thereof, or shall provide a combination of such dedication and payment for the total number of units proposed. The computation of land or fees to be dedicated, the standards by which the alternative of land or fees is to be chosen, and the disposition of such dedicated land or fees shall be governed by the provisions of the Unified Development Code to this Code. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Subdivisions or lots therein which were approved after March 8, 1977, where there has been no change in zoning to permit an increase in the density from that existing at the time of approval of the plat; provided, however, any development under NMSA 1978, § 47-7-14.A, Building Unit Ownership Act, shall not be considered to be a subdivision after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives. 
(2)  Any residential building or mobile housing unit replacing a similar existing structure which has been torn down or removed, provided there is no increase in the number of residential units on the lot developed. 
(c)  Where the applicant proposes to build at a density greater than that authorized at the time of approval of a subdivision after March 8, 1977, the amount to be paid under this section shall be the difference between the fee calculated at the currently authorized density and the fee attributable to such lot at the originally platted density. 
(d)  Land or fees in lieu thereof dedicated pursuant to the terms of this section shall be dedicated or paid or an agreement and bond shall be provided pursuant to the Unified Development Code to this Code at the time an application is made for a building permit pursuant to section 7-2-1 or a parking permit pursuant to section 17-1-8. 
(Code 1969, § 8-9; Ord. No. 2007-1184, 9-8-10) 
Sec. 7-1-2. - Sidewalks and ramps for handicapped. 
(a)  The owner of any property upon which a building is constructed shall, before issuance of a certificate of occupancy, install sidewalks under the following circumstances: 
(1)  Along the street adjacent to any residential building, where sidewalks on any adjacent lot abut the lot upon which such building is located. 
(2)  In any commercial district. 
(3)  In any manufacturing district, adjacent to any major street shown on the city major thoroughfare plan. 
(b)  All such sidewalks shall be constructed pursuant to the requirements of Chapter 24 and shall have ramps for handicapped persons at each intersection. 
(Code 1969, § 8-10) 
ARTICLE 2. - BUILDING CODE 

Sec. 7-2-1. - Adopted; amendments. 
    There is adopted by reference the same code or other minimum standards for building that is or may be adopted by the General Construction Bureau of the Construction Industries Division of the New Mexico Regulations and Licensing Department, referred to as the New Mexico Administrative Code, Title 14, Chapters 5-10, subject to the exceptions set forth below: 
(a)  Section 14.5.2.9 of the New Mexico Administrative Code is amended by deleting paragraphs 1, 2, 4, 5 and 6 from subsection A, and by revising subsection B to read as follows: Residential: Adoption only of paragraphs 6, 7, 8, and 9 of the building portion of R105.2 and adding paragraph 10 that reads: Any work that is not otherwise regulated by a specific provision of the NMRBC. Section 14.5.2.9 is further amended to exempt the following from the requirements of a building permit: 
(1)  Minor repairs less than $500.00 in value; 
(2)  Installation of work which is done after regular business hours or during a holiday or when immediate action is imperative to safeguard life, health or property, provided the person making installation or performing the work applies for a permit covering the installation of work not later than the next business day after the beginning of such work. 
(b)  Section 14.5.2.14 A. of the New Mexico Administrative Code is amended by adding the following paragraphs to Section A.: 
Irrespective of any extensions necessitated by inactivity which have been granted, any building permit issued shall be valid only for a period of two years from the date the permit is issued. Said expiration date shall be clearly noted on the building permit. After expiration of the two-year period, the permittee shall apply for a new permit and shall pay a new permit fee. The building official may renew the permit, but no more than once, and then only if shown by the permittee that circumstances beyond his control have prevented his finishing the project within two years. If the project is not completed after four years, any further extension may be granted at the discretion of the community development director. 
A copy of the building permit shall be posted by the permittee at a conspicuous place on or near the construction site at all times from the time work commences until completion of the same. 
(c)  Section 14.5.5.11 of the New Mexico Administrative Code referring to fees is amended to refer to such schedule of building permit fees and plan review fees as are prepared by the director of community development and recommended to the city council. Such fee schedules, when adopted and approved by resolution of the city council, shall be filed in the office of the city clerk and shall govern the amount to be charged for building permit fees and plan checking fees. 
(d)  Section 14.5.2.16 of the New Mexico Administrative Code is amended to read as follows: 
Investigation fee. An investigation fee, in addition to the permit fee, shall be collected whether or not a permit is then or subsequently issued. The combined permit fee and the investigation fee required shall be five percent of the permit valuation of the structure for which no permit was secured. The payment of such fee shall not except any person from compliance with all other provisions of this code nor from any penalty prescribed by law. 
(e)  Section 14.5.3.9 F., Additional Inspections, of the New Mexico Administrative Code is amended by adding the following to the end of paragraph F: 
All construction work for which a permit is required shall be subject to inspection. Routine specific inspections for the permitted project shall be determined by the City of Farmington Building Inspection Division at the time of the issuance of the permit and shall always include a final inspection. The building inspection division may make or require any inspection, including continuous inspections, to ascertain that the work complies with the provisions of this code. 
(Code 1969, § 8-1; Ord. No. 98-1084, § 1, 10-27-98; Ord. No. 05-1162, §§ 1-6, 1-25-05; Ord. No. 2008-1203, § 1, 4-22-08) 
Sec. 7-2-2. - National Electrical Safety Code adopted. 
(a)  There is adopted by reference the National Electrical Safety Code, 1990 edition or the most recent edition thereof if such code shall be amended or revised, as promulgated and published by the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc. 
(b)  Notwithstanding provisions of the National Electrical Safety Code (NESC) to the contrary, the National Electrical Safety Code shall be effective as of October 1, 1990; shall apply to the installation, operation, or maintenance of electric supply and communication lines and their associated equipment; and shall apply to all new installations and extensions. No new building, line, equipment or structure shall be installed, erected, built, constructed or operated which is contrary to or in violation of the provisions of the National Electrical Safety Code. 
(c)  The National Electrical Safety Code shall apply to and upon all property, public and private, located within the city and shall apply to all buildings, lines, equipment, structures, property and easements held, owned or operated by the city, wherever located. 
(d)  A property owner or other person who wishes to construct, install or erect buildings, structures or equipment near or adjacent to existing electric lines, facilities or equipment shall provide the required separations or clearances or shall bear the expense of complying with the requirements of the National Electrical Safety Code (NESC). 
(Code 1969, § 8-1.1) 
Sec. 7-2-3. - Copies of codes and fee schedules on file. 
    Copies of the codes and fee schedules adopted pursuant to this article shall be kept on file at all times in the office of the city clerk and in the building inspection division and shall be available during business hours for inspection by members of the public. 
(Code 1969, § 8-2) 
Sec. 7-2-4. - Penalty for noncompliance. 
(a)  Any person failing to comply with the provisions of the codes as set forth in this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-1-10. 
(b)  Any person convicted of continuing to work at a construction site in violation of a notice to stop work that was properly issued and posted at the work site shall be subject to the following penalties: 
(1)  First offense-Mandatory minimum penalty of $100.00 fine; 
(2)  Second offense-Mandatory minimum penalty of $300.00 fine; 
(3)  Third offense-Mandatory minimum penalty of $500.00 fine. 
(Code 1969, § 8-4; Ord. No. 2010-1224, § 1, 2-23-10) 
Sec. 7-2-5. - Appeals. 
    Appeals under this article shall be made to the director of the construction industries division of the New Mexico Department of Regulation and Licensing pursuant to Section 14.5.1.13C of the New Mexico Administrative Code effective January 1, 2008, except that any appeal arising from an interpretation or application of a provision in this chapter which is different than the provisions of the New Mexico Administrative Code shall be heard by the administrative review board of the City of Farmington. 
(Code 1969, § 8-3; Ord. No. 98-1084, § 2, 10-27-98; Ord. No. 05-1162, § 7, 1-25-05; Ord. No. 2008-1203, § 2, 4-22-08) 
Sec. 7-2-6. - Cancellation of building permits. 
(a)  Cancellation by mutual consent. Upon presentation of a written document signed by both the owner and general contractor, any existing building permit may be canceled immediately. An application for a replacement building permit may be immediately presented by either the owner or by a different licensed general contractor. Until such replacement permit is granted, all work on the property shall cease and a stop work order shall be posted on the property by the building inspection division. 
(b)  Cancellation by one party. 
(1)  Method of cancellation: Either the owner or the general contractor may cancel an existing building permit by making a written request to the building inspection division. The requesting party shall certify, in writing, that the other party has received written notice of the termination of the contract between the parties and of the intention to cancel the building permit. The requesting party shall also certify, in writing, that the holders of all other permits applicable to the project have been notified of the termination. Upon receipt of a proper request for cancellation of a building permit, the building inspection division shall post a stop work order on the premises. Nothing herein shall prohibit the performance of such emergency work as may be needed to protect public safety or to maintain the property in its existing condition. 
(2)  Waiting period. If either party cancels an existing building permit pursuant to this section, no new building permit shall be issued for a period of seven days following the cancellation. During this seven day period, the building inspection division shall perform an inspection of all work performed to the date of cancellation to note any observable items not in conformance with applicable codes at the time of such inspection. 
(Ord. No. 02-1127, § 1, 2-26-02) 
ARTICLE 3. - ELECTRICAL CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Electric substation and gas regulator stations, § 27-27-15. 

Sec. 7-3-1. - Adoption of codes. 
(a)  The city council, except as modified by section 7-3-3, adopts by reference the conditions, provisions, limitations and terms of the electrical codes and rules adopted and by the Construction Industries Division of the New Mexico Regulations and Licensing Department, including but not necessarily limited to the State of New Mexico Electrical Code and the State of New Mexico Construction Industries Division Rules and Regulations. 
(b)  The city council, except as modified by section 7-3-3, adopts by reference the conditions, provisions, limitations and terms of the Farmington Electric Utility System Meter and Service Guide, as amended. 
(c)  The National Electrical Safety Code (NESC) is adopted as set forth in section 7-2-2. 
(Code 1969, § 11-30) 
State Law reference- Codes adopted and enforced by reference, NMSA 1978, § 3-17-6; trade bureaus, standards, conflicts, NMSA 1978, § 60-13-44. 
Sec. 7-3-2. - Availability of copies. 
    Copies of this article and the codes adopted in this article, including the Farmington Electric Utility System Meter and Service Guide, and copies of this article and Article 6 of Chapter 26 including the permit fee schedule, permit forms, rules and regulations, etc., shall be available for inspection by the public during normal business hours in the office of the electrical inspector and the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 11-50) 
Sec. 7-3-3. - Amendment. 
    The city council may from time to time, by separate resolution of the city council, modify or change the codes and rules adopted by section 7-3-1 to clarify or change administrative procedures, adopt different fee schedules, or to establish more restrictive standards which conform to the needs of the city. No such resolution shall be adopted by the city council unless the proposed resolution has been submitted to the electrical code advisory committee, established by section 7-3-5, not less than 30 days prior to the date of adoption of such resolution. The changes, standards, or procedures adopted by any such separate council resolution shall be more restrictive than the standards established and adopted by section 7-3-1 and, if a conflict occurs, the standard or provision which provides the greatest safety and protection to the public shall control. 
(Code 1969, § 11-31) 
Sec. 7-3-4. - Electrical inspector. 
(a)  The city shall employ an electrical inspector, who shall be charged with enforcement of this article. The electrical inspector shall meet qualifications established by law. 
(b)  The electrical inspector shall enforce this article, the provisions of the electrical codes and the rules and regulations and shall conduct inspections, maintain appropriate records, and perform related work as assigned. 
(Code 1969, §§ 11-40, 11-41) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-3-1 et seq. 
Sec. 7-3-5. - Electrical code advisory committee. 
(a)  The electrical code advisory committee is created, to consist of seven members. Three members shall be licensed electrical contractors, one member shall be a licensed journeyman, one member shall be a professional electrical engineer, one member shall be a licensed architect, and one other member shall be appointed at large. 
(b)  Members shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city council and shall serve staggered three-year terms at the pleasure of the mayor. 
(c)  The electrical code advisory committee shall meet at the direction of the mayor or at the direction of the chairman of the committee as often as may be necessary to conduct its business. All meetings shall be in compliance with the Open Meeting Act. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of the electrical code advisory committee to review the city electrical codes, to recommend changes or amendments to the electrical codes, and to assist the city electrical inspector and the city building inspector. 
(e)  Alternate members of the committee may be appointed by the mayor. 
(f)  The absence of a member of the committee for three consecutive meetings shall be grounds for removal of such member. 
(Code 1969, § 11-44) 
Sec. 7-3-6. - Penalties for violation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions of the codes adopted under section 7-3-1, this article or Article 6 of Chapter 26. 
(b)  Any person convicted in the municipal court of a violation of the provisions stated in subsection (a) of this section shall be punished in the manner specified in section 1-1-10. 
(Code 1969, § 11-60) 
Sec. 7-3-7. - Jurisdiction; other remedies. 
(a)  The municipal court shall have jurisdiction to enforce penalties for violation of this article, for violation of the codes and rules and regulations adopted by this article and Article 6 of Chapter 26 within the city limits and within its planning and platting jurisdiction pursuant to NMSA 1978, § 3-18-6. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this article or the provisions stated in subsection (a) of this section shall be construed to preclude the filing of an action in the state magistrate court for violation of the state electrical code or to preclude the pursuit by the city of any legal or equitable remedy in any court or forum of appropriate jurisdiction to effect the intent and purpose of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 11-61) 
Sec. 7-3-8. - Electrical permit expiration date and renewal. 
(a)  All electrical permits shall be valid for a period of one year from the date the permit is issued. The expiration date shall be clearly noted on the electrical permit. 
(b)  Not more than 60 and not less than 30 days prior to expiration of the original electrical permit, the city building inspection division will send a notice to the permittee stating that the electrical permit is due for renewal, and the request for renewal shall be filed with the building inspection division prior to its expiration. If a request for renewal is not timely filed with the city, no further inspections will be made under the original electrical permit. 
(c)  If the original permit is allowed to expire, it will be necessary to apply for a new permit and a fee of $25.00 will be charged. There shall be no charge for the renewal of an electrical permit if the renewal request is on file with the city prior to the expiration of the original permit. 
(d)  Written notice shall be sent to all permittees who were issued electrical permits prior to April 14, 1992. The notice shall state the following: 
(1)  Electrical permits that were issued before July 1, 1991, must be renewed within 30 days after the date of the notice; and 
(2)  Electrical permits issued after July 1, 1991, must be renewed within the 30-day period before the expiration of one year from the permit date. 
(e)  Permits which are not renewed as specified in this section shall be null and void. A new application and permit shall be required if a permit is not renewed as provided in this section. A permit may only be renewed one time. Thereafter a new permit will be required. A renewed electrical permit is valid for one year. 
(Code 1969, § 11-32) 
Sec. 7-3-9. - Electrical permit and inspection fees. 
    Notwithstanding section 7-3-1, the provisions of the codes adopted by section 7-3-1 which pertain to electrical permit and inspection fees shall be modified by this section. A schedule of electrical permit and inspection fees prepared and recommended by the community development director and approved by the city council has been adopted. The fee schedule is filed in the city clerk's office and governs the amount to be charged for electrical permit and inspection fees. 
(Ord. No. 05-1162, § 8, 1-25-05) 
ARTICLE 4. - PLUMBING AND MECHANICAL CODES 

Sec. 7-4-1. - Adopted. 
    There are adopted by the city for the purpose of establishing minimum standards, rules and regulations for the installation and maintenance of fixtures, plumbing, consumers' gas pipe, appliances, and other materials installed in the course of the mechanical installation the same minimum codes or standards which are adopted by the Mechanical Trade Board of the Construction Industries Commission of the state, under the Construction Industries Licensing Act, save and except such portions as may be deleted, modified or amended in this article, to provide higher standards for the city, of which not less than three copies shall at all times be upon file in the office of the city plumbing inspector. Such standards are adopted and incorporated by reference as fully as though set forth verbatim in this section. 
(Code 1969, § 27-1) 
Sec. 7-4-2. - Plumbing/mechanical inspector. 
    The city shall employ a plumbing/mechanical inspector, who shall be charged with the enforcement of the provisions of the codes adopted in this article. The plumbing/mechanical inspector shall meet those qualifications set out by statutory law and shall have full power and duty as provided by the codes adopted in this article and shall further enforce the plumbing administrative law as required by statute. 
(Code 1969, § 27-2) 
Sec. 7-4-3. - Permit and inspection fees. 
    Notwithstanding section 7-4-1, the provisions of the codes adopted by section 7-4-1 which pertain to permit and inspection fees shall be modified by this section. In lieu thereof, there are adopted the schedule of mechanical and plumbing permit and inspection fees prepared and recommended by the director of community development and approved by the city council. Such fee schedule, when adopted and approved by resolution of the city council, shall be filed in the city clerk's office and shall govern the amount to be charged for mechanical and plumbing permit and inspection fees. 
(Code 1969, § 27-1.1) 
Sec. 7-4-4. - Proper plumbing and connection required. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section, the term "place of human habitation" shall mean any place where there is a reasonable requirement for disposal of sewage, human excrement or other liquid waste and includes buildings, structures, tents, vehicles, mobile homes, campers and other like places used as an abode, dwelling or residence, either for living purposes or as a place of employment for humans, when there is a reasonable requirement for disposal of sewage, human excrement or other liquid waste. This definition shall not preclude the emergency use of places for human habitation in an emergency, nor shall it preclude temporary recreational camping where otherwise permitted in public parks or grounds under special permits or in private yards for periods of not to exceed five days. Places of human employment need not be considered under this definition if adequate toilet and sanitation facilities are available for use of employees in reasonably close proximity to the place of employment. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use a place of human habitation within the city or to allow a place of human habitation to be used as living quarters or to rent a place of human habitation for living quarters, which has not been connected with proper plumbing or with a private sewer system as required by the plumbing code adopted in this article. 
(c)  All places of human habitation not equipped with proper plumbing or not connected to sewer lines or septic tanks as required in this article are declared to be nuisances, and all equitable remedies for the abatement of such nuisances may be used. The penalties provided in section 1-1-10 shall not affect the right of the city to such equitable remedies. 
(Code 1969, §§ 27-3, 27-4) 
Chapter 8 - BUSINESSES AND SALES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Business operations at airport, § 3-2-1 et seq.; alcoholic beverages, ch. 5; cable communications, ch. 9; noise from street sales, § 12-5-16; offenses against property, § 18-3-1 et seq.; shoplifting, § 18-3-7; oil and gas wells, ch. 19; soliciting and canvassing at Lake Farmington, § 20-3-10; economic development, § 22-2-1 et seq.; handbill distribution, § 23-1-6; solid waste receptacles required for certain businesses, § 23-1-10; sale and installation of automobile sunscreening material, § 25-3-48; sale of motor vehicles, § 25-7-1 et seq.; utilities, ch. 26. 
State Law reference- Authority to license or regulate businesses, NMSA 1978, § 3-38-1; authority to regulate sales of merchandise, NMSA 1978, § 3-18-12. 

ARTICLE 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adult oriented business shall have that meaning ascribed to it in the Unified Development Code. 
    Amusement hall means any arcade, building or premises having as its primary business the providing of mechanical or electronic amusement devices, including but not limited to the following: pinball machines, electronic or video games of skill or chance, claw or scoop machines, jukeboxes or coin-operated table games. Pool rooms and billiard parlors not having more than three mechanical or electronic amusement devices shall not be defined as an amusement hall for the purposes of this chapter. 
    Business means any profession, trade or occupation and all and every kind of calling whether or not carried on for profit, except those organizations exempt from the federal income tax pursuant to section 501(c)(3) of the United States Internal Revenue Code as amended or renumbered; provided, however, the term "business" shall include the phrase "unrelated trade or business" of such organizations as the latter term is defined in section 513 of the United States Internal Revenue Code of 1954, as amended or renumbered. 
    Canvasser, solicitor or peddler means as defined in Article 8 of this chapter, provided the terms shall not include the activities of persons who sell solely to other businesses, either of goods or services used in the trade of such other businesses or of goods for the purpose of resale of such other businesses. 
    Conduct; carry on means engage in, carry on, own, maintain, manage or operate any business, trade, art, profession, calling, employment, occupation or any commercial, industrial or professional pursuit, vocation or enterprise in this city. 
    Extended hours of operation means the period of time from 2:00 a.m. until 5:00 a.m. 
    Garage sale means a sale involving the offering for sale of multiple items of personal property on property occupied as a residence. 
    Kiddie ride carnival and exhibits means any carnival and exhibits consisting exclusively of rides and exhibits for children with no amusement devices other than such rides and with no games of chance or skill and not operating past the hour of 10:00 p.m. 
    Outdoor sales event means a temporary sales event by an individual business or group of businesses held outdoors and adjacent to the building from which the sales are normally conducted, subject to a site plan being approved by the community development department and the fire department inspecting all enclosed tents. The term includes but is not limited to tent sales, parking lot sales, sidewalk sales or outdoor clearance sales." 
    Place of business means any location, building or portion thereof or premises in which or from which a business is carried on. The term includes but is not limited to an office, warehouse, yard, location where books and records are kept, the location from which business is solicited. 
    Rummage sale means the sale of used goods and hand-crafted goods donated to or by a church, school, or fraternal organization or preschool exempt from taxation as nonprofit, conducted on the premises of the entity involved. 
    Special event means an event for business or community promotion sponsored by one or more businesses or organizations for a period not to exceed one week, where the promotor provides adequate parking, private patrol officers or police protection, if required, a list of participating vendors to the city clerk and subject to a site plan being approved by the community development department and the fire department inspecting all enclosed tents. The term does not include outdoor sales events as defined in this section. 
    Street vending means the display or sale of goods or merchandise not in or from an enclosed permanent building to be conducted for a period of five days or less. Written permission from the property owner and a site plan approved by the community development department must be provided before a business registration or license is issued. If an enclosed tent is erected, the fire department may require inspection prior to any sales being conducted. 
(Code 1969, § 17-1-1; Ord. No. 99-1105, § 2, 10-26-99; Ord. No. 2007-1184, 9-8-10; Ord. No. 2017-1296, § 1, 4-11-17 ) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-1-2. 
ARTICLE 2. - REGISTRATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authorization for business registration, NMSA 1978, § 3-38-3. 

Sec. 8-2-1. - Required; unlawful conduct; penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in, conduct or carry on any business or occupation within the city without first registering the business or occupation or obtaining a license therefor and without first paying the fees, in compliance with this chapter. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly file an application for issuance or renewal of any business registration or business license on which any of the information required by section 8-2-2 has been falsified. 
(c)  Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-1-10. 
(d)  The remedies provided in this section are not exclusive, and if any person engages in business in the city without obtaining the required registration or license for such business, the city may proceed in any manner authorized by law, including specifically but not limited to the procedures set forth in NMSA 1978, §§ 3-38-5 and 3-38-6. 
(Code 1969, § 17-1-12) 
Sec. 8-2-2. - Application. 
    Any person filing an application for issuance or renewal of any business registration or business license shall include in the application the following information: 
(1)  The exact nature or kind of business for which a license is requested. 
(2)  The form of business enterprise under which the business is to be conducted, i.e., sole proprietorship, partnership, limited partnership or corporation. 
(3)  The place where such business is to be carried on and, if the business is not to be carried on at any permanent place of business, the places of residence of the owners of the business. 
(4)  The name, other than the name of the applicant, under which the business will be operating, if any. 
(5)  The time of operation during the full 24-hour period. 
(6)  The names and places of residence of all owners of the business; if the owner is a corporation or partnership, the application shall state the names and places of residence of the officers or general partners thereof. 
(7)  The applicant's current revenue division taxpayer identification number. 
(8)  Such further information as the clerk may deem necessary to enable issuance of the certificate, including all required state or federal licensing. 
(Code 1969, § 17-1-8; Ord. No. 2017-1296, § 2, 4-11-17 ) 
Sec. 8-2-3. - Application to do business. 
    Any person proposing to engage in business within the city limits shall apply for and pay a business registration fee for each outlet, branch or location or place of business within the city prior to engaging in business, unless such person is required to obtain a business license under Article 3 of this chapter. 
(Code 1969, § 17-1-4) 
Sec. 8-2-4. - Imposition of business registration fee. 
    There is imposed on all business being conducted in the city a business registration fee of $35.00, pursuant to NMSA 1978, § 3-38-3. 
(Code 1969, § 17-1-2; Ord. No. 03-1152, § 1, 10-28-03; Ord. No. 2017-1296, § 3, 4-11-17 ) 
Sec. 8-2-5. - Exemption; two or more businesses. 
(a)  No business registration fee shall be imposed on any business which is licensed under Article 3 of this chapter pursuant to NMSA 1978, § 3-38-1. 
(b)  Any person who operates under the same name two or more businesses, one or more of which requires a business license under Article 3 of this chapter and one or more of which does not require a business license, shall obtain a separate registration or license and shall pay a separate fee for each such business. 
(Code 1969, § 17-1-3) 
Sec. 8-2-6. - Compliance with building, fire and zoning restrictions.
