    No license or registration shall be issued pursuant to this chapter unless and until the applicant for such license provides the city clerk with the address of the proposed location from which the business will be conducted and the clerk determines that the facilities and buildings at the location listed meet all applicable building and fire code and zoning restrictions in force within the city. 
(Code 1969, § 17-1-11; Ord. No. 2017-1296, § 4, 4-11-17 ) 
Sec. 8-2-7. - Transferability. 
    No registration issued pursuant to this article shall be transferable from one business to another, or from one person conducting a business to a succeeding person conducting the same business. 
(Code 1969, § 17-1-5) 
Sec. 8-2-8. - Renewal. 
    Before March 1 of each year, any person conducting business in the city and subject to this chapter shall apply for renewal of the business registration or business license with the city clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 17-1-6; Ord. No. 2006-1178, § 1, 11-14-06; Ord. No. 2017-1296, § 5, 4-11-17 ) 
Sec. 8-2-9. - Late fees. 
    If any person fails to obtain the appropriate registration or license pursuant to this chapter or fails to renew an existing registration or license, this person shall pay a late fee in an amount not to exceed that permitted by state statute. This surcharge shall be in addition to all other fees imposed by this chapter. 
(Code 1969, § 17-1-7; Ord. No. 2006-1178, § 2, 11-14-06) 
Sec. 8-2-10. - Display. 
    The city clerk shall provide a suitable certificate of registration or license to be furnished to each place of business coming within the terms of this chapter, and such certificate of registration or license shall be prominently displayed at the place of business for which such registration or license is issued. Solicitors and similar licensees shall carry the license on their person while engaging in the business for which such license is issued. 
(Code 1969, § 17-1-9) 
Sec. 8-2-11. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-1296, § 6 , adopted April 11, 2017, repealed § 8-2-11, which pertained to duplicates and derived from Code 1969, § 17-1-10. 
ARTICLE 3. - LICENSE 

Sec. 8-3-1. - Purpose. 
    The city council finds and declares that the licensing and regulation of the businesses enumerated in this article are conducive to the promotion of the health, general welfare and safety of the public. 
(Code 1969, § 17-2-1) 
Sec. 8-3-2. - Applicability of Article 2. 
    All sections of Article 2 of this chapter, except sections 8-2-3 through 8-2-5 and 8-2-7 and any other section which by its terms can apply only to businesses subject to registration fees and not subject to licensing pursuant to this article, shall apply in full force and effect to businesses which are licensed under this article. 
(Code 1969, § 17-2-2) 
Sec. 8-3-3. - Required. 
    All persons engaged in the pursuits, businesses and occupations enumerated in this article shall, before commencing business and thereafter annually before March 1, secure a license from the city under the procedures set forth in this chapter and shall pay the license fees set forth in this article in connection with each such pursuit, business or occupation. 
(Code 1969, § 17-2-3; Ord. No. 2006-1178, § 3, 11-14-06) 
Sec. 8-3-4. - Effect of other licensing provisions. 
    Whenever other licensing provisions of this Code differ from the provisions of this article, the provisions elsewhere in this Code applicable to the specific type of license addressed shall take precedence. 
(Code 1969, § 17-2-10) 
Sec. 8-3-5. - Investigation of applicant. 
    Upon receipt of an application for a business license under this article, the city clerk shall determine whether the proposed operation may be carried on without conflict with any city ordinance and may cause such investigation of the applicant as may be necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare. The clerk may investigate the nature of the proposed business to determine the degree that such business will affect the public health, safety and general welfare; the level of supervision such business may require; the degree to which such business may attract crowds or children; the accessibility of the proprietors of such business when complaints made to the city must be investigated; and the possibility of illegal activity transpiring at the proposed place of business. If, as a result of such investigation, the city clerk determines that the issuance of a business license is in conflict with any ordinance or is not in the interest of the health, safety, general welfare of the public, the application shall be denied. 
(Code 1969, § 17-2-5; Ord. No. 2017-1296, § 8, 4-11-17 ) 
Editor's note- Formerly section 8-3-6. Ord. No. 2017-1296, § 7 , adopted April 11, 2017 repealed § 8-3-5, which pertained to exemptions and derived from Code 1969, § 17-2-4. The following sections were subsequently renumbered. 
Sec. 8-3-6. - License fee imposed on listed businesses. 
    The stated license fees are imposed upon the following businesses when conducted within the city, in lieu of and not in addition to the registration fee assessed pursuant to Article 2 of this chapter (fees are annual unless otherwise noted): 
(1)  Adult oriented businesses (subject to the provisions of the Unified Development Code) ..... $250.00 
(2)  Alarm system business ..... 50.00 
(3)  Amusement halls ..... 300.00 
(4)  Armored cars, as regulated by Article 11 of this chapter ..... 35.00 
(5)  Auctions, per event ..... 25.00 
(6)  Body art establishment ..... 100.00 
(7)  Boxing, wrestling or martial arts contests, per event ..... 50.00 
(8)  Canvassers, solicitors or peddlers, as defined in Article 8 of this chapter, per solicitor, each three months ..... 30.00 
(9)  Carnival, circus or menagerie, except kiddie ride carnivals, per day ..... 100.00 
(10)  Mobile food units, per unit ..... 35.00 
(11)  Home occupation ..... 35.00 
(12)  Kennels, as regulated by Chapter 6 ..... 35.00, plus the 20.00 annual inspection fee authorized by section 6-3-1 
(13)  Kiddie ride carnivals, per day ..... 30.00 
(14)  Massage therapists ..... 35.00 
(15)  Outdoor concerts, exhibitions and amusements for profit, per day ..... 50.00 
(16)  Outdoor sales events, per event ..... 10.00 
(17)  Pawnbrokers, as regulated by Article 7 of this chapter ..... 250.00 
(18)  Phrenologists, clairvoyants, palmists and fortunetellers, each three months ..... 100.00 
(19)  Pool rooms, billiard halls and bowling alleys ..... 35.00 
(20)  Private investigators, as regulated by Article 9 of this chapter ..... 35.00 
(21)  Private patrol operators, as regulated by Article 9 of this chapter ..... 50.00 
(22)  Sales of seasonal items (Christmas trees, etc.), per event ..... 30.00 
(23)  Secondhand dealers or junk dealers, as regulated by Article 6 of this chapter ..... 35.00 
(24)  Special events (license is required of sponsor only), per event ..... 25.00 
(25)  Stores, restaurants, diners, hotels/motels, coffee shops, fast food outlets and service stations that operate under the extended hours of operation ..... 50.00 
(26)  Street vending per day ..... 10.00 
(27)  Taxicabs, as regulated by Article 10 of this chapter: 
a.  First four or fewer vehicles ..... 100.00 
b.  Additional charge for each vehicle ..... 25.00 
(Code 1969, § 17-2-6; Ord. No. 98-1079, § 3, 8-11-98; Ord. No. 99-1105, § 3, 10-26-99; Ord. No. 03-1152, §§ 2-4, 10-28-03; Ord. No. 2008-1206, § 3, 6-24-08; Ord. No. 2007-1184, 9-8-10; Ord. No. 2017-1296, § 9, 4-11-17 ) 
Editor's note- Formerly section 8-3-7. 
Sec. 8-3-7. - Transferability. 
    No license issued pursuant to this article shall be transferable from one business to another. 
(Code 1969, § 17-2-7; Ord. No. 99-1105, § 4, 10-26-99; Ord. No. 2017-1296, § 10, 4-11-17 
Editor's note- Formerly section 8-3-8. 
Sec. 8-3-8. - Revocation. 
    When a person is required to obtain a license as provided in this article or a registration as provided in Article 2 of this chapter and has violated any article in this chapter or any other city ordinance relating thereto, or has failed to comply with the New Mexico Unfair Practices Act or any other provision of state law pertaining to such business, or whenever in the judgment of the city clerk the public welfare should require it, any such license or business registration issued such person by the city may be revoked. No such license shall be revoked until the city clerk notifies the holder of the license in writing that the revocation is pending and will become final in 30 days, unless the revocation is stayed by applying to the administrative review board as provided in section 2-4-40 for a hearing to appeal the decision. Application for this appeal shall be made as outlined in section 2-4-40. If no appeal is taken within 30 days, the revocation decision shall become final. If an appeal route is chosen, the licensee shall have further rights of appeal as provided for in sections 2-4-42 and 2-4-43. 
(Code 1969, § 17-2-8; Ord. No. 2010-1221, § 1, 1-12-10; Ord. No. 2017-1296, § 11, 4-11-17 ) 
Editor's note- Formerly section 8-3-9. 
State Law reference- Denial or revocation of license, NMSA 1978, § 3-38-2. 
Sec. 8-3-9. - Appeal procedure. 
    An applicant for a business license or business registration who has been denied a license in whole or in part may appeal the city clerk's decision to the administrative review board as set forth in division 2 of Article 4 of Chapter 2. 
(Code 1969, § 17-2-9; Ord. No. 2017-1296, § 12, 4-11-17 ) 
Editor's note- Formerly section 8-3-10. 
ARTICLE 4. - DISTRESS SALES 

Sec. 8-4-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Distress merchandise sale means any offer to sell to the public or any sale to the public of goods, wares or merchandise on the implied or direct representation that such sale is in anticipation of the termination of a business at its present location or that the sale is being held other than in the ordinary course of business. Distress merchandise sales shall include but are not limited to any sale advertised either specifically or in substance as a fire sale, smoke and water damage sale, adjustment sale, liquidation sale, creditor's sale, insolvent sale, trustee's sale, bankrupt sale, save us from bankruptcy sale, insurance salvage sale, mortgage sale, assignee's sale, adjuster's sale, must vacate sale, quitting business sale, receiver's sale, loss of lease sale, forced out of business sale, removal sale, change of ownership sale or new location sale. 
    Person means any individual, estate, trust, receiver, cooperative association, association, club, corporation, company, firm, partnership, joint venture, syndicate or other entity. 
(Code 1969, § 17-4-2) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-1-2. 
Sec. 8-4-2. - Applicability of article. 
(a)  This article shall not apply to any sale conducted by a public officer as a part of his official duties, to any sale for which an accounting must be made to a court of law or to any sale conducted pursuant to an order of a court of law. 
(b)  This article does not apply to seasonal sales, clearance sales or similar special sales of nondistress merchandise. 
(Code 1969, § 17-4-10) 
Sec. 8-4-3. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating this article shall upon conviction be punished as provided in section 1-1-10. 
(Code 1969, § 17-4-11) 
Sec. 8-4-4. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to advertise or conduct a distress merchandise sale without having first obtained a license in accordance with this article. 
(Code 1969, § 17-4-3) 
Sec. 8-4-5. - Application for license. 
    Any person desiring to conduct a distress merchandise sale shall make a written application verified under oath to the city clerk at least 15 days prior to the date on which the sale is to commence. However, if the merchandise to be sold consists of perishable goods or goods damaged by smoke, fire or water, the 15-day time period will not be applicable. Each application shall contain the following information and such other information as the city clerk shall require: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner of the goods, wares or merchandise to be sold. 
(2)  A description of the place where such sale is to be held. 
(3)  The nature of the occupancy of the place where such sale is to be held, whether by lease or otherwise, and the effective date of the termination of the occupancy of the premises. 
(4)  The commencement and termination dates of the distress merchandise sale. 
(5)  A full and complete statement of the facts regarding the reasons why the distress merchandise sale is being conducted, the manner in which the sale is to be conducted, the means to be employed in advertising the sale, together with the content of any proposed advertisement or advertising themes or copies thereof. 
(6)  If a defunct business is involved, the name and address of the defunct business and the owner or former owner thereof. 
(7)  A complete and detailed inventory of the goods, wares and merchandise, including goods received on consignment, to be offered at the distress merchandise sale; the terms and conditions of the acquisition of the property; the amount and description of the goods, wares or merchandise to be sold; and the location of the goods, wares and merchandise at the time of filing the application. 
(8)  A statement that the applicant has not, in contemplation of the distress merchandise sale, ordered, purchased or received on consignment any goods, wares or merchandise for the purpose of selling them at the sale within 90 days prior to filing the application. 
(9)  A statement that no goods will be added to the inventory after the application is made or during the sale. 
(10)  A statement that the applicant or his principal officers or agents have not been convicted of a violation of this article or had a license issued under this article revoked within five years of the filing of this application. 
(Code 1969, § 17-4-4) 
Sec. 8-4-6. - Examination and investigation; grounds for denial. 
    The city clerk may, upon the filing of an application for a license required under this article, investigate the applicant and examine his affairs in relation to the proposed sale and may examine the inventory and records of the applicant. No license shall be issued if it is found that: 
(1)  The applicant has held a sale subject to regulation under this article at the location described in the application, within three years from the date of the application; 
(2)  The application states that the applicant or any of his principal officers or agents has been convicted of a violation of this article or has had a license issued under this article revoked within five years of the filing of this application; 
(3)  The inventory submitted with the application includes goods, wares or merchandise purchased or held on consignment by the applicant or added to his stock in contemplation of such sale and for the purpose of selling the stock at the distress sale. Any unusual addition to the stock of goods, wares or merchandise which is made within 90 days prior to the filing of the application shall be prima facie evidence that the addition was made in contemplation of the sale and for the purpose of selling the goods at the sale; 
(4)  The applicant, in ticketing the goods, wares or merchandise for sale, has misrepresented the original retail price or value thereof; 
(5)  The advertisement or advertising themes are false, fraudulent, deceptive or misleading in any respect; 
(6)  The sales methods to be used by the applicant in conducting the sale will work a fraud upon the purchasers; 
(7)  The information set forth in the application is insufficient; 
(8)  Representations made in the application are false; or 
(9)  The applicant has acquired bankrupt stock or other distress sale merchandise from another area within six months of the application. 
(Code 1969, § 17-4-5) 
Sec. 8-4-7. - License fee; renewal. 
(a)  The fee for any license issued pursuant to this article shall be $50.00 or one-fourth of one percent of the inventory cost value of the goods, wares or merchandise to be sold at the sale, whichever is more. In no case, however, shall the license fee exceed $200.00. 
(b)  If, during the period that the license is in effect, it appears to the city clerk that all of the goods in the original inventory have not been sold, the city clerk may, upon application and for good cause shown, extend the license for a period not to exceed 30 days. 
(Code 1969, § 17-4-7) 
Sec. 8-4-8. - Conditions for issuance of license. 
    If the application submitted for the license required by this article complies with this article and if the required license fee has been paid, the city clerk shall issue the applicant a license to advertise and conduct the sale described in the application, subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The sale shall be held at the place named in the application. 
(2)  The sale shall be held by the licensee for a period of not more than 90 days following the date set forth in the license. 
(3)  Only goods, wares and merchandise included in the inventory attached to the application shall be displayed on the premises and sold at the sale. 
(4)  The license shall be prominently displayed at the location of the sale at all times. 
(5)  The licensee shall keep suitable books at the sale location which shall be open for inspection by the city clerk during normal business hours. 
(Code 1969, § 17-4-6) 
Sec. 8-4-9. - Revocation of license. 
    The city clerk shall revoke any license issued pursuant to this article if he finds that the licensee has: 
(1)  Violated any section of this article; 
(2)  Violated any condition of the license; 
(3)  Made any material misstatement in the application for the license; 
(4)  Failed to include in the inventory required by this article all the goods, wares or merchandise being offered for sale; 
(5)  Offered or permitted to be offered at the sale any goods, wares or merchandise not included in the inventory attached to the application; 
(6)  Failed to keep suitable records of the sale; 
(7)  Made or permitted to be made any false or misleading statements or representations in advertising the sale or in displaying, ticketing or pricing goods, wares or merchandise offered for sale; or 
(8)  Been guilty of any fraudulent practice in the conduct of the sale authorized by the license. 
(Code 1969, § 17-4-8) 
Sec. 8-4-10. - Confidentiality. 
    The filing of an application for a license required under this article, the contents of the application and the issuance of the license shall be confidential information, and no disclosure thereof shall be made except that which is necessary in the administration of this article. However, disclosure of the information mentioned in this section may be made with the consent of the applicant. The filing of the application and the issuance of the license shall not be confidential after public notice of the proposed sale has been given by the applicant. 
(Code 1969, § 17-4-9) 
ARTICLE 5. - GARAGE AND RUMMAGE SALES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate sales of merchandise, NMSA 1978, § 3-18-12. 

Sec. 8-5-1. - Garage sales. 
    Any person proposing to conduct or carry on a garage sale shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  All sale items shall be limited to used domestic items owned by the applicant; 
(2)  No person shall accept or take in for sale any goods on a consignment basis; 
(3)  No sign shall be posted anywhere in the city advertising such sale, except that the property owner may install on the residential lot on which such sale is to be held one sign, not larger than 15 inches by 24 inches, advertising such sale. Such sign shall be erected not sooner than one day prior to the date of the sale and shall be removed at the end of the last day upon which the sale is held; 
(4)  Not more than two such sales per annum shall be held at the premises if occupied by the same family or any member of such family; and 
(5)  Any sale conducted pursuant to this article shall be confined to the period between 8:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. of any day and shall not extend in excess of three consecutive days. 
(Code 1969, § 17-3-3) 
Sec. 8-5-2. - Rummage sales. 
    Any person proposing to conduct or carry on a rummage sale shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  All sale items shall be used domestic items or hand-crafted goods donated to or by the sponsoring organization, its members or employees or an organization which is exempt from taxation as nonprofit. 
(2)  No goods shall be sold on a consignment basis. 
(3)  Not more than four rummage sales per year shall be held on a given premises. 
(4)  Parking on the premises where the sale is to be held must be approved in advance by the city clerk. If the parking on the premises complies with the Unified Development Code, the city clerk shall approve the parking. 
(5)  The rummage sale shall be confined to the period between 8:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. of any day and shall not extend in excess of two days. 
(Code 1969, § 17-3-4; Ord. No. 2007-1184, 9-8-10) 
Sec. 8-5-3. - Penalty for noncompliance. 
    Any person violating any section of this article shall upon conviction be punished as set forth in section 1-1-10. 
(Code 1969, § 17-3-5) 
ARTICLE 6. - JUNK AND SECONDHAND DEALERS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate, license or tax secondhand dealers and junk store dealers, NMSA 1978, § 3-18-24; junk dealers, NMSA 1978, § 57-7-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-6-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Junk dealer means any person engaged in purchasing or otherwise acquiring, for sale or barter, any material such as old iron, copper, brass, lead, zinc, tin or other metals, metallic cable, wire, rope, bottles, rubber or other like material. 
    Secondhand dealer means any person engaged in purchasing, for sale or barter, used furniture or other secondhand or used material or articles, but the term does not include automobile dealers. 
(Code 1969, § 24-2-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar definitions, NMSA 1978, § 57-7-1. 
Sec. 8-6-2. - Posting of article; false reports. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every junk dealer or secondhand dealer to keep a copy of this article posted in a conspicuous place. 
(b)  Any junk dealer or secondhand dealer who shall make or keep on file a false report or a false writing of consent shall upon conviction have his license revoked and shall be punished as provided in section 1-1-10. 
(Code 1969, § 24-2-9) 
Sec. 8-6-3. - Records of personal property acquired. 
    Every person engaged in any or all of the businesses enumerated in this article shall keep a permanent book record, in ink, of all personal property acquired by him in the conduct of the business. The records of such business shall be open to inspection of the police officers during regular business hours. The records shall contain a description of the property, the date acquired, the name and residence of the person from whom acquired, and the amount of the purchase price or other consideration. 
(Code 1969, § 24-2-7) 
State Law reference- Records of purchases, NMSA 1978, § 57-7-2. 
Sec. 8-6-4. - Daily report of business transactions. 
    Every person engaged in any of the businesses enumerated in this article shall furnish to the chief of police, on a form prescribed by the chief of police, before 12:00 noon each day, a true and correct record of each transaction had at his place of business on the previous day, as called for in such form. 
(Code 1969, § 24-2-8) 
Sec. 8-6-5. - Transactions with minors. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any junk dealer or secondhand dealer doing business in the city to purchase or otherwise acquire, from any minor under the age of 18 years, any personal property of any nature, without having first obtained, from the parent or guardian of such minor, consent to such transaction, in writing, signed by the parent or guardian. Such writing shall contain the name or description of the article, the name of the minor, his age and residence, the date of the transaction and the amount of the loan or purchase price to be received. It shall be the duty of the junk dealer or secondhand dealer to ascertain that such written consent is in fact signed by such parent or guardian. Failure to do so shall constitute a violation of this article. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of every secondhand dealer or junk dealer to file such written consent with the chief of police on or before the first Monday of the month following its receipt. If no personal property has been purchased or acquired during any month by the junk dealer or secondhand dealer, he shall file a report with the chief of police so stating, which report shall be filed on or before the first Monday of each month. 
(Code 1969, § 24-2-6) 
Secs. 8-6-6-8-6-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 8-6-31. - Required. 
    Every junk dealer or secondhand dealer shall, before engaging in such business, obtain a license from the city clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 24-2-2) 
Sec. 8-6-32. - Application. 
    Any person desiring a license required under this division shall make an application in writing to the city clerk in the form and as provided in section 8-2-2. 
(Code 1969, § 24-2-3) 
Sec. 8-6-33. - Fee. 
    If the license required by this division is granted by the city clerk, a license fee as provided in section 8-3-7 shall be paid, and no other license fee or occupation tax shall be collected for the same business. Secondhand dealers shall be the same as junk dealers for the purpose of fixing the amount of the license fee required. 
(Code 1969, § 24-2-4) 
Sec. 8-6-34. - Revocation. 
    Any license granted under this division may be revoked as provided in section 8-3-9. 
(Code 1969, § 24-2-5) 
ARTICLE 7. - PAWNBROKERS[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Pawnbrokers Act, NMSA 1978, § 56-12-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-7-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Pawnbroker means any person engaged in the act of lending money or extending credit on the security of pledged or pawned goods or purchasing tangible personal property with an express or implied agreement or understanding that it may be redeemed or repurchased by the seller at a stipulated price. 
(Code 1969, § 24-1-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar definition, NMSA 1978, § 56-12-2. 
Sec. 8-7-2. - Posting of article. 
    It shall be the duty of every pawnbroker to keep a copy of this article posted in a conspicuous place. 
(Code 1969, § 24-1-10) 
Sec. 8-7-3. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any pawnbroker who is found guilty of a violation of any section of this article shall be guilty of a petty misdemeanor. Any licensee who violates any section of this article shall be subject to having his license revoked or suspended by the city council. Revocation or suspension of such license shall not bar prosecution of the licensee under the penal provisions of section 1-1-10. Criminal prosecution will not bar proceedings to revoke or suspend the holder's license. 
(Code 1969, § 24-1-15) 
Sec. 8-7-4. - Forfeiture and civil actions for excess service charges. 
    The violation of any section of this article and any covered transaction shall be deemed a forfeiture of the entire amount of the pawn service charge contracted for or allowable under the transaction. If a pawn service charge in excess of the amounts allowable under this article has been paid in any covered transaction, the person by whom it has been paid or his legal representative may recover by civil action triple the amount of service charge paid. Any civil action under this section shall be commenced within two years from the date the serious transaction was consummated. 
(Code 1969, § 24-1-16) 
Sec. 8-7-5. - Prohibited practices. 
    A pawnbroker shall not: 
(1)  Knowingly enter into a pawn transaction with a person under the age of 18 years or under the influence of alcohol or any narcotic, drug, stimulant or depressant; 
(2)  Make any agreement requiring the personal liability of a pledgor in connection with the pawn transaction; 
(3)  Accept any waiver, in writing or otherwise, of any right or protection accorded a pledgor under this article; 
(4)  Fail to exercise reasonable care to protect pledged goods from loss or damage; 
(5)  Fail to return a pledged good to a pledgor upon payment of the full amount due to the pawnbroker on the pawn transaction. If a pledged good is lost or damaged while in the possession of the pawnbroker, the pawnbroker shall compensate the pledgor for the reasonable value of the lost or damaged good; 
(6)  Make any charge for insurance in connection with a pawn transaction; 
(7)  Purchase or otherwise receive any item of property on which the manufacturer's nameplate, serial number or identification mark has been obviously defaced, altered, covered or destroyed; 
(8)  Purchase or otherwise receive any item of property which the pawnbroker knows is not lawfully owned by the person offering the property; 
(9)  Enter into a pawn transaction in which the unpaid principal balance exceeds $2,000.00; or 
(10)  Require that any of the proceeds of any cash loan be spent at the pawnbroker's place of business or in any other manner directed by the pawnbroker. 
(Code 1969, § 24-1-14) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 56-12-14. 
Sec. 8-7-6. - Records of pawned property. 
    Every person doing business as a pawnbroker shall keep a permanent book record, in ink, of all personal property acquired by him in the conduct of the business. The records of such business shall be open to inspection by the police officers during regular business hours. The records shall contain the name of the item; a description of the item, including make and model number if any, serial numbers and other identifying marks; the date, time and type of pawn transaction; the name and address of the person offering the item; a description of the person offering the item, including sex, complexion, hair color, approximate height and weight, and date of birth; and the type of identification used by the person offering the item and the identifying number of that identification. If the offering person presents the driver's license for identification, a report shall include the state and date of issuance. Persistent or frequent erroneous or incomplete entries in or delays in submitting the required reports shall constitute a violation of this section and shall be subject to the general penalty provisions of section 1-1-10. 
(Code 1969, § 24-1-6) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 56-12-12. 
Sec. 8-7-7. - Identification of items. 
    Each item pledged or pawned to or purchased by the licensed pawnbroker for which a report is required shall have attached to it a tag with an alphabetic or numeric identification system matching that item with its corresponding report and record. 
(Code 1969, § 24-1-7) 
Sec. 8-7-8. - Pawn ticket. 
(a)  Every pawnbroker shall, at the time of each pawn transaction, deliver to the person pawning or pledging personal property a ticket signed by the pawnbroker containing the information required to be made in the pawnbroker's daily report to the city. 
(b)  The holder of such ticket shall be presumed to be the person entitled to redeem the pledged or pawned item, and the pawnbroker shall deliver such item to the person presenting this ticket on payment of the principal amount owed and all other lawful charges. 
(c)  The pawn ticket required by this section shall further contain all disclosures of credit terms required to be disclosed to the pledgor by the Federal Truth in Lending Act. 
(Code 1969, § 24-1-8) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 56-12-10. 
Sec. 8-7-9. - Daily record of business transactions. 
    Each licensed pawnbroker shall furnish to the chief of police, on a form prescribed by the chief of police, before 12:00 noon of each business day, a true and correct record of each transaction had at his place of business on the previous business day. 
(Code 1969, § 24-1-9) 
Sec. 8-7-10. - Default by pledgor; disposition of pawned property. 
(a)  Except as otherwise specified in this section, upon default by the pledgor, the pawnbroker shall comply with the requirements of NMSA 1978, §§ 55-9-501-55-9-507 in the disposition of the pledged goods. 
(b)  Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, the pawnbroker shall not dispose of the pledged property, except by redemption, until at least 90 days after the indebtedness has become due. 
(c)  Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, if the pawnbroker disposes of the pledged property by sale in the regular course of his business, such sale shall conform to the requirements of NMSA 1978, § 55-9-504. If a surplus remains after sale of the pledged property, the pawnbroker must make a record of the sale in the amount of the surplus and must notify the pledgor by first class mail sent to the pledgor's last known address of the amount of the surplus and the pledgor's right to claim it at a location specified in the notice within 90 days of the date of mailing of the notice, if the surplus is $100.00 or less, or within 12 months of the date of mailing of the notice if the surplus is greater than $100.00. If the first class mail addressed to any person is returned unclaimed to the pawnbroker, the pawnbroker must post and maintain on a conspicuous public part of his premises an appropriately entitled list naming each such person. Ninety days or 12 months, as applicable, after the date of such mailing or posting, whichever is later, the pawnbroker may retain as his own property any surplus remaining unclaimed by the pledgor. 
(Code 1969, § 24-1-11) 
Sec. 8-7-11. - Record of disposition of property after default of pledgor. 
    Every pawnbroker shall keep a permanent record, fully itemized, of all pledged property disposed of following default by the pledgor. The record shall include the following: 
(1)  The number of the pawned transaction; 
(2)  The name and address of the pledgor; 
(3)  The date of the pawned transaction and the date of the last payment received as service charge or on principal; 
(4)  The date of disposition of the pledged property pursuant to this article; 
(5)  The method of disposition of the pledged property; and 
(6)  The amount and disposition of any surplus following disposition of the pledged property. 
(Code 1969, § 24-1-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 56-12-12. 
Sec. 8-7-12. - Pawn service charge. 
(a)  For the first 30-day period of the pawn transaction, a pawnbroker may charge $7.50 or ten percent of the amount loaned, whichever is greater, provided that such charge shall not be made on the refinancing of an existing loan or credit transaction. A loan or extension of credit shall be considered to be refinancing of an existing loan if any part of the proceeds of the subsequent loan is applied toward the payment of a prior loan with the same pawnbroker. 
(b)  For the remaining period of the pawn transaction, including any refinancing, no pawnbroker shall charge, directly or indirectly or by any subterfuge, a pawn service charge in connection with any pawn transaction at a rate in excess of four percent per month on the unpaid principal balance of the loan or extension of credit. 
(c)  The pawn service charges in this section are limiting maximums, and nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit a pawnbroker from contracting for or receiving a lesser rate than established in this section. 
(Code 1969, § 24-1-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 56-12-13. 
Secs. 8-7-13-8-7-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 8-7-36. - Required. 
(a)  Every pawnbroker shall, before engaging in such business, obtain a license from the city clerk. The license for pawnbrokers shall expire in accordance with Article 2 of this chapter and must be renewed annually. The license shall be conspicuously displayed at the place of business. Upon receipt of each annual license, each pawnbroker shall register or reregister with the chief of police. 
(b)  No person who has been convicted of a felony shall be eligible for license as a pawnbroker. 
(c)  Doing business as a pawnbroker without a license is a violation of this Code and is punishable as provided in section 1-1-10. 
(Code 1969, § 24-1-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 56-12-4. 
Sec. 8-7-37. - Application. 
    Any person desiring a license required under this division shall make an application in writing upon a form provided by the city clerk to the office of the city clerk as provided in section 8-2-2. 
(Code 1969, § 24-1-3) 
Sec. 8-7-38. - Fee. 
    If a license required by this division is granted by the city clerk, a license fee as provided in section 8-3-7 shall be paid. 
(Code 1969, § 24-1-4) 
Sec. 8-7-39. - Bond. 
    Every application for a new license required under this division shall include a proof of bond, which has been executed and delivered to the city clerk. The bond shall be in the amount of $5,000.00, in a form approved by the city attorney and by the state, and shall be conditioned upon the conduct of the pawnbroker's business according to this Code. The bond shall be for the benefit of each and every person damaged by a breach of any condition set forth in the bond. Each pawnbroker shall provide the city clerk with 30 days' written notice of the cancellation of the bond. 
(Code 1969, § 24-1-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 56-12-6. 
ARTICLE 8. - PEDDLERS 

Sec. 8-8-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Peddler means any person who goes from house to house, place to place, or from street to street carrying, conveying, or transporting foods, wares, or merchandise, meats, fish, vegetables, fruits, garden truck, farm products, or provisions, offering or exposing such for sale or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers. The term "peddler" shall include the terms "hawker, huckster, transient merchant and itinerant vendor." 
    Solicitor means any person who goes from house to house, place to place, or from street to street soliciting, taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise, or services (including orders, contracts, or subscriptions for books, magazines, periodicals, real estate sales or listings, insurance contracts, or tangible or intangible personal property of any nature) or soliciting, taking orders or attempting to take orders for services to be furnished or performed in the future, whether or not such individual has, carries or exposes for sale a sam ple of the subject of such sale or whether he is collecting advance payments on such sales or not. 
(Code 1969, § 25-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-1-2. 
Sec. 8-8-2. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person convicted of violating this article shall be punished in the manner specified in section 1-1-10. 
(Code 1969, § 25-4) 
Sec. 8-8-3. - Exemptions. 
    The following persons are exempt from this article: 
(1)  Those persons representing charitable associations, organizations existing under the provisions of NMSA 1978, § 53-8-1 et seq., or NMSA 1978, § 53-10-1 et seq., pertaining to nonprofit corporations and unincorporated associations, or which are exempt from taxation under 26 USC 501. 
(2)  Those peddlers and solicitors invited by the owner or occupant of the premises to enter upon the premises; provided, however, that if any invitation is obtained by the use of any misrepresentation or promise of a gift or a prize or by the use of any game or device or by the use of any other means other than for the purpose of the sale of the actual products offered by the vendor, the invitation shall be deemed null and void. 
(Code 1969, § 25-3) 
Sec. 8-8-4. - Posted premises; requests to leave, permitted hours. 
(a)  No peddler or solicitor shall enter any premises or attempt to peddle or solicit where the owner or occupant of such premises has indicated his desire not to be contacted for sales or solicitations by the placing of a "no solicitors" or "no peddlers" sign on those premises, visible to persons approaching or entering onto the premises. Any such entrance or attempt to peddle shall constitute a violation of this section. 
(b)  A peddler or solicitor that has entered onto any premises to attempt to peddle or solicit shall leave the premises immediately when asked to do so or when the owner or occupant has declined to purchase the goods or services being solicited. A failure to leave immediately shall constitute a violation of this section. 
(c)  Door to door residential solicitation shall be permitted from 10:00 a.m to 7:00 p.m. Any attempt to solicit at a residence outside of these hours is prohibited and constitutes a violation of this section. 
(Code 1969, § 25-2; Ord. No. 2010-1221, § 2(1)-(3), 1-12-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2010-1221, § 2(1)-(3), adopted Jan. 12, 2010 amended § 8-8-4 title to read as herein set out. Former § 8-8-4 title pertained to invitation required to enter posted premises. 
ARTICLE 9. - PRIVATE INVESTIGATORS AND PRIVATE PATROL OPERATORS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Law enforcement, ch. 15. 
State Law reference- Private Investigators and Polygraphers Act, NMSA 1978, § 61-27A-1 et seq.; local regulations authorized, NMSA 1978, § 61-27A-17. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-9-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Licensee means a person, including a manager, licensed under this article and includes but is not limited to private investigator or private patrol operator. 
    Manager means the individual under whose direction and control, charge or management the business of a licensee is operated. The manager and the business are colicensees. 
    Private investigator means a person other than an insurance adjuster who for any consideration whatsoever engages in business or accepts employment to furnish or agrees to make or makes an investigation for the purpose of obtaining information with reference to crime or wrongs done or threatened against the United States or any state or territory of the United States; the identity, habits, conduct, business, occupation, honesty, integrity, credibility, knowledge, trustworthiness, efficiency, loyalty, activity, movement, whereabouts, affiliation, association, transactions, acts, reputation or character of any person; the location, disposition or recovery of lost or stolen property; the cause or responsibility for fires, liables, losses, accidents or damage or injury to persons or properties; or securing evidence to be used before any court, board, officer or investigating committee. 
    Private patrol operator means a person who for any consideration whatsoever agrees to furnish or furnishes or accepts employment as a uniformed or nonuniformed watchman, guard, patrolman or other person to protect persons or property or to prevent the theft, unlawful taking, loss, embezzlement, misappropriation or concealment of any goods, wares, merchandise, money, bonds, stocks, notes, documents, papers or property of any kind; or perform the service of such watchman, guard, patrolman or other person for any of such purposes. 
    Registrant means any individual who is employed by a licensee as a private investigator or private patrol operator, and is registered to do so under this article. 
(Code 1969, § 28B-1; Ord. No. 2007-1193, § 1, 11-27-07) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-1-2. 
Sec. 8-9-2. - Exceptions. 
    This article does not apply to the following: 
(1)  A person employed exclusively and regularly by one employer in connection with the affairs of such employer, only, and where there exists an employer-employee relationship. 
(2)  An officer or employee of the United States or of this state or any political subdivision thereof while such officer or employee is engaged in the performance of his official duties. 
(3)  A person engaged exclusively in the business of obtaining and furnishing information as to the financial rating of persons. 
(4)  A charitable philanthropic society or association duly incorporated under the laws of this state which is organized and maintained for the public good and not for private profit. 
(5)  A person engaged exclusively in a profession licensed by a board of this state, other than a private investigator. 
(6)  A licensed collection agency or an employee thereof while acting within the scope of his employment while making an investigation incidental to the business of the agency, including an investigation of the location of a debtor or his property. 
(7)  Admitted insurers and agents and insurance brokers licensed by the state performing duties in connection with insurance transactions by them. 
(8)  Any institution subject to the jurisdiction of the commissioner of banking (director of the financial institutions, division of the commerce and industry department) of the state or the comptroller of currency of the United States. 
(9)  Insurance adjusters acting in the normal scope of their duties in insurance adjusting and investigation. 
(10)  Attorneys. 
(11)  Special event employees. A licensee may hire employees for periods of time not to exceed five days for special celebrations, parades or similar events without such employees being registered. This exception shall not be used to circumvent the registration of permanent employees as provided in this article and, therefore, use of each, same special event employee shall not exceed three times annually. The licensee under whom the special event employee is working shall inform the city clerk about the use of a special event employee immediately, furnishing his name and length of employment. 
(Code 1969, § 28B-4) 
Sec. 8-9-3. - Penalties for having no license or registration or hiring nonregistered employees. 
(a)  When a license is required by this article and a person without being licensed engages in a business regulated by this article or assumes to act as or represents himself to be a licensee, he is guilty of a petty misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of $100.00 for the first offense. Subsequent offenses shall be punished as set forth in section 1-1-10. 
(b)  When a registration is required to be obtained by this article and a person without being registered engages in an activity that requires registration or assumes to act or represents himself to be a registrant, he is guilty of a petty misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of $25.00 for the first offense. Subsequent offenses shall be punished as set forth in section 1-1-10. 
(c)  Any licensee subject to this article who employs an unregistered employee is guilty of a petty misdemeanor and shall be fined $100.00 for each employee not registered on the first offense. Subsequent offenses shall be punished as set forth in section 1-1-10. 
(Code 1969, § 28B-3) 
Sec. 8-9-4. - Compliance with state law. 
    Under this article all licensees and registrants shall, in addition to any applicable sections of this article, fully comply with any applicable provisions of NMSA 1978, § 67-27A-1 et seq. 
(Code 1969, § 28B-15) 
Sec. 8-9-5. - Uniforms and vehicle insignia. 
(a)  Uniform. No licensee or registrant under this article shall wear any uniform or a pattern or design that may be mistaken for or confused with the uniform in use by the regular members of the police department, the county sheriff's department or the state police. All uniforms to be utilized by a person or registrant shall be exhibited to the chief of police and approval obtained in accordance with this subsection prior to such uniform being worn or utilized. A licensee shall not be required to change the design or pattern of a uniform if any of the government agencies mentioned in this subsection change the pattern or design of the uniform in use to a pattern or design similar to one adopted for use by the licensee. Use of badges by private investigators is prohibited by this section and by state law under NMSA 1978, § 61-27A-12. 
(b)  Vehicle insignia. No licensee or registrant shall operate a vehicle with an insignia, decal or other marking of a pattern or design that may be mistaken for or confused with a vehicle having an insignia, decal or other marking in use by the regular members of the police department, county sheriff's department or the state police. All insignias, decals or other markings to be utilized on a vehicle operated by a licensee or registrant shall be exhibited to the chief of police and approval obtained in accordance with this subsection prior to being utilized. The licensee shall not be required to change the pattern or design of a vehicle insignia, decal or other marking if any of the government agencies mentioned in this subsection change the pattern or design of the vehicle insignia, decal or other marking in use to a pattern or design similar to one used by a licensee. 
(Code 1969, § 28B-20) 
Sec. 8-9-6. - Carrying firearms. 
    Licenses or registrations issued under this article shall not authorize the carrying of any concealed loaded or other deadly weapon contrary to law or to use any firearm or other weapon in a negligent manner contrary to section 18-5-42. 
(Code 1969, § 28B-21) 
Secs. 8-9-7-8-9-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE AND REGISTRATION 

Sec. 8-9-36. - Required. 
(a)  Any person offering private investigator or private patrol operator services shall be licensed. If a license is required of a nonindividual, the manager of the business shall qualify under section 8-9-38 and, as provided in section 8-9-37, shall be a colicensee. 
(b)  Any person working as a private investigator or private patrol operator for a licensee or working for a person described in subsection (a) of this section as a private patrol operator or a private investigator shall be registered. 
(c)  Employees working under licensees either in management or nonmanagement positions, except for managers who work for a nonmanagement licensee and as such are colicensees, need not be registered if their duties do not fall within the definition of private investigators or private patrol operators. 
(d)  Neither a licensee nor a manager need to make an additional application if he also wishes to be registered. 
(Code 1969, § 28B-2) 
Sec. 8-9-37. - Qualifications of registrants. 
    Under this division, a registrant need not meet the additional qualification as set forth in section 8-9-38. However, the application required from a registrant, the investigation by the chief of police and the grounds for denying and revoking a registration shall be the same for a registrant as for a licensee. 
(Code 1969, § 28B-6) 
Sec. 8-9-38. - Qualifications of business of licensee; manager. 
(a)  Under this division, the business of each licensee other than an individual shall be operated under the direction, control, charge or management of a licensed manager. To qualify for a license, the business must show it shall be operated by a manager who possesses the qualifications prescribed under this division for the type of business he will be managing. The business is considered licensed only under this certain manager. 
(b)  If the manager who has qualified as provided in this division ceases, for any reason whatsoever, to be connected with the same licensee, the licensee shall notify the city clerk in writing within 30 days from such cessation. If the licensee fails to notify the city clerk within the 30-day period, its license shall be revoked and may be reinstated only upon the filing of a new application and payment of the application fees. The businesses' license shall continue under a new manager if the city clerk is so informed within 30 days and the new manager qualifies as provided in this division. 
(Code 1969, § 28B-5) 
Sec. 8-9-39. - Application for license or registration. 
    Any person desiring to be licensed or registered as required by this division shall make application to the city clerk, and the application shall be immediately transmitted to the chief of police for investigation. If the applicant is a nonindividual (i.e., a corporate business being run by a manager), the business and manager shall make a coapplication. Such application shall be verified under oath and shall include the following information pertaining to the individual applicant: 
(1)  Full name, age, and residence of the applicant. 
(2)  Business address. 
(3)  A chronological statement of residences and occupations for a period of ten years next preceding the date of the application. 
(4)  A statement of the experience obtained as a security officer, private detective, private investigator or experience in related fields, and the duration of total experience. 
(5)  A full set of classifiable fingerprints, and one recent photograph of the applicant of a type prescribed by the attorney general. 
(6)  A statement describing any and all arrests by law enforcement officials, including the nature of the offense or charges filed and whether the arrest resulted in a conviction or finding of guilt, and, if so, the penalty assessed for such violation. 
(7)  Employer's name, address and telephone number. 
(8)  A copy of a license or registration or application for such issued or to be issued by the state. 
(9)  A statement as to whether the applicant desires to be licensed or registered as a private patrol operator, a private investigator or both. 
(Code 1969, § 28B-7; Ord. No. 2007-1193, § 2, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 8-9-40. - Bond. 
(a)  No license shall be issued under this division unless the applicant files with the city clerk a surety bond executed by a surety company authorized to do business in the state in the sums as follows: 
(1)  If the licensee employs one to 20 registrants, $5,000.00. 
(2)  If the licensee employs 20 or more registrants, $10,000.00. 
(b)  The bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful and lawful conduct of the business licensed by this division and upon faithful compliance with this article by the licensee. Such bond, as to its form, execution and sufficiency of the surety, shall be approved by the city attorney. An endorsement for the appropriate amount on any bond furnished pursuant to the provisions of the New Mexico Private Investigator's and Polygraphers Act, NMSA 1978, § 61-27A-1 et seq., shall be sufficient if such endorsement names the licensee as a principal and assures all the undertakings required of the licensee under this article. 
(c)  Bonds executed and filed with the city clerk pursuant to this section shall remain in force and effect until the surety has terminated future liability by 30 days' notice to the city clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 28B-19) 
Sec. 8-9-41. - Investigation by chief of police; approval or denial of application. 
(a)  Upon receipt from the city clerk of the application for a license or registration required under this division, the chief of police shall cause an investigation to be made of the applicant. The investigation shall be completed as soon as reasonably possible and in any event within 30 days of receipt of the application. 
(b)  Upon completion of the investigation, the chief of police shall approve or deny the application. If the application is denied, the chief of police shall forward a written report stating specific reasons for such denial to the city clerk. 
(c)  Upon approval of an application by the chief of police, the application shall be filed in the city clerk's office under the name of the sponsoring licensee. 
(Code 1969, § 28B-8; Ord. No. 2007-1193, § 3, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 8-9-42. - Grounds for denial. 
    Under this division, the chief of police may deny a license or registration to an applicant if the applicant has: 
(1)  Committed any act which, if committed by a licensee or registrant, would be grounds for revocation of a license or registration under section 8-9-43. 
(2)  Committed any act constituting dishonesty or fraud. 
(3)  Been convicted of a felony, any crime involving moral turpitude, or convicted of a crime committed while illegally using, carrying or possessing a deadly weapon. 
(4)  Been refused a license or registration or had a license or registration revoked under this chapter or under the Private Investigators and Polygraphers Act of the State of New Mexico, NMSA 1978, § 61-27A-1 et seq., or has been an officer, director, partner or manager of any person who has been refused a license or registration under this state law or whose license or registration has been revoked. 
(5)  While unlicensed or unregistered, committed or aided and abetted the commission of any act for which a license or registration is required under this article. 
(6)  Knowingly made any false statement in his application. 
(Code 1969, § 28B-12; Ord. No. 2007-1193, § 4, 11-27-07) 
State Law reference- Denial, suspension or revocation of license, NMSA 1978, § 61-27A-13. 
Sec. 8-9-43. - Revocation. 
(a)  The continued validity of any license issued under this division shall be contingent upon the licensee's maintaining a good and sufficient bond in good standing at all times as required by section 8-9-40. If the licensee fails to maintain the bond as required in this division, the city clerk shall revoke the license issued and shall notify the licensee of such action by certified mail, return receipt requested. The licensee in such case shall surrender his license to the city clerk, and the license shall not be reissued until an appropriate bond has been filed by the applicant. 
(b)  The chief of police may suspend or revoke a license or registration if he, after appropriate investigation, shall make reasonably detailed findings and determine in writing, that the licensee or registrant has: 
(1)  Made any false statement or given any false information in connection with an application for a license or a renewal or reinstatement of a license; 
(2)  Violated any section of this article or the Private Investigators and Polygraphers Act, NMSA 1978, § 61-27A-1 et seq.; 
(3)  Been convicted of a felony; any crime involving moral turpitude; or any crime committed while illegally using, carrying or possessing a deadly weapon; 
(4)  Wilfully failed or refused to render to a client services or a report as agreed between the parties for which compensation has been paid or tendered in accordance with the agreement between the parties; 
(5)  Impersonated or permitted or aided another to impersonate a law enforcement officer or employee of the United States or of any state or political subdivision thereof; 
(6)  Committed an assault, battery or kidnapping or used force or violence on any person without proper justification; 
(7)  Knowingly violated or advised, encouraged or assisted the violation of any court order or injunction in the course of his business; 
(8)  Acted as a runner or capper for an attorney; 
(9)  Been adjudged mentally incompetent or insane by regularly constituted authorities; 
(10)  Knowingly issued a worthless or otherwise fraudulent payroll check that is not redeemed within two days of denial of payment of any bank; 
(11)  Committed any act which is a ground for denial of an application for a license or registration under section 8-9-45; 
(12)  Been convicted of a crime involving the illegal possession or use of dangerous or narcotic drugs. 
(c)  Any party aggrieved by the revocation of a license or registration shall have a right of appeal as if the original application had been denied and subject to the same appeal procedures found in section 8-9-44. 
(Code 1969, § 28B-14; Ord. No. 2007-1193, § 5, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 8-9-44. - Appeal procedure. 
(a)  Under this division, upon return of the application to the city clerk, the city shall notify the applicant of approval or denial of the application within ten business days. 
(b)  An applicant whose application has been denied shall be entitled to appeal the denial to the city manager. The applicant shall make a written demand for an appeal within ten business days of notification of denial or revocation. 
(c)  The city manager shall review the application and the written denial for the application by the chief of police and issue a written decision upholding or reversing the denial within 15 days of the written demand for an appeal. 
(d)  If the city manager upholds the denial of the application, the city manager's written decision upholding the denial of the application shall contain specific reasons and findings for such denial. 
(e)  Any person aggrieved by the action of the city manager in upholding the denial of an application under this section may appeal such decision to the district court within 30 days of such final decision. 
(Code 1969, § 28B-9; Ord. No. 2007-1193, § 6, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 8-9-45. - Records. 
    The city clerk shall keep a record of all licenses and registrations issued, revoked or terminated by the licensee or registrant pursuant to this division. A license is valid from July 1 through June 30 of each year and is subject to renewal as other city business licenses. 
(Code 1969, § 28B-11; Ord. No. 2007-1193, § 7, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 8-9-46. - Additional requirements for licensees; city occupation license. 
(a)  Every licensee under this division shall, as a condition precedent to acting as a licensee under this division, additionally obtain and maintain in force and effect a good and sufficient city occupation license. 
(b)  Every licensee who employs registrants under this division shall, from the date of employing such individuals and at least monthly from that date, furnish a list to the city clerk of individuals registered under the licensee and who are working in the city limits. Every licensee shall, within five business days of any change in the list of registrants, notify the city clerk in writing of any change in such list. 
(c)  If, after 30 days from the date of notification of termination of a registrant by a licensee under subsection (b) of this section, the registrant has not furnished proof of employment with another licensee or surrendered his registration card to the city clerk as required by section 8-9-47, the city clerk shall notify the licensee who employed the registrant that the registration card has not been surrendered. Within five business days of such notification, the licensee shall either surrender the registration card to the city clerk or provide to the city clerk in such form as the city clerk may require a certificate setting forth the following: 
(1)  The last known address and telephone number of the registrant; 
(2)  Any information the licensee may have as to the whereabouts of the registrant; 
(3)  That the registrant is no longer employed by the licensee and that the licensee after due diligence is unable to obtain the registration card from the registrant for surrender to the city; 
(4)  That the licensee will continue to make diligent effort to obtain the registration card from the registrant for surrender to the city unless the registrant has obtained employment with another licensee; and 
(5)  That the state has been notified of the fact that the registration card has not been surrendered to the city unless the registrant has obtained employment with another licensee. 
(d)  Every licensee shall, upon any change thereof, notify the city clerk of any change in his residence address, location or place of employment, the name under which he does business, or of any change of offices or partners. Any change of manager requires notice as set forth in section 8-9-38. 
(e)  Any security observations, stakeouts, use of guard dogs or other law enforcement-related activity shall be reported to and coordinated with the police department. Reports under this subsection are confidential and shall only be used for official City purposes and not released to others. 
(f)  Every licensee shall, at all times, be legally responsible for the proper conduct in business under this article of each employee of such licensee. 
(Code 1969, § 28B-17; Ord. No. 2007-1193, § 8, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 8-9-47. - Termination of employment. 
(a)  If a registrant under this division ceases to be actively employed as a private patrol operator or a private investigator for a period of 30 days, he shall notify the city clerk of such fact in writing and surrender his registration card as required under the bonding provisions of section 8-9-40. 
(b)  If, within 90 days from the termination, the registrant is once again employed by the same licensee or another licensee, he may reinstate his registration by applying to the city clerk; however, no further investigation shall be necessary. 
(c)  Every registrant who ceases working for more than 90 days and every licensee who quits business for any length of time shall make a complete new application for the license or registration. 
(Code 1969, § 28B-18; Ord. No. 2007-1193, § 10, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 8-9-48. - Assignability. 
    Neither a license nor a registration issued under this division is assignable. 
(Code 1969, § 28B-13; Ord. No. 2007-1193, § 11, 11-27-07) 
ARTICLE 10. - TAXICABS[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Parking in bus and taxicab stands, § 25-4-8. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-10-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Owner means any person granted a license under this article to operate a taxicab on the streets of the city. 
    Taxicab means and includes every motor vehicle that, together with a driver, is for hire to transport passengers over the streets of the city, irrespective of whether such operations extend beyond the city limits. 
(Code 1969, § 31-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-1-2. 
State Law reference- Taxicabs defined, NMSA 1978, § 66-1-4.17. 
Sec. 8-10-2. - Taxicab driver's identification. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner to allow any driver to operate any taxicab licensed as required in this article unless there is conspicuously posted within the taxicab and in view of passengers using the taxicab: 
(1)  A recent photograph of the driver of the taxicab. 
(2)  The name of the driver and his age. 
(3)  The name of the owner for whom the driver is authorized to operate a taxicab. 
(b)  Each owner shall keep and maintain at all times a complete and accurate record of all drivers employed by him, which record shall show in detail the names and addresses and the dates of the beginning and termination of employment of such drivers, the taxicab driven by each driver and the hours during which each such driver was on duty during each day or night of his employment, as well as a list of all days and nights on which each employee was absent from his employment. Such records shall be displayed to the police department at any time upon demand and shall not be destroyed without permission of the chief of police or such other person who may be designated, unless five years have elapsed since the driver was employed by the owner. 
(c)  Upon employment of any taxicab driver, each owner shall inform the chief of police of the fact of employment, the name of the driver employed, the date the employment began, the number of the driver's license of the driver and such other information concerning the driver as the chief of police may require. At the same time the owner shall furnish the chief of police with a picture of the driver identical with the photograph required to be posted in the taxicab under this section. Upon termination of employment of any driver, the owner shall inform the chief of police of such termination and the date of termination of employment. 
(Code 1969, § 31-6) 
Sec. 8-10-3. - Identification of taxicab. 
    Each owner of a licensed taxicab shall be required to mark the vehicles used in his business in a manner which clearly indicates to the public that this vehicle is one for hire. Each taxicab shall be suitably labeled at all times during which it is being operated as a taxicab. 
(Code 1969, § 31-7) 
Sec. 8-10-4. - Schedule of fares. 
    Every taxicab owner shall keep posted, in a conspicuous place in the passenger compartment of each taxicab operated, an explanation of fees to be charged, whether it is on a time or zone basis. It shall be unlawful to charge any fees other than what is so posted. 
(Code 1969, § 31-5) 
Secs. 8-10-5-8-10-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OWNER'S LICENSE 

Sec. 8-10-31. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate any taxicab in the city unless the owner makes proper application for a license, as explained in section 8-10-32, pays the appropriate license fees as prescribed by section 8-3-7 and such license is granted. 
(Code 1969, § 31-2) 
Sec. 8-10-32. - Application. 
    The application for an owner's license required under this division shall be tendered to the licensing division of the city clerk's office. It shall be verified under oath and shall set forth the following: 
(1)  A full identification, including residence and business addresses and phone numbers, of the applicant and all other persons to be directly or indirectly connected with the managing or the financing of the taxicab business. 
(2)  The location and name of the business for which the license is requested. 
(3)  The past experience of the applicant in reference to the taxicab business, and the name, address and past experience of the person to be in charge of the premises of the business. 
(4)  The number of vehicles proposed to be operated and a complete description of the vehicles. 
(5)  The form of business enterprise under which the business is to be conducted, i.e., sole proprietorship, partnership, limited partnership, or corporation. 
(6)  The time of operation during a 24-hour period. 
(7)  The applicant's current revenue division taxpayer identification number or evidence of application for such number. 
(8)  The proposed schedule of fares as required to be posted in the taxicab in section 8-10-4, and such schedule shall be in the same size and physical form as will be posted in the taxicab. 
(9)  The current taxicab drivers' names and other information as required in section 8-10-2. 
(10)  Such further information as the city may deem necessary to enable the issuance of the license. 
(Code 1969, § 31-3) 
Sec. 8-10-33. - Issuance; display. 
    The city clerk, through the licensing division, shall provide a suitable certificate of license to each applicant complying with the terms of this article, and such license shall be displayed at the place of business. The license shall be renewed annually as outlined in section 8-2-8. 
(Code 1969, § 31-4) 
Sec. 8-10-34. - Revocation. 
(a)  The city council may revoke any owner's license issued under this division for falsification of any documents required in this article, for violating any section of this article or for failure to pay any judgment for damages arising from the unlawful or negligent operation of a taxicab. However, no license shall be revoked, except after notice to the owner to show cause why it should not be revoked, at a hearing before the city council. Such notice to the owner shall be in writing and shall state the reason for revocation and the time and place of hearing. 
(b)  The remedies provided in this section are not exclusive, and if any section of this article is violated by the owner, the city may proceed in any manner authorized by law including the procedure set forth in NMSA 1978, §§ 3-38-5 and 3-38-6. 
(Code 1969, § 31-8) 
ARTICLE 11. - ARMORED CAR SERVICES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-11-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Armored car means and includes any vehicle used for the transportation of currency or anything of value, which is constructed or equipped to afford protection against theft or loss of such currency or thing of value in connection with such transportation, or, in connection with such transportation, protection is provided by armed guards. 
    Armored car service means and includes the furnishing of service for the transportation of currency or anything of value by means of armored car. 
(Code 1969, § 31-9) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-1-2. 
Sec. 8-11-2. - Liability of city. 
    This article shall not be construed as imposing upon the city, its officials, or its employees any liability or responsibility for the operation of armored car service by any person licensed under this article. 
(Code 1969, § 31-14) 
Secs. 8-11-3-8-11-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 8-11-31. - Required 
    No person shall conduct or operate an armored car service in the city without having first obtained a license as provided in this division, and no person shall conduct or operate an armored car service except upon compliance with all of the sections of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 31-10) 
Sec. 8-11-32. - Application; fee. 
(a)  The application for the license required by this division shall be in writing and filed with the licensing division of the city clerk's office. It shall be verified under oath and shall set forth the following: 
(1)  A full identification, including residence and business addresses and phone numbers, of the applicant and all other persons to be directly or indirectly connected with the managing or the financing of the armored car service. 
(2)  The location and name of the business for which the license is requested. 
(3)  The past experience of the applicant in reference to the armored car business, and the name, address and past experience of the person to be in charge of the premises of the business. 
(4)  The number of vehicles proposed to be operated and a complete description of the vehicles. 
(5)  The form of business enterprise under which the business is to be conducted, i.e., sole proprietorship, partnership, limited partnership or corporation. 
(6)  The applicant's current revenue division taxpayer identification number or evidence of application for such number. 
(7)  The current armored car driver's names and other information as required in section 8-11-33. 
(8)  Fingerprints of the applicant and of all the drivers of the armored cars are to be taken by the police department and placed on file there. 
(9)  Such further information as the city may deem necessary to enable the issuance of the license. 
(b)  Such application shall be accompanied by a fee of $25.00 to be used in defraying the expenses of enforcing this article. The license shall be renewed annually as outlined in section 8-2-8. 
(Code 1969, § 31-11) 
Sec. 8-11-33. - Additional employees of licensee. 
    A person holding a license under this division may employ other persons not named in the original application or in any renewal application, but the person shall promptly report to the chief of police the name and residence address of such person so employed and shall furnish like information as to such employee as is required of the employer in the employer's application for a license. The employer shall likewise have such employees fingerprinted by the police department. 
(Code 1969, § 31-12) 
Sec. 8-11-34. - Revocation of owner's license. 
(a)  The city council may revoke any owner's license issued under this division for falsification of any documents required in this division, for violating any section of this article or for failure to pay any judgment for damages arising from the unlawful or negligent operation of an armored car. However, no license shall be revoked, except after notice to the owner to show cause why it should not be revoked, at a hearing before the city council. Such notice to the owner shall be in writing and shall state the reason for revocation and the time and place of the hearing. 
(b)  The remedies provided in this section are not exclusive, and if any section of this article is violated by the owner, the city may proceed in any manner authorized by law, including the procedure set forth in NMSA 1978, §§ 3-38-5 and 3-38-6. 
(Code 1969, § 31-13) 
ARTICLE 12. - LODGERS' TAX[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Finance, § 2-5-1 et seq. 
State Law reference- Lodgers Tax Act, NMSA 1978, §§ 3-38-13-3-38-24. 

Sec. 8-12-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Board means the lodgers' tax advisory board. 
    Gross taxable rent means the total amount of rent paid for lodging, not including gross receipts tax or local sales tax. 
    Lodgers' tax. See Occupancy tax. 
    Lodging means the transaction of furnishing rooms or other accommodations by a vendor to a vendee who for rent uses, possesses or has the right to use or possess any room or other unit of accommodation in or at a taxable premises. 
    Lodgings means the rooms or other accommodations furnished by a vendor to a vendee by the taxable service of lodging. 
    Occupancy tax means the tax, also known as lodgers' tax, on lodging, authorized by this article. 
    Person means a corporation, firm, other body corporate, partnership, association or individual, including an executor, administrator, trustee, receiver or other representative appointed according to law and acting in a representative capacity, but not including the United States, the state, any corporation, department, instrumentality or agency of the federal government or the state government, or any political subdivision of the state. 
    Rent means the consideration received by a vendor in money, credits, property or other consideration valued in money for lodgings subject to an occupancy tax authorized in this article.
