(e)  Status of disaster successors. A person designated as a disaster successor holds that designation at the pleasure of the designator, provided that he must be replaced if removed. He retains his designation as disaster successor until replaced by another appointed by the authorized designator. 
(Code 1969, § 9-9) 
Sec. 10-3-3. - Assumption of powers and duties of officer by disaster successor. 
    If an attack occurs, if any officer named in subsections 10-3-2(a) and (b) is unavailable, his disaster successor highest in rank in order of succession who is available shall exercise the powers and discharge the duties of such officer. The disaster successor shall exercise these powers and discharge these duties only until such time as the lawful incumbent officer or a disaster successor higher in rank in order of succession exercises or resumes the exercise of the powers and discharge of the duties of the office or until, where an actual vacancy exists, a successor is appointed to fill such vacancy or is elected and qualified by law. 
(Code 1969, § 9-10) 
Sec. 10-3-4. - Record of successors. 
    The incumbent, his address and rank and the order of succession of each disaster successor under this article shall be filed with the county clerk, and each designation, replacement, or change in order of succession of a disaster successor shall become effective when the designator files with the county clerk the successor's name, address and rank in order of succession. The city clerk shall keep on file all such data regarding duly authorized disaster successors, and such file shall be open to public inspection. 
(Code 1969, § 9-11) 
Sec. 10-3-5. - Formalities of taking office. 
    At the time of their designation, disaster successors named pursuant to this article shall take such oath and shall do such other things, if any, as may be required to qualify them to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office to which they may succeed. 
(Code 1969, § 9-12) 
Chapter 11 - COURT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; civil emergencies, ch. 10; law enforcement, ch. 15; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 18; traffic and vehicles, ch. 25. 
State Law reference- Municipal courts, NMSA 1978, § 35-14-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE 2. - MUNICIPAL JUDGE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-3-1 et seq. 

Sec. 11-2-1. - Creation of office; qualifications; vacancies. 
(a)  The Farmington Municipal Court shall have two municipal court judges. They shall be known as municipal judge I and municipal judge II. Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, both the municipal judge I and the municipal judge II shall exercise such rights and shall perform such duties as are set forth in this chapter or prescribed by law. 
(b)  Municipal judges shall be qualified electors and residents of the city. 
(c)  No person shall be eligible for election or appointment to the office of municipal judge unless such person shall have graduated from high school or shall have attained the equivalent of a high school education as indicated by possession of a certificate of equivalency issued by the state department of public education based upon the record made on the General Education Development Test. 
(d)  Municipal judges shall, before taking office, take and subscribe an oath or affirmation in writing to support the constitution and laws of the United States and the state and the laws of the city, and to impartially discharge and perform all of the duties of such office to the best of his ability, which oath of office shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(e)  If a vacancy occurs during the term of a municipal judge, the city council may appoint a duly qualified person to serve until the next regular municipal election. 
(Code 1969, § 2-28; Ord. No. 98-1087, § 1, 11-24-98) 
State Law reference- Qualifications, bond, salary of municipal judge, NMSA 1978, § 35-14-3; election, term and vacancy of municipal judge, NMSA 1978, § 35-14-4. 
Sec. 11-2-2. - Salary; duties; administration; training. 
(a)  The salary for the municipal judge I for each term of office shall be 90 percent of that authorized by law to be paid to a state magistrate judge upon the date of the election of the municipal judge I to that position. The municipal judge I shall be provided benefits and accrue leave on the same basis as a regular full-time city employee. The salary for the municipal judge II for each term of office shall be 40 percent of that authorized by law to be paid to a magistrate judge upon the date of the election of the municipal judge II to that position. The municipal judge II shall be provided benefits and accrue leave on the same basis as a regular part-time city employee. 
(b)  The municipal judge I shall act as the presiding judge for the court and shall devote full time and attention to the office, including such hours on weekends and holidays as may be necessary in order to fully and efficiently discharge the duties of such office as they may be set forth under the laws of the United States, the state and the city. As the presiding judge, the municipal judge I shall exercise control over the administrative functions of the court, shall assign cases, schedule court sessions, set sentencing guidelines, adopt local rules, supervise court personnel and generally be responsible for the efficient operation of the court. The municipal judge II shall devote at least 20 hours a week to the duties of office, working such hours and performing such duties as shall be assigned by the municipal judge I. Both judges shall comply with the Code of Judicial Conduct or any similar code that shall be adopted by the state for the conduct of judges in the state and shall follow all rules of procedure for the municipal courts as may be promulgated by the state supreme court. 
(c)  Any attorney serving as municipal judge I is prohibited from engaging in the private practice of law. Nor shall any such person serving as municipal judge I hold any other political office or engage in any other business or employment during such service. Any attorney serving as municipal judge II may engage in the private practice of law, provided that such person shall avoid undertaking any representation involving matters that will come before the municipal court. 
(d)  The municipal judge I, or in his absence the municipal judge II, shall make monthly reports to the city council of all moneys collected by the municipal court. The reports shall include an itemized statement showing the different amounts collected, the purpose of collection, and the name of the person and the date of payment by such person. Such reports shall be filed with and the moneys collected in connection therewith shall be paid to the city treasurer not later than the tenth day of the month following collection. 
(e)  Both municipal judges shall annually, as a condition of discharging the duties of their office, successfully complete a judicial training program approved according to law, unless exempted from this requirement by the chief justice of the supreme court. No municipal judge shall receive a salary until such judge has successfully completed or has been exempted from the required judicial training program. 
(Code 1969, § 2-30; Ord. No. 98-1087, § 2, 11-24-98; Ord. No. 01-1123, § 1, 6-26-01) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 3-14-6-3-14-8. 
Sec. 11-2-3. - Temporary vacancy and appointments. 
(a)  If a temporary incapacity or absence of a duly elected or appointed municipal judge occurs, the municipal judge I may appoint a temporary municipal judge to serve during the temporary incapacity or absence of the elected municipal judge from a list of registered voters designated by the council as provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Appointments of the temporary municipal judge shall be made: 
(1)  In writing by the regularly elected municipal judge and filed in the office of the city clerk and in the office of the municipal court clerk. 
(2)  From a list to be prepared in the month of April of each year by the city council of persons designated by the council as qualified to act as temporary municipal judge, which list shall be reflected by motion duly made, passed and adopted and reflected in the minutes of the city council. 
(Code 1969, § 2-31; Ord. No. 98-1087, § 3, 11-24-98) 
Sec. 11-2-4. - Jurisdiction. 
(a)  The municipal court shall have jurisdiction over all offenses and complaints under city ordinances and may issue subpoenas and warrants and may punish for contempt. 
(b)  The municipal court shall have jurisdiction over violation of campus traffic or parking regulations if there is a written agreement entered into between a state educational institution or post-secondary educational institution and the city as provided by state law. 
(c)  The municipal court's personal jurisdiction extends to any defendant who has been properly served with criminal process of the court anywhere in the state if that criminal process arises out of a charge of violation of a municipal ordinance prohibiting driving while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or drugs. 
(Code 1969, § 2-29; Ord. No. 2011-1250, § 1, 10-25-11) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 35-14-2. 
Sec. 11-2-5. - Complaints and warrants. 
    All complaints filed with and all warrants issued by the municipal judge shall be filed and issued in conformity with the state statutes and the rules of court governing the prosecution of suits in municipal courts (Rules of Municipal Courts, Judicial Volume 1 NMSA 1978). 
(Code 1969, § 2-32) 
ARTICLE 3. - SENTENCING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 11-3-1. - Imprisonment for nonpayment of fine; credit for days spent in jail. 
    The municipal judge rendering a judgment of conviction against any person for the violation of this Code or any other city ordinance shall, if the fine is not paid at once, order that such person be committed to the city jail until such fine shall be fully paid. Except as otherwise provided by law, no such imprisonment shall exceed 90 days for any one offense or more than one day for each $10.00 for such fine assessed and not paid. Any allowance made to any person committed to the city jail for work or labor performed by him shall be in addition to the allowance provided in this section for time spent by such person in the city jail. 
(Code 1969, § 10-1-2; Ord. No. 98-1086, § 1, 11-24-98) 
Sec. 11-3-2. - Prisoners required to work. 
(a)  Every person committed to jail by the municipal judge for the violation of any city ordinance or this Code shall be required to work for the city at such labor as his strength will permit, either within or without the jail. 
(b)  Prisoners incarcerated for failure to pay fines or in lieu of payment of fines shall receive credit for such incarceration in an amount equal to eight times the current federal minimum wage for each days incarceration. 
(c)  Labor by prisoners shall be performed under the direction of the chief of police or the administrator of the San Juan County Detention Center, or other place provided by the city for the incarceration of offenders, and such prisoner shall be required to work not exceeding ten hours each working day. Prisoners who perform labor shall receive credit for hours worked toward the payment of any fine calculated at the amount of eight times the current federal minimum wage per day. Such credit shall not be in addition to the credit awarded pursuant to section 11-3-2(b). 
(d)  No person incarcerated for nonpayment of fines or in lieu of fines shall be held more than 60 days, even though the fines or costs, or both, exceed the amount credited toward repayment during those 60 days. 
(Code 1969, § 10-1-3; Ord. No. 98-1086, § 2, 11-24-98; Ord. No. 01-1124, §§ 1, 2, 6-26-01) 
Sec. 11-3-3. - Procedure upon arrest generally; citation or summons as first process in certain cases. 
(a)  In any action for the violation of any city ordinance this Code in which an arrest has not been made, a warrant for the arrest of the defendant may issue in the first instance upon the affidavit of any person making a complaint that he has reasonable grounds to believe the person charged is guilty. Any person arrested upon such warrant shall, without unnecessary delay, be taken before the municipal judge to be tried for the alleged offense or be allowed to post an appropriate bond. 
(b)  The first process shall be a citation or summons in cases involving violations of any city ordinance or section of this Code not amounting to a breach of the peace, requiring the party charged to appear before the municipal court at a time fixed in the citation or summons. Upon the failure of the person charged to appear, a warrant for his arrest shall forthwith issue by the municipal judge for the offense specified in the citation or summons, commanding that the person charged shall be arrested and proceedings had as when arrest is made upon a warrant issued upon affidavit as provided in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  If any person has been issued a penalty assessment pursuant to the provisions of the motor vehicle and traffic code or pursuant to any other statute, ordinance or rule of court authorizing a penalty assessment which provides that a defendant may enter a plea without a hearing, waive the right to trial and pay the prescribed penalty, the person may elect to do so after the effect of such action and the amount of the penalty to be paid has been explained to such person by the officer issuing the penalty assessment citation. This shall be evidenced by the signature of the person under a statement declaring his intention to do so, appearing on the penalty citation in such form as may be prescribed by law. The officer issuing the citation shall also provide the person making this election with a business reply envelope addressed to the municipal court. Any person electing to pay a penalty assessment who does not remit the appropriate penalty to the municipal court within five days of the date of signature on the penalty assessment citation evidencing the choice to plead and waive the right to trial shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(d)  If a citation has been conspicuously affixed to a vehicle pursuant to section 25-2-42, the presumption established by section 25-2-43 shall apply, and the owner and operator of the vehicle shall answer the citation in the same manner set forth in subsection (b) of this section as if the citation were personally served to the owner and operator. However, the schedule of penalties and instructions to the defendant printed upon the traffic parking citation shall be notice thereof and shall serve as the explanation required by subsection (b) of this section, as if it had been read and explained to the owner and the operator of the vehicle by the officer, and the registered owner shall be notified as provided in section 25-2-42 prior to the issuance of a warrant for the arrest of such owner. 
(e)  Notwithstanding subsections (a), (b) and (c) of this section or the provisions of Chapter 25 pertaining to traffic and motor vehicles, a police officer may require a person named as a defendant to immediately appear before the municipal judge or the designee of the municipal judge to determine the conditions of such person's release, if the police officer has reasonable cause to believe that: 
(1)  Such person will or is about to flee the jurisdiction of the municipal court and will not appear before the court as directed. 
(2)  Such person has failed or refused to sufficiently identify himself or to supply the required information for identification. 
(3)  Such person refuses to sign a notice to appear as requested. 
(4)  The continued liberty of such person constitutes an unreasonable risk of bodily harm to himself or to others. 
(5)  Such person is not a resident of the city or has no ties with the jurisdiction of the municipal court reasonably sufficient to ensure the appearance of such person or there is substantial risk that such person will refuse or fail to appear before the court or pay the penalty assessment as directed. 
(6)  Such person may be wanted in another jurisdiction. 
(7)  Such person has previously failed to respond to a citation or a summons or has violated the conditions of any pretrial release program. 
(8)  Such person has indicated that he will not, in fact, pay any penalty assessment agreed to by such person. 
(Code 1969, § 10-1-4) 
Sec. 11-3-4. - Authority of certain officials to issue citations as first process. 
(a)  The following city officials are authorized to issue citations as first process in lieu of summons upon forms approved by the municipal court for violations of the city ordinances or this Code: 
(1)  Police officers. 
(2)  Special police officers, when performing duties within their limited authority pursuant to sections 15-3-1 through 15-3-9 of the City Code. 
(3)  Community service officers. 
(4)  Park rangers-animal control officers. 
(5)  Code compliance and zoning compliance officers. 
(6)  Fire chief, assistant chiefs, captains and lieutenants, when performing duties pursuant to section 13-2-3. 
(7)  Educational institution security personnel that have been commissioned pursuant to section 15-5-1 of the City Code. 
(b)  Such persons shall not be authorized to issue any citation except within the scope of their duties as defined in this Code or, if not so defined, as limited by their traditional duties and expertise. This subsection shall not apply to police officers, nor shall it apply to the enforcement of section 25-4-2 or 25-4-3 by the listed code compliance and fire personnel. 
(c)  This section shall not be construed as a limitation upon the power of any such person or official to seek or pursue any other lawful process or legal remedy. 
(Code 1969, § 10-1-5; Ord. No. 03-1153, § 1, 11-11-03; Ord. No. 2011-1250, §§ 2, 3, 10-25-11) 
Sec. 11-3-5. - Continuing violation, warning notice. 
(a)  If an alleged violation of any city ordinance or this Code is of a continuing nature, a citation shall not be issued unless the alleged offender has first been given a written warning notice not more than 30 days and not less than five days prior to the issuance of the citation. Such warning shall set forth the section of the ordinance or this Code alleged to have been violated. Such warning notice shall not be required of police officers or in the authorized enforcement of the parking sections of Chapter 25 or of Chapter 6 pertaining to animals or for any offense which presents an immediate danger to public health, safety or welfare. 
(b)  Correction of or reasonable action taken toward the correction of conditions constituting an offense shall be taken into consideration by the issuing officer in determining whether a citation should be issued or by the court in mitigation of any penalty for an offense. 
(Code 1969, § 10-1-6) 
Sec. 11-3-6. - Bail bonds. 
    Whenever any person shall have been arrested under this Code or any other city ordinance and for any reason a continuance or postponement of the trial in such cause shall be granted, the municipal judge shall admit such person to bail upon the execution and filing of a bond with good and sufficient sureties, conditioned upon the appearance of such person at the time and place of trial, and from time to time thereafter until such time as the cause shall have been finally determined. 
(Code 1969, § 10-1-7) 
Sec. 11-3-7. - Jury trial not allowed. 
    All causes under this Code or any other city ordinance shall be tried before the municipal judge, and no jury trial shall be allowed in any case. 
(Code 1969, § 10-1-8) 
Sec. 11-3-8. - Election between sections of Code. 
    When the same offense shall be created or shall be punishable by and under different chapters or sections of this Code or any other city ordinance, the prosecuting officers shall elect under which section to proceed, and no more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same offense, but nothing in this section shall prevent the same act from constituting two or more separate and distinct offenses under this Code or any other city ordinance, each punishable separately. The fact that a repeated or continuing offense has been once punished shall not be any defense to prosecution for the continuance or repetition of such offense thereafter. 
(Code 1969, § 10-1-9) 
Secs. 11-3-9-11-3-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ALTERNATIVES 

Sec. 11-3-36. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Deferral of sentence means the postponement by the court, upon such conditions as the court may impose, of any sentencing determination for a specified period of time. If the court's conditions are met for the requisite time, the charge against the defendant shall be dismissed without imposition of any sentence. 
    Probation means the system or procedure under which a person found guilty of an offense upon judgment or plea is released by the court, without imprisonment, subject to such terms and conditions as the court may impose. 
    Probation officer means a person designated by the municipal judge to make a presentence report, to supervise a person placed on probation or to otherwise act as a probation officer with regard to the imposition of probation pursuant to this division. 
    Suspension of sentence means an act of the municipal court whereby any sentence which may be imposed by the court for the violation of this Code or any other city ordinance is announced by the court, but the execution of such sentence is suspended with the imposition of conditions by the court. 
(Code 1969, § 10-2-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-1-2. 
Sec. 11-3-37. - Presentence investigations; police cooperation. 
    The municipal court may in its discretion order a presentence investigation for a person convicted of any offense. Whenever an investigation is required, the probation officer shall promptly inquire into the circumstances of the offense; the attitude of the complainant; and the criminal record, social history and the present mental and physical condition of the person. The police department shall furnish to the probation officer such criminal records as the probation officer may request. Where in the opinion of the court it is desirable, the investigation shall include a physical and a mental examination of the person. 
(Code 1969, § 10-2-2) 
Sec. 11-3-38. - Suspension of sentence; probation. 
(a)  The municipal court may, upon entry of a plea of guilty or nolo contendere or judgment of conviction: 
(1)  Suspend in whole or in part the execution of sentence; 
(2)  Place a person on probation for a period not exceeding one year on terms and conditions the court deems best, or both; or 
(3)  Defer sentencing for a period of not more than one year. 
(b)  The suspension of execution of the sentence or probation or both shall be granted only when the municipal judge is satisfied it will serve the ends of justice and of the public and that the person's liability for any fine or other punishment imposed is fully discharged upon successful completion of the terms and conditions of probation. 
(Code 1969, § 10-2-4) 
Sec. 11-3-39. - Revocation of probation. 
    If upon a hearing to revoke probation a probationer or defendant is found by the municipal court to have violated the terms of his probation or to have violated the terms or conditions of the suspension of his sentence or deferral of sentence, the court may continue or revoke the probation or suspension of the execution of the sentence, and the court may impose any sentence which might have originally been imposed. 
(Code 1969, § 10-2-5) 
Sec. 11-3-40. - Community service. 
    As used in this section, the term "community service" means any labor that benefits the public at large or any public, charitable or educational entity or institution. The municipal court may, as a condition of probation, require the convicted defendant to serve a period of volunteer labor to be known as community service. The type of labor and period of service shall be at the sole discretion of the court. Any person receiving community service shall be immune from any civil liability other than gross negligence arising out of the community service, and any person who performs community service pursuant to court order or any criminal diversion program shall not be entitled to any wages, shall not be considered an employee for any purpose, and shall not be entitled to worker's compensation, unemployment benefits or any other benefits otherwise provided by law. 
(Code 1969, § 10-2-6) 
Chapter 12 - ENVIRONMENT[1] 
Footnotes:

State Law reference- Environmental Improvement Act, NMSA 1978, § 74-1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE 2. - NUISANCES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Public nuisances, § 18-5-11; nuisances on property, § 23-1-4. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate and prohibit industrial nuisances, NMSA 1978, § 3-18-13; authority to define and abate nuisances, NMSA 1978, § 3-18-17. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 12-2-1-12-2-25. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WEEDS AND DEBRIS 

Sec. 12-2-26. - Duty of property owner. 
    It shall be unlawful and a violation of this Code for the owner, agent, lessee or occupant of any lot, tract or parcel of land within the city to allow weeds, grass, bushes or deleterious, noxious or unhealthful growths to lie, grow or be located upon any such property or along any street or avenue adjoining the property between the property line and the curbline thereof or on or along any alley adjoining the property between the property line and the center of such alley. However, such prohibition shall not apply to lands primarily agricultural in nature, except that owners of such lands shall be required to keep weeds down between the property line of such property and the center of any right-of-way and shall be required to keep the weeds down within 20 feet of any subdivision or area that is being kept weed free. 
(Code 1969, § 13-30) 
Sec. 12-2-27. - Accumulation of refuse. 
    It shall be unlawful and a violation of this Code for the owner, agent, lessee or occupant of any lot, tract or parcel of land within the city to allow refuse, rubbish, garbage, trash, solid waste or unsightly debris to accumulate upon such property. 
(Code 1969, § 13-31) 
Sec. 12-2-28. - Resolution of city council finding premises covered with ruins, rubbish, wreckage or debris. 
(a)  The city shall, when informed that any premises or property within the city is covered with ruins, rubbish, wreckage or debris, cause an investigation to be made into the premises and shall make findings with reference to such investigation. 
(b)  If the city, as a result of any such investigation, finds that any premises, tract of land or property within the city is covered with ruins, rubbish, wreckage or debris and that such premises are a menace to the public comfort, health, peace or safety of the city, the city shall adopt a resolution which shall: 
(1)  Include such findings; 
(2)  Order and direct the owner, occupant or agent in charge of such property or premises to remove such ruins, rubbish, wreckage or debris from such premises and from the city; 
(3)  Notify the owner, occupant or agent in charge of such property or premises that such owner, occupant or agent in charge must commence removing such ruin, rubbish, refuse, wreckage or debris within ten days of the receipt of a copy of the resolution or of the posting and publishing of a copy of the resolution or file a written objection with the city clerk asking for a hearing upon such resolution before the city council; 
(4)  Notify such owner, occupant or agent in charge of such property or premises that, if such written objection is filed, the city council shall: 
a.  Fix a date for a hearing upon its resolution and such objection; 
b.  Consider all evidence for and against the removal resolution at the hearing; and 
c.  Determine if the resolution should be enforced or rescinded; 
(5)  Notify the owner, occupant or agent in charge of such property or premises that such owner, occupant or agent in charge may appeal to the district court from any determination of the city council by giving notice of appeal to the city council within five days after determination made by the city council and by filing a petition in the district court within 20 days after determination made by the city council; and 
(6)  Notify such owner, occupant or agent in charge of such property or premises if such owner, occupant or agent in charge fails to commence the removal of such ruins, rubbish, wreckage or debris: 
a.  Within ten days of being served a copy of the resolution or of the posting and publishing of the resolution; 
b.  Within five days of the determination by the city council following objection by the owner and hearing upon the matter as provided in this section that the resolution shall be enforced; or 
c.  After the district court enters judgment sustaining the determination of the city council. 
(c)  The city will remove such ruins, rubbish, wreckage or debris at the cost and expense of the owner of such property, and the reasonable cost of the removal thereof shall constitute a lien against the lot, parcel of land and premises from which it was removed. Such lien shall be subject to foreclosure in the manner provided in NMSA 1978, §§ 3-36-1-3-36-6. 
(Code 1969, § 13-32) 
Sec. 12-2-29. - Service and publication of resolution. 
    A copy of the resolution adopted by the city council pursuant to subsection 12-2-28(b) shall be served upon the owner, occupant or agent in charge of the property or premises. If the owner, as shown by the real estate records of the county clerk, occupant or agent in charge of the real estate or premises cannot be served within the city, a copy of the resolution shall be posted upon the premises and a copy of the resolution shall be published one time in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
(Code 1969, § 13-33) 
Sec. 12-2-30. - Failure to remove. 
(a)  As provided in this division, the city may remove such ruins, rubbish, refuse, wreckage or debris at the cost and the expense of the owner if the owner, occupant or agent in charge of any property or premises within the city fails to commence the removal of ruins, rubbish, refuse, weeds, wreckage or debris upon such property: 
(1)  Within ten days of being served a copy of the resolution adopted pursuant to subsection 12-2-28(b) or of the posting and publication of the resolution, unless such time is extended by the filing of a written objection with the city clerk; 
(2)  Within five days of a determination by the city council that its resolution shall be in force; or 
(3)  After the district judge enters judgment sustaining the determination by the city council. 
(b)  If the city performs the work as provided in subsection (a) of this section, the reasonable cost of such removal shall constitute a lien against such lot, parcel, real estate or premises and against the ruin, rubbish, refuse, weeds, wreckage or debris so removed therefrom. 
(c)  The city attorney shall prepare and file in the records of the county clerk an appropriate claim of lien which shall be subject to foreclosure in the manner provided in NMSA 1978, §§ 3-36-1-3-36-6. 
(d)  With the consent of the owner, the city may pay for costs of removal of any such wreckage, rubbish, refuse, weeds, debris by granting to the person removing such material the legal title to all salvageable material in lieu of all other compensation. In such case, any person removing any such rubbish or debris shall leave the premises from which the material has been removed in a clean, level and safe condition, suitable for further occupancy or construction and with all excavations filled. 
(Code 1969, § 13-34) 
Sec. 12-2-31. - Additional penalty. 
    The fact that assessments have been made against property as provided for in this division shall not prevent the owner, agent or lessee from being punished by fine or jail under section 1-1-10, but such fine or penalty may be imposed on those found guilty of violating this division in all cases, whether an assessment has or has not been made in accordance with this division. 
(Code 1969, § 13-35) 
Secs. 12-2-32-12-2-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - WRECKED, JUNKED OR NONOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLES 

Sec. 12-2-56. - Presumption. 
(a)  Any motor vehicle that does not display a currently effective license plate, registration permit, or any motor vehicle that is dismantled, nonoperating, wrecked or junked, or that is on blocks, jacks or other supports is presumed to be nonoperating, within the meaning of section 12-2-57. 
(b)  Any motor vehicle, including one used for racing purposes, that does not conform to the equipment requirements of this Code and that shows visible body damage is presumed to be a wrecked vehicle for the purposes of section 12-2-57. 
(Code 1969, § 19-77; Ord. No. 2011-1239, § 1, 2-22-2011) 
Sec. 12-2-57. - Leaving on street or private property. 
(a)  No person shall leave any partially dismantled, nonoperating, wrecked or junked motor vehicle on any street or highway within the city. 
(b)  No person in charge or control of any property within the city, whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee or otherwise, shall allow any partially dismantled, nonoperating, wrecked, junked or discarded motor vehicle to remain on such property longer than 48 hours, and no person shall leave any such vehicle on any property within the city for a longer time than 48 hours. However, this section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Any vehicle in an enclosed building, enclosed structure, or that is obscured by fencing, landscaping, screens, or that is covered with a tarp or car cover that makes the vehicle not visible from any other public or private property. 
(2)  Vehicles upon the premises of a business enterprise operated in a lawful place and manner which are necessary to the operation of the business enterprise and which otherwise comply with parking provisions of the Unified Development Code, provided that such vehicles shall not remain on such property longer than a period of six months. 
(3)  Vehicles located in an appropriate storage place or depository maintained in a lawful place and manner by the city. 
(4)  Vehicles in an appropriate storage area authorized by the Unified Development Code or other similar city ordinances. 
(Code 1969, § 19-78; Ord. No. 2007-1184, 9-8-10; Ord. No. 2011-1239, § 2, 2-22-2011) 
ARTICLE 3. - AIR POLLUTION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Clean Indoor Air Act, NMSA 1978, § 24-16-1 et seq.; Air Quality Control Act, NMSA 1978, § 74-2-1 et seq. 

Sec. 12-3-1. - Short title. 
    This article may be cited as the "Clean Indoor Air Ordinance." 
(Code 1969, § 9A-1-1) 
Sec. 12-3-2. - Legislative findings. 
(a)  The city council finds the 1986 and 2006 Surgeon General's Reports concludes that tobacco smoke is a major contributor to indoor air pollution; that breathing secondhand smoke is a cause of disease, including lung cancer in healthy nonsmokers; that separation of people and tobacco smoke within the same air space may reduce but does not eliminate exposure to environmental tobacco smoke. 
(b)  The council further finds the 1986 and 2006 Surgeon General's Reports conclude that the risk of disease from environmental tobacco smoke is related to the level of exposure over time, and, therefore, a reduction of smoke in city buildings, public places and places of employment constitute a public health priority. 
(c)  The council further finds it necessary to restrict smoking in specific areas not covered by the state Clean Indoor Air Act, NMSA 1978, § 24-16-1 et seq., which calls for no smoking in public places except in certain designated areas. 
(Code 1969, § 9A-1-2; Ord. No. 2006-1173, § 1, 8-22-06) 
Sec. 12-3-3. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to: 
(1)  Recognize public health as a priority. 
(2)  Protect the public health and safety by regulating the burning of tobacco in city buildings, public places, and places of employment. 
(3)  Protect employees' and customers' rights to be free from secondhand smoke by regulating the burning of tobacco in city buildings, public places and places of employment. 
(Code 1969, § 9A-1-3; Ord. No. 2006-1173, § 2, 8-22-06) 
Sec. 12-3-4. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business means a sole proprietorship, partnership, joint venture, corporation, or other business entity, either for profit or nonprofit, including retail establishments where goods or services are sold as well as professional corporations and other entities where legal, medical, dental, engineering, architectural, or other professional services are delivered. 
    Common area means any enclosed area designated or otherwise allowed to be used for the mutual enjoyment of a general public or for customers or patrons in general. 
    Designated outdoor smoking area means any area where smoking may be permitted, designated by an employer or manager, outside an enclosed indoor workplace or enclosed indoor public place, provided that smoking shall not be permitted near any building entrance, including a door, window or ventilation system of any facility where smoking is prohibited under the provisions of this Clean Indoor Air Ordinance, so as to disallow secondhand smoke from entering the enclosed indoor workplace or enclosed indoor public place. 
    Employee means a person who is employed by an employer in consideration for direct or indirect monetary wages or profit, and a person who volunteers his or her services for a nonprofit entity. 
    Employer means a person, business, partnership, association, corporation, including a municipal corporation, trust, or nonprofit entity that employs the services of one or more individual persons. 
    Enclosed area means all space between a floor and ceiling that is enclosed on all sides by solid walls or windows (exclusive of doorways), which extends from the floor to the ceiling. 
    Health care facility means an office or institution providing care or treatment of diseases, whether physical, mental, or emotional, or other medical, physiological, or psychological conditions, including but not limited to, hospitals, rehabilitation hospitals or other clinics, including weight control clinics, nursing homes, homes for the aging or chronically ill, laboratories, and offices of surgeons, chiropractors, physical therapists, physicians, dentists, and all specialists within these professions. This definition shall include all waiting rooms, hallways, private rooms, semiprivate rooms and wards within health care facilities. 
    Physically separated means separated from smoke-free public places by continuous floor-to-ceiling walls which are interrupted only by entrances or exits to smoking areas that are equipped with doors that can be closed when not in use. 
    Place of employment means an area under the control of a public or private employer that employees normally frequent during the course of employment, including, but not limited to, work areas, employee lounges, restrooms, conference rooms, meeting rooms, classrooms, employee cafeterias and hallways. A private residence is not a "place of employment" unless it is used as a child care, adult day care, or health care facility. 
    Private club means any nonprofit group, including fraternal organizations and an auxiliary or subsidiary group organized and operated under the laws of this state with a membership of not less than fifty members who pay membership dues at the rate of not less than $5.00 per year and who, under the constitution and bylaws of the club, have all voting rights and full membership privileges and is the owner or lessor of premises used exclusively for club purposes operated solely for recreation, social, patriotic, political, benevolent or athletic purposes and has been granted an exemption by the United States from the payment of federal income tax as a club under the provisions of section 501 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. 
    Private residence means any place of abode that is more than temporary and that is presumed and recognized as one's domicile, regardless of temporary absence. 
    Public place means an enclosed area to which the public is invited or in which the public is permitted, including but not limited to, banks, churches, convenience stores, educational facilities, health care facilities, hotel and motel lobbies, laundromats, public transportation facilities, reception areas, restaurants, retail food production and marketing establishments, retail service establishments, retail stores, shopping malls, sports arenas, theaters, and waiting rooms. A private residence is not a "public place" unless it is used as a child care, adult day care or health care facility. 
    Public transit depot means an enclosed area for the purchase of tickets, boarding or public waiting for the use of public transportation. 
    Restaurant means an eating establishment, including but not limited to, coffee shops, cafeterias, sandwich stands, and private and public school cafeterias, which gives or offers for sale food to the public, guests, or employees, as well as kitchens and catering facilities in which food is prepared on the premises for serving elsewhere. 
    Service line means an indoor line in which one or more persons are waiting for or receiving service of any kind, whether or not the service involves the exchange of money. 
    Shopping mall means an enclosed public walkway or hall area that serves to connect retail or professional establishments. 
    Smokefree means that there shall be no smoking within an enclosed area. 
    Smoking means inhaling, exhaling, or burning any lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe or other combustible tobacco product. 
    Sports arena means sports pavilions, stadiums, gymnasiums, health spas, boxing arenas, swimming pools, roller and ice rinks, bowling alleys, and other similar places where members of the general public assemble to engage in physical exercise, participate in athletic competition, or witness sports or other events. 
(Code 1969, § 9A-1-4; Ord. No. 2006-1173, § 3, 8-22-06) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-1-2. 
Sec. 12-3-5. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  A person who smokes in an area where smoking is prohibited by the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a violation of this article punishable by a fine not exceeding $50.00 for each separate offense. 
(b)  A person who owns, manages, operates, or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment and who knowingly fails to comply with the provisions of this ordinance shall be guilty of a violation of this article, punishable by: 
(1)  A fine not exceeding $100.00 for a first violation. 
(2)  A fine not exceeding $200.00 for a second violation occurring within one year of the first. 
(3)  A fine not exceeding $500.00 for each additional violation occurring within one year of the previous violation. 
(c)  The city attorney, at the request of a municipal official, in addition to other remedies, may institute an action or proceeding to enjoin, restrain, correct or abate the violation of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 9A-1-10; Ord. No. 2006-1173, § 4, 8-22-06) 
Sec. 12-3-6. - Enforcement. 
    Enforcement of this article shall be by citation from the police department, the fire emergency services department or code compliance. Notice of the provisions of this ordinance shall be given to all applicants for a business license in the City of Farmington. Any citizen who desires to register a complaint under this article may initiate enforcement with code compliance. The fire department, or designee, during other mandated inspections, shall inspect the premises for compliance with this article. An owner, manager, operator, person in control of the premises, or employee of an establishment regulated by this article shall inform persons violating this article of the appropriate provisions hereof. In addition to the remedies provided by the provisions of this section, the city attorney or any person aggrieved by the failure of the owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of a public place or a place of employment to comply with the provisions of this article may apply for injunctive relief to enforce the provisions in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1969, § 9A-1-11; Ord. No. 2006-1173, § 5, 8-22-06) 
Sec. 12-3-7. - Inspection of premises; violation notices. 
(a)  Whenever necessary to make an inspection to enforce this article or whenever an enforcement officer, as defined in section 12-3-6, has reasonable cause to believe that there exists in any building or upon any premises any violation, the enforcement officer may enter the building or premises at all reasonable times to inspect the premises or to perform any such duties imposed upon the enforcement officer by this article. However, if any such building or premises is occupied, he shall first present proper credentials and request entry, and if such building or premises is unoccupied, he shall first make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or other person having charge or control of the building or premises and request entry. If such entry is refused, the enforcement officer is required to obtain an inspectorial search warrant as described in the state Public Health Act, NMSA 1978, §§ 24-1-16-24-1-19. 
(b)  The procedure set forth in NMSA 1978, §§ 24-1-16-24-1-19, is incorporated by reference into this article as a method whereby enforcement officers may enter premises to enforce this article. 
(Code 1969, § 9A-1-12; Ord. No. 2006-1173, § 6, 8-22-06) 
Sec. 12-3-8. - Smoking in public places. 
    Subject to the exceptions provided in this article, smoking shall be prohibited in all enclosed public places within the City of Farmington, including but not limited to, the following public places: 
(1)  All common areas of airports. All airport restaurants will abide by smoking regulations established in this article for all other restaurants. All offices and exclusive leasehold areas within the airports that are not public places will abide by smoking regulations established in this article for places of employment. 
(2)  Areas available to and customarily used by the general public in businesses and nonprofit entities patronized by the public, including, but not limited to, professional offices, banks, laundromats, hotels and motels. 
(3)  Bingo facilities. 
(4)  Buses and other means of public transit under the authority of the city; taxicabs; and ticket, boarding, and waiting areas of public transit depots. However, this prohibition does not prevent the establishment of having enclosed separate waiting areas for smoking. 
(5)  Convention facilities, including the City of Farmington Civic Center. 
(6)  Educational facilities, both public and private, excluding residences used to "home school" children living in the residence. 
(7)  Elevators. 
(8)  Every room, chamber, place of meeting or public assembly under the control of the city during such time as a public meeting is in progress. 
(9)  Facilities primarily used for exhibiting a motion picture, stage, drama, lecture, musical recital, or other similar performance. 
(10)  Galleries, libraries and museums. 
(11)  Hospitals and health care facilities. 
(12)  Hotel and motel lobbies. 
(13)  Licensed child care and adult day care facilities. 
(14)  Lobbies, hallways, and other common areas in apartment buildings, condominiums, trailer parks, retirement facilities, nursing homes, and other multiple-unit residential facilities. 
(15)  Polling places during elections. 
(16)  Restaurants. 
(17)  Restrooms, lobbies, reception areas, hallways, and other common-use areas. 
(18)  Retail stores. 
(19)  Rooms, chambers, places of meeting or public assembly, including school buildings, under the control of an agency, board, commission, committee or council of the city or a political subdivision of the state, to the extent the place is subject to the jurisdiction of the City of Farmington. 
(20)  Service lines. 
(21)  Shopping malls. 
(22)  Sports arenas, including enclosed places in outdoor arenas. 
(Code 1969, § 9A-1-5; Ord. No. 2006-1173, § 7, 8-22-06) 
Sec. 12-3-9. - Smoking in places of employment. 
    Except as provided in section 12-3-11(5) below, smoking shall be prohibited in all enclosed facilities within places of employment. This includes common work areas, auditoriums, classrooms, conference and meeting rooms, private offices, elevators, hallways, medical facilities, cafeterias, employee lounges, stairs, restrooms and all other enclosed facilities. 
(Ord. No. 2006-1173, § 8, 8-22-06) 
Sec. 12-3-10. - Reasonable distance. 
    Smoking shall be prohibited near entrances, windows and ventilation systems of all worksites and public places where smoking is prohibited by this Clean Indoor Air Ordinance. An individual who owns, manages, operates or otherwise controls the use of any premises subject to the provisions of this Clean Indoor Air Ordinance may establish a designated outdoor smoking area that extends a reasonable distance from any entrances, windows and ventilation systems to any enclosed areas where smoking is prohibited, and the reasonable distance shall be a distance sufficient to ensure that tobacco smoke does not enter the building or facility through entrances, windows, ventilation systems or any other means. 
(Ord. No. 2006-1173, § 9, 8-22-06) 
Sec. 12-3-11. - Exceptions. 
    Notwithstanding any other section of this article to the contrary, the following areas shall not be subject to the restrictions of this article: 
(1)  Private residences, except when used as a licensed child care, adult day care or health care facility. 
(2)  Hotel and motel rooms that are rented to guests and are designated as smoking rooms. 
(3)  Private rooms in nursing homes and long term care facilities that are occupied by a person who has requested in writing to be placed in a room where smoking is permitted, provided that smoke from these places does not infiltrate into areas where smoking is prohibited under the provisions of this article. 
(4)  Designated outdoor smoking areas. 
(5)  Enclosed offices or rooms within a place of employment used on behalf of a place of employment, provided that: 
a.  Smokers are the only persons present in the room or office, and 
b.  Smoke from the ignited source does not enter areas where other persons are present or permitted, and 
c.  Smoke is filtered or otherwise dissipates before other persons enter the room or office. 
(6)  Private clubs as defined in section 12-3-4. 
(Code 1969, § 9A-1-7; Ord. No. 2006-1173, § 10, 8-22-06) 
Sec. 12-3-12. - Posting of signs in public places. 
(a)  Signs stating "smoking" or "no smoking" or other signs indicating smoking restrictions, whichever are appropriate, with letters of not less than one inch in height or the international no smoking symbol consisting of a pictorial representation of a burning cigarette enclosed in a red circle with a red bar across it shall be posted where it is clear, conspicuous and easily legible in all public places where smoking is restricted by this article by the owner, operator, manager or other person having control of such building or other place. Places of employment, except to the extent they are also public places, are exempt from this subsection (a). 
(b)  Every place of employment where smoking is permitted by this article shall have posted at every entrance a conspicuous sign clearly stating that smoking is permitted. 
(c)  All ashtrays shall be removed from any area where smoking is prohibited by this article. 
(Code 1969, § 9A-1-8; Ord. No. 2006-1173, § 11, 8-22-06) 
Sec. 12-3-13. - Buildings with multiple businesses. 
    The owner or manager of a building that houses multiple businesses located in the same building shall be responsible for declaring public places therein smokefree. 
(Code 1969, § 9A-1-9; Ord. No. 2006-1173, § 12, 8-22-06) 
Sec. 12-3-14. - No retaliation; non waiver of rights. 
    No person or employer shall discharge, refuse to hire, or in any manner retaliate against an employee, applicant for employment, or customer because that employee, applicant, or customer exercises any rights afforded by this article or reports or attempts to prosecute a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2006-1173, § 13, 8-22-06) 
Sec. 12-3-15. - Other applicable laws. 
    This article shall not be interpreted or construed to permit smoking where it is otherwise restricted by other applicable laws. 
(Ord. No. 2006-1173, § 14, 8-22-06) 
ARTICLE 4. - LAND GRADING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 12-4-1. - Permit required for grading. 
(a)  No person shall grade, cut, fill or excavate, nor cause the same to be performed in any place without first obtaining a permit from the city engineer. No permit shall be issued until the applicant has prepared and submitted a dust remediation plan. The plan shall include action reasonably calculated to reduce blowing dirt. Acceptable dust remediation plans may include information regarding the commencement of construction, landscaping, planting of growing crops, application of dust retardant, fencing, or any other action intended to reduce blowing dirt. The plan shall contain an implementation schedule. The plan shall be subject to approval by the city engineer. 
(b)  Any fee for a permit issued pursuant to this section shall be established by city council resolution. 
(c)  The term grading shall mean any leveling activity which results in the removal of vegetation from the surface of property. 
(d)  The term cutting shall include any dirt removal which results in a slope or grade greater than 30 percent on the remaining property. 
(e)  Any person grading, filling, cutting, or excavating property subject to this section without having first obtained a permit or having failed to follow the approved dust remediation plan shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished in accordance with section 1-1-10 of the Farmington City Code. 
(f)  As used herein, the term tract shall mean any contiguous area of land owned or controlled by the same person, partnership, corporation or other entity whether or not the same has previously been platted, surveyed, or otherwise described as two or more parcels and includes areas previously platted for dedication as public right-of-way. 
(Code 1969, § 15-1; Ord. No. 99-1090, § 1, 2-9-99) 
Sec. 12-4-2. - Exemptions. 
(a)  This article shall not apply to any tract smaller than two acres. 
(b)  This article shall not apply to the removal of materials referred to in this article from any land within the city, the transportation of such materials, or the use of such materials to fill lands within the city when such operations are carried on as an integral process in connection with any public contract awarded by the state, the city, or any political subdivision of the state or the United States. 
(c)  None of the sections of this article relating to land filling shall apply in the case of land filling made at any sanitary landfill designated by the city. 
(d)  This article shall not apply to fill made through the use of gravel, aggregate or other materials in the construction or maintenance of driveways, parking areas or residence yards, or in laying or maintaining asphalt or blacktop areas. 
(e)  This article shall not apply to plowing or other turning of soil required for agricultural purposes. 
(Code 1969, § 15-6; Ord. No. 99-1090, §§ 2, 3, 2-9-99) 
Sec. 12-4-3. - Liability of city. 
    The city shall not be liable for any injury to any person or for the injury to any property of any person arising out of operations carried on under any permit issued by the city under this article. 
(Code 1969, § 15-8) 
Sec. 12-4-4. - Presumptions of responsibility. 
    Whenever materials referred to in this article are removed from any land in the city or whenever such materials are used to fill land in the city, the presumption shall exist for the purposes of this article that such operations are carried on with the knowledge and consent of the person owning, leasing or occupying such land, and the person owning, leasing or occupying land upon which a violation of this article is apparent shall be deemed prima facie responsible for the violation so evidenced and subject to punishment as prescribed by section 1-1-10. 
(Code 1969, § 15-10) 
Sec. 12-4-5. - Injunctive right of city. 
    Any operations carried on by any person in removing materials from any lands within the city or in transporting materials so removed or in filling lands within the city, except in conformity with this article, may be enjoined by the city in an action instituted by the city in a court of competent jurisdiction. The institution of any proceeding to enjoin unauthorized operations prohibited under this article shall not affect the rights of the city under section 1-1-10 to recover the penalty prescribed therein for violation of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 15-11) 
Sec. 12-4-6. - Failure to abate blowing dirt. 
    No person, firm, corporation or other entity owning or controlling property within the city limits of Farmington shall fail or refuse to abate a manmade condition which increases the blowing of dirt from the property. The code compliance officer shall notify the owner or person controlling the property of the problem and shall discuss abatement methods with the owner or responsible party. Should the owner of, or person controlling the property, fail to implement abatement procedures within 15 days after being contacted by code compliance, the person may be cited into municipal court and, upon conviction shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to a fine of not more than $500.00 per violation. For purposes of this section, the owner of, or person in control of property, may be cited for a separate violation for each day that no approved abatement methods are implemented. The provisions of this section shall be applicable to tracts of land larger than one-half acre. 
(Ord. No. 99-1090, § 4, 2-9-99) 
Secs. 12-4-7-12-4-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 12-4-31. - Required. 
    No person shall remove soil, rock, debris or other material from any lands in the city to reduce the grade thereof when such materials are to be transported therefrom to any other lands within or without the corporate limits of the city; no person shall transport soil, rock, debris, refuse, garbage or other materials to any lands within the city for the purpose of providing materials to increase the grade of such lands; and no person shall fill any lands within the city with soil, rock, debris, refuse, garbage or other materials transported to such lands from a point of origin other than the lands being filled to increase the grade of such lands unless he shall have obtained a permit therefor upon payment of the fees as provided in this division and in conformity with this article. 
(Code 1969, § 15-2) 
Sec. 12-4-32. - Application. 
(a)  Application for a permit for the removal of materials referred to in this article from land within the city shall be made by the person owning, leasing or in possession of such land. 
(b)  Application for a permit for the transportation of the materials referred to in this article from lands within the city to other lands within or without the city shall be made by the person transporting such materials. 
(c)  Application for a permit for filling lands within the city shall be made by the person owning, leasing or in possession of the lands to be filled. 
(d)  All applications for permits under this division shall be made to the building inspector. 
(e)  If materials are removed from any land in the city, the application shall specify the name of the owner or the lessee or person in possession or the person occupying such land, the location of the land from which such materials are to be removed, the nature of the materials to be moved and the reduction in grade to be accomplished, the indicated condition of the premises when such removal has been accomplished, and the place to which such materials are to be moved. If the application is made by other than the owner of such lands, the consent of the owner to the issuance of such permit must be obtained before a permit will be issued. 
(f)  If materials are transported from any lands in the city to a point within or without the city, the application shall state the location of the lands from which such materials are to be removed and the location of the lands to which such materials are to be transported, the increase in grade to be accomplished and the indicated condition of the premises when such fill has been accomplished. 
(g)  If land is filled in the city through the use of materials referred to in this article, the application shall specify the name of the owner or the lessee or person in possession or the person occupying the land, the location of the land to be filled, and the increase in grade to be accomplished. If the application is made by other than the owner of such land, the consent of the owner to the issuance of such permit must be obtained before a permit will be issued. 
(Code 1969, § 15-3) 
Sec. 12-4-33. - Fees. 
    The fees to be paid for the permit required by this division shall be as follows: 
(1)  Materials to be removed. The fee shall be $10.00 per acre or any fraction thereof for the total acreage of the lands from which such materials are to be removed. 
(2)  Transportation of materials. 
a.  The fee shall be $5.00, which fee shall cover the transportation of materials referred to in this article as are to be removed from the location for which a permit has been issued for the removal therefrom or the transportation of such materials to the location to be filled and for which a permit has been issued. 
b.  For the transportation of materials from two or more separate locations for which permits have been issued for the removal of materials therefrom or for the transportation of materials to two or more separate locations to be filled for which permits have been issued, separate fees for the transportation of such materials shall be required from each such location or to each such location. 
(3)  Filling lands. The fee shall be $10.00 per acre or any fraction thereof for the total acreage of the land to be filled. 
(4)  Additional fees. The fees payable under this section shall be in addition to any fees payable by any person licensed to engage in such activities in the city. 
(Code 1969, § 15-5) 
Sec. 12-4-34. - Prerequisites to issuance. 
(a)  Removal of materials. No permit shall be issued by the building inspector for the removal of materials referred to in this article from any lands within the city until he has inspected the land and has determined that the removal of such materials can be made without endangering the support of other land or improvements on land adjacent or contiguous thereto and that the condition of such land from which such materials are to be removed when such removal has been accomplished will result in a grade comparable to the grade of the land contiguous thereto and that the condition of such land from which such materials are to be removed when such removal has been accomplished will not result in any dangerous or unsafe condition. No permit shall be issued unless the owner, occupant or lessee of such land agrees to take all necessary precautions to ensure that such premises will not be rendered unsafe or dangerous or offensive during the period of operations required for such removal of such materials or within the foreseeable future thereof. 
(b)  Fill. No permit shall be issued by the building inspector for the fill of any land within the city through the use of materials referred to in this article until he has inspected the land to be filled and has determined that such land can be filled through the use of such materials and that the condition of such land to be filled when such fill has been accomplished will result in a grade comparable to the grade of the land contiguous thereto and that the condition of such land to be filled when such fill has been accomplished will not result in any dangerous or unsafe condition. No permit shall be issued unless the owner, occupant or lessee of such lands agrees to take all actions in connection with such fill that would be required for sanitary landfills to prevent fire from any combustible materials used in such fill during such operations and to prevent offensive or obnoxious odors from arising during such operations or within the foreseeable future thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 15-4) 
Sec. 12-4-35. - Suspension of operations. 
    If, at any time during the operations carried on under any permit issued under this division, the building inspector shall determine that the operations permitted are not being carried on in conformity with this article, he shall serve written notice upon the person to whom such permit has been issued specifying the defects. Thereupon, no further operations shall be carried on under such permit until the defects have been remedied and certification in writing has been made by the building inspector. 
(Code 1969, § 15-7) 
Sec. 12-4-36. - Appeal from decisions of building inspector. 
    Any person who, upon application for a permit under this division, is denied such permit by the building inspector or any person having been issued a permit under this division and whose operations have been suspended and not reinstated by the building inspector, being aggrieved by the decision of the building inspector, may appeal such determination to the city council. The city council after hearing on due notice to such person and to the building inspector shall affirm, modify or make such decision in the matter as is proper. Such person shall have the right to appear at such hearing in person or by his attorney. 
(Code 1969, § 15-9) 
ARTICLE 5. - NOISE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Noise at street excavations, § 24-5-27. 

Sec. 12-5-1. - Definitions. 
    All technical terminology used in this article not defined in this section shall be in conformance with applicable publications of the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) or its successor body. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    A-weighted sound level means the sound pressure level in decibels as measured on a sound level meter using the A-weighting network. The level so read is designated dBA. 
    Construction means any site preparation, assembly, erection, substantial repair, alteration, or similar action, including demolition, for or of public or private rights-of-way, structures, utilities or similar property. 
    Decibel means a unit for measuring the volume of sound, equal to 20 times the logarithm to the base 10 of the ratio of the pressure of the sound measured to the reference pressure, which is 20 micropascals (20 micronewtons per square meter). 
    Emergency means any occurrence or set of circumstances involving actual or imminent physical trauma or property damage which demands immediate action. 
    Emergency vehicle means the same as ascribed to it in state statute. 
    Emergency work means any work performed for the purpose of preventing or alleviating the physical trauma or property damage threatened or caused by an emergency. 
    Gross vehicle weight rating means the value specified by the manufacturer as the recommended maximum loaded weight of a single motor vehicle. When trailers and tractors are separable, the gross combination weight rating (GCWR), which is the value specified by the manufacturer as the recommended maximum loaded weight of the combination vehicle, shall be used. 
    Motor carrier vehicle engaged in interstate commerce means any vehicle for which regulations apply pursuant to section 18 of the Federal Noise Control Act of 1972 (PL 92-574), as amended, pertaining to motor carriers engaged in interstate commerce. 
    Motor vehicle and motorcycle mean the same as ascribed to them in section 25-1-1. 
    Noise means any sound which is excessive, offensive, or otherwise disturbing to persons of normal sensitivities. 
    Person means any individual, association, partnership, or corporation, and includes any officer, employee, department, agency or instrumentality of a state or any political subdivision of a state. 
    Public place means any real property or structure thereon which is owned or controlled by a governmental entity. 
    Public right-of-way means any street, avenue, boulevard, highway, sidewalk or alley or similar place which is owned or controlled by a governmental entity. 
    Real property boundary means an imaginary line along the ground surface and its vertical extension, which separates the real property owned by one person from that owned by another person, but not including intrabuilding real property divisions. 
    Sound means an oscillation in pressure, particle displacement, particle velocity or other physical parameter, in a medium with internal forces that causes compression and rarefaction of that medium. The description of sound may include any characteristic of sound, including duration, intensity and frequency. 
    Sound level means the A-weighted sound pressure level obtained by the use of a sound level meter as defined in this section. 
    Sound level meter means an instrument meeting specifications of the American National Standards Institute for a type I or type II sound level meter which uses the A-weighting network. 
(Code 1969, § 20A-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-1-2. 
Sec. 12-5-2. - Penalties. 
    Any person found guilty of violating this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-1-10. 
(Code 1969, § 20A-16) 
Sec. 12-5-3. - Public nuisance; abatement; additional remedies. 
    The operation or maintenance of any device, instrument, vehicle or machinery, in violation of this article, which causes an immediate threat to the health and welfare of persons within the city shall be deemed and is declared to be a public nuisance and may be subject to summary abatement by a restraining order or injunction issued by a court of competent jurisdiction. This is not intended to preclude resort to any other legal remedy that may be had according to law. 
(Code 1969, § 20A-17) 
Sec. 12-5-4. - Evidence of violation. 
    Evidence establishing that an activity is causing or has caused the permissible sound level to be exceeded by more than five decibels at a point designated in any section of this article shall be deemed to be a prima facie evidence of a violation of this article. Sound level measurements taken in order to show such prima facie violation must conform to the procedures as outlined in section 12-5-5. 
(Code 1969, § 20A-2) 
Sec. 12-5-5. - Procedures for measurements. 
    Unless otherwise provided in this article, sound level measurements shall be taken with a sound level meter whose microphone is located at any point on the real property boundary or other point as provided in this article, no closer than five feet from any wall or vertical obstruction when possible, and where practicable not less than five feet above ground level, but in no event less than three feet above ground. A minimum of three readings shall be taken at two-minute intervals. The sound level shall be the average of these readings. 
(Code 1969, § 20A-3) 
Sec. 12-5-6. - Exemption for emergencies, emergency work. 
    This article shall not apply to the emission of sound for the purpose of alerting persons to the existence of an emergency or the emission of sound in the performance of emergency work. 
(Code 1969, § 20A-4) 
Sec. 12-5-7. - Variances. 
(a)  The city council shall have the authority, consistent with this section, to grant special variances to this article which may be requested when it finds or determines that: 
(1)  Strict conformance with this article would cause a hardship upon any person; 
(2)  The offending noise will be for a short duration and compliance with this article will be impractical; 
(3)  The benefit to the community of the activity creating the offending noise is greater than the adverse effect on the community of the noise created; or 
(4)  The applicant needs additional time to modify equipment or take other action in order to comply with this article. 
(b)  Notice of an application for a variance granted under this section shall be published in the same manner as provided for notice of ordinances and shall be granted only after the matter is considered in a hearing at a regularly scheduled council meeting. 
(c)  The city manager, with the permission of the mayor, may grant a temporary permit to an applicant for a variance to exceed levels established in this article until action is taken by the council on the application for a variance. 
(d)  Special variances shall be granted by notice to the applicant containing all necessary conditions, including a time limit on the permitted activity. The special variance shall not become effective until all conditions are agreed to by the applicant. Noncompliance with any condition of a special variance shall terminate it and subject the person holding it to those sections of this article regulating the source of sound or activity for which the special variance was granted. Application for an extension of the time limits specified in special variances or for modification of other substantial conditions shall be treated as are applications for initial variances. 
(Code 1969, § 20A-5) 
Sec. 12-5-8. - Maximum permissible sound levels by receiving land use. 
(a)  No person shall operate or cause to be operated on private property any source of sound in such a manner as to create a sound level which exceeds the limit set forth for the receiving land use category in table I when measured at or within the property boundary of the receiving land use.

(b)  Any person who shall violate this section in a manner which does not constitute an immediate threat to the health and welfare of the city shall, prior to any prosecution in municipal court, be notified in writing that he is in violation and that he has ten days in which to comply with this section. Such notice shall be served personally or by mailing to the violating person at his last known address notice by registered mail, return receipt requested, marked deliver to addressee only. If, at the expiration of the ten-day period, the violation continues, nothing in this section shall limit the power of the city to enforce this section. 
(Code 1969, § 20A-6; Ord. No. 2011-1240, § 1, 3-8-2011) 
Sec. 12-5-9. - Motor vehicles and motorcycles on public rights-of-way. 
(a)  No person shall operate or cause to be operated a motor vehicle or motorcycle on a public right-of-way at any time in such a manner that the sound level emitted by the motor vehicle or motorcycle exceeds the level set forth in table II in this section. Measurements of the sound levels emitted shall be measured at a point 50 feet from the center of the lane of traffic upon which the motor vehicle being measured is traveling. Section 12-5-5 shall not apply to measurements taken to enforce this section.

(b)  The following are exempt from the operation of this section: 
(1)  Emergency vehicles; 
(2)  Any motor vehicles engaged in a professional or amateur sanctioned competitive sports event for which an admission or entry fee is charged, or practice or time trials for such event; 
(3)  Any motor vehicle engaged in a manufacturer's engineering, design or equipment test; or 
(4)  Construction or agricultural equipment either on a job site or traveling on highways, subject to section 12-5-12. 
(Code 1969, § 20A-7) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 25. 
Sec. 12-5-10. - Recreational motorized vehicles operating off public rights-of-way. 
(a)  Except as permitted in subsection (b) of this section, no person shall operate or cause to be operated any recreational motorized vehicle off a public right-of-way in such manner that the sound level emitted therefrom exceeds 80 dBA at a distance of 50 feet or more from the path of the vehicle when operated on a public place or at or across the boundary of private property when operated on private property. This section shall apply to all recreational motorized vehicles, whether or not duly licensed and registered, including but not limited to commercial or noncommercial racing vehicles, motorcycles, go-carts, snowmobiles, amphibious craft, campers and dune buggies, but not including motorboats. Section 12-5-5 will not apply to measurements taken to enforce this section. 
(b)  Any motorized recreational vehicle engaged in a professional or amateur sanctioned competitive sports event for which an admission or entry fee is charged or practice or time trials for such event shall be exempted from this section. 
(Code 1969, § 20A-8) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 25. 
Sec. 12-5-11. - Places of public entertainment. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, play, or permit the operation or playing of any radio, television, phonograph, drum, musical instrument, sound amplifier, or similar device which produces, reproduces, or amplifies sound in any place of public entertainment at a sound level greater than 90 dBA as read on a sound level meter at any point that is normally occupied by a customer, unless a conspicuous and legible sign is located outside such place, near each public entrance, stating, "Warning: Sound levels within may cause permanent hearing impairment." In no event shall the sound level measured as indicated in this section exceed 110 dBA. 
(Code 1969, § 20A-9) 
Sec. 12-5-12. - Time limits for construction activity; operation of power tools in residential areas. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to do, perform or engage in any construction work of any nature in the city between the hours of 7:00 p.m. of one day and 7:00 a.m. of the next day or at any time on Sunday, if any such activity shall cause noises whose levels result in excess of the limits as stated in section 12-5-8. This subsection shall not prohibit any work performed because of emergency as defined in section 12-5-1. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to operate or permit the operation of any mechanically powered saw, drill, sander, grinder, lawn or garden tool, snow blower or similar device used outdoors in residential areas between the hours of 8:00 p.m. of one day and 9:00 a.m. of the following day so as to cause the sound level limits established in table I in section 12-5-8 to be exceeded at the property line.
