State Law reference- Authority to impose a solid waste collection fee, NMSA 1978, § 3-48-3. 
Sec. 23-2-8. - Bins and containers provided by city. 
(a)  This section shall apply to bins and containers which are provided by the city for either residential or business refuse collection or which are provided pursuant to agreement for the use thereof by the owner, occupant or other person in charge of premises within the city. 
(b)  The customer service administrator may require owners, occupants or other persons in charge of premises within the city who conduct business operations, shopping centers, mobile home parks or apartment complexes; who generate quantities of refuse greater than that of the average residence or household within the city; or whose residence, business or premises is so located that the use of a city-provided bin or container is more feasible than the collection from individual residences or businesses to utilize bins or containers furnished by the city for refuse collection and to pay the fees therefor established by this article. 
(c)  The customer service administrator may furnish refuse collection service through bins or containers provided by the city to persons other than business users under appropriate agreements with the city, provided the administrator finds that such service is economically feasible and city bins and containers are available for such service. 
(d)  The customer service administrator may require individual residents or businesses to utilize a city-provided bin or container in lieu of individual residential or business service if such bin or container is not located an unreasonable distance from the individual residence or business and collection from such bin or container is reasonably required by conditions encountered in the operation of the city refuse collection and disposal system. 
(e)  The customer service administrator may require the owner of any apartment building, shopping center, mobile home park or similar property having separate units which generate refuse to: 
(1)  Provide and maintain suitable refuse facilities; 
(2)  Utilize city bins or containers; 
(3)  Deposit all refuse in such receptacles or containers; 
(4)  Place all receptacles in a place convenient for removal; and 
(5)  Make payment directly to the city for all such city services rendered to such apartment, shopping center, mobile home park or similar property. 
(f)  All persons receiving refuse collection service through bins or containers provided by the city shall comply with rules and regulations established by the customer service administrator for the use, care and location of such containers and shall keep the lids and covers furnished for such containers on such containers in a tight or closed position at all times except when they are being filled or emptied. 
(g)  All persons receiving refuse collection service through bins or containers provided by the city shall, if required by the customer service administrator and as a condition to receipt of collection service, provide a suitable level ground, cement or asphalt pad constructed to specifications of the city engineer, upon which to locate city bins and containers, and shall provide any appropriate safety devices for use in connection with such bins or containers which may be reasonably required by the customer service administrator. 
(h)  It is unlawful for any person, other than such persons as are required and authorized by this section to receive refuse collection service through bins or containers provided by the city, to deposit refuse or any other material in such bins or containers provided by the city. The customer service administrator is authorized to place on all bins or containers provided by the city for refuse collection a notice that unauthorized dumping is prohibited by this subsection. 
(Code 1969, § 13-54) 
Sec. 23-2-9. - Placement of bins and containers and preparation of refuse and recyclable materials for collection. 
(a)  Bags and containers for individual residential service. This subsection applies to all customers or users receiving individual residential service, as specified in subsection 23-2-7(a)(1). 
(1)  Residential containers (polycarts), bags or containers. All owners, occupants, customers or other persons in charge of any premises within the city who receive individual residential service shall place all garbage, trash, waste, refuse or recyclable material in the applicable residential container (polycart) provided to the customer by the city. Any garbage, trash, waste or refuse in excess of what can be reasonably placed within the polycart so that the lid closes and the total weight of the polycart does not exceed 150 pounds or 69 kilograms shall be placed in tied disposable bags or in watertight cans which shall: 
a.  Be of sufficient size to hold not less than five gallons (19 liters) or more than 32 gallons (122 liters). 
b.  Contain not in excess of 50 pounds (23 kilograms) of garbage, trash, waste or refuse in any one extra bag, can, or container. 
c.  Have close fitting covers and be rodentproof. 
d.  Have handles on the sides of adequate size and strength for the container. 
e.  Have no ragged or sharp edges or any other defects likely to hamper or injure the person collecting the contents. 
(2)  Underground receptacles. Collection will not be made from underground receptacles. Underground receptacles shall not be used for the storage of solid waste awaiting collection. 
(3)  Additional containers furnished by owner. All bags, cans and containers that are used for holding combustible or noncombustible garbage, waste, rubbish or refuse, which otherwise cannot reasonably be placed within the polycart provided to the customer by the city, shall be furnished and maintained in good condition by the owner, occupant or other person in charge of the premises. 
(4)  Replacement of damaged containers. Any can or container provided by the customer that does not conform to the requirements of this subsection or that has ragged or sharp edges or that has other similar defects which hamper or may injure any person collecting the contents thereof must be replaced by a proper can, container, or receptacle within ten days of notice to that effect from the contractor or the customer service administrator. Any such can or container that is not replaced by the owner or occupant of the premises after such notice may be collected and disposed of as rubbish by the contractor. 
(b)  Preparation of refuse and recyclable material for collection. This subsection shall apply to all materials, whether placed for individual collection service or placed in containers or bins provided by the city. 
(1)  Waste material. All waste material deposited in any refuse bag, bin or container shall comply with the following: 
a.  Garbage shall be strained of all liquids and wrapped in paper. 
b.  Dangerous trash items and all waste material of an injurious nature, such as broken glass, lightbulbs, sharp pieces of metal, fluorescent tubes and television tubes, shall be securely wrapped to prevent injury to the collection crews. 
c.  The material shall not be of a flammable or explosive nature. 
d.  Incinerated items shall be completely free of combustion. 
(2)  Contagious disease refuse. The removal of wearing apparel, bedding or other refuse from homes or other places where highly infectious or contagious disease has prevailed shall be performed under the supervision and according to the rules and regulations of the state's environmental improvement division. Such refuse shall not be placed in bags, cans or containers for regular city collection. 
(3)  Hazardous refuse. No hazardous refuse, such as poison, acids, caustics, chemicals, infected materials or explosives, shall be placed in any receptacle used for collection by the city or disposed of at the sanitary landfill nor shall such be collected by the city. Hazardous refuse shall be disposed of according to regulations of the state or federal government at authorized disposal sites. 
(4)  Boxes and crates. All trash such as boxes, cartons and crates shall be collapsed and secured at the collection site so as to prevent movement by the elements. 
(5)  Vegetation. Tree trimmings, hedge clippings and similar materials shall be cut to length, not to exceed four feet, and securely tied in bundles not more than two feet thick before being deposited for collection. Such refuse may be placed beside the refuse containers. Tree and shrubbery branches, limbs and trimmings cut by landscape or tree-service contractors or other commercial workers or resulting from land being cleared shall not be the responsibility of the city. 
(6)  Recyclable materials. No items other than recyclable materials approved by the city or the city's contractor shall be placed in the recyclable container. Any variation of items placed in the recyclable containers that are not included in the approved recyclable materials list will be a violation of this section. 
(c)  Location and concealment of bins and containers. This subsection applies to all bins and containers, whether provided by the owner or by the city. All bags, bins or containers that are stored other than at the rear of the house, business, building or structure shall be concealed from public view unless otherwise authorized by the customer service administrator. 
(Code 1969, § 13-55; Ord. No. 2008-1208, §§ 6-9, 9-9-08) 
Sec. 23-2-10. - Collection; location; time of placement. 
(a)  This section shall apply to all owners, occupants and other persons in charge of premises in the city who receive individual residential refuse collection service. 
(b)  All residential containers (polycarts), except for those polycarts provided to a qualified physically disabled resident as defined in section 23-2-1, shall be placed out for pickup no later than 7:00 a.m. on the regularly scheduled collection day, but no earlier than 7:00 p.m. on the evening prior to the regularly scheduled collection day, unless otherwise authorized by the customer service administrator. All other bags, cans and containers shall be placed out for collection only on the collection day applicable to the premises. Residential containers (polycarts) and all other bags, cans and containers shall be placed at ground level as close to the back of the front curb as possible, or within 15 feet of the edge of the roadway where no curb is present, without causing interference with pedestrians, vehicular traffic, or fire hydrants. All containers shall be clearly visible and accessible to collection employees and free from any obstructions, including but not limited to trees, shrubbery, walls, fences, and vehicles. All emptied containers shall be removed from the curb area within 12 hours after collection. 
(c)  Special service shall be provided to any qualified physically disabled resident, as defined in section 23-2-1. The contractor shall take the cart from the front of the residence to the truck and return the cart to its original location. The contractor shall place a label on all residential containers (polycarts) at residences that qualify for such service. The customer service administrator may require documentation from a physician to determine if a customer qualifies for this service. 
(d)  If the customer service administrator finds that service from a right-of-way is hazardous or otherwise not feasible because of the weather or condition of the right-of-way and the customer has frontage on a second right-of-way, the customer service administrator may notify the customer that service will be from the second right-of-way, and the customer shall place containers for collection within 15 feet from the second right-of-way after being so notified. The decision of the customer service administrator may be appealed to the administrative review board. 
(e)  All residential containers (polycarts), bags, cans, and containers shall at all times, other than when placed for collection in accordance with subsection (b) of this section, be kept within the premises of the owner, occupant, or other person in charge of the premises or otherwise placed away from public view and in such a manner so as to preclude the scattering of garbage, trash or refuse. If spilling or scattering does occur, it shall be the responsibility of the owner or occupant to remove and properly dispose of such spillage. 
(f)  Upon request, the contractor shall collect normal household discarded furniture and appliances, including sofas, chairs, beds, refrigerators, dryers, hot water heaters, and similar items. Persons requesting this service shall be notified by the contractor as to the date collection will occur. Items for collection shall be placed at curbside no earlier than 12:00 noon on the day preceding the scheduled collection. This service shall be available to residential areas only. A reasonable fee will be assessed for this service by the contractor, subject to review of such fees by the customer service administrator. 
(Code 1969, § 13-56) 
Sec. 23-2-11. - Dead animals. 
(a)  No person shall deposit or otherwise place for collection by the city or its contractor any carcass or portion of any animal, bird or reptile. 
(b)  Dead animals shall be disposed of in a manner specified in Chapter 6, pertaining to animals. 
(c)  Any person in the city having knowledge of the existence of location of a dead animal, bird or reptile shall immediately notify the park ranger-animal control officer of the location of such dead animal, bird or reptile and shall provide such information as the park ranger-animal control officer or agent designated by the city may require. 
(Code 1969, § 13-56.1) 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 6. 
Sec. 23-2-12. - Construction sites and transportation of materials. 
(a)  Every person who has secured a building permit from the city shall, prior to the start of any construction activity, furnish or place on those premises a container or fenced area of suitable size and design to contain all refuse that might be disturbed or removed from the premises by the wind or elements. 
(b)  If such container or fenced area is filled, the person securing the building permit shall cause the container or fenced area to be emptied and its contents removed to an appropriate sanitary landfill. 
(c)  No person shall allow refuse, rubbish or other waste to blow or be carried from the premises for which the building permit was secured. 
(d)  A person mentioned in subsection (a) of this section who obtains the proper building permit and complies with this chapter shall be exempt from payment of a refuse collection fee set by the city. 
(e)  The city shall not be responsible for the collecting or hauling of building material originating from the private property preliminary to, during or subsequent to the construction of new buildings, alterations or additions to existing buildings of whatever type or from demolition of existing structures. Such materials shall be removed by the owner of the property or by the contractor. No new certificate of occupancy shall be issued until such material has been removed by the owner or contractor. Such material shall be removed and disposed of in the designated landfill as provided in city ordinances. 
(f)  A person engaged in demolition who has obtained a permit from the city must remove the debris and structural parts and contain their elements from scattering in the same manner as set out in sections of this Code pertaining to a construction site. The conveyance or transportation of such materials from the site shall be in accordance with city ordinances. This removal is exempt from the refuse collecting fee requirements. 
(g)  A person mixing concrete or transporting concrete on city streets shall not drop or leave waste concrete upon the city streets or upon any property within the city unless permission of the property owner is first obtained. No person shall transport concrete upon the public streets except in a proper truck or vehicle which prevents the spillage or leakage of concrete upon the public streets. 
(Code 1969, § 13-57) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 7; traffic and vehicles, ch. 25. 
Sec. 23-2-13. - Transportation of refuse. 
(a)  Any vehicle used to transport refuse, trash or tree or shrubbery trimmings must have suitable covers to prevent the loss of contents on property or roadways. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or move any vehicle upon any public way unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent its contents from dropping, shifting, leaking or otherwise escaping therefrom. However, sand or other abrasives may be dropped for the purpose of securing traction, and water, salt or other substance may be sprinkled upon a roadway in course of cleaning, clearing or maintaining such roadway by appropriate city departments. 
(Code 1969, § 13-58) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 25. 
Sec. 23-2-14. - Sanitary fill. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code shall prohibit the dumping of refuse into areas designated as sanitary fill areas by the city if done in compliance with this chapter and applicable rules and regulations of the environmental improvement division and the customer service administrator. 
(b)  Ownership of refuse material set for collection or disposed of in the city sanitary fills shall be vested in the city or such person as it may convey such title to by contract. It is unlawful for anyone other than the city or title holder to take such refuse material without the written consent of the title holder. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person not an agent or employee of the city to be upon the sanitary fill premises unless depositing refuse thereon. Other persons will be prosecuted for trespass. 
(Code 1969, § 13-59) 
Sec. 23-2-15. - Junk and appliances. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place or leave outside any building or dwelling any dilapidated furniture, appliance, machinery, equipment, building material, vehicle or portions thereof or other item which is either wrecked, junked, dismantled or in inoperative condition and which is not completely enclosed within a building or dwelling. Any such item which remains on the property of the occupant for a period of ten days after notice of violation shall be presumed to be abandoned and subject to being removed from the property by the city, after notice to the landowner as provided in section 12-2-28. This shall not apply to authorized junk dealers or establishments engaged in the repair, rebuilding, reconditioning or salvaging of equipment. 
(Code 1969, § 13-60) 
Sec. 23-2-16. - Airtight appliances, refrigerators or containers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave outside any building in a place accessible to children any appliance having an airtight snap lock or similar device without first removing the lock or door from the appliance, refrigerator or container. This section shall not apply to any appliance, refrigerator or container which has been placed adjacent to the building and is crated, strapped or locked to such an extent that it is impossible for a child to obtain access to any airtight compartment thereof. Any such appliance shall be kept from public view. 
(Code 1969, § 13-61) 
Cross reference- Abandonment of dangerous container, § 18-5-8. 
Sec. 23-2-17. - Disposal by actual producers. 
(a)  Vehicles. The actual producer of refuse or the owner of premises upon which refuse is accumulated who desires personally to collect and dispose of such refuse shall do so in compliance with regulations of the sanitation department. Such collection shall be accomplished through the use of a refuse-tight vehicle provided with a tight cover and so operated as to prevent offensive odors escaping therefrom and refuse from being blown, dropped or spilled. 
(b)  Rules and regulations. The city may promulgate rules and regulations, subject to the approval of the city council, concerning individual collection and disposal. 
(c)  Fee. Nothing in this section shall be construed to exempt actual producers of refuse or the owners of premises upon which refuse is accumulated from the fees for refuse collection provided in this article, unless otherwise specifically exempted from payment of such fees. 
(Code 1969, § 13-62) 
Sec. 23-2-18. - Scavenging. 
(a)  Scavenging. It is unlawful to scavenge, collect or scatter refuse at any city landfill or to scavenge, collect, or scatter refuse from any bag, container, bin or can placed or provided for collection of refuse pursuant to this chapter. City agents or employees and the contractor employed by the city for sanitation collection service shall, in the performance of their duties, be exempt from this subsection. 
(b)  Dissemination. It shall also be unlawful for any person to give, sell, show, deliver or otherwise disseminate to any other person any item removed or taken from any bag, container, bin or can placed or provided for collection of refuse pursuant to this chapter. It shall also be unlawful for any person to examine, copy, reproduce or extract information from any item placed within any such receptacle regardless of whether such item is removed or not. 
(c)  Exceptions. Nothing in this section shall prohibit a person from removing refuse from a receptacle owned by or provided to that same person. This section shall not apply to any federal, state, county or city law enforcement officer acting within the scope of such officer's duties while conducting a criminal investigation. 
(Code 1969, § 13-64; Ord. No. 00-1117, 10-24-00) 
Chapter 24 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city saved from repeal, § 1-1-12(a)(3); any ordinance establishing or prescribing grades in the city saved from repeal, § 1-1-12(a)(6); any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor saved from repeal, § 1-1-12(a)(7); buildings and building regulations, ch. 7; sidewalks and ramps for handicapped, § 7-1-2; cable communications, ch. 9; noise from street sales, § 12-5-16; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 17; playing in the street, § 18-1-1; mutilation or destruction of street markers, § 18-3-8; obstruction of streets, sidewalks or entrances to public buildings, § 18-5-3; planning and development, ch. 22; sweeping litter onto streets, alleys or sidewalks, § 23-1-3; traffic and vehicles, ch. 25; utilities, ch. 26.

ARTICLE 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1-1. - Water running over streets or sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause irrigation or other waters to run or flow on, over or across any public street, alley or sidewalk. 
(Code 1969, § 21-75) 
Cross reference- Water generally, § 26-2-1 et seq. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate the throwing on or depositing on streets and sidewalks, NMSA 1978, § 3-49-1(F). 
Sec. 24-1-2. - Ramps for handicapped persons. 
(a)  Required. Whenever any curbing or sidewalk adjacent to a corner at an intersection is constructed, repaired or remodeled to a major degree by the city street department or by any person, ramps shall be installed so as to avoid any barriers to access by handicapped persons between the sidewalk and the street or road. The city engineer or his designee shall inspect all such ramps. 
(b)  Permit. A permit issued by the building inspector shall be required for the construction of ramps for the handicapped as required by subsection (a) of this section; however, the building department shall not charge any fee for such a permit. 
(Code 1969, §§ 29-22, 29-23) 
Cross reference- Sidewalks and ramps for handicapped, § 7-1-2. 
ARTICLE 2. - CURBS AND DRIVEWAYS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to provide for curbs, gutters and crosswalks, NMSA 1978, § 3-49-1(H). 

Sec. 24-2-1. - Curb cut permit required. 
    No curbing shall be removed, damaged or cut for any purpose without first securing a permit therefor from the building inspector and paying a fee as set by section 24-2-2. 
(Code 1969, § 29-6) 
Sec. 24-2-2. - Curb cut permit fees. 
    The fee for curb cut permits shall be as follows: 
(1)  For curb cuts on curbs adjacent to residential property, a fee of $5.00 shall be charged. 
(2)  For all other curb removals, a fee of $10.00 shall be charged. 
(3)  For curb cuts on curbs at intersections, which cut is for the purpose of or is designed to include a ramp for handicapped persons, no fee shall be charged. 
(Code 1969, § 29-7) 
Sec. 24-2-3. - Marking of outer lines. 
    The applicant for a permit for a curb cut or removal shall plainly mark the outer lines of the cut and removal to be made, so the lines may be accurately followed by the workers making such cut or removal and inspected by the city. 
(Code 1969, § 29-8) 
Sec. 24-2-4. - Widths. 
(a)  Except as provided in this section, all curb cuts and removals for driveways shall be as follows: 
(1)  A single driveway for residential use shall be established as 12 feet in width. 
(2)  A double driveway for residential use shall be established as 24 feet in width. 
(3)  Removal of a curb to provide a driveway for commercial purposes shall not include more than 40 feet of such curb. 
(b)  If the curb cut and removal is proposed by an applicant wherein the specifications that have been set forth in subsection (a) of this section may not adequately serve the property for the uses proposed, complete plans and specifications shall be submitted to the building inspector. The building inspector shall refer such plans and specifications to the city council within five days thereafter, with his recommendation in writing for approval or rejection, and the question of such approval or rejection shall be considered at the agenda of the next regular meeting of the city council. Upon approval thereof, a special permit for the cutting and removal of curbing and construction of such driveway as set forth in such plans and specifications shall be issued by the building inspector upon payment of the appropriate fee. 
(Code 1969, § 29-9) 
Sec. 24-2-5. - Curb backing. 
(a)  After a curb has been removed, an apron or driveway shall be placed from the curbline to the sidewalk. If no sidewalk exists, such driveway or apron shall be constructed a distance of four feet in back of the curb and raised to the top of the previous curb grade in such a manner as to prevent any drain water from running behind the curb. The driveway or apron must consist of concrete, a minimum of six inches thick, or bituminous compound not less than two inches thick, on the approved base. 
(b)  On all proposed curbing removals and on all existing curbing lay-downs which provide for access onto paved streets, there shall be required a minimum of four feet behind the curbline of properly placed and graded concrete or asphaltic concrete pavement. For all such accessways to commercial properties, such as gasoline service stations, trucking yards, drive-in restaurants, fountains and other food service concerns and other business enterprises which provide off-street parking and would otherwise create a source of mud, debris, etc., which would normally be carried onto the paved street, there shall be required a minimum paving approach of concrete or asphaltic concrete of no less than 25 feet behind the curb or as may otherwise be required by the city council. 
(Code 1969, § 29-10) 
ARTICLE 3. - SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION 

Sec. 24-3-1. - Permit required, fee. 
    No sidewalk or other structure shall be constructed upon any street right-of-way, highway or alleyway without first securing a permit from the building inspector and paying the fee required by the Uniform Building Code. 
(Code 1969, § 29-11) 
Sec. 24-3-2. - Plans and specifications. 
    Plans for any proposed construction under this article shall be submitted to the building inspector, together with the application for a construction permit. All plans submitted shall be made in conformity with specifications laid down from time to time by the city council upon recommendation of the city engineer. 
(Code 1969, § 29-12) 
Sec. 24-3-3. - Limitations on issuance of permits. 
    No permit required by this article will be issued in which the proposed construction will conflict with the public interest, including but not limited to the widening, surfacing, installing sidewalks or otherwise improving the city streets. 
(Code 1969, § 29-13) 
ARTICLE 4. - ENCROACHMENT ON CITY PROPERTY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit the encroachment or obstruction of streets, NMSA 1978, § 3-49-1(B). 

Sec. 24-4-1. - Unlawful. 
    No person shall encroach on, in, over, or under any real property owned by the city or any public right-of-way, as defined in section 24-5-1, including easements, by any structure or object of any kind or character, temporary or permanent in nature, and whether such encroachment is real, personal, or mixed property. 
(Code 1969, § 29-50) 
Sec. 24-4-2. - Exemptions. 
    Section 24-4-1 shall not apply to those encroachments which: 
(1)  After applying the criteria of section 24-4-1, are not encroachments by law; 
(2)  Are authorized by a valid, unrevoked permit granted as provided in this article; or 
(3)  Are authorized by valid written agreement made by and between the city and an owner of real property under terms and conditions similar to those set forth in this article and otherwise protecting the rights of third parties and the public in general. 
(Code 1969, § 29-51) 
Sec. 24-4-3. - Application for permit. 
(a)  Application for a revocable permit to encroach on city-owned property shall be made by and in the name of the owner or of a person lawfully entitled to use the real property in connection with which the permit is sought to be obtained and shall be acknowledged by the applicant. 
(b)  The application shall set forth the name and address of the applicant, the nature and description of the proposed encroachment, the location and description of the city-owned property proposed to be encroached upon, the nature of the applicant's interest in and the location and legal description of the property in connection with which the permit is sought to be obtained, the reasons for the application, such other information, including plats, as may be required by the community development director, and the following statement: 
I understand and agree that any permit issued hereon shall be issued pursuant and subject to the provisions of Chapter 24 of the Farmington City Code, that such permit may be revoked by the City of Farmington, acting by and through its community development director, at any time, and that the encroachment must be removed within 30 days thereafter; that no right, title or interest in any property owned by the City of Farmington shall vest or accrue to me by reason of the issuance of such permit or exercise of the privilege given thereby; that I will not suffer or permit any dangerous or defective condition of property to exist in connection with the exercise of the privilege; and that I will hold harmless the City of Farmington for any damages arising out of, from or in connection with the exercise of the privilege granted by the issuance of the permit sought. 
(c)  The application shall be filed with the community development director and shall be referred by him to such other departments as might be affected by the issuance of the permit for their recommendation and comments. After such reference, the community development director shall approve such application and issue the permit requested, if the application shows: 
(1)  The proposed permit would not cause public property to become dangerous or hazardous to the public when used by the public for the purpose for which it was intended to be used; 
(2)  The proposed encroachment will not in itself become in a dangerous or defective condition or unreasonably endanger or interfere with public health, safety or convenience; 
(3)  The encroachment will not become unsightly; and 
(4)  The issuance of the permit is otherwise in the interests of the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city. 
(d)  If an application is made to the community development director which does not meet the conditions as stated in this section, the community development director may deny such application or may approve such application subject to such terms and conditions as he shall consider necessary to make the proposed encroachment meet the standards of this section. 
(Code 1969, § 29-52) 
Sec. 24-4-4. - Permit issuance, fee, privileges granted, expiration, renewal. 
(a)  If the permit required by this article is approved, the community development director shall collect a fee of $30.00 to recover the costs of handling the application and shall issue an encroachment permit. The community development director shall forward the permit to the city clerk, who shall keep in the clerk's office a record of all such permits issued. 
(b)  Each permit shall be construed as authorizing merely the temporary privilege to encroach to the extent permitted and subject to the conditions therein stated. No permit shall be deemed to transfer any right, title or interest of the city. 
(c)  Each permit shall expire five years from the date it is issued. No encroachment shall continue to exist after expiration unless the permit is renewed. 
(d)  Each permit may be renewed for successive five-year periods without payment of an additional permit fee. 
(Code 1969, § 29-53) 
Sec. 24-4-5. - Revocation of permit. 
    Whenever it shall appear to the community development director that the approved encroachment does not meet the conditions for issuance as set out in section 24-4-3 or does not meet any conditions imposed upon issuance of the permit, he shall advise the applicant that the permit has been revoked and that the applicant has 30 days in which to remove the encroachment. 
(Code 1969, § 29-54) 
Sec. 24-4-6. - Dangerous and defective conditions prohibited; liability of permittee. 
    By acceptance of performance of the privilege or any part thereof under a permit issued pursuant to this article, the permittee or his heirs, successors or assigns shall not allow, by commission or omission, any dangerous or defective condition to exist at any time in, on, under or across the property for which the permit is issued and shall hold harmless the city for any and all injuries or damage caused to any person or property arising out of the permittee's use of the permit property. 
(Code 1969, § 29-55) 
Sec. 24-4-7. - Removal. 
    Encroachments permitted under this article shall be removed immediately after expiration or cancellation of the permit. Any encroachment not removed is declared to be a nuisance. Failure, neglect or refusal to remove an unauthorized encroachment within 30 days after notice by the city shall constitute a misdemeanor punishable as set forth in section 1-1-10. As additional remedies, the city may remove such encroachment and collect the entire cost and expense thereof from the person responsible therefor, may compel its removal or abatement by instituting the proper proceedings in a court of competent jurisdiction, or shall pursue such other remedies as may be available to it at law or equity. If the permittee sought the permit in connection with land owned by him, the cost of removing any encroachment incurred by the city shall constitute a lien on such property. 
(Code 1969, § 29-56) 
Sec. 24-4-8. - Appeals. 
    If any person is aggrieved by the actions of the community development director taken pursuant to this article, the aggrieved person shall appeal the decision of the community development director to the administrative review board by advising the city clerk of his intent to do so within 30 days after the decision complained of. Upon receipt of notice of an appeal by the aggrieved person, the city clerk shall schedule a hearing before the administrative review board on the agenda of such board's next regularly scheduled meeting. The purpose of the hearing will be to determine if the decision of the community development director was properly made pursuant to this article. If any person is aggrieved by the decision of the administrative review board, he shall appeal to the district court within a period of 30 days from such decision. 
(Code 1969, § 29-57) 
ARTICLE 5. - STREET EXCAVATIONS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate the opening or repair of streets, NMSA 1978, § 3-49-1(D). 

Sec. 24-5-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Applicant means any person required by this article to apply for a permit and any person authorized by this article to make an excavation or enter a substructure opening without applying for a permit. 
    Block means 300 linear feet. 
    Emergency is broadly defined as the repair, restoration or replacement of an existing substructure which is required to maintain the public health, safety and welfare. 
    Excavation means any hole, trench, ditch or depression which penetrates through any paved or unpaved surface in a public place resulting from the removal by a person of pavement, dirt or other material, except a substructure opening. 
    Person means any individual, estate, trust, receiver, cooperative association, club, corporation, franchised utility company, firm, partnership, joint venture, syndicate, or other entity, including the city and other public agencies. 
    Public place means all property owned by, maintained, dedicated to or controlled by the city, including but not limited to streets, highways, alleys, bicycle paths, pedestrian or equestrian paths, ways, places, sidewalks, plazas, parks, easements, utility easements and rights-of-way. 
    Public right-of-way means the total area of land deeded, reserved by plat, dedicated to or otherwise acquired by the city, the county or the state, primarily for the use of the public for the movement of people, goods and vehicles. 
    Substructure means any facility located below the surface of any public place. 
    Substructure opening means an opening into a lawful substructure, the top of which is approximately flush with the adjoining surface of a public place and which is so constructed as to permit frequent opening without injury or damage to a public street or public place and without removal of pavement, dirt or other material. 
(Code 1969, § 29-61) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-1-2. 
Sec. 24-5-2. - License required. 
(a)  No person shall be issued an excavation license until the following actions are completed: 
(1)  A license application has been completed and signed by the applicant. 
(2)  The license applicant has certified in writing that the applicant has read and understands the contents of this article and that all who will be responsible for work under this article will be required to read and understand this article. 
(3)  The applicant has agreed: 
a.  To complete all work required by this article and covered by the permit. 
b.  To complete any specific item requested by the city within five days after written notice is given by the city to do so. 
c.  If the applicant does not complete the work requested by the city within such five-day period the city may, at its election, complete the work and bill the applicant at established charges for such work. 
d.  To repair or correct incomplete work, defective materials or defective workmanship that may occur within a period of three years from the date the city accepts such work, within ten days of request by the city for correction of such incomplete or defective work. 
e.  To obtain any business registration permit, business license, or any other license or permit required by the city. 
(4)  The community development director has approved the license. 
(b)  Licenses shall be issued without cost to the applicant and shall remain valid for a period of one year subject to cancellation for failure of the applicant to comply with any of the sections of this article. 
(c)  The city manager may, upon receipt of reasonable proof to his satisfaction that an applicant licensed under this article has violated the terms of this article or has been convicted in municipal court of a violation of this article, following reasonable notice to the applicant and a hearing if requested by the applicant, cause the license to be canceled or suspended. 
(d)  Any person aggrieved by the decision of the city manager to cancel or suspend a license may appeal such decision to the administrative review board in the manner specified in section 2-4-39. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62) 
Sec. 24-5-3. - Permits and approvals. 
(a)  No person shall make any street excavation without first obtaining a license and a permit pursuant to this article, unless specifically exempted by this article. Excavations performed by a contractor under contract with the city and occasional excavations made to provide water or sewer service to a single-family residence are exempt from the licensing requirements of this article. The community development director shall promulgate rules, standards and regulations required for enforcement of this article, which shall be approved by the city council. Following approval, copies shall be provided to each licensee. 
(b)  No entrance may be made into any substructure opening by any person without compliance with the rules, standards and regulations prescribed by the community development director and approved by the city council. Permits are not required for entrance into substructure openings; however, licenses shall comply with sections 24-5-10 and 24-5-12 through 24-5-17 if such sections are applicable under the circumstances. 
(c)  Each licensee shall further be responsible for the performance of any work done for the licensee by any subcontractor of the licensee. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.1) 
Sec. 24-5-4. - Permit applications. 
(a)  Every person required to obtain a permit by this article must be licensed and shall make application to the community development director on forms provided by the director which shall be substantially as follows: 
APPLICATION FOR PAVING 
AND/OR STREET CUT PERMIT 
Permit No. _____      Date _____ 
Name of Applicant _____ 
Address _____  Phone _______

_____

Actual: Square Feet of Pavement to be Replaced (to be completed by the city) _____ 
Summer _______ Winter _______ Rate @ _______ a Sq. Foot
