Contractor/Owner 
Water & Sewer Dept. 
Street Dept. 
Const. Inspection Department 
File 
(b)  An approved permit shall constitute the authority of the permittee to occupy the public place for which the permit has been approved. 
(c)  In an emergency, excavations may be made by a licensee without first obtaining a permit therefor, provided that each person so making an excavation shall file an application for a permit as soon as possible during the next normal working day of the city following the date of commencement of the excavation. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.2) 
Sec. 24-5-5. - Permits for grading, cuts or fill in public places. 
    Permits are required for grading, cuts or fill in any public place. Permits shall be issued without cost where existing ground contours have not been altered to approved city grades. This section shall apply to all public places, including but not limited to unimproved subdivisions, alleys, easements and drainageways. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.3) 
Sec. 24-5-6. - Liability insurance; self-insurance. 
(a)  No person shall make an excavation or enter a substructure opening or perform work under a permit or do earth work in a public place until such person has furnished a certificate of insurance satisfactory to the risk management administrator certifying that such person is insured against claims for damages for personal injury and for property damage which may arise from or out of the performance of the work of such person or any work performed by a subcontractor, an agent, employee or any person directly or indirectly employed by such person or his subcontractor. Such insurance must insure against collapse, explosive hazard, damage to nearby utilities and underground work by equipment on the street, and must include protection for a period of one year from the date of completion of an excavation against liability arising from completed operations. Liability limits shall be at least those limits specified for municipal coverage under the Tort Claims Act, and each certificate must provide that notice of not less than ten days be given to the risk management administrator prior to cancellation of any such insurance policy. 
(b)  Any public utility company having a net worth in excess of $10,000,000.00 is not required to comply with the insurance requirements of this section if such utility provides written notice to the risk management administrator of the written election of such utility to be self-insured and if such utility provides satisfactory proof not later than January 10 of each year that the utility does in fact have such net worth. Any such certificate furnished by such public utility shall further set forth in writing that such utility shall be responsible for and shall hold harmless the city against all claims and liabilities arising from the making of any street excavation pursuant to this article that is made by such public utility, its agents or employees or by any subcontractor of such public utility or by anyone directly or indirectly employed by such public utility. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.4) 
Sec. 24-5-7. - Excavation administration and inspection fee. 
    An excavation administration and inspection fee of $5.00 shall be charged for each excavation permit. An excavation permit must be issued for each portion of the work of continuous trench within the public place. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.5) 
Sec. 24-5-8. - Incomplete or defective work; street surface restoration fund. 
(a)  Incomplete or defective work. Any person or permittee who performs work to which this article applies is required to correct any work which is found to be incomplete or which contains defective materials or defective workmanship for a period of three years from the date such work was completed and accepted by the city. If the person performing such work fails to correct incomplete or defective work within ten days of city notification to such person and upon failure of such person to complete such work or correct such deficiency, the city may, at its election, complete such work and bill the person performing the work for work required to be done by the city. 
(b)  Schedules for payment to street surface restoration fund. Excavations shall not be made in any city street or public place unless required by absolute necessity or due to an emergency. When an excavation is required in a city street or in a public place, a payment shall be made to a street surface restoration fund based on the following schedules: 
(1)  Newly constructed street. No excavation permit will be issued, except for emergencies or upon a showing of absolute necessity, for any street that has not been in service for five years prior to the date of the proposed excavation. If excavation is required due to an emergency or is of a nature deemed absolutely necessary by the community development director to be performed within such five-year period, payment to the surface street restoration fund shall be made by the person who caused the excavation to be required, based upon the city annual street maintenance contract cost, for the full street width, the full length of the excavation, plus an additional 30 feet at each end of such excavation. 
(2)  Streets constructed five to eight years prior to excavation. If a street was constructed more than five but less than eight years prior to the proposed excavation or if the street proposed for excavation was overlaid, heater remixed, or otherwise was the subject of major maintenance within a period of three years prior to the proposed excavation, payment to the street surface restoration fund shall be made based upon the current city annual street maintenance contract for one-half of the width of the street, the full length of the excavation, plus an additional 30 feet at each end of the excavation. 
(3)  Streets with major maintenance within three to five years from date of proposed excavation. If a street shall have been the subject of major maintenance not less than three or more than five years from the date of the proposed excavation, payment to the street surface restoration fund based upon the current city annual street maintenance contract shall be made for one-quarter of the width of the street, the full length of the excavation, plus 30 feet at each end of the excavation. 
(4)  Other streets. Excavations in streets which are not defined in subsections (b)(1), (2) and (3) of this section do not require payment into the street surface restoration fund. 
(c)  Compliance with standards. Payment to the street surface restoration fund shall be in addition to any requirement of this article that excavations and street repairs be performed pursuant to standards established by the community development director for excavation, substructure entrance, street repair and pavement patching. 
(d)  Use of funds. The city shall use funds deposited in the street surface restoration fund for resurfacing the city streets and resurfacing areas which have been damaged due to excessive excavation activity. 
(e)  Exemption from fund. Deposits due to the street surface restoration fund are not required where excavation is not made into an asphalt or concrete surfaced street. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.6) 
Sec. 24-5-9. - Waiver of permit or payment to street surface restoration fund. 
(a)  The city manager may waive the requirement of obtaining a permit under this article or may waive payment to the street surface restoration fund where the obtaining of the permit or the imposition of such fees would be unfair or create undue hardship. 
(b)  The city manager shall: 
(1)  Establish appropriate standards governing conditions under which a waiver may be granted; or 
(2)  In specific cases where standards for a waiver have not been established, make specific findings in support of or against the granting of a waiver. 
(c)  Any person aggrieved by the granting or refusal or failure to grant a waiver by the city manager under this section may appeal to the administrative review board pursuant to section 2-4-40. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.7) 
Sec. 24-5-10. - Routing of traffic; warning signs. 
(a)  Any person performing work under this article must take appropriate measures to maintain, during the entrance into a substructure opening or performance of excavation work, traffic conditions as near normal as practicable at all times so as to cause as little inconvenience as possible to the occupants of abutting or affected property and to the public. 
(b)  The community development director may, at his sole discretion, require in writing that any person subject to this article notify various public agencies and the public of proposed work prior to the issuance of a permit or as a condition of issuance prior to any proposed work. 
(c)  Warning signs shall be placed near each excavation or substructure opening so as to give adequate warning to vehicular and pedestrian traffic both day and night. Cones or other approved devices shall be located so as to properly channel traffic in accordance with the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, as adopted and amended by the state. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.8) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 25. 
Sec. 24-5-11. - Interference with vital structures. 
    Under this article work must be performed and conducted so as not to interfere with access to fire hydrants, fire stations, fire escapes and all other vital structures or equipment designated by the community development director. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.9) 
Sec. 24-5-12. - Maintenance of traffic and pedestrian flow. 
    Any person subject to this article shall maintain safe and adequate passage of vehicle and pedestrian traffic on all streets and at all street intersections as required by the community development director and in accordance with section 24-5-10. When a street has been closed or detoured because of an excavation, the community development director must be notified prior to removal of barricades and other traffic control devices. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.10) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 25. 
Sec. 24-5-13. - Protection of utilities; surface water drainage. 
(a)  Under this article, relocation of privately owned utilities that are covered by a city franchise shall be governed by the provisions of that franchise. 
(b)  Any person subject to this article must, at his own expense, support and protect all utilities that may in any way be affected by the excavation work and must do everything necessary to support, sustain and protect such utilities under, over, along or across the work. All persons are encouraged to use the services of the Blue Stake locator service to locate existing utilities. If utilities are damaged, including but not limited to pipe damage, pipe coating, other encasement or other devices, the owner of the utility must be notified immediately. Unless otherwise authorized, damages shall be repaired by the utility, and the person making the excavation shall promptly reimburse the utility for such repair expenses. Every person subject to this article shall inform himself, before excavating, of the location of all utilities in or near the area of excavation. 
(c)  Every person subject to this article shall also protect the excavation from surface water flow by appropriate diversion or ponding devices. Care shall be used to prevent damage to property or structures of others as a result of the installation of any such diversion or ponding device. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.11) 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 26. 
Sec. 24-5-14. - Abandonment of substructures. 
    Under this article, whenever the use of a substructure is abandoned, except for abandonment of a surface line designed to serve a single property owner, each person having any interest in such substructure must, at least 30 days prior to such abandonment, file with the community development director a statement in writing giving in detail the location of the substructure proposed to be abandoned. Unless otherwise provided by law, the city or the state or any agency or political subdivision thereof may, at any time thereafter, require such person to remove at the expense of such person the abandoned substructure or the city, at its sole election, may remove such substructure, and such person shall then reimburse the city for the cost of removal from any public place. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.12) 
Sec. 24-5-15. - Protection of adjoining property. 
    Any person subject to this article shall, at all times and at such person's own expense, preserve and protect from injury any adjoining property by taking suitable measures for that purpose. Where, in the protection of such property, it is necessary to enter upon private property for the purpose of taking appropriate protection measures, such person shall, unless otherwise provided by law, obtain permission from the owner of such private property. Persons subject to this article must, at the expense of such person, shore up and protect all buildings, walls, fences or other property which may be damaged during the progress of the excavation work and shall be responsible for all damages to private property resulting from failure of the person subject to this article to properly protect and carry out such work. Such person may not remove, even temporarily, any tree or shrub which exists in any public place without first obtaining the permission of the community development director. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.13) 
Sec. 24-5-16. - Care of excavated material. 
(a)  All material excavated pursuant to this article and that is piled adjacent to the excavation or in any public place must be piled and maintained so as not to endanger the public and those working in the excavation and so as to cause as little inconvenience as possible to those persons using the public place and the adjoining property. All excavations shall comply with applicable city ordinances and rules and regulations. All material excavated must be laid completely along the side of the excavation and shall be kept trimmed so as to cause as little inconvenience as is reasonably possible to vehicle and pedestrian traffic unless otherwise directed by the community development director. Excavated material may not be used as a barricade. In order to expedite the flow of traffic or to keep dirt and dust from spreading or flying, the person subject to this article shall use guards or other methods to maintain dirt and dust control or shall appropriately water and keep wet such excavated material. 
(b)  Traffic markings removed as a part of the excavation shall be replaced with materials similar to those originally in place and in the manner satisfactory to the community development director. The city may, in its sole discretion, elect to replace such traffic markings and to charge such expense to the person making such excavation. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.14) 
Sec. 24-5-17. - Cleanup. 
    Each person subject to this article shall thoroughly clean up all rubbish, excess earth, rock and other debris resulting from excavation work and from the public place. All cleanup operations at the location of such excavation shall be accomplished at the expense of the person subject to this article and in compliance with section 24-5-16. During the progress of the work, the community development director may order, immediately after completion of such work and at the expense of the person making the excavation, the person subject to this article to clean up and remove all refuse, dirt and unused material of any kind resulting from such work. Upon failure to do so within 24 hours after having been notified in writing to do so, the community development director may cause such cleanup work to be done and the cost thereof to be charged to the person responsible therefor. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.15) 
Sec. 24-5-18. - Protection of drainageways. 
    Any person subject to this article shall maintain all gutters, easement crossings and related drainageways free and unobstructed for the full depth and width thereof or shall provide adequate substitutes for any such watercourses which may be blocked by any excavation. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.16) 
Sec. 24-5-19. - Breaking through pavement. 
(a)  Under this article, the use of pavement breakers which endanger existing structures or other property or which produce noise levels in violation of Article 5 of Chapter 12 are unlawful and prohibited. 
(b)  Saw cutting of concrete may be required by the community development director when the nature of the job or condition of the street warrants. If saw cutting is required, the depth of the cut must be at least one-third the total thickness of the pavement. 
(c)  Sections of sidewalks or curb and gutter are to be removed to the nearest expansion joint, score line or saw cut edge. Sidewalk cuts parallel to the street shall normally require removal of the entire sidewalk unless other methods are approved in writing, in advance, by the community development director. 
(d)  Unstable pavement must be removed over cave-ins, and the subgrade shall be treated in the same manner as the main excavation. 
(e)  Pavement edges must be trimmed to a vertical face and neatly aligned with the centerline of any trench. All cuts shall be parallel or perpendicular to the street except for drop inlet connection lines. 
(f)  The person subject to this article shall not be required to repair damage which existed prior to the excavation unless the cut made by such person leaves small floating sections which are unstable, in which case such person shall remove such sections and backfill such areas as well as the area of excavation. 
(g)  All such excavations shall be accomplished according to standards developed by the community development director and approved by the city council. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.17) 
Sec. 24-5-20. - Depth of structures. 
    Under this article, the minimum cover of any new substructure, excepting lawful entrances thereto, shall be in accordance with approved utility location drawings for such streets unless otherwise permitted in writing by the community development director. Nothing in this section shall impose a duty upon any person owning a utility to maintain the depth required in this section upon subsequent changes in grade in the surface unless, in the opinion of the community development director, the grade of such substructure interferes with the public safety or maintenance of or travel upon a public place, in which event the substructure shall be lowered by and at the expense of the owner of the utility. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.18) 
Sec. 24-5-21. - Backfilling. 
    Unless specifically exempted in writing by the community development director, any person who trenches or excavates on or within a public place for any purpose whatsoever shall be required to backfill the trench or excavation as follows: 
(1)  In all trenches or excavations, the material used in backfilling must consist of the original excavated material or other material as required by the community development director in a finely divided form free from large lumps, large stones, rocks, pieces of old concrete or asphalt pavement, or large wet or gummy masses and must be placed compacted in layers or lifts as provided in this section from the bottom of the trench or excavation to the top of the trench or excavation. 
(2)  Each layer or lift shall be placed evenly, level and of such depth that the degree of compaction as required in this section may be obtained throughout the entire backfill without exceeding the depth of layer or lift as recommended by the manufacturer of the compaction equipment being used, for the various soil types encountered, or as determined by actual compaction tests of the lift or layer in place, or as directed by the community development director. In no event shall the method of compaction being used cause damage to a pipeline or other subsurface structure in the trench, excavation or any property adjacent thereto. 
(3)  Each lift or layer must be sufficiently moistened so that when compacted moisture content shall meet the following requirements: 
a.  The backfill material when placed in a trench must be thoroughly compacted to a minimum of 90 percent of maximum density through the entire depth of the excavation or trench, with the exception that the top six inches in residential streets and the top 12 inches in arterial streets must be compacted to a maximum of 95 percent of maximum density. 
b.  Tests for compliance with this subsection shall be performed by the city or by a laboratory approved by the city. The 95 percent of maximum density requirements may be waived if the backfill or subgrade material contains 35 percent or more of material passing the no. 200 sieve, in which case the compaction must be not less than 90 percent of maximum density. 
c.  The moisture content of the backfill material in place must not exceed the optimum by more than two percent or be less than the optimum by more than five percent unless otherwise directed by the community development director. 
d.  Obtaining of the correct moisture content is the responsibility of the person doing the trench or excavation backfill. 
e.  Optimum moisture and maximum density shall be determined in accordance with the American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) D-1577, including all revisions thereof. Costs for such testing shall be paid for by the person doing the trench or excavation backfill. 
(4)  When a trench or excavation has been cut through existing pavement, the compaction for the top six inches and 12 inches as referred to in subsection (3) of this section shall mean the six inches or 12 inches of material which is placed immediately below the bottom or base of the existing pavement slab. The remainder of the backfill up to the top of the existing pavement surface is to be compacted sufficiently to provide a level and safe riding surface and shall be maintained in that condition by the person making the excavation until the permanent pavement patch can be placed, which shall in any event be done within a period of ten days. 
(5)  Backfill and compaction inspection must be made as required by the community development director. The community development director is authorized to make or to have made backfill moisture density tests for the purpose of determining compliance with the compaction requirements of this section. Such tests are to be made in accordance with the Standard Procedures of the American Standards for Testing and Materials (ASTM), including the latest revisions thereof. All costs connected with this testing shall be done at the expense of the person doing the actual backfill and compaction work. 
(6)  If the completed backfill fails to meet the density requirements of this section when tested or otherwise fails as evidenced by settlement of the trench or excavation, the community development director may order the faulty backfill material removed, replaced and recompacted to the required density specified in this section and retested at the expense of the person originally responsible for such backfill. The community development director may also order the replacement of all pavement destroyed or damaged as the result of backfill failure settlement. 
(7)  If a person responsible fails to comply with the requirements of this section, the city manager may, after notice to the responsible person and the opportunity to be heard, refuse to grant any further permit to such person to thereafter engage in trenching or excavation in any public place. The city manager shall, subject to appeal to the administrative review board, be authorized and empowered, following a hearing and the opportunity to be heard, suspend, cancel or withdraw a license or permit issued for the performance of any work which is not done in accordance with this article or to the reasonable satisfaction of the community development director. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.19) 
Sec. 24-5-22. - Restoration of surface. 
(a)  Upon completion of the backfilling of any excavation made pursuant to this article, the permittee shall notify the community development director. Permanent resurfacing shall be done by the responsible person, if qualified, or by city forces at cost or by the city's contractor under the street maintenance contract as directed by the community development director. The community development director shall establish a minimum charge for work of less than one square yard. The cost of all resurfacing shall be borne by the responsible person. The responsible person must resurface the excavation within a period of ten days after acceptance of density tests by the city. If the city has accepted the responsibility for pavement resurfacing, the person responsible must keep each excavation safe for pedestrian and vehicle traffic for ten days after giving notice of completion of backfilling unless a longer period is required due to extreme weather conditions. In any case, the person accepting the responsibility for restoring the pavement surface remains responsible for keeping the excavation safe for pedestrian and vehicular traffic until the pavement surface has been accepted by the city. 
(b)  Acceptance or approval of excavation work or backfilling by the community development director shall not prevent the city from asserting a claim against the person responsible for incomplete or defective workmanship or material which may occur within three years from the date of completion and city acceptance of the excavation work or backfilling. The presence of the community development director during the performance of any work shall not relieve the person responsible from responsibility under this subsection. 
(c)  When permits are issued for work on arterial, collector, downtown or important streets which may be designed by the community development director, all such streets shall be patched with temporary asphalt or approved bridging across the excavation at the end of each working day and shall be opened to traffic unless other procedures are approved in advance by the community development director. 
(d)  In order to allow easy identification of restoration work, a six-inch diameter spray painted area shall be placed at each end of the work, colored as follows: 
(1)  City (identifies liquid waste), green. 
(2)  City (identifies water), blue. 
(3)  City (identifies storm sewer), green and white. 
(4)  Telephone systems (identifies telephone lines), orange. 
(5)  Cable television system (formerly Teleprompter) (identifies cable TV), orange and white. 
(6)  City (identifies electric lines), red. 
(7)  Natural gas utility (identifies gas lines), yellow. 
(8)  City (identifies traffic control lines), orange and black. 
(9)  City (identifies fire lines), orange and gray. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.20) 
Sec. 24-5-23. - Completion methods. 
    The requirements of sections 24-5-19, 24-5-20, and 24-5-21 must be completed by one of the following methods: 
(1)  By the person responsible, provided the qualifications of such person to do so have been approved by the community development director in writing as to adequate equipment, personnel and knowledge of backfilling and surfacing methods. 
(2)  By any person who has first been approved by the community development director in writing as to qualifications and provided such person complies with all sections of this article which relate to responsible persons, the qualifications referred to in this subsection being the same as those referred to in subsection (1) of this section. 
(3)  By city forces, provided the person responsible requests the city in writing to do any or all portions of the work. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.21) 
Sec. 24-5-24. - Trenches. 
    The maximum length of open trench permissible at any time under this article shall not exceed two blocks, and the trench in at least one of such blocks must be ready for paving with the other block in the process of being backfilled. No pavement may be scored or otherwise marked for removal in excess of two blocks. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.22) 
Sec. 24-5-25. - Prompt completion of work. 
(a)  The issuance of an excavation permit pursuant to this article places upon the permittee the obligation to begin work at the site indicated upon the permit within ten days from date of the permit. The permit shall be null and void if the permittee does not commence work at the work site within such ten-day period, without a refund of the fee. The permittee shall obtain a new permit, including payment of the required fee, before work is commenced. 
(b)  After an excavation is commenced, the permittee must diligently pursue all excavation work covered by the excavation permit and shall promptly complete the work and restore the public place to the standards specified by the community development director so as not to obstruct the public place or travel thereon more than reasonably necessary. The excavation shall be backfilled and tested within three days after completion of work within the excavation and the site restored to standards specified by the community development director within ten days after density tests are accepted. If weather conditions prevent work completion, the additional time required by such weather conditions shall be added to such time periods. The city may complete the required work and charge the applicant for all costs required to complete such work at the rate specified in the city street maintenance contract if the permittee fails to complete the work. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.23) 
Sec. 24-5-26. - Urgent work. 
    If, in the judgment of the city, traffic conditions, safety or convenience of the traveling public or the public interest require that excavation work be performed speedily, the community development director may, at the time the permit is granted, order that sufficient men and adequate facilities be employed by the permittee 24 hours per day for the purpose of completing such excavation work in the shortest time possible. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.24) 
Sec. 24-5-27. - Noise, dust, debris and working hours. 
    Each person issued a permit under this article must conduct and carry out excavation work in such a manner as to avoid unnecessary inconvenience and annoyance to the public and occupants of neighboring property. Persons subject to this article shall comply with all applicable laws, rules, and regulations, including air quality control regulations, water quality control regulations, and Article 5 of Chapter 12 pertaining to noise. Removed sanitary sewer pipe must be removed daily. Under no circumstances will sanitary pipe be left exposed overnight. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.25) 
Cross reference- Noise generally, § 12-5-1 et seq. 
Sec. 24-5-28. - Preservation of survey monuments. 
    Under this article, any survey monument set for the purpose of locating or preserving the lines of any street, property subdivision, precise survey reference point or a permanent survey benchmark within the city may not be removed or disturbed without first obtaining permission in writing from the community development director. Permission to remove or disturb such monument, reference point or benchmark will be granted only upon condition that the person requesting such permission shall pay all expenses incident to the proper replacement of such monument. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.26) 
Sec. 24-5-29. - Inspections. 
    The community development director may make such inspections as found reasonably necessary for the enforcement of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.27) 
Sec. 24-5-30. - Advance notice of improvements. 
    The city shall endeavor to keep the public informed of proposed street or sidewalk improvements in order that facilities may be installed prior to the making of such improvements. It is the responsibility of the person applying for such permit to install necessary substructures in advance of such improvements whenever possible. 
(Code 1969, § 29-62.28) 
ARTICLE 6. - PARADES[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 25. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate parades and processions, NMSA 1978, § 66-7-9(3). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 24-6-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Parade means a parade, march, ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant, sporting event, athletic event, bikeathon, fun run, race, fundraising event, procession of any kind, or any similar display in or upon the streets, sidewalk, or other public place within the city. 
    Parade permit means a permit required by section 24-6-31. 
(Code 1969, § 22A-2) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-1-2. 
Sec. 24-6-2. - Violations. 
    Any person violating this article shall be guilty of a petty misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-1-10. 
(Code 1969, § 22A-13) 
Sec. 24-6-3. - Duties of permittee. 
    Any person issued a permit under division 2 of this article shall ensure that: 
(1)  The parade chairman or other person heading or leading such activity shall carry the parade permit upon his person during the conduct of the parade; 
(2)  The parade is conducted in compliance with all permit directions and conditions; and 
(3)  The parade is conducted in compliance with applicable laws and ordinances. 
(Code 1969, § 22A-10) 
Sec. 24-6-4. - Public conduct during parades. 
(a)  Interference. No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct, impede or interfere with any parade or with any person, vehicle or animal participating or used in a parade. 
(b)  Driving through parades. No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles or persons comprising a parade when such vehicles or persons are in motion and are conspicuously designated as a parade. 
(Code 1969, § 22A-11) 
Secs. 24-6-5-24-6-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 24-6-31. - Required. 
    No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or start any parade unless a parade permit shall have been obtained from the chief of police. This section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Funeral processions. 
(2)  Students going to and from school classes or participating in educational activities, provided that such conduct is under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper school authorities. 
(3)  A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
(4)  Sidewalk processions which observe and comply with traffic regulations and control devices, utilizing that portion of the sidewalk nearest the street but at no time more than half of the sidewalk. 
(Code 1969, § 22A-3) 
Sec. 24-6-32. - Application. 
(a)  Filing with chief of police. A person seeking issuance of a parade permit shall file an application with the chief of police on forms provided by that officer. 
(b)  Filing period. An application for a parade permit shall be filed with the chief of police not less than ten days or more than 180 days before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade. 
(c)  Contents. The application for a parade permit shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such parade. 
(2)  If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization and of the authorized and responsible heads of such organization. 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade chairman and who will be responsible for its conduct. 
(4)  The date when the parade is to be conducted. 
(5)  The route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination point. 
(6)  The approximate number of persons and animals and vehicles which will constitute such parade; the type of animals and description of the vehicles. 
(7)  The hours when such parade will start and terminate. 
(8)  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed. 
(9)  The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade. 
(10)  The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at any such assembly area. 
(11)  The interval of space to be maintained between units of such parade. 
(12)  If the parade is designed to be held by and on behalf of or for any person other than the applicant, a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade, authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his behalf. 
(13)  Any additional information which the chief of police shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should issue. 
(14)  The names, addresses and telephone numbers of persons who will act as parade marshals and who will be responsible for the conduct of portions or units of the parade and designating the portion or unit of the parade for which each is responsible. 
(Code 1969, § 22A-4) 
Sec. 24-6-33. - Standards of issuance. 
    The chief of police shall issue a parade permit if, upon considering the contents of the application and such other information as he may otherwise obtain, he finds that: 
(1)  The time, duration, route and size of the parade will not unreasonably disrupt the movement of traffic. 
(2)  The parade or assembly is of the size and nature such that it will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers to properly police the line of movement or assembly area or the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent reasonable police protection to the balance of the city. 
(3)  The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at the assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with the proper fire or police protection of or ambulance service to areas contiguous to such assembly areas. 
(4)  The parade will not cause such a concentration of persons, animals or vehicles or a combination thereof such as to prevent proper police, fire and ambulance services to the parade area or areas contiguous thereto. 
(5)  The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route. 
(6)  The parade or assembly will not interfere with another parade or assembly for which a permit has been granted. 
(7)  The parade is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any product, goods or event and is not decided to be held purely for private benefit. 
(8)  The conduct of the parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or to create a disturbance. 
(9)  The permittee has provided for a sufficient number of parade marshals to control the orderly conduct of the parade or assembly in conformity with the parade permit. 
(Code 1969, § 22A-5) 
Sec. 24-6-34. - Notice of action taken on application. 
    Within three days after the filing of the application as required by this article, the chief of police shall mail to the applicant a notice stating that the application: 
(1)  Has been approved; 
(2)  Will be approved upon the posting of a bond with the city, stating the specific reasons a bond will be required and stating the amount of the bond based on a fair estimate of the amount required to indemnify the city for the cost incurred in maintaining the additional manpower necessary to secure, control, protect and manage the proposed parade; or 
(3)  Is denied and stating in detail the exact reasons for such denial. 
(Code 1969, § 22A-6) 
Sec. 24-6-35. - Contents. 
    Each parade permit shall state the following information: 
(1)  Starting time. 
(2)  Minimum speed. 
(3)  Maximum speed. 
(4)  Maximum interval of space to be maintained between the units of the parade. 
(5)  The portions of the street to be traversed that may be occupied by the parade. 
(6)  The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof. 
(7)  Such other information, conditions and directions as may be included by the chief of police to ensure that the parade will be conducted in conformance with the standards of issuance provided in section 24-6-33. 
(Code 1969, § 22A-9) 
Sec. 24-6-36. - Alternative permit. 
    The chief of police, in denying an application for a parade permit, may notify the applicant that an alternative permit will be issued authorizing the conduct of a parade on a date, at a time, over a route or in some other manner different from that specified in the application. An applicant desiring to accept an alternative permit shall, within three days after notice of the action of the chief of police, file a written notice of acceptance with the chef of police. An alternative permit shall conform to the requirements of and shall have the effect of a parade permit under this article. 
(Code 1969, § 22A-8) 
Sec. 24-6-37. - Revocation. 
    The chief of police shall have the authority to revoke a parade permit issued under this article when: 
(1)  There occurs any violation of the standards of issuance as set forth in section 24-6-33. 
(2)  The information contained in the application for a parade permit is found to be false in any material detail. 
(3)  The permittee, parade chairman, any parade marshal or any other participant in such parade shall violate any applicable law or ordinance. 
(Code 1969, § 22A-12) 
Sec. 24-6-38. - Appeal procedure. 
    Any person aggrieved shall have the right to appeal the action taken under this article by the chief of police to the city council. The appeal shall be taken within 15 days after the notice of the decision of the chief of police. The city council shall act upon the appeal at its next regularly scheduled meeting, but not later than 20 days from the time of receipt of the appeal. 
(Code 1969, § 22A-7) 
ARTICLE 7. - STREET NAMES AND ADDRESSES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate the naming of streets, NMSA 1978, § 3-49-1(N). 

Sec. 24-7-1. - Purpose and intent. 
    The purpose and intent of this article is to: 
(1)  Adopt consistent standards for street names and addresses in the city. 
(2)  Expedite emergency, utility and personal service provision through an orderly street name and address system. 
(3)  Ensure street names are not duplicated or confused because of spelling, pronunciation or alignment. 
(4)  Ensure assignment and posting of specific street numbers to each property. 
(5)  Provide an administrative procedure for street name or number assignment, change and appeal. 
(6)  Define the area in which city address policy is implemented. 
(7)  Provide for the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(Code 1969, § 29-1) 
Sec. 24-7-2. - House number and street address required. 
(a)  All properties within the city or its address jurisdiction shall have a house number and street address assigned by the director of the community development department consisting of a street name and number designating its position relative to the address grid. Addresses shall be posted on all properties in accord with standards adopted by the city. 
(b)  Each property owner/occupant shall place an assigned house number in a readily visible location upon the principal structure(s) facing the street from which the property is addressed, e.g., at the front entrance to the home or structure. Interior units of an apartment, condominium project, mobile home park or the like, shall post the appropriate designation at each individual unit. 
(c)  House numbers shall be in numeric form, at least three and one-half inches in height, and be posted in plain sight at least six feet above grade and in contrasting color to the background upon which they are mounted. If the structure is set back from the principal roadway over 50 feet, the address shall be posted at a driveway leading to the structure, at least three feet above grade and in manner of color, size and visibility specified above. 
(Code 1969, § 29-2; Ord. No. 2016-1284 , § 1, 4-26-16) 
Sec. 24-7-3. - Address jurisdiction. 
    All land area within the boundary described in the Joint Powers Agreement between the city and the county which pertains to street addressing jurisdiction shall receive street names and addresses pursuant to this article. This area of address jurisdiction shall be referred to as the "Farmington Address Jurisdiction." 
(Code 1969, § 29-3) 
Sec. 24-7-4. - Policy. 
(a)  All proposed street names within the city's planning and platting jurisdiction are subject to approval by the city council, after recommendation by the community development department to ensure conformance to the policies set forth in this article. 
(b)  Street names and addresses in the address jurisdiction shall conform to policies set forth in this article and shall be subject to modifications by the community development director in a manner specified in this article. 
(c)  Standards for street names and addresses, including assignment, use and posting, shall be prepared by the community development director in conformance with departmental policy and applicable regulations of the U.S. Postal Service. Such standards, rules and regulations shall be approved by the city council and shall be on file in the office of the community development department. 
(Code 1969, § 29-4) 
Sec. 24-7-5. - Changes and appeals. 
(a)  Street name changes. Street name changes may be proposed by the general public or by city staff. Requests for street name changes shall be submitted to the community development department. After soliciting comments from all affected city departments, utility and service companies, and after notification of adjoining property owners by mail, community development staff will review the request to ensure the proposed street name conforms with established policies and will forward a recommendation to the city council for a public hearing and final action. Once a street name change has been approved, notice of such change shall be sent to all adjacent property owners and appropriate service and utility organizations. New street signs shall be posted at appropriate locations. 
(b)  Address number changes. Address number changes may be requested by the general public or by city staff. The community development director shall review the proposed address number change to ensure that it conforms with established policies and then shall either approve or deny such request. Upon approval, the community development director shall implement the address change by notifying the affected property owner or resident and all utility companies and service organizations by mail. 
(c)  Appeals. The administrative review board shall hear and render judgments on an appeal of a decision of the community development director regarding addressing and street name assignments or changes in accord with the guidelines established for the board and its actions as specified in division 2 of Article 4 of Chapter 2. 
(Code 1969, § 29-5) 
Chapter 25 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles at airport, § 3-4-1 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 7; court, ch. 11; noise by motor vehicles and motorcycles on public way, § 12-5-9; noise by recreational motorized vehicles operating off public rights-of-way, § 12-5-10; noise from motor vehicle horns and signalling devices, § 12-5-17; fire lanes, § 13-3-8; routes for explosives, flammables or other hazardous materials, § 13-3-9; law enforcement, ch. 15; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 17; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 18; tampering with motor vehicle, § 18-3-9; interfering with traffic or pedestrians, § 18-5-2; traffic regulations at Lake Farmington, § 20-3-3; cleanliness of parking lot, § 23-1-8; transportation of solid waste materials from construction site, § 23-2-12; transportation of refuse generally, § 23-2-13; streets and sidewalks, ch. 24; routing of traffic for street excavations, § 24-5-10; maintenance of traffic and pedestrian flow for street excavations, § 24-5-12; parades, § 24-6-1 et seq. 
State Law reference- Motor Vehicle Code, NMSA 1978, § 66-1-1 et seq.; traffic generally, NMSA 1978, § 66-7-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 25-1-1. - State motor vehicle code adopted. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, the following sections of the New Mexico Motor Vehicle Code, a traffic code, are adopted by reference pursuant to section NMSA 1978, § 3-17-6: 
(1)  NMSA 1978, § 66-1-4 (definitions). 
(2)  NMSA 1978, §§ 66-3-13, 66-3-17 and 66-3-18 (registration plates). 
(3)  NMSA 1978, §§ 66-3-701-66-3-707, inclusive, (bicycles). 
(4)  NMSA 1978, §§ 66-3-801-66-3-1101, inclusive, except NMSA 1978, §§ 66-3-876-66-3-886 (equipment and safety of vehicles). 
(5)  NMSA 1978, §§ 66-5-1-66-5-43, and 66-5-229(c), inclusive, except that portion of NMSA 1978, § 66-5-39 fixing a maximum penalty of 364 days in jail, and NMSA, 1978, §§ 66-5-501 through 504 (Ignition Interlock Licensing Act). 
(6)  NMSA 1978, §§ 66-7-1-66-7-416, inclusive (traffic laws). 
(7)  NMSA 1978, §§ 66-8-1-66-8-140, except sections providing felony penalties, those portions of NMSA 1978, § 66-8-116 fixing the amount of penalty assessments, and that portion of NMSA 1978, § 66-8-102 permitting a maximum penalty of 364 days in jail. 
(b)  All amendments to the sections of the New Mexico Motor Vehicle Code listed in subsection (a) of this section and all new sections passed by the state legislature in articles 7 and 8 of such code, except those prescribing felony penalties, shall become city ordinances without further action on the part of the city council. 
(Code 1969, § 19-1; Ord. No. 2009-1212, § 3, 3-10-09) 
Sec. 25-1-2. - Short title; form of citation. 
(a)  This chapter may be cited as "City of Farmington Motor Vehicle and Traffic Code." 
(b)  In traffic citations for violations of the motor vehicle code sections incorporated by section 25-1-1 and other references to such sections, the form of citation shall be to section 25-1-1 followed by the appropriate reference to the state code section incorporated. (Example: A speeding violation would be 25-1-1/66-7-301.) Such reference shall indicate a violation of or reference to this chapter and not the state statute. 
(Code 1969, § 19-2) 
Sec. 25-1-3. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm of fire, as used in section 25-1-1/66-7-362 shall include any training or testing exercise officially conducted by the fire emergency services department. 
    Alley means a public way within a block primarily intended for service and access to the rear or the side of property by vehicle and not designed for general or through traffic. The junction of an alley with a roadway shall not constitute an intersection as defined in NMSA 1978, § 66-7-1. 
    Central business district means all streets and portions of streets within the area described as follows: Beginning at a point on the north side of Apache Street and the west side of Airport Drive, east along the north edge of Apache Street to the east side of Butler Avenue; thence south to Vine Avenue; thence southwesterly along the southeast side of Vine Avenue to Main Street; thence southeast along the north side of Main Street to the east side of Hutton Road; thence due south to the north right-of-way line of the D & R G Railroad; thence along such north right-of-way line to its most westerly point; thence on a continuous line to the west side of Lake Avenue; thence north along Lake Avenue to the south side of Main Street; thence west along Main Street to the west side of Airport Drive; thence north along the west side of Airport Drive to the point of beginning. 
    Commercial vehicle means every vehicle designed, maintained or used primarily for the transportation of property. 
    Corner lot means any lot bounded on two or more adjacent sides by public highways. 
    Divided street means any street containing a physical barrier, intervening space or clearly indicated dividing section so construed to impede vehicular traffic and separating vehicular traffic traveling in opposite directions. 
    Loading zone means a space adjacent to a curb for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or materials. 
    Municipal parking lot means any lot owned or leased by the city, including but not limited to downtown public parking areas and parking areas located on, near or about any city-owned or leased public building. 
    Nighttime means the hours between one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour before sunrise. 
    Official time standard. Whenever certain hours are named in this chapter, they shall mean standard time or daylight saving time as may be in current use. 
    Parking meter means any mechanical device or meter placed or erected under the authority of the city for the regulation of parking, pursuant to this chapter. 
(Code 1969, § 19-3) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-1-2. 
Sec. 25-1-4. - Applicability of chapter. 
(a)  This chapter shall apply only to traffic or parking on the public way or on property owned by the city, except as provided by subsection (b) of this section or where a different place is specifically referred to in a given section. 
(b)  The provisions of 25-1-1/66-7-201 through 25-1-1/66-7-215, 25-1-1/66-8-102, 25-1-1/66-8-113, 25-1-1/66-8-114, and 25-1-1/66-8-115 shall apply on highways and on public and private property within the city. However, nothing in this subsection shall prohibit participation in organized and supervised events or contests conducted on private property with permission of the owner, provided that the property owner and organizer or sponsor are required to conduct such activity in a manner that is designed to safeguard the public. 
(Code 1969, § 19-4) 
ARTICLE 2. - TRAFFIC ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 25-2-1. - Authority and duties of police and fire emergency services departments. 
(a)  It is the duty of police officers and such officers as may be assigned by the chief of police to enforce all city traffic regulations and all applicable state vehicle laws. 
(b)  Police officers or such officers as may be assigned by the chief of police are authorized to direct all traffic by voice, hand or signal in conformance with traffic laws and regulations. If a fire or other emergency occurs, they may direct as conditions require, notwithstanding the traffic laws and regulations, in order to expedite traffic or to safeguard pedestrians. 
(c)  Officers of the fire emergency services department may direct or assist police in directing traffic at the scene of a fire or in its immediate vicinity. 
(d)  It shall be the further duty of the police department to perform the following with respect to this chapter: 
(1)  Enforce traffic regulations applicable to street traffic; 
(2)  Make arrests for traffic violations; 
(3)  Investigate accidents; 
(4)  Cooperate with the traffic engineer and other city officials in the administration of traffic laws and regulations and in developing methods to improve traffic conditions; and 
(5)  Carry out those duties imposed on it by this chapter. 
(e)  The police department may, with the approval of the city manager, establish a traffic division to perform the duties prescribed in subsection (d) of this section, without further authorization. 
(Code 1969, § 19-5) 
Sec. 25-2-2. - Records of police department. 
(a)  The traffic division or the police department shall keep a record of traffic accidents, warnings, arrests, convictions, complaints and alleged violations of this chapter or state vehicle laws reported for each person within its jurisdiction. 
(b)  The records shall be filed alphabetically under the name of the person concerned. 
(c)  Each person's record shall: 
(1)  Include a record of the final disposition of all alleged violations of this chapter or state vehicle laws; 
(2)  Show all types of violations and the total of each type; and 
(3)  Accumulate during at least a five-year period and be maintained complete for at least the most recent five-year period. 
(d)  Accident reports or cards referring to them shall be filed alphabetically by location. Whenever accidents in any particular location become numerous, the police department or traffic division shall cooperate with the traffic engineer in conducting studies of such accidents and determining remedial measures. 
(Code 1969, § 19-6) 
Sec. 25-2-3. - Giving false information of accidents. 
    No person shall give information to the police department in oral or written reports of accidents, knowing or having reason to believe that the information is false. 
(Code 1969, § 19-8) 
Sec. 25-2-4. - Traffic engineer. 
(a)  The traffic engineering administrator will serve as the traffic engineer and shall exercise the powers and duties as provided in this chapter. 
(b)  It shall be the general duty of the traffic engineer to determine the installation and proper timing and maintenance of traffic control devices, conduct engineering analysis of traffic accidents and devise remedial measures, conduct engineering investigations of traffic conditions, cooperate with other city officials in the development of ways and means to improve traffic conditions and carry out such additional powers and duties as are imposed by this chapter. 
(Code 1969, § 19-9) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-3-1 et seq. 
Sec. 25-2-5. - Emergency and experimental regulations. 
(a)  The city council or the traffic engineer is empowered to make and enforce temporary traffic regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions. 
(b)  The city council or the traffic engineer is empowered to make and enforce experimental traffic regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions. 
(c)  No such temporary or experimental regulation shall remain in effect for more than 90 days. 
(d)  The city council or the traffic engineer may test traffic control devices under actual conditions of traffic. 
(Code 1969, § 19-10) 
Sec. 25-2-6. - Authority to maintain traffic control devices. 
    The city council or the traffic engineer shall place and maintain such traffic control devices, lanes, crosswalks or safety zones as may be deemed necessary to carry out this chapter to regulate, warn or guide traffic or otherwise ensure the safety of pedestrians and traffic. All such traffic control devices erected shall conform to the state manual and specifications. 
(Code 1969, § 19-11) 
Sec. 25-2-7. - Obstruction of official traffic control devices or intersection visibility. 
(a)  As used in this section, an obstruction includes but is not limited to any sign, fence, ornament, hedge, shrub, tree or display, but does not include a building. 
(b)  No person shall hide or obscure any official traffic control device or railroad sign or signals by parking a vehicle or erecting any object or by allowing bushes, hedges, trees or other vegetation to grow so as to obscure traffic control devices or railroad signals. 
(c)  Unobstructed vision for traffic safety shall be maintained by the property owner or occupant on all corner lots regardless of the zone classification. No obstruction between 30 inches and eight feet above the street level shall be placed or maintained within a triangular area bounded by the street property lines of the corner lot and a line connecting the points 25 feet distant from a point at the intersection of an extension of the curblines of such lot. 
(d)  Every obstruction interfering with official traffic control devices or railroad signals is a public nuisance, and the city council or traffic engineer may remove the obstruction or cause it to be removed without notice and assess costs involved to the violator. 
(Code 1969, § 19-12) 
Sec. 25-2-8. - Moving or molesting unattended vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person who is not the owner of any vehicle or any person who does not have express permission of the owner thereof to move, start, attempt to move, attempt to start, molest, tamper with or manipulate any vehicle or part thereof or any control of any such vehicle left unattended upon the public ways. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to a police officer or member of the fire emergency services department or street maintenance department who, in the discharge of his duty, legally moves or causes to be moved any such unattended vehicle, nor to any person who moves such vehicle at the direction of or in compliance with orders from a police officer or member of the fire emergency services department or street maintenance department who, in the discharge of his duties, legally orders or directs the moving of such unattended vehicle. 
(Code 1969, § 19-13) 
Secs. 25-2-9-25-2-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TRAFFIC VIOLATIONS BUREAU[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-4-1 et seq. 

Sec. 25-2-36. - Established; purpose; hours. 
    There is established a traffic violations bureau to assist the municipal court in its administrative work. The personnel of the bureau shall be responsible to the municipal judge, and the bureau shall be open at such hours as the municipal judge may designate. 
(Code 1969, § 19-80) 
Sec. 25-2-37. - Duties generally. 
    The following duties are imposed upon the traffic violations bureau in reference to traffic offenses: 
(1)  It shall accept designated fines, issue receipts and represent in court such violators as are permitted and desire to plead no contest, waive court appearance and give power of attorney. 
(2)  It shall receive and issue receipts for cash bail from the persons who must or wish to be heard in court, enter the time for their appearance on the court docket, and notify the arresting officer or city attorney or the liaison officer, if any, to be present. 
(3)  It shall keep a record of all violations of this chapter and of state vehicle laws of which any person has been charged, together with a record of final disposition of all such alleged offenses. Such record shall be maintained as to show all types of violations and the total of each. Such record shall be kept for at least that period of time required by the New Mexico Records Retention Act, NMSA, § 66-8-132C, as amended from time to time. 
(4)  It shall keep records of traffic citations, warnings, arrests, convictions and complaints reported for each driver. 
(Code 1969, § 19-81; Ord. No. 98-1086, §§ 3-5, 11-24-98) 
Sec. 25-2-38. - Authority of municipal judge. 
    The municipal judge shall designate the specified offenses under this chapter and other city traffic ordinances and the state traffic laws in respect to which payments of fines may be accepted by the traffic violations bureau in satisfaction thereof; shall specify by suitable schedules the amount of such fines for first, second and subsequent offenses, provided such fines are within the limits declared by law or ordinance; and shall further specify what number of such offenses shall require appearance before the municipal judge. 
(Code 1969, § 19-82) 
Sec. 25-2-39. - Election of person charged to appear at bureau or before municipal judge. 
(a)  Any person charged with an offense for which payment of a fine may be made to the traffic violations bureau under section 25-2-38 and who has not elected to pay a penalty assessment therefor shall have the option of paying such fine within the time specified in the notice of arrest at the traffic violations bureau upon entering a plea of no contest and upon waiving appearance in court or may have the option of depositing required lawful bail. Upon a plea of not guilty the person shall be entitled to a trial as authorized by law. 
(b)  The payment of a fine or penalty assessment to the bureau shall be deemed an acknowledgment of conviction of the alleged offense, and the bureau, upon accepting the prescribed fine, shall issue a receipt to the violator acknowledging payment thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 19-83; Ord. No. 98-1086, § 6, 11-24-98) 
_____

The following sections of this chapter shall be penalty assessment misdemeanors and have the indicated fine:
