ARTICLE 2. - WATER[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Polluting municipal reservoir, § 20-1-3; water running over streets or sidewalks, § 24-1-1. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-2-1. - Unlawful taking or diversion. 
(a)  The word "person" as used in this section shall include the city and any other governmental agency or political subdivision, as well as any natural person, individual, firm, association, partnership or corporation. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this Code for any person to willingly and knowingly steal, divert or take, without the permission or authority of the owner, lessee or other person lawfully entitled thereto, any water, whether treated or untreated, from any river, ditch, canal, acequia, or from any fire hydrant, water tap, water hydrant, or from any waterway, channel, spring, fountain, or reservoir, including Lake Farmington or any lake, river, or channel in the city or under its jurisdiction, limits, or control. 
(Code 1969, § 21-75.1) 
Secs. 26-2-2-26-2-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONSERVATION OF WATER IN EMERGENCIES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2003-1141, § 1, adopted Apr. 22, 2003, repealed the former Div. 2, §§ 26-2-31-26-2-36, and enacted a new Div. 2 as set out herein. The former Div. 2 pertained to similar subject matter. For complete derivation see the Code Comparative Table at the end of this volume. 

Sec. 26-2-31. - Declaration of an emergency. 
    If a water shortage occurs in the city water system due to conditions of drought, lack of rainfall or snowpack, damage to the water system or facilities, failure of a key system component or facility, or due to civil or other emergency, the city council may implement water conservation measures based upon the stages contained within this division. The city council, upon consultation with the city manager, shall determine when each stage is to be implemented based on the operational requirements of the system and estimated water supply and demand projections. Implementation of the stages need not be sequential and the duration of each stage will be determined by the city council, upon consultation with the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 2003-1141, § 1, 4-22-03) 
Sec. 26-2-32. - Notice of water conservation stages. 
    Upon declaration by the city council of any of the stages described within this division which require water conservation measures, the city manager, or his designee, shall publish a notice describing such action at least once in a daily newspaper having the greatest circulation within the city. One copy of such notice and proof of publication shall be filed with the city clerk. The city manager, or his designee, shall also give notice to the local news media, television and radio broadcasting stations and use such other means that reasonably may be available to notify water customers of required water conservation actions. Notice of termination of any stage shall be given in the same manner. 
(Ord. No. 2003-1141, § 1, 4-22-03) 
Sec. 26-2-33. - Establishment of water conservation stages. 
(a)  The following water conservation stages are hereby established: 
(1)  Stage 1 - Water shortage advisory 
(2)  Stage 2 - Water shortage watch 
(3)  Stage 3 - Water shortage warning 
(4)  Stage 4 - Water shortage emergency 
(b)  Some or all of the following guidelines may be used by the city council in determining when it would be appropriate to establish each water conservation stage; 
(1)  Stage 1 - Water shortage advisory - (Water use reduction goal = ten percent) 
a.  Snowpack levels in the basin are, or projected to be, below 50 percent of average; 
b.  Projected in-stream flow levels in the Animas and San Juan Rivers are expected to be below 50 percent of average; 
c.  Water storage level of the city's reservoir (Farmington Lake) is less than 75 percent of normal for the time of year; 
d.  The Palmer Drought Index indicates severe to extreme drought for the Animas River and San Juan River basins; or, 
e.  The existence of other conditions, such as failure of a key system component or civil emergency, which the city council determines may negatively impact water supply. 
(2)  Stage 2 - Water shortage watch - (Water use reduction goal = 15 percent) 
a.  Water storage level of the city's reservoir (Farmington Lake) is below 80 percent of capacity and the influent/effluent ratio (i.e., the ratio of the amount of water entering into system or storage and the amount of water leaving the system through treatment and distribution or evaporation) is projected to be between 50 percent and 80 percent over the next 30 days or more; or, 
b.  The stage 1 water reduction goal of ten percent has not been met after being in place for a reasonable period of time. 
(3)  Stage 3 - Water shortage warning - (Water use reduction goal = 35 percent) 
a.  Water storage level of the city's reservoir (Farmington Lake) is below 80 percent of capacity and the influent/effluent ratio is projected to be below 50 percent over the next 30 days or more; or, 
b.  Water storage level of the city's reservoir (Farmington Lake) is below 65 percent of capacity and the influent/effluent ratio is projected to be below 80 percent over the next 30 days or more; or, 
c.  The stage 2 water reduction goal of 15 percent has not been met after being in place for a reasonable period of time. 
(4)  Stage 4 - Water shortage emergency - (Water use reduction goal = 50 percent) 
a.  Water storage level of the city's reservoir (Farmington Lake) is below 50 percent of capacity and the influent/effluent ratio is projected to be below 150 percent over the next 30 days or more; or, 
b.  Failure of a major system component which significantly affects the water system's ability to meet demand; or, 
c.  The stage 3 water reduction goal of 35 percent has not been met after being in place for a reasonable period of time. 
(Ord. No. 2003-1141, § 1, 4-22-03) 
Sec. 26-2-34. - Stage 1 - Water shortage advisory. 
    The following voluntary water conservation measures shall be in effect once a stage 1 water shortage advisory has been declared by the city council: 
(1)  Landscape or lawn watering should be limited in such a manner so as to reduce overall water usage by at least ten percent. 
(2)  Landscape or lawn watering with automated sprinkler systems between the hours of 10:00 a.m to 6:00 p.m. is discouraged. Landscape or lawn watering with manual sprinkler systems between the hours of 12:00 noon to 4:00 p.m. is discouraged. 
(3)  Watering early in the morning is recommended to avoid excess evaporation and discourage fungus growth, and lawns should be aerated to improve absorption and reduce runoff. Lawn watering should be done only when the lawn needs watering. 
(4)  Sprinkler systems should be shut off when it is raining. 
(5)  Fugitive water which overflows the landscaped area being watered and leaves the property is discouraged. 
(6)  Landscape and lawn watering should be stopped when winds are strong enough to cause the water to leave the area being watered. 
(7)  Installation of new landscaping is discouraged and if any new plant material is installed, only drought resistant or low-water-use plants should be used. Mulch should be placed around all existing plants, trees, shrubs, or flower gardens to hold moisture in the soil. 
(8)  Washing of hard surfaces, such as parking lots, driveways or sidewalks, is discouraged. 
(9)  Indoor and outdoor leaks should be repaired immediately upon discovery. 
(10)  Filling of swimming pools or hot tubs is discouraged. Swimming pools and hot tubs should be covered when not in use. 
(11)  Outdoor use of water for recreational purposes is discouraged. 
(12)  Restaurants should be encouraged to provide water to customers only upon request. 
(13)  Hotels, motels and other lodging facilities are requested to promote water conservation by encouraging guests to minimize use of towels and not changing bed linens for multi-night stays except once every four days. 
(14)  Ornamental fountains with re-circulated water may be operated only when winds do not exceed 12 mph. Ornamental fountains without re-circulated water are discouraged. 
(15)  Use of fire hydrants should be limited to firefighting use and use of fire hydrants for other purposes discouraged unless metered. 
(16)  Car washing at residences is discouraged. All hoses used for landscape watering, car washing or other uses should be equipped with a shut off nozzle. 
(17)  Car washing at self serve car washes is encouraged and businesses that wash vehicles are encouraged to use high pressure wash systems. 
(18)  Water users are encouraged to replace old plumbing fixtures with low flow fixtures, such as low flow showerheads, faucets and toilets, or retrofit existing fixtures with low flow devices, such as toilet tank dams, water-filled plastic jugs, or a brick. 
(19)  Water users are encouraged to take shorter showers; not to let the water run continuously while brushing teeth or shaving; and to flush only when necessary. 
(20)  Appliances which use water, such as dishwashers and clothes washers, should be run only with full loads. 
(21)  Evaporative coolers should be run only when needed and have a thermostat to control their operation. Evaporative coolers that bleed off water should be replaced with an evaporative cooler that uses re-circulated water. 
(22)  Hot water heaters should be insulated; the temperature set appropriately; and partially drained once per year. 
(23)  Outdoor open burning which requires water to be available for extinguishment is discouraged. 
(24)  New accounts for bulk sale of water are permitted, but with contract language to curtail use in other stages. 
(25)  Treated water bulk sales contracts shall be encouraged to be reduced or diminished by ten percent (based on the same month of the preceding year) or at a percentage which is in the same ratio or proportion as the supply by the city's own customers is being reduced or diminished, whichever is greater, until the stage 1 restrictions are lifted. 
(Ord. No. 2003-1141, § 1, 4-22-03) 
Sec. 26-2-35. - Stage 2 - Water shortage watch. 
    The following mandatory water conservation measures shall be in effect once a stage 2 water shortage watch has been declared by the city council: 
(1)  Landscape or lawn watering shall be restricted to Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday for locations with even numbered addresses and to Wednesday, Friday and Sunday for locations with odd numbered addresses. 
(2)  Landscape or lawn watering with automated sprinkler systems shall be prohibited between the hours of 10:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. Landscape or lawn watering with manual sprinkler systems shall be prohibited between the hours of 12:00 noon to 4:00 p.m. 
(3)  Sprinkler systems shall be shut off when it is raining. 
(4)  Fugitive water which overflows the landscaped area being watered and leaves the property is prohibited. 
(5)  Landscape and lawn watering shall be stopped when winds are strong enough to cause the water to leave the area being watered. 
(6)  Installation of new landscaping is discouraged until stage 2 restrictions are lifted. 
(7)  Water waste by leaks or inefficient sprinklers is prohibited. Indoor and outdoor leaks or improperly operating sprinklers shall be repaired immediately upon discovery. 
(8)  Washing of hard surfaces, such as parking lots, driveways or sidewalks, is prohibited, except in emergencies, as determined by the fire department, to remove spills of hazardous materials or to eliminate dangerous conditions which threaten the public health, safety or welfare. 
(9)  Filling of swimming pools for private use after declaration of stage 2 restrictions is prohibited. Private swimming pools and spas already filled may be kept full, but shall not be emptied and refilled, and must be covered when not in use. Filling, refilling and covering restrictions shall not apply to public pools and spas, including those at hotels, motels, and private clubs. 
(10)  Restaurants shall be required to provide water to customers only upon request. 
(11)  Hotels, motels and other lodging facilities shall be requested to promote water conservation by encouraging guests to minimize use of towels and not changing bed linens for multi-night stays except once every four days. 
(12)  Ornamental fountains with re-circulated water may be operated only when winds are not strong enough to cause water to leave the fountain. Ornamental fountains without re-circulated water are prohibited. 
(13)  Use of fire hydrants should be limited to firefighting use and use of fire hydrants for other purposes discouraged unless metered. Outdoor open burning which requires water to be available for extinguishment is prohibited. 
(14)  Car washing at residences and fund raising car washes at commercial businesses are discouraged. All hoses used for landscape watering, car washing or other uses shall be equipped with a shut off nozzle. 
(15)  Car washing at self serve car washes is permitted and businesses that wash vehicles are encouraged to use high pressure wash systems. 
(16)  Adherence to all of the voluntary measures set forth in the stage 1 "water shortage advisory" that are not made mandatory by stage 2 is highly encouraged. 
(17)  New contracts for treated water bulk sales are prohibited. 
(18)  Treated water bulk sales contracts shall be reduced or diminished by 15 percent (based on the same month of the preceding year) or at a percentage which is in the same ratio or proportion as the supply by the city's own customers is reduced or diminished, whichever is greater, until the stage 2 restrictions are lifted. 
(Ord. No. 2003-1141, § 1, 4-22-03) 
Sec. 26-2-36. - Stage 3 - Water shortage warning. 
    The following mandatory water conservation measures shall be in effect once a stage 3 water shortage warning has been declared by the city council: 
(1)  Landscape or lawn watering shall be restricted to Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday for locations with even numbered addresses and to Wednesday, Friday and Sunday for locations with odd numbered addresses. 
(2)  Landscape or lawn watering with automated sprinkler systems shall be prohibited between the hours of 10:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. Landscape or lawn watering with manual sprinkler systems shall be prohibited between the hours of 12:00 noon to 4:00 p.m. 
(3)  Sprinkler systems shall be shut off when it is raining. 
(4)  Fugitive water which overflows the landscaped area being watered and leaves the property is prohibited. 
(5)  Landscape and lawn watering shall be stopped when winds are strong enough to cause the water to leave the area being watered. 
(6)  Installation of new landscaping shall be prohibited until stage 3 restrictions are lifted, unless such landscaping is necessary to comply with some other existing code, ordinance or requirement. 
(7)  Water waste by leaks or inefficient sprinklers is prohibited. Indoor and outdoor leaks or improperly operating sprinklers shall be repaired immediately upon discovery. 
(8)  Washing of hard surfaces, such as parking lots, driveways or sidewalks, is prohibited, except in emergencies, as determined by the fire department, to remove spills of hazardous materials or to eliminate dangerous conditions which threaten the public health, safety or welfare. 
(9)  Filling of swimming pools for private use after declaration of stage 3 restrictions is prohibited. Private swimming pools and spas already filled may be kept full, but shall not be emptied and refilled, and must be covered when not in use. Filling, refilling and covering restrictions shall not apply to public pools and spas, including those at hotels, motels, and private clubs. 
(10)  Restaurants shall be required to provide water to customers only upon request. 
(11)  Hotels, motels and other lodging facilities shall be required to promote water conservation by requiring guests to minimize use of towels and not changing bed linens for multi-night stays except once every four days. 
(12)  Operation of ornamental fountains is prohibited. 
(13)  Use of fire hydrants shall be limited to firefighting use and use of fire hydrants for other purposes is prohibited. Outdoor open burning which requires water to be available for extinguishment is prohibited. 
(14)  Car washing at private residences and fund raising car washes at commercial businesses are prohibited. All hoses used for landscape or garden watering or other uses shall be equipped with a shut off nozzle and limited to the hours specified for lawn watering. 
(15)  Car washing at self-serve and automated car washes is permitted. 
(16)  Car washing at businesses that wash vehicles shall use high pressure wash systems. 
(17)  Rates for the usage of water shall be increased, commencing with the first billing cycle after the effective date of stage 3, as follows: 
a.  The rates for usage by all customer classes shall be subject to a surcharge or credit as contained in the attached "Schedule A - Stage 3 - Water shortage warning water rate surcharge schedule." 
b.  Where multiple detached, single family units are located on the same property and share a single meter, the usage shall be calculated by multiplying the usage blocks by the number of units for purposes of assessing the surcharge. 
c.  Any customer with unique unforeseen or mitigating circumstances for whom the stage 3 water rates cause an undue hardship may appeal the application of this rate to the customer's account by appealing to the water conservation hearing officer in the manner provided for in section 26-2-41. 
(19)  Treated water bulk sales contracts shall be reduced or diminished by 35 percent (based on the same month of the preceding year) or at a percentage which is in the same ratio or proportion as the supply by the city's own customers is reduced or diminished, whichever is greater, until the stage 3 restrictions are lifted. 
(20)  Adherence to all of the voluntary measures set forth in the stage 1 "water shortage advisory" that are not made mandatory by stage 3 is highly encouraged.

(Ord. No. 2003-1141, § 1, 4-22-03; Ord. No. 2006-1177, § 5, 10-24-06; Ord. No. 2018-1308, § 1, 6-12-18 ) 
Sec. 26-2-37. - Stage 4 - Water shortage emergency. 
    The following mandatory water conservation measures shall be in effect once a stage 4 water shortage emergency has been declared by the city council: 
(1)  Landscape or lawn watering shall be prohibited. 
(2)  Installation of new landscaping shall be prohibited until stage 4 restrictions are lifted. 
(3)  Water waste by leaks is prohibited. Indoor leaks shall be repaired immediately after discovery. 
(4)  Washing of hard surfaces, such as parking lots, driveways or sidewalks, is prohibited, except in emergencies, as determined by the fire department, to remove spills of hazardous materials or to eliminate dangerous conditions which threaten the public health, safety or welfare. 
(5)  Filling of swimming pools and spas after declaration of stage 4 restrictions is prohibited. Swimming pools and spas already filled shall not be refilled and must be covered when not in use. 
(6)  Restaurants shall be required to provide water to customers only upon request. 
(7)  Hotels, motels and other lodging facilities shall be required to promote water conservation by requiring guests to minimize use of towels and not changing bed linens for multi-night stays except once every four days. 
(8)  Operation of ornamental fountains is prohibited. 
(9)  Use of fire hydrants shall be limited to firefighting use and use of fire hydrants for other purposes is prohibited. Outdoor open burning which requires water to be available for extinguishment is prohibited. 
(10)  Car washing is prohibited (including fund raising car washes at commercial businesses), except at self-serve and automated car washes which shall be operated only on Wednesday through Saturday between the hours of 10:00 a.m and 5:00 p.m., unless the operator of the car wash obtains a permit from the water utility based on a demonstration that alternate methods of operation or alternate days and hours of operation will result in a reduction in water use equal to what would be achieved by compliance with the days and hours specified in this section. 
(11)  Car washing at businesses that wash vehicles shall be limited to Wednesday through Saturday between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. and must be done using a high pressure wash system. 
(12)  New accounts for bulk sale of water are prohibited. 
(13)  Rates for the usage of water shall be increased commencing with the first billing cycle after the effective date of stage 4, as follows: 
a.  The rates for usage by all customer classes shall be subject to a surcharge or credit as contained in the attached "Schedule B - Stage 4 - Water shortage emergency water rate surcharge schedule." 
b.  Where multiple detached, single family units are located on the same property and share a single meter, the usage shall be calculated by multiplying the usage blocks by the number of units for purposes of assessing the surcharge. 
c.  Any customer with unique unforeseen or mitigating circumstances for whom the stage 4 water rates cause an undue hardship may appeal the application of this rate to the customer's account by appealing to the water conservation hearing officer in the manner provided for in section 26-2-41. 
(14)  Raw water bulk sales shall be suspended until stage 4 restrictions are lifted. 
(15)  Treated water bulk sales contracts shall be reduced or diminished by 50 percent (based on the same month of the preceding year) or at a percentage which is in the same ratio or proportion as the supply by the city's own customers is reduced or diminished, whichever is greater, until the stage 4 restrictions are lifted. 
(16)  Adherence to all of the voluntary measures set forth in the stage 1 "water shortage advisory" that are not made mandatory by stage 4 is highly encouraged.

Sec. 26-2-38. - Exemptions to water conservation measures. 
    The following irrigation methods and types of uses are exempt from the mandatory water conservation measures: 
(1)  During stages 1 and 2, newly installed sod and landscaping shall be exempted from the water use restrictions for a period of 60 days from the date of initial installation of such sod or landscaping. To avoid enforcement action, the owner of the property shall apply to the water department for an exemption and may be required to provide a bill of sale to establish the commencement date for such exemption. Newly installed seed or sod lawns shall be exempted from the specified day watering schedule, but are not exempted from the hours of the day when watering is permitted. As provided for elsewhere in this chapter, installation of new lawn or landscaping during stage 3 and stage 4 is prohibited. 
(2)  The watering of athletic or playing fields and other heavily used public areas, and of tees and greens at golf courses, is not restricted to the days and times specified herein, but may only be conducted under a permit from the water utility after submission of a watering plan which minimizes water use and conforms, as much as is reasonably possible, to the requirements of the stage in effect. 
(3)  The time of day watering restrictions shall not apply to hand watering or drip irrigation of vegetable and flower gardens, trees, or shrubs, however, the day of week watering restrictions in effect at the time still must be observed. Lawn watering may not be done in this manner between the hours of 12:00 noon and 4:00 p.m. and water waste is prohibited. Hand watering shall mean holding in the hand a hose with a positive shutoff nozzle attached and does not include operating a hose with a sprinkler or manually operating an irrigation controller. 
(4)  The time of day and day of week water use restrictions shall not apply to any person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of growing or selling plants of any kind, but such uses shall be required to comply with all other water conservation measures specified in each stage. 
(5)  Water treatment plants and wastewater treatment plants are exempt from this division in its maintenance practices of washing down and back flushing of equipment using treated water essential to the proper and safe operation of the treatment plant. Electric power generating plants are exempt from this division for treated water it uses for makeup and cooling tower purposes that are essential for the proper, safe, and full operation of the plant. 
(6)  Homes, commercial establishments and governmental entities that have large landscaped areas where daily active use, water pressure limitations or inadequate irrigation equipment, that restricts the owner's ability to irrigate within the time limits specified within any of the stages, may develop an irrigation plan to designate a portion of its landscape area as "even" or "odd" for the purpose of complying with the water use restrictions and shall submit such plan to the water department for approval. 
(7)  Individuals or entities that own irrigation ditch rights or private wells for irrigating lands also served by city water are exempt from the water use restrictions, but are encouraged to use such water prior to using city water and are encouraged to comply with the time of day, specified day restrictions and fugitive water provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 2003-1141, § 1, 4-22-03) 
Sec. 26-2-39. - Enforcement of water conservation restrictions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use water during any of the stages described within this division which require mandatory water conservation measures and which violates the requirements of such stages, or which violates any termination or turnoff order, or which violates any water rationing system. Enforcement of the water conservation restrictions specified in stages 2, 3, or 4 shall be by the police department or a code compliance officer in the following manner: 
(1)  The first violation shall result in the issuance of a notice of violation to the party committing said violation and to the water customer if the person committing the violation is not the water customer. The notice of violation shall advise the party of the nature of the violation and the section of this division of the City Code that has been violated. The offender and the water customer shall be provided with an educational packet containing information describing the water conservation stage in effect. 
(2)  Upon observation of a second violation or upon reasonable cause to believe that a second violation has occurred, unless otherwise specified elsewhere in this chapter, a citation shall be issued to the party violating this section of the City Code notifying the party of the specific violations observed and the penalty to be imposed. Fees required to be paid as a penalty for violation of the provisions of this division shall be paid as a surcharge upon the water bill of the regular water customer or shall be due as an assessment to the city by the person who committed the violation in the case the offender is not a regular water customer. The penalties for second and subsequent violations shall be as specified in section 26-2-40 of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 2003-1141, § 1, 4-22-03) 
Sec. 26-2-40. - Penalties for violation of water use restrictions. 
(a)  All violations of stage 2, 3 or 4 water use restrictions shall be under the jurisdiction of the water conservation hearing officer, who shall be the city manager, or such other persons designated by the city manager, to serve as an impartial arbitrators at any hearings related to the enforcement of this chapter. Any person, firm, or corporation who is determined to have violated any required provision of this division shall be required to pay the following fees: 
Stage 2 - Water shortage watch 
First violation Notice of violation-no fee. Second violation $100.00 Third violation $300.00 Fourth and subsequent violations $500.00 or termination of service.  
Stage 3 - Water shortage warning 
First violation Notice of violation-no fee. Second violation $200.00 Third violation $400.00 Fourth and subsequent violations 500.00 or termination of service.  
Stage 4 - Water shortage emergency 
First violation $200.00 Second violation $400.00 Third or subsequent violations $500.00 or termination of service.  
(Ord. No. 2003-1141, § 1, 4-22-03; Ord. No. 2018-1306, § 1, 4-10-18 ; Ord. No. 2018-1308, § 3, 6-12-18 ) 
Sec. 26-2-41. - Appeals of penalties for violation of water use restrictions. 
(a)  Any person who has been assessed a penalty or surcharge under this chapter and desires to appeal such penalty or surcharge, shall submit a written request for a hearing before the water conservation hearing officer to the City of Farmington Customer Service Division. Such written request shall be submitted within ten calendar days from the date of receipt of the notice of violation in the case of a penalty, or in the case of a surcharge, within ten calendar days from the date of the postmark of the most recent utility bill. 
(b)  Upon scheduling the hearing, the water customer shall be given written notice of the hearing by personal delivery or certified or registered mail deposited in the mail to the last known address of the customer or violator at least ten calendar days before the hearing. 
(c)  All hearings shall be open to the public and shall be held only after notice has been provided to the water customer as provided for in this chapter. Notice of the hearing shall be posted in the lobby of city hall at least 72 hours prior to the time of the hearing. 
(d)  Conduct of the hearing: 
(1)  The hearing shall be conducted by the water conservation hearing officer (hereinafter, "hearing officer"). 
(2)  Formal rules of evidence shall not apply to the conduct of the hearing. 
(3)  Cross-questioning is neither prohibited nor encouraged. The hearing officer shall have full discretion whether to allow it. 
(4)  The hearing officer may hear testimony from any witness. 
(5)  After calling the hearing to order, the hearing officer shall outline the procedure to be followed in the conduct of the hearing. 
(6)  The hearing may be recessed or adjourned to another time and/or place upon the discretion of the hearing officer. 
(e)  At the hearing, the hearing officer may consider such factors as the steps the water user has taken to correct the violation; any unusual or unique circumstances that may have contributed to the violation having occurred; any extraordinary hardship caused by the imposition of such penalties; and any other relevant information presented by the water customer. Collection of the penalty shall be held in abeyance during the pendency of any hearing. The hearing officer shall have the authority to suspend or cancel all or part of the penalty imposed for such violation if the hearing officer determines that the penalty was inappropriately imposed or that the water customer has taken reasonable steps to prevent reoccurrence of such violation. The hearing officer shall make a record of the proceeding which shall include findings of fact and conclusions of law. 
(f)  The decision of the hearing officer may be appealed to the board of public utility commissioners. The board of public utility commissioners shall conduct a public hearing on the appeal in a manner similar to the procedure followed by the hearing officer described in this section. At the appeal hearing, the board of public utility commissioners shall review the record created by the hearing officer and may consider such other factors as the steps the water user has taken to correct the violation; any unusual or unique circumstances that may have contributed to the violation having occurred; any extraordinary hardship caused by the imposition of such penalties; and any other relevant information presented by the water customer. Collection of the penalty shall be held in abeyance during the pendency of any hearing. The board of public utility commissioners shall have the authority to suspend or cancel all or part of the penalty imposed for such violation if the board determines that the penalty was inappropriately imposed or that the water customer has taken reasonable steps to prevent reoccurrence of such violation. The board of public utility commissioners shall make a record of the proceeding which shall include findings of fact and conclusions of law. The decision of the board of public utility commissioners is the final step in the administrative procedures and is conclusive upon the water customer or violator. Any water customer or violator shall be considered to have exhausted all available administrative remedies upon issuance of the decision by the board of public utility commissioners. Any customer or violator aggrieved by the decision of the board of public utility commissioners may appeal such decision to district court. 
(Ord. No. 2003-1141, § 1, 4-22-03) 
Secs. 26-2-42-26-2-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - IRRIGATION WATER, DITCHES AND LATERALS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city regarding canals and ditches, NMSA 1978, § 3-53-4. 

Sec. 26-2-66. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Director means the director of the water and wastewater department or the employee or designee appointed by the city manager to carry out the responsibility contemplated by this division. 
    Community ditch means a community ditch, ditch company, or acequia existing under NMSA 1978, § 73-3-28 or under the state statutes for the purpose of transporting irrigation water from a river to a lateral. 
    Irrigation water means and includes any raw untreated water transported through a community ditch and into a lateral intended to be used for watering of lawns, gardens, fields, parks, orchards or similar uses. Irrigation water does not include stormwater or floodwater. 
    Lateral means and includes any ditch or pipe used for the conveyance of irrigation water which extends or emanates from a community ditch. 
    User means any person who has a lawful right to receive and use irrigation water from a lateral. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-1-2. 
Sec. 26-2-67. - Policy. 
    It is the intent of this division to ensure that persons who receive irrigation water through laterals within the city shall bear the expense of maintaining the laterals and that other residents are not required to subsidize the expense of providing irrigation water. Laterals shall be maintained according to standards established by the city. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-2) 
Sec. 26-2-68. - Map of laterals and list of users. 
    For the purpose of this division, the director shall prepare and maintain maps of all laterals within the city and shall prepare and maintain a list of all irrigation water users within the city which shall be available for inspection by the public. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-11) 
Sec. 26-2-69. - Maintenance of laterals by users; association of users. 
(a)  Under this division, it is the duty and responsibility of all users of irrigation water to clean and maintain the laterals used to transport irrigation water through the city or to any premises within the city unless the maintenance of such ditches and laterals has been assumed by the city. 
(b)  The director may require that all users upon a lateral form an association of users on the lateral and that one representative or an alternate representative be elected and designated by the users to deal with the city as the representative of users on the lateral in dealings between the city and the users in matters which pertain to the lateral. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-3) 
Sec. 26-2-70. - Payment for irrigation water. 
    Users from laterals, in addition to the obligation to maintain laterals set forth in this division, shall pay for the use of irrigation (raw) water at the rates specified in this chapter for irrigation (raw) water unless the user is the owner or lessee of a valid water right. The city may require the user to file proof of the user's water right with the city. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-4) 
Sec. 26-2-71. - Reasonable rules for equitable use of water. 
    Under this division, the director may prescribe reasonable rules and regulations pertaining to the use of waters from laterals to ensure that the waters will be made equitably available to users on the lateral. Such rules shall be submitted to the city council for adoption and shall be revised from time to time as required. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-5) 
Sec. 26-2-72. - Contamination. 
    It is unlawful for any person to intentionally contaminate, poison, or pollute any lateral or any water in a lateral. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-21) 
Sec. 26-2-73. - Refusal to maintain lateral. 
    It is unlawful for any person who has a duty to maintain a lateral within the city to fail or refuse to clean or maintain such lateral. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-22) 
Sec. 26-2-74. - Obstruction of laterals. 
    It is unlawful for any person, other than for the purpose of lawfully obtaining water therefrom, to obstruct any lateral in the city which is used for the purpose of transporting irrigation water through or within the city or to dump refuse or rubbish, as defined in section 23-1-1, into any such lateral. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-23) 
Sec. 26-2-75. - Unlawful use of water. 
    It is unlawful for any person who does not have a legal right to use or withdraw, steal, divert or take water from a lateral. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-24) 
Sec. 26-2-76. - Obedience to rules. 
    It is unlawful for any person to refuse to obey reasonable rules and regulations promulgated by the director and approved by the city council for equitable use of water from laterals. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-25) 
Sec. 26-2-77. - Assumption of maintenance of certain laterals by city. 
    The city, acting through the director, may in its discretion undertake the maintenance of any lateral within the city when users on such lateral request city maintenance and the city deems it in the best interest of the city to undertake such maintenance or if the director shall determine that the city must maintain such lateral due to the failure or refusal of one or more of the users to keep and maintain such lateral according to city standards. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-6) 
Sec. 26-2-78. - Procedure for assumption of maintenance; notice to users. 
    If the director determines that is necessary for the city to maintain a lateral or any part thereof due to the failure or refusal of one or more users to maintain the lateral according to standards established by the city, the director shall cause a notice to be served upon the user of the lateral. The notice shall notify the user that a determination has been made that the city must assume maintenance of the lateral due to the failure of the user to maintain the lateral according to city standards, that the cost thereof shall be assessed against the user, and that the city shall perform such maintenance and assess the cost thereof to the user after the expiration of 30 days from the date of such notice to the user unless the user shall appeal such determination by the director to the administrative review board within 30 days from the user's receipt of the notice. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-7) 
Sec. 26-2-79. - Notice of city maintenance. 
    The notice of maintenance to be performed by the city referenced in section 26-2-78 shall be duly served upon the user of the lateral. If the user cannot be personally served with the notice, a copy thereof shall be posted at the entrance of the principal building or structure located upon the premises which receives irrigation water from the lateral, and a copy shall be sent to the last known address of the user by certified mail, return receipt requested. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-8) 
Sec. 26-2-80. - Protest and appeal. 
    Under this division, it shall be the duty of each and every user to effect the maintenance upon the lateral described in the notice within the time prescribed in the notice unless the user shall file a protest and notice of appeal from the determination of the director with the administrative review board pursuant to section 2-4-40. If the user files an appeal to the administrative review board, the director shall withhold action upon his determination pending outcome of the appeal unless failure on the part of the city to maintain the lateral will endanger the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-9) 
Sec. 26-2-81. - Standards and specifications for lateral maintenance. 
    The director shall promulgate and develop standard specifications for maintenance of laterals within the city. Such standards and specifications shall be submitted to the city council for review. Following approval by the city council, laterals in the city shall be maintained in accordance with such standards. Such standard specifications shall be periodically reviewed and updated. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-10) 
Sec. 26-2-82. - Annual determination of maintenance costs; proposed assessment list. 
    The director shall annually prepare and submit to the city council an estimate of the cost which will be required to maintain laterals within the city along with a list of costs proposed to be assessed against each user for lateral maintenance. The proposed assessment list shall be in writing and shall include at least the following information: 
(1)  A description of lateral for which assessment is to be made. 
(2)  The name and address of each user on the lateral. 
(3)  A description of property to be served from the lateral. 
(4)  The amount of the proposed assessment. 
(5)  Elements of cost which were used to determine the assessment. 
(6)  The basis or formula used to calculate the assessment to each user. 
(7)  Other pertinent information. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-12) 
Sec. 26-2-83. - Review and approval of assessment by council. 
    The city council shall review the estimate of costs and the list of proposed assessments prepared in accordance with section 26-2-82 and shall make such changes, additions or corrections as it deems necessary. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-13) 
Sec. 26-2-84. - Notice and hearing on assessments; protest. 
    On or before the first Monday in April of each year, a copy of the assessment to be made against each user of a lateral shall be mailed to each user at the last known address of the user. Each user shall be notified as part of the assessment that any user who wishes to object to the assessment or to the manner or method of its calculation may appeal to the administrative review board by filing a protest in the office of the city clerk within 15 days of the user's receipt of the assessment. A user may protest the proceedings, the assessment roll, or the assessment made to the user. A user may not protest upon the grounds that the assessment creates a personal or economic hardship for the user. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-14) 
Sec. 26-2-85. - Hearing on protest. 
    The administrative review board shall hear and determine all protests under this division pursuant to the procedures established in section 2-4-40. Persons aggrieved by a decision of the administrative review board may appeal to the city council as specified in section 2-4-40. Any assessment made under this division shall be held in abeyance pending the outcome of protest proceedings, provided that interest shall accrue upon the assessment as provided in section 26-2-87. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-15) 
Sec. 26-2-86. - Review by district court. 
    Any user may petition the district court for review of an assessment made under this division within 30 days after exhausting administrative remedies before the administrative review board and before the city council. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-16) 
Sec. 26-2-87. - Assessment due date; interest. 
    Assessments rendered under this division are due and payable to the city 30 days after notice of the assessment is sent to the user. Interest shall accrue on unpaid assessments at the rate of 12 percent per annum from the due date until paid. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-17) 
Sec. 26-2-88. - Payment of assessments for capital improvements in annual installments. 
(a)  Under this division, a user may elect to pay that portion of an assessment which is for capital improvements in annual installments of not less than ten percent of the value of the improvement each year plus interest on the unpaid amount of the assessment at the rate specified in section 26-2-87, provided that any annual payment allowed upon the capital improvement portion of the assessment under this section, excluding interest, except for the final payment, shall not be less than $180.00. 
(b)  A user who elects to pay the capital improvement portion of an assessment in annual installments must file a written notice of such election in the office of the city clerk within 30 days of the date of the first notice of assessment for a particular capital improvement. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-17.1) 
Sec. 26-2-89. - Lien for assessment; foreclosure. 
    Assessments made pursuant to this division shall constitute a lien against the property served, which may be perfected and foreclosed upon as provided by NMSA 1978, §§ 3-18-25 and 3-36-1 et seq. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-18) 
Sec. 26-2-90. - Delinquent assessment or water payment. 
    Under this division, it is unlawful for any user who is delinquent in payment of an assessment for lateral maintenance or who is delinquent in payment of charges for irrigation water to use water from a lateral. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-19) 
Sec. 26-2-91. - Termination of water use for delinquency. 
    The director shall terminate delivery of irrigation water to any user who is delinquent in payment of an assessment due under this division or who is delinquent in payment of charges for irrigation water. 
(Code 1969, § 32-12-20) 
ARTICLE 3. - SEWER USE AND WASTEWATER CONTROL[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city regarding sewers, NMSA 1978, § 3-18-25. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-3-1. - Definitions. 
    Definitions not contained in this section shall be governed by definitions set forth in subchapter N entitled "Effluent Guidelines and Standards" contained in 40 CFR 401 et seq. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Combined sewer means a sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage. 
    Director means the director of the water and wastewater department or his designated representative. 
    Duplex means a building, establishment or structure containing two residential units. 
    Environmental coordinator means the person designated by the city manager to supervise the operation of the approved pretreatment program and who is charged with certain responsibilities under this article. 
    General service means water or sewer service to other than residential units and includes but shall not necessarily be limited to service to office, commercial and industrial units. 
    Interference with any sewage treatment process means any condition or combination of conditions which causes degradation of the operational efficiency of a sewage treatment process. 
    Lateral sewer means an individual user's sewer pipe beginning at the public sewer and extending to the premises actually served. The lateral sewer shall be maintained by the user. The lateral sewer includes the stub to which a user connects. The term is interchangeable with the term "service line," "house service connection" or "building sewer." 
    Multiunit means a building, establishment or structure or a group of buildings, establishments or structures containing four or more residential units or two or more general service units. 
    Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
    Owner means the lawful owner or any tenant or occupant of the premises. 
    Place of human habitation means any place where there is a reasonable requirement for disposal of sewage, human excrement or other liquid waste and includes buildings, structures, tents, vehicles, mobile homes, campers, and other like places used as an abode, dwelling or residence, either for living purposes or as a place of employment for humans when there is a reasonable requirement for disposal of sewage, human excrement or other liquid waste. This definition shall not preclude the emergency use of places for human habitation in an emergency, nor shall it preclude temporary recreational camping where otherwise permitted in public parks or grounds under special permits or in private yards for periods of not to exceed five days. Places of human employment need not be considered under this definition if adequate toilet and sanitation facilities are available for use of employees in reasonably close proximity to the place of employment. 
    Public sewer means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties shall have equal rights and which is controlled by public authority. 
    Rate means the schedule of charges to be paid for water or sewer service supplied to any unit by the city. 
    Residential means water or sewer service which is used for dwelling or residential use as distinguished from office or commercial purposes. Residential service shall include service to single-family dwellings, duplexes, triplexes, and individually metered mobile homes or multiunits that are used for dwelling or residential purposes. 
    Sanitary sewer or sewer system means a public sewer which carries sewage and to which stormwaters, surface waters, and groundwaters are not intentionally admitted. 
    Sewage means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions and industrial establishments, together with such groundwaters, surface waters and stormwaters as may be present. 
    Sewage treatment plant, sewage works means any facility, devices and structures used for receiving and treating sewage from the sanitary sewer system. 
    Sewer means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
    Sewerage system means all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating and disposing of sewage. 
    Storm drain or storm sewer means a sewer which carries storm and surface wastes and drainage, but excludes sewage and polluted industrial wastes, other than unpolluted cooling water. 
    Triplex means a building, establishment or structure containing three residential units. 
    Unit means a single-family dwelling or a single general service entity or establishment where a single activity is carried on. 
    Use means any purpose for which water is required by any unit. 
    Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Code 1969, § 32-2) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-1-2. 
Sec. 26-3-2. - Penalty for violation. 
(a)  Any person who violates any effluent standard or limitation of this article, who violates any term or condition of a wastewater discharge permit, who fails to complete a filing or reporting requirement, who fails to perform or properly report any required monitoring, who violates a final order or determination of the environmental coordinator or hearing officer, who fails to pay any established sewer charge or who otherwise violates any section of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-1-10. 
(b)  Each separate violation shall constitute a separate offense, and, upon conviction, each day of violation shall constitute a separate offense. Each violation of a concentration limit shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1969, § 32-13-1) 
Sec. 26-3-3. - Additional remedies for enforcement. 
    The penalties specified in this article and in section 1-1-10 shall not limit the right of the city to obtain injunctive relief or any other legal remedy otherwise available to the city for enforcement of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 32-13-2) 
Sec. 26-3-4. - Insanitary deposits prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city or in any area under jurisdiction of the city any human or animal excrement, sewage, industrial waste, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
(Code 1969, § 32-70) 
Sec. 26-3-5. - Discharge to natural outlets. 
    It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with this article. 
(Code 1969, § 32-71) 
Sec. 26-3-6. - Construction, maintenance of privies, septic tanks or similar facilities. 
    Except as provided in this article, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. 
(Code 1969, § 32-72) 
Sec. 26-3-7. - Mandatory connection to public sewer. 
    The owner of any house, building or property which is used for human habitation, occupancy, employment or other human purposes and which is located upon a property where public sewer facilities are available is required at his expense to connect such premises directly with the proper public sewer as provided in section 7-4-4. 
(Code 1969, § 32-73) 
Sec. 26-3-8. - Specifications for installing sewer service pipes. 
(a)  Any person who installs service pipes under the public streets shall make such installations subject to the following requirements and specifications: 
(1)  Under all state roads or highways, cast iron pipe shall be used. 
(2)  Under all arterial streets of the city, cast iron pipe shall be used. 
(3)  Under all streets within the city limits which are not state roads or highways or arterial streets and which line shall be situated in dry soil of 36 inches or more in depth, cast iron, transite or vitrified clay shall be used. 
(4)  Under all streets within the city limits which are not state roads or highways or arterial streets, and which line shall be situated in wet soil of 36 inches or more in depth, cast iron or vitrified clay shall be used. 
(5)  Under any street wherein the line shall be situated less than 36 inches in depth, cast iron pipe only shall be used. 
(6)  Bedding material for the installation of any sewer service pipe under public streets within the city shall be in accordance with the specifications established by the city council or its authorized agent. 
(7)  In all soils of wet porous consistency, cast iron saddles shall be placed before the installation of the line. 
(b)  The plumbing inspector is charged with the responsibility of the enforcement of this section, and any person making such installations shall first secure approval therefor from the plumbing inspector. 
(Code 1969, § 32-1) 
Sec. 26-3-9. - Specifications for connections to city sewer system. 
(a)  All connections and taps, which are made to the city sewer pipes and city sewer system, shall be made only with an approved tapping machine and using only approved saddles which conform to specifications of the city. Such specifications shall be promulgated by the public works director and submitted to the city council for approval. Following approval by the city council, a copy of such specifications shall remain on file at all times in the office of the public works director and shall be available upon reasonable occasions for inspection and copying by members of the public. 
(b)  All new sanitary sewer line design and construction shall conform to the Uniform Standard Specifications for Public Works Construction Projects, most recent edition, and applicable provisions of ASTM C 443. If a conflict exists, the Uniform Standard Specifications for Public Works Construction Projects shall prevail. 
(Code 1969, § 32-1.1; Ord. No. 2012-1260, § 3, 11-13-12) 
Sec. 26-3-10. - Conflict in standards. 
    If a conflict occurs between the requirements of this article, the plumbing code, or the rules and regulations of the environmental improvement department (EID), the higher and more strict standard shall be applied to the applicable situation. 
(Code 1969, § 32-1.2) 
Secs. 26-3-11-26-3-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL 

Sec. 26-3-36. - Connection where public system unavailable. 
    Where a public sewer is not available under division 1 of this article, the building, premises or place of human habitation shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system as required by section 7-4-4. 
(Code 1969, § 32-80) 
Sec. 26-3-37. - Connection to public sewer upon availability; abandonment of facilities. 
    At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage disposal system, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with Article 4 of Chapter 7. Such connection shall be made within 120 days after date of official notice to do so, and septic tanks, cesspools and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material pursuant to Article 4 of Chapter 7. 
(Code 1969, § 32-81) 
Sec. 26-3-38. - Operation and maintenance. 
    The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the city. 
(Code 1969, § 32-82) 
Secs. 26-3-39-26-3-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to require connection to public sewer, NMSA 1978, § 3-26-3. 

Sec. 26-3-66. - Permit required; connections generally. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any unauthorized person to uncover, to make any connections with or opening into or to use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the public works director. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any unauthorized person to make any connection to a public sewer or to any sewer line or facility or pipe which is located in any public street, public easement or public right-of-way at any point other than a legal point of connection or disposal. 
(c)  The legal point of connection or disposal in any public street, public easement or public right-of-way shall be the point of connection designated by the public works director or the plumbing inspector pursuant to specifications which may be adopted by the public works director. 
(Code 1969, § 32-90; Ord. No. 2012-1260, § 3, 11-13-12) 
Sec. 26-3-67. - Connections made in presence of public works director or plumbing inspector. 
(a)  The public works director may require that any plumbing connection be made in his presence or in the presence of the plumbing inspector. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to make any plumbing connection in violation of this section. 
(Code 1969, § 32-90.1; Ord. No. 2012-1260, § 3, 11-13-12) 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. 2012-1260, adopted Nov. 13, 2012, changed the title of § 26-3-67 from "Connections made in presence of community development director or plumbing inspector" to "Connections made in presence of public works director or plumbing inspector." 
Sec. 26-3-68. - Owner's costs. 
    All costs and expenses incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(Code 1969, § 32-91) 
Sec. 26-3-69. - Direct connection per lot required. 
(a)  Terms used in this section shall have the same meanings given to terms described in the plumbing code adopted in section 7-4-1. This section shall be incorporated into the plumbing code adopted pursuant to section 7-4-1 as though set forth therein verbatim. 
(b)  Except as provided in this section, the use of "wye," "T" or similar sewer pipe connections designed to connect sewer pipes to serve more than one lot prior to connection to the public sewer is expressly prohibited. 
(c)  The drainage system for each lot shall be directly connected to the public sewer, with such connection to be made at the legal point of connection as designated by the public works director. 
(d)  Pursuant to section 313 of the plumbing code, the drainage system of each new building and of new work installed in any existing building shall be separate and independent from that of any other building. When available every building shall have an independent connection with a public or private sewer. However, where one building stands in the rear of another building on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining court, yard or driveway, the building drain from the front building may be extended to the rear building. 
(e)  A private sewer shall not serve more than one lot, except that private sewer lines may be authorized by the public works director pursuant to safeguards and specifications established by the public works director in connection with: 
(1)  The construction or development of condominiums under the Condominium Act, NMSA 1978, §§ 47-7-1-47-7D-20; or 
(2)  Development or construction under the Building Unit Ownership Act, NMSA 1978, §§ 47-7-1-47-7-25 and 47-7-26-47-7-28. 
(f)  The building sewer for a single building located upon a separate lot shall be directly connected to the public sewer by a separate sewer pipe, with such connection to be made at the legal point of connection designated by the public works director. 
(g)  If more than one building is located on one lot: 
(1)  A sewer drain system plan for such lot shall be presented to and approved by the public works director. 
(2)  Each drainage system on such lot must be directly connected to the public sewer, with such connection to be made at the legal point of connection designated by the public works director. 
(3)  Each building on such lot may, if approved by the public works director, be directly connected to the public sewer by a separate sewer pipe, with such connection to be made at the legal point of connection designated by the public works director. 
(h)  That portion of a sewer pipe that serves a separate lot, separate drainage system or separate building that is located within a public street, public easement or public right-of-way and that connects the drainage system or the building sewer to the public sewer shall be installed and maintained in the public street, easement or right-of-way by the owner of the adjoining lot to which such pipe is connected according to specifications established by the public works director. All such sewer lines that are larger than four inches in diameter shall require the installation of a manhole structure at the expense of the owner of the adjoining lot being served in accordance with specifications established by the public works director. 
(i)  A variance from the requirements of this section may be granted only for extreme hardship. 
(j)  If a variance is granted by the administrative review board or the city council from the requirements of this section: 
(1)  Adequate safeguards such as installation of cleanouts, installation of backwater valves, and similar safeguards pursuant to recommendations and specifications established by the public works director shall be required as a condition to the granting of the variance; and 
(2)  A document, which sets forth a legal description of the property affected, the date of issuance of the variance and the terms and conditions of the variance, shall be filed and placed of record with the county clerk before any occupancy permit is granted. 
(Code 1969, § 32-92; Ord. No. 2012-1260, § 3, 11-13-12) 
Sec. 26-3-70. - Use of old building sewers. 
    Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the director, to meet all requirements of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 32-93) 
Sec. 26-3-71. - Construction standards generally. 
    The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of pipe, pointing, testing and backfilling the trench shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing codes or other applicable rules and regulations by the city. 
(Code 1969, § 32-94) 
Sec. 26-3-72. - Elevation of building sewer. 
    Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(Code 1969, § 32-95) 
Sec. 26-3-73. - Connection of sources of runoff or groundwater. 
    No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
(Code 1969, § 32-96) 
Sec. 26-3-74. - Connection to public sewer. 
    The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing codes or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the director before installation. 
(Code 1969, § 32-97) 
Sec. 26-3-75. - Guarding of excavations; restoration of public property. 
(a)  Any person who excavates or who is responsible for an excavation for building sewer installation shall adequately guard the excavation with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. 
(b)  Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored by such person in a manner satisfactory to the city. 
(Code 1969, § 32-98) 
Sec. 26-3-76. - Action of director upon discharge of waters possessing characteristics enumerated in division 4. 
    If any waters or wastes from a building sewer are discharged or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in division 4 of this article and which in the judgment of the director may have a deleterious effect upon the sewerage system, processes, equipment or receiving waters or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the director may: 
(1)  Reject the wastes; 
(2)  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers; 
(3)  Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and 
(4)  Require payment to cover the added cost of handling and treating the wastes which are not covered by existing sewer charges under section 26-4-82. 
(Code 1969, § 32-104) 
Sec. 26-3-77. - Pretreatment or equalization of waste flows. 
    Under this division, if the director permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the director and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes, ordinances and laws. Such facilities shall be maintained in proper operation by the owner and at the expense of the owner. 
(Code 1969, § 32-105) 
Sec. 26-3-78. - Grease, oil and sand traps or interceptors. 
    For building sewers, grease, oil and sand traps or interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the director, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts or any flammable wastes, sand or other harmful ingredients, except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All traps or interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the director and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. Grease and oil traps or interceptors shall be installed in all new filling stations, garages, restaurants and other new facilities wherein heavy discharge of grease and oil is to be expected. 
(Code 1969, § 32-106) 
Sec. 26-3-79. - Manholes. 
    When required by the director, the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located, shall be constructed in such a manner as to prevent the infiltration of groundwaters and surface waters, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the director. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense and shall be maintained by the owner so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(Code 1969, § 32-107) 
Sec. 26-3-80. - Special agreements. 
    No statement contained in this article shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the city for treatment, subject to payment therefor by the industrial concern. 
(Code 1969, § 32-109) 
Secs. 26-3-81-26-3-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - USE OF SEWERS[7]
