When requested and demonstrated by the user furnishing a report that such information should be held confidential, the portions of a report that might disclose trade secrets or secret processes shall not be made available for inspection by the public, but shall be made available immediately upon request to governmental agencies for uses related to the NPDES program or pretreatment program and in enforcement proceedings involving the person furnishing the report. Wastewater constituents and characteristics and other effluent data, as defined by 40 CFR 2.302, will not be recognized as confidential information and will be available to the public without restriction. 
(Ord. No. 2012-1260, § 1, 11-13-12) 
Sec. 26-3-122. - Publication of users in significant noncompliance. 
    The environmental coordinator shall publish annually, in a newspaper of general circulation that provides meaningful public notice within the jurisdictions served by the POTW, a list of the users which, at any time during the previous 12 months, were in significant noncompliance with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements. The term "significant noncompliance" shall be applicable to all significant industrial users (or any other industrial user that violates paragraphs (3), (4) or (8) of this section) and shall mean: 
(1)  Chronic violations of wastewater discharge limits, defined here as those in which 66 percent or more of all the wastewater measurements taken for the same pollutant parameter during a six-month period exceed (by any magnitude) a numeric pretreatment standard or requirement, including instantaneous limits as defined in section 26-3-106. 
(2)  Technical review criteria (TRC) violations, defined here as those in which 33 percent or more of wastewater measurements taken for each pollutant parameter during a six-month period equals or exceeds the product of a numeric pretreatment standard or requirement, including an instantaneous limits, as defined in sections 26-3-111 through 26-3-115, multiplied by the applicable criteria (1.4 for BOD, TSS, fats, oil, and grease, and 1.2 for all other pollutants except pH); 
(3)  Any other discharge violation of a pretreatment standard or requirement as defined by section 26-3-106 (daily maximum, long-term average, instantaneous limit, or narrative standard) that the environmental coordinator determines has caused, alone or in combination with other discharges, interference or pass through, including endangering the health of POTW personnel or the general public; 
(4)  Any discharge of a pollutant that has caused imminent endangerment to the public or to the environment, or has resulted in the environmental coordinator's exercise of its emergency authority to halt or prevent such a discharge; 
(5)  Failure to meet, within 90 days of the scheduled date, a compliance schedule milestone contained in a wastewater discharge permit or enforcement order for starting construction, completing construction, or attaining final compliance; 
(6)  Failure to provide, within 30 days after the due date, any required reports, including baseline monitoring reports, reports on compliance with categorical pretreatment standard deadlines, periodic self-monitoring reports, and reports on compliance with compliance schedules; 
(7)  Failure to accurately report noncompliance; or 
(8)  Any other violation, which may include a violation of best management practices, which the environmental coordinator determines will adversely affect the operation or implementation of the local pretreatment program. 
(Ord. No. 2012-1260, § 1, 11-13-12) 
Sec. 26-3-123. - Administrative enforcement remedies. 
(a)  Notification of violation. When the environmental coordinator finds that a user has violated, or continues to violate, any section of this division, a wastewater discharge permit, or order issued under this division, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, the environmental coordinator may serve upon that user a written notice of violation. Within ten days of the receipt of this notice, an explanation of the violation and a plan for the satisfactory correction and prevention thereof, to include specific required actions, shall be submitted by the user to the environmental coordinator. Submission of this plan in no way relieves the user of liability for any violations occurring before or after receipt of the notice of violation. Nothing in this section shall limit the authority of the environmental coordinator to take any action, including emergency actions or any other enforcement action, without first issuing a notice of violation. 
(b)  Conciliation. The environmental coordinator may enter into consent orders, assurances of compliance, or other similar documents establishing an agreement with any user responsible for noncompliance. Such documents will include specific action to be taken by the user to correct the noncompliance within a time period specified by the document. Such documents shall have the same force and effect as the administrative orders issued pursuant to subsections (d) and (e) of this section and shall be judicially enforceable. 
(c)  Show cause hearing. The environmental coordinator may order a user who has violated, or continues to violate, any section of this division, a wastewater discharge permit, or order issued under this division, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement to appear before the environmental coordinator and show cause why the proposed enforcement action should not be taken. Notice shall be served on the user specifying the time and place for the meeting, the proposed enforcement action, the reasons for such action, and a request that the user show cause why the proposed enforcement action should not be taken. The notice of the meeting shall be served personally or by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, at least ten days before the hearing. Such notice may be served on any authorized representative of the user. A show cause hearing shall not be a bar against or prerequisite for taking any other action against the user. 
(d)  Compliance orders. When the environmental coordinator finds that a user has violated, or continues to violate, any section of this division, a wastewater discharge permit, or order issued under this division, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, the environmental coordinator may issue an order to the user responsible for the discharge directing that the user come into compliance within a specified time. If the user does not come into compliance within the time provided, sewer service may be discontinued unless adequate treatment facilities, devices, or other related appurtenances are installed and properly operated. Compliance orders also may contain other requirements to address the noncompliance, including additional self-monitoring and management practices designed to minimize the amount of pollutants discharged to the sewer. A compliance order may not extend the deadline for compliance established for a pretreatment standard or requirement, nor does a compliance order relieve the user of liability for any violation, including any continuing violation. Issuance of a compliance order shall not be a bar against or a prerequisite for taking any other action against the user. 
(e)  Cease and desist orders. When the environmental coordinator finds that a user has violated, or continues to violate, any section of this division, a wastewater discharge permit, or order issued under this division, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement or that the user's past violations are likely to recur, the environmental coordinator may issue an order to the user directing it to cease and desist all such violations and directing the user to: 
(1)  Immediately comply with all requirements; and 
(2)  Take such appropriate remedial or preventive action as may be needed to properly address a continuing or threatened violation, including halting operations and terminating the discharge. 
    Issuance of a cease and desist order shall not be a bar against or a prerequisite for taking any other action against the user. 
(f)  Emergency suspensions. The environmental coordinator may immediately suspend a user's discharge, after informal notice to the user, whenever such suspension is necessary to stop an actual or threatened discharge, which reasonably appears to present or cause an imminent or substantial endangerment to the health or welfare of persons. The environmental coordinator may also immediately suspend a user's discharge, after notice and opportunity to respond, that threatens to interfere with the operation of the POTW or that presents or may present an endangerment to the environment. 
(1)  Any user notified of a suspension of its discharge shall immediately stop or eliminate its contribution. If a user fails to immediately comply voluntarily with the suspension order, the environmental coordinator may take such steps as deemed necessary, including immediate severance of the sewer connection, to prevent or minimize damage to the POTW, its receiving stream, or endangerment to any individuals. The environmental coordinator may allow the user to recommence its discharge when the user has demonstrated to the satisfaction of the environmental coordinator that the period of endangerment has passed, unless the termination proceedings in subsection (g) of this section are initiated against the user. 
(2)  A user that is responsible, in whole or in part, for any discharge presenting imminent endangerment shall submit a detailed written statement, describing the causes of the harmful contribution and the measures taken to prevent any future occurrence, to the environmental coordinator prior to the date of any show cause or termination hearing under subsections (c) and (g) of this section. 
    Nothing in this section shall be interpreted as requiring a hearing prior to any emergency suspension under this section. 
(g)  Termination of discharge. In addition to subsection 26-3-118(e), any user who violates the following conditions is subject to discharge termination: 
(1)  Violation of wastewater discharge permit conditions; 
(2)  Failure to accurately report the wastewater constituents and characteristics of its discharge; 
(3)  Failure to report significant changes in operations or wastewater volume, constituents, and characteristics prior to discharge; 
(4)  Refusal of reasonable access to the user's premises for the purpose of inspection, monitoring, or sampling; or 
(5)  Violation of the pretreatment standards in section 26-3-112. 
    Such user will be notified of the proposed termination of its discharge and be offered an opportunity to show cause under subsection (c) of this section why the proposed action should not be taken. Exercise of this option by the environmental coordinator shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, taking any other action against the user. 
(Ord. No. 2012-1260, § 1, 11-13-12) 
Sec. 26-3-124. - Judicial enforcement remedies. 
(a)  Injunctive relief. When the environmental coordinator finds that a user has violated, or continues to violate, any section of this division, a wastewater discharge permit, or order issued under this division, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, the environmental coordinator may petition the district court through the city's attorney for the issuance of a temporary or permanent injunction, as appropriate, which restrains or compels the specific performance of the wastewater discharge permit, order, or other requirement imposed by this division on activities of the user. The environmental coordinator may also seek such other action as is appropriate for legal and/or equitable relief, including a requirement for the user to conduct environmental remediation. A petition for injunctive relief shall not be a bar against or a prerequisite for, taking any other action against a user. 
(b)  Damages and enforcement costs. 
(1)  A user who has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this division, an individual wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement shall be liable to the city for a maximum fine of $1,000.00 per violation, per day, as provided in subsection 1-1-10(e) of this Code. In the case of a monthly or other long-term average discharge limit, penalties shall accrue for each day during the period of the violation. 
(2)  The environmental coordinator may recover reasonable attorneys' fees, court costs, and other expenses associated with enforcement activities, including sampling and monitoring expenses, and the cost of any actual damages incurred by the city. 
(3)  In determining the amount of civil liability, the court shall take into account all relevant circumstances, including, but not limited to, the extent of harm caused by the violation, the magnitude and duration of the violation, any economic benefit gained through the user's violation, corrective actions by the user, the compliance history of the user, and any other factor as justice requires. 
(4)  Filing a suit for civil penalties shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, taking any other action against a user. 
(c)  Criminal prosecution. 
(1)  A user who willfully or negligently violates any section of this division, a wastewater discharge permit, or order issued under this division, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of $1,000.00 per violation per day or imprisonment for 90 days or both. 
(2)  A user who willfully or negligently introduces any substance into the POTW which causes personal injury or property damage shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor and be subject to a penalty of at least $1,000.00 per violation per day or be subject to imprisonment for not more than 90 days or both. This penalty shall be in addition to any other cause of action for personal injury or property damage available under state law. 
(3)  A user who knowingly makes any false statements, representations, or certifications in any application, record, report, plan, or other documentation filed or required to be maintained pursuant to this division, a wastewater discharge permit or order issued under this division or who falsifies, tampers with, or knowingly renders inaccurate any monitoring device or method required under this division shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of $1,000.00 per violation per day or imprisonment for not more than 90 days or both. 
(4)  In the event of a second conviction, a user shall be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 per violation, per day, or imprisonment for not more than 90 days, or both. 
(d)  Remedies nonexclusive. The remedies provided for in this division are not exclusive. The environmental coordinator may take any, all, or any combination of these actions against a noncompliant user. Enforcement of pretreatment violations will generally be in accordance with the city's enforcement response plan. However, the environmental coordinator may take other action against any user when the circumstances warrant. Further, the environmental coordinator is empowered to take more than one enforcement action against any noncompliant user. 
(Ord. No. 2012-1260, § 1, 11-13-12) 
Sec. 26-3-125. - Supplemental enforcement action. 
(a)  Performance bonds. The environmental coordinator may decline to issue or reissue a wastewater discharge permit to any user who has failed to comply with any section of this division, a previous wastewater discharge permit, or order issued under this division, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, unless such user first files a satisfactory bond, payable to the city, in a sum not to exceed a value determined by the environmental coordinator to be necessary to achieve consistent compliance. 
(b)  Water supply severance. Whenever a user has violated or continues to violate any section of this division, a wastewater discharge permit or order issued under this division, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, water service to the user may be severed. Service will recommence, at the user's expense, only after it has satisfactorily demonstrated its ability to comply. 
(c)  Public nuisances. A violation of any section of this division, a wastewater discharge permit or order issued under this division, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement is declared a public nuisance and shall be corrected or abated as directed by the environmental coordinator. Any person(s) creating a public nuisance shall be subject to section 18-5-11 governing such nuisances, including reimbursing the city for any costs incurred in removing, abating, or remedying the nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 2012-1260, § 1, 11-13-12) 
Sec. 26-3-126. - Affirmative defenses to discharge violations. 
(a)  Upset. Under this division, the affirmative defense of upset shall apply as follows: 
(1)  For the purposes of this subsection, the term "upset" means an exceptional incident in which there is unintentional and temporary noncompliance with categorical pretreatment standards because of factors beyond the reasonable control of the user. An upset does not include noncompliance to the extent caused by operational error, improperly designed treatment facilities, inadequate treatment facilities, lack of preventive maintenance, or careless or improper operation. 
(2)  An upset shall constitute an affirmative defense to an action brought for noncompliance with categorical pretreatment standards if the requirements of subsection (a)(3) of this section are met. 
(3)  A user who wishes to establish the affirmative defense of upset shall demonstrate, through properly signed, contemporaneous operating logs or other relevant evidence, that: 
a.  An upset occurred and the user can identify the cause of the upset; 
b.  The facility was at the time being operated in a prudent and workmanlike manner and in compliance with applicable operation and maintenance procedures; and 
c.  The user has submitted the following information to the environmental coordinator within 24 hours of becoming aware of the upset; if this information is provided orally, a written submission must be provided within five days: 
1.  A description of the indirect discharge and cause of noncompliance; 
2.  The period of noncompliance, including exact dates and times or, if not corrected, the anticipated time the noncompliance is expected to continue; and 
3.  Steps being taken and planned to reduce, eliminate, and prevent recurrence of the noncompliance. 
(4)  In any enforcement proceeding, the user seeking to establish the occurrence of an upset shall have the burden of proof. 
(5)  A user will have the opportunity for a judicial determination on any claim of upset only in an enforcement action brought for noncompliance with categorical pretreatment standards. 
(6)  A user shall control production of all discharges to the extent necessary to maintain compliance with categorical pretreatment standards upon reduction, loss, or failure of its treatment facility until the facility is restored or an alternative method of treatment is provided. This requirement applies in the situation where, among other things, the primary source of power of the treatment facility is reduced, lost, or fails. 
(b)  Prohibited discharge standards. A user shall have an affirmative defense to an enforcement action brought against it for noncompliance with the general prohibitions in subsection 26-3-111(a) or the specific prohibitions in subsection 26-3-111(b) if it can prove that it did not know, or have reason to know, that its discharge, alone or in conjunction with discharges from other sources, would cause pass through or interference and that either: 
(1)  A local limit exists for each pollutant discharged and the user was in compliance with each limit directly prior to, and during, the pass through or interference; or 
(2)  No local limit exists, but the discharge did not change substantially in nature or constituents from the user's prior discharge when the city was regularly in compliance with its NPDES permit, and, in the case of interference, was in compliance with applicable sludge use or disposal requirements. 
(c)  Bypass. 
(1)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this subsection, shall have the following meanings, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
a.  Bypass means the intentional diversion of waste streams from any portion of a user's treatment facility. 
b.  Severe property damage means substantial physical damage to property, damage to the treatment facilities which causes them to become inoperable, or substantial and permanent loss of natural resources which can reasonably be expected to occur in the absence of a bypass. Severe property damage does not mean economic loss caused by delays in production. 
(2)  A user may allow any bypass to occur which does not cause pretreatment standards or requirements to be violated, but only if it also is for essential maintenance to ensure efficient operation. These bypasses are not subject to subsections (c)(3) and (4) of this section. 
(3)  If a user knows in advance of the need for a bypass, it shall submit prior notice to the environmental coordinator, at least ten days before the date of the bypass, if possible. 
a.  A user shall submit oral notice to the environmental coordinator of an unanticipated bypass that exceeds applicable pretreatment standards within 24 hours from the time it becomes aware of the bypass. A written submission shall also be provided within five days of the time the user becomes aware of the bypass. The written submission shall contain a description of the bypass and its cause; the duration of the bypass, including exact dates and times, and, if the bypass has not been corrected, the anticipated time it is expected to continue; and steps taken or planned to reduce, eliminate, and prevent reoccurrence of the bypass. The environmental coordinator may waive the written report on a case-by-case basis if the oral report has been received within 24 hours. 
(4)  Bypass is prohibited, and the environmental coordinator may take an enforcement action against a user for a bypass, unless: 
a.  Bypass was unavoidable to prevent loss of life, personal injury, or severe property damage; 
b.  There were no feasible alternatives to the bypass, such as the use of auxiliary treatment facilities, retention of untreated wastes, or maintenance during normal periods of equipment downtime. This condition is not satisfied if adequate backup equipment should have been installed in the exercise of reasonable engineering judgment to prevent a bypass which occurred during normal periods of equipment downtime or preventive maintenance; and 
c.  The user submitted notices as required under subsection (c)(3) of this section. 
d.  The environmental coordinator may approve an anticipated bypass, after considering its adverse effects, if the environmental coordinator determines that it will meet the three conditions listed in subsection (c)(4)a. of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2012-1260, § 1, 11-13-12) 
Sec. 26-3-127. - Wastewater treatment rates. 
(a)  A hauled wastewater user shall pay such fees to the city for the privilege of discharging septic waste into the POTW according to the schedule of fees that may be approved and adopted by action of the city council from time to time. 
(b)  Users shall pay a surcharge to be set by the city council for violation of the following local limits: 
400 mg/l COD. 
300 mg/l TSS. 
100 mg/l FOG. 
(Ord. No. 2012-1260, § 1, 11-13-12) 
Sec. 26-3-128. - Pretreatment charges and fees. 
    The city may adopt reasonable fees for reimbursement of costs of setting up and operating the city's pretreatment program which may include: 
(1)  Fees for wastewater discharge permit applications, including the cost of processing such applications; 
(2)  Fees for monitoring, inspection and surveillance procedures including the cost of collection and analyzing a user's discharge, and reviewing monitoring reports submitted by users; 
(3)  Fees for reviewing and responding to accidental discharge procedures and construction; 
(4)  Fees for filing appeals; and 
(5)  Other fees as the city may deem necessary to carry out the requirements contained in this article. These fees relate solely to the matters covered by this article and are separate from all other fees, fines and penalties chargeable by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2012-1260, § 1, 11-13-12) 
Secs. 26-3-129-26-3-155. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - SEPTIC WASTE DISPOSAL 

Sec. 26-3-156. - Permit required. 
    Any person wishing to dispose of septic waste at the city waste water treatment plant shall obtain a permit from the public works director and pay the fees required by this division. The public works director, in his discretion, may refuse to accept applications for disposal of septic waste material which has been generated outside of the city limits. 
(Code 1969, § 32-11-1; Ord. No. 2012-1260, § 3, 11-13-12) 
Sec. 26-3-157. - Application for permit. 
    Any person wishing to obtain a permit required by this division shall complete and file an application for such permit, which shall be in such form as the public works director may require and which shall contain, but shall not be limited to, the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and phone number of the applicant. 
(2)  A description of the type of septic material to be disposed of, i.e., recreational vehicle dumping, domestic septic tank sewage, commercial septic tank cleaning, etc. 
(3)  The address or origin of the septic waste material. 
(4)  The quantity in gallons of septic waste for disposal. 
(5)  A description of the tank truck or vehicle used to transport the septic waste to the wastewater treatment plant, including, but not necessarily limited to, the vehicle manufacturer, model, unit number, license plate identification and septic tank capacity. 
(6)  The name, address and phone number of the owner of the septic waste material. 
(Code 1969, § 32-11-2; Ord. No. 2012-1260, § 3, 11-13-12) 
Sec. 26-3-158. - Certification of permit application. 
(a)  The applicant for a permit required by this division shall certify, declare or affirm under penalty of perjury, in such form as the public works director shall require, that the application is true and correct and that the septic waste does not contain hazardous materials, PCBs or other material which is prohibited from being discharged into the city wastewater sewers or treatment plant. 
(b)  The applicant may be required to further certify, if the public works director requires, that the septic waste presented for disposal was generated within the city limits. 
(Code 1969, § 32-11-3; Ord. No. 2012-1260, § 3, 11-13-12) 
Sec. 26-3-159. - Issuance of permit. 
    If the public works director finds the application for the permit required in this division to be in order and the appropriate permit fee has been paid, a permit, in such form as may be specified by the public works director, shall be issued to the applicant, which shall include instructions as to the place and procedure to be followed, including cleanup and applicable safety procedures, for discharging or dumping of the septic waste material. 
(Code 1969, § 32-11-5; Ord. No. 2012-1260, § 3, 11-13-12) 
Sec. 26-3-160. - Denial of permit. 
(a)  The public works director may deny a permit for discharge of septic waste under this division if the director has reasonable grounds to believe that: 
(1)  The application contained false statements or false information; 
(2)  The quantity of waste is too great for the wastewater treatment plant to handle; 
(3)  The septic waste contains PCBs, hazardous waste or other material which would be detrimental to the wastewater treatment plant; 
(4)  The applicant will not follow procedures specified for disposal; or 
(5)  The septic material to be disposed of would otherwise be detrimental to the public health, safety and welfare. 
(b)  Any such denial shall be in writing and shall state the reasons for the denial. A signed copy of the denial shall be provided to the applicant. 
(Code 1969, § 32-11-6; Ord. NNo. 2012-1260, § 3, 11-13-12) 
Sec. 26-3-161. - Appeal of permit denial. 
    Any person denied a permit under this division may appeal such denial to the administrative review board in the manner specified in division 2 of Article 4 of Chapter 2. 
(Code 1969, § 32-11-7) 
Sec. 26-3-162. - Fees. 
    Domestic and commercial septic tank haulers discharging septic waste into the city's wastewater treatment plant shall pay the charges assessed in section 26-4-82 of this Code. 
(Code 1969, § 32-11-4; Ord. No. 2006-1177, § 4, 10-24-06) 
ARTICLE 4. - RATES AND CHARGES[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Finance, § 2-5-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-4-1. - Inseparable charges and service. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, the water, sewer and trash services of the city are nonseparable services, and the request for the furnishing of one service shall mean the charge and collection, whether used or not, of all other services. Similarly, a request for the termination of one such utility service is a request for the termination of all such utility services, and a termination of utility service for a portion of a structure is declared to be termination of utility services for all of the structure. 
(b)  The furnishing of separate utility services will be permitted when it is not otherwise possible for the city to furnish all of those services. 
(c)  If one or more of the utility services is not used when available, the minimum rates as set forth in the applicable rate sections of this article shall be charged and collected with the charges for the utilities used. 
(d)  Electric utility service shall not be subject to this section. 
(Code 1969, § 32-1.3) 
Sec. 26-4-2. - Separable charges for contractors and developers. 
(a)  Contractors or developers building new dwelling units shall be charged for water in the same manner as a single-family residence only for that period during which such units are under construction. 
(b)  No meter shall be set or other services provided for any premises to the extent that any billings to the contractor, whether miscellaneous or utility, are in arrears. 
(Code 1969, § 32-1.4) 
Secs. 26-4-3-26-4-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WATER RATES AND CONNECTION CHARGES 

Sec. 26-4-31. - Individual meters for each unit; installation charge. 
    Except as provided in section 26-4-32, subsection 26-4-34(b) and section 26-4-45, no unit shall be furnished water from the city water system unless such water shall be measured by a water meter established by the water department for each unit. Each unit served shall be under separate ownership or control of the water user and shall be located on a separately owned tract of land unless otherwise authorized by the city manager pursuant to section 26-4-32, subsection 26-4-34(b) and section 26-4-45. The fee or charge for the installation of such meter shall be paid by the person owning such unit before water service shall be furnished. 
(Code 1969, § 32-3) 
Sec. 26-4-32. - Exception to requirement of single meter. 
(a)  Multiunit residential and multiunit general service units that are under a single ownership may be furnished water from the city water system through one master meter upon the rates specified for multiunits in section 26-4-33. 
(b)  The city manager may also, subject to review by the city council, upon determination that unnecessary expense and undue burden or other unreasonable difficulty would be caused by the requirement set forth in section 26-4-31 that a single meter be required for each residential or general service unit, permit and direct that water service be provided through one or more meters of adequate size installed by the city and paid for by the user, as provided in section 26-4-31, to serve two or more units. 
(c)  The director may enter into separate contracts, notwithstanding section 26-4-1 pertaining to nonseparable charges, and service the installation of separate meters for sprinkling and lawn watering if the customer can demonstrate that the installation of a separate meter will provide an equitable sewer service charge to such customer. Sprinkling meters shall be subject to periodic inspection by the city. 
(d)  The city manager may authorize water service to separate meters installed within mobile home parks as an exception to section 26-4-31 which requires that units to which water service be provided be under single ownership on a separately identified tract of land. 
(Code 1969, § 32-6)

2 Year 2 rates shall take effect the first billing cycle after December 1, 2015. 
3 Year 3 rates shall take effect the first billing cycle after December 1, 2016. 
4 Year 4 rates shall take effect the first billing cycle after December 1, 2017. 
5 Year 5 rates shall take effect the first billing cycle after December 1, 2018. 
(10)  Automatic adjustment. 
a.  Beginning in calendar year 2019, no later than October 15 of each year, the city manager shall: 
1.  Notify the city council that under this section, an automatic increase in water rates shall take place equal to 75 percent of the change in the Consumer Price Index (Department of Labor, Bureau of Labor Statistics, Consumer Price Index-All Urban Consumers, Water and Sewerage Maintenance (CPI) or its equivalent successor index) over the previous 12-month period ending the previous July 1 and what the proposed increase will be in the form of a percentage increase; and 
2.  Publish in a newspaper of general circulation and post in the city hall lobby and on the city's web-site a notice providing what the proposed increase would be and stating that the proposed increase will be effective on December 1 of that year unless the council, by affirmative action, adopts a motion cancelling the proposed increase on or before November 15. 
b.  Unless the council, by affirmative action taken on or before November 15, cancels the implementation of the new proposed rates, the proposed increase based on the change in the CPI will take effect and shall be reflected on all water charges billed after December 1 of that year. 
(Code 1969, § 32-4; Ord. No. 2006-1177, § 1, 10-24-06; Ord. No. 2014-1271, §§ 1, 3, 11-11-14) 
Sec. 26-4-34. - Exceptions to rates. 
(a)  Drip allowance. Notwithstanding any other section of this chapter the city council may, in its discretion, allow a reasonable drip allowance on the rates and charges in order to prevent the freezing of meters and lines during the winter months. 
(b)  Large users. Notwithstanding any other section of this chapter, the city manager, subject to the approval of the city council, may negotiate and establish separate water rates and reasonable rate classifications for water users' associations whose members are not individually metered by the city, commercial water users, other municipalities and water users of similar classifications. All such contracts shall be in writing and all such contracts, except those entered into with other municipalities, which provide for water usage outside of the city limits shall, among other things, unless for good cause waived by the city council, require that the water user shall: 
(1)  Abide by all terms and conditions of any applicable city ordinance, rule or regulation which pertains to the providing of water service. 
(2)  Require that the user provide bond or security to guarantee payment of utility service. 
(3)  Unless specifically otherwise authorized by the city council, pay by cash in advance and prior to installation all costs and expenses which the city may incur to provide water service to the point of delivery, including but not necessarily limited to the cost and expense of water lines, extensions, meters, meter backflow preventer, engineering, licenses, permits, fees, legal expenses and the cost and expense of obtaining easements and rights-of-way. 
(4)  Pay for any cost of service study which may be required to determine the cost at which water should be provided to the water user. 
(5)  Pay for the cost of water. 
(6)  Comply with all federal, state, county or city land subdivision rules and regulations which may be made applicable to properties to be served under the agreement and require any person who receives water through the water user's association and the owner of any property who is to be served through the water user to comply with such rules and regulations. 
(7)  Agree that all water lines and facilities shall be installed in publicly dedicated streets or within rights-of-way or within easements which are or will be assigned easily and readily to the city without cost to the city upon annexation to the city of the property to be served. 
(8)  Agree that all water lines and facilities which may be installed by the user beyond the city meter, including but not necessarily limited to pipes, lines, equipment, regulators, meters, meter cans and stubs, shall meet or exceed the standards established by the city for such installation at the time of installation and shall be installed and maintained pursuant to city inspection procedures. 
(9)  Agree that all lines and facilities shall be certified and properly installed by a licensed and qualified contractor and that all installations shall be inspected by a qualified inspector or engineer acceptable to the city. 
(10)  Agree that, as a condition of receiving service, each customer of the large user or water users' association shall provide to the city a written agreement in such form as the city may require, signed by the owner of the parcel of land that is to receive water service, which shall constitute a covenant that will attach to and run with such land and that shall be binding upon such owner and the heirs, personal representatives, successors and assigns of such owner, wherein the owner of the property to receive water service shall agree to the annexation of the property so served to the city at such time as the city council may determine that the growth and expansion of the city requires such annexation. 
(11)  Agree that the city will not be obligated to provide fire protection or other municipal service to the users or to persons who reside outside of the city limits. 
(12)  Agree to be fully responsible for pumping and delivery of water service beyond the meter and that city will not be obligated to provide more water or water pressure greater than that which is specified in any agreement between the city and the large water user. 
(13)  Agree to, periodically at such times and in such form as may be requested by the city, provide the city with a list of all water users served through the large water user or water users' association, identified by customer name, address, and phone number; the large user's meter number; description of the property to be served; and such other information as the city may require. 
(14)  Agree that the large water user, water users' association, or other entity receiving water shall, in case of drought, water shortage, or other emergency, be subject to the same curtailment or restriction upon use of water as are other persons who receive water from the city water system. 
(Code 1969, §§ 32-6.2, 32-6.4) 
Sec. 26-4-35. - Connection charge. 
(a)  A service connection charge shall be charged for connection of water service as follows: 
(1)  If water only is connected, $15.00. 
(2)  If both water and electricity are connected, $30.00. 
(b)  As used in this section, service connection (turn-on) shall include all water service connections except those specified in section 26-4-36 pertaining to reconnection charges and shall include initial service connections, interim connections, and connections required due to change of occupancy, even though such connections may only involve reading of an installed meter and administrative paperwork required. 
(Code 1969, § 32-7; Ord. No. 98-1069, § 2, 2-24-1998) 
Sec. 26-4-36. - Reconnection charge. 
    The following service reconnection charges shall be charged for reconnection of water service after service has been disconnected for failure to pay the assessed rates or charges for water service: 
(1)  For each reconnection during regular city business hours ..... $4.00 
(2)  For each reconnection after regular city business hours ..... 6.00 
(Code 1969, § 32-7.1; Ord. No. 98-1069, § 3, 2-24-1998) 
Sec. 26-4-37. - Billing; due date; delinquency. 
    Bills for water service shall be prepared in accordance with the rates and charges specified in this chapter and processed in accordance with the adopted rules and regulations for electric service (FEUS). Bills for water service shall be sent to each owner, or user, by mail, monthly. The amount of such bill shall be due and payable on the billing date specified on such bill; and if not paid on or before the 14th day after the billing date specified on the bill, the amount thereof shall thereafter be deemed delinquent and subject to the late charges and collection procedures specified in such rules and regulations and subject to the lien claim of the city as provided in section 26-4-39. 
(Code 1969, § 32-8; Ord. No. 98-1069, § 4, 2-24-1998) 
Sec. 26-4-38. - Payment for water connection charges. 
    Any charge to be collected by the city under the provisions of this division for connections with the city water system shall be due and payable at the time the connection is made, except as authorized elsewhere in this chapter for main line extension fees and impact fees. 
(Code 1969, § 32-9; Ord. No. 98-1069, § 5, 2-24-1998) 
Sec. 26-4-39. - Lien for unpaid water service and connection charges. 
    All unpaid water service or connection charges levied and collectible under this division are declared to be a lien upon the property benefited, but such lien shall not be enforceable until a declaration of the lien claim is filed with the county clerk. Such lien shall describe the property against which the lien is claimed, shall set forth the amount of the claim and shall state the date of the service or connection. 
(Code 1969, § 32-10) 
Sec. 26-4-40. - Standby water service charge. 
(a)  As used in this section, the term "improved property" shall mean that buildings, structures or improvements have been made or placed upon such property which require water, plumbing or connection to a public or private sewer system under this chapter or pursuant to the building or plumbing codes. 
(b)  There is imposed a standby water service charge upon all improved lots or land within the city that do not have a city water connection and city water service. 
(c)  In order for such standby water service charge to be levied, the improved property must adjoin a street, right-of-way or easement in which a city water line exists or shall otherwise be accessible to such and to which city water connections can be made to adequately service such property. 
(d)  The standby water service charge shall be equivalent to the minimum customer and capacity charge per unit which could be served to such improved property based upon the improvements upon, the use made of, and the zoning of such property as determined by the city manager. Residential lots shall be charged the minimum residential unit rate specified in section 26-4-33. The appropriate general service unit capacity and volume charge per month shall be based upon the actual number of apartment, commercial or industrial units upon such property as determined by the city manager. 
(e)  Charges under this section shall be imposed and billed monthly along with regular utility billing and shall become delinquent in the same manner as other water utility accounts. 
(f)  The charges imposed by this section shall constitute a lien superior to all other liens except general property taxes upon the property so charged and shall be the personal responsibility of the owner thereof. The lien shall be enforced as provided in NMSA 1978, §§ 3-36-1-3-36-6. 
(g)  No charge shall be made pursuant to this section for service to any lot or land where, for technical or equitable reasons as determined by the city manager, water service could not be reasonably used by such property. 
(h)  Any person aggrieved by a charge imposed under this section or by any determination made by the city manager may appeal to the board of public utility commissioners within 30 days after the imposition of such charge or such determination. 
(Code 1969, § 32-10.1) 
Sec. 26-4-41. - State governmental gross receipts tax and other taxes. 
    The state governmental gross receipts tax and other taxes, if applicable, shall be added to all rates and charges established under this division relating to water rates and connection charges, including but not necessarily limited to charges made to residential and commercial users within and without the city limits, large water users, water users' associations, wholesale customers and connection, disconnection and reconnection and standby charges. 
(Code 1969, § 32-10.2) 
Sec. 26-4-42. - State water conservation fee. 
    There is imposed and charged on all water sold by the city a state water conservation fee of $0.04 per 1,000 gallons purchased. The state water conservation fee shall be billed as a distinct and separate charge to each customer and shall be billed to and paid by all customers, whether retail or large users, whether located in or outside of the city, and whether purchasing raw or treated water. 
(Code 1969, § 32-10.3) 
Sec. 26-4-43. - New water service installations. 
(a)  A new water service installation is a request for service where water service has not been provided previously and shall fall into one of the following classes: 
(1)  New water service installation with stub where connection to the system only requires setting of a water meter; and 
(2)  New water service installation without stub where connection to the system requires tapping of the water main, installation of a service line from the main to the meter and setting of a meter can and meter. 
(b)  Charges for all classes of new water service installations shall be made in accordance with a list of such charges to be kept on file at all times in the offices of the community development department and city clerk. This list shall be prepared and updated annually by the public works director, or designee, and approved by the city manager. Each of the charges contained on the list shall approximate the direct costs of labor and materials in making the new water service installation requested plus 15 percent for indirect costs and overhead. 
(Code 1969, § 32-5; Ord. No. 98-1069, § 1, 2-24-1998; Ord. No. 2012-1260, § 3, 11-13-12) 
Sec. 26-4-44. - Policy for extension of water service outside of city limits. 
(a)  It shall be the policy of the city that new water service outside of the city limits shall be restricted to those zones within the boundaries of the water system master plan (WSMP) for which reservoirs and delivery systems have been constructed, except when the city council shall determine that extraordinary circumstances exist and that the extension of municipal water service beyond the boundaries of the WSMP is in the best interests of the citizens of the city. However, this policy shall not prevent the city from entering into contractual agreements with bona fide water user associations or other large water users for the purpose of supplying water in bulk quantities pursuant to section 26-4-34. 
(b)  The boundaries of the WSMP shall be reviewed periodically and amended if necessary to ensure that ample amounts of serviceable land remain available for development. 
(c)  Future expansion by the city within the boundaries of the WSMP which is aimed at serving new areas or improving service to areas already serviced shall be allowed only after finding that a need for the expansion exits and, for new service, after the cost of providing new service is weighed against revenues to be derived from new customers. 
(d)  Future annexation action by the city shall be taken only after due consideration is given to the constraints of the water delivery system, in order to avoid annexing territory which lies beyond the boundaries of the WSMP. 
(e)  The board of public utility commissioners, in the reasonable exercise of its discretion, may grant a variance to the policy set forth in this section and may authorize water service to single-family residential units beyond the WSMP boundaries if the owner of the property to be served shall enter into a written agreement as required by section 26-4-45 subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  A variance shall not be granted if the elevation of the property to be served is greater than the elevation of the city water tank which serves the area. 
(2)  A variance shall not be granted if the distance from the premises to be served to a city water distribution line is greater than 600 feet. 
(f)  The board of public utility commissioners, in the granting of a variance pursuant to subsection (e) of this section, shall take the following factors, among others, into consideration: 
(1)  The proximity of the premises to be served to the city limits; 
(2)  Benefits which may result to the city such as increased revenues, better water circulation, and the like; 
(3)  The ability of the city to otherwise satisfy water service requirements of other city residents in the areas; 
(4)  Water pressure available and water pressure problems which may be encountered if the variance is granted; 
(5)  The impact upon other residents in the area to be served; and 
(6)  The density of development in the area for which service has been requested and the probability of future development in the area. 
(Code 1969, § 32-6.1) 
Sec. 26-4-45. - Conditions of water service to customers outside city limits. 
(a)  Service to customers located within the water system master plan boundary. If water service is requested to a piece of property that is located outside the city limits, but within the water system master plan boundary, and it has been determined by the city that it is either not possible or not desirable to annex the property at the time the request for service is received, the city manager may enter into an agreement with the owner of the property to provide water service to an individual single-family residential unit if the agreement is in writing and requires the owner of the property to be served to agree to the following as conditions of service: 
(1)  To pay a rate for service that is equal to 11/2 times the rate paid for such services by in-city customers. 
(2)  The property to be served shall be subject to a lien for payment of charges for any and all municipal services provided by the city to the property. 
(3)  To sign a petition requesting the annexation of the property served to the city at such time and under such terms and conditions as the city council directs. 
(4)  To comply with all applicable ordinances and rules and regulations of the city, including this division, pertaining to the providing of water and of any other utility service which may be provided to the property to be served. 
(5)  To furnish a bond or other security in such form as the city may require to guarantee payment for utility services. 
(6)  To comply with all federal, state, county, or local land subdivision regulations which may be applicable to the premises including those of the city. 
(7)  To pay in advance for any line extension required to serve the property pursuant to the rules and regulations of the city. 
(8)  To provide any and all easements, which shall be dedicated to the city and which be in such form as the city may require, as may be necessary to provide water service to the property to be served. 
(9)  That all lines, meters, and other facilities required to serve the premises shall meet or exceed city standards and specifications and shall be subject to city installation and inspection procedures. 
(10)  That there shall be no obligation on the part of the city to provide fire protection or other city services to the property to be served. 
(11)  That the user and owner of the property to be served shall be subject to the sections of this Code which pertain to conservation and curtailment of water service if a drought, lack of rainfall or other emergency occurs. 
(12)  That the water service is to be used for the single-family residential unit applied for only and that no connection will be made to or water provided to any other building or structure. 
(13)  That failure of the water user or of the owner of the property to be served to abide by the rules and regulations of the city shall be cause for termination of water service to the property. 
(14)  That subsections (a)(1) through (13) of this section shall be incorporated into the agreement as covenants, which shall attach to and run with the land to be served. 
(b)  Service to single-family residential units located outside the water system master plan. The city manager may enter into agreements to provide water service to single-family residential units located outside of the city limits and outside the water system master plan only if a variance has been granted for such water service by the board of public utility commissioners. Any such agreement shall be in writing, shall be approved by the city attorney, shall include all restrictions or conditions imposed by the board of public utility commissioners or the city council, shall require the owner of the property to be served, among other things, to agree to all of the conditions set forth in subsection (a) of this section and further require the owner of the property to be served to agree that: 
(1)  There may not be adequate water pressure available to serve the premises and the owner must, therefore, at the owner's expense, provide supplemental pumping, pressure and water storage facilities to be located on owner's premises. 
(2)  The supply of water available to serve the premises may be severely limited or interrupted from time to time. 
(3)  During a water shortage or emergency, water users within the city water system master plan shall be first served and water available for the owner in such case may be severely limited or restricted. 
(4)  Subsections (b)(1) through (3) of this section shall be incorporated into the agreement as covenants, which shall attach to and run with the land to be served. 
(Code 1969, § 32-6.3) 
Secs. 26-4-46-26-4-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SEWER RATES AND CONNECTION CHARGES 

Sec. 26-4-76. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Fixture unit value consists of the value assigned to each fixture unit. 
    Public or commercial sewer unit means any sewer unit other than a single residence sewer unit with fixture unit values of ten or less. 
    Sewer unit consists of a fixture or group of fixtures added to or connected with the city sewer system. 
    Single residence sewer unit means a sewer unit utilized by a single family with fixture unit values of 13 or less. 
(Code 1969, § 32-11) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-1-2. 
Sec. 26-4-77. - Fixture unit values assigned to fixture units. 
    Under this division, fixture unit values are assigned to the following fixture units as follows: 
Fixture Unit Fixture 
Unit 
Value One sand trap 8 One toilet or one clinic sink 6 One urinal 4 Any one of the following: sink, bathtub, laundry tub, washer, drain, floor drain, hopper, shower stall, slop sink or sump 2 One lavatory, one drinking fountain, one dental unit, or any other one fixture not specifically named in this subsection 1  
(Code 1969, § 32-12) 
Sec. 26-4-78. - Sewer unit connection charges generally. 
    Except as provided in the following subsections of this section, there is levied and assessed and the city shall charge and collect a minimum amount of $75.00 for each sewer unit, whether single residence or public or commercial, and additional amounts, whenever applicable, as follows: 
(1)  For any sewer unit added to a single residence sewer unit and used in connection therewith, $4.00 for each fixture unit value in excess of 13. 
(2)  For public or commercial sewer units, and except as provided in subsection (3) of this section, $7.50 for each fixture unit value in excess of ten and up to and including 100 fixture unit values; for fixture unit values in excess of 100 at the rate of $2.00 per fixture unit value. 
(3)  A minimum charge of $75.00 shall be made and collected for each trailer in a trailer court and for each living or sleeping unit in a duplex, triplex, apartment house, hotel or motel until ten of such minimum charges have been collected; thereafter, at the rate of $5.00 for each fixture unit value up to and including 150 fixture unit values, which total of 150 fixture unit values shall include all fixture unit values included in the ten minimum charge public or commercial sewer units. For fixture unit values in excess of 150 and in excess of the ten minimum charge public or commercial sewer units, at the rate of $2.00 for each fixture unit value. 
(Code 1969, § 32-13) 
Sec. 26-4-79. - Sewer unit connection charges when additional sewer facilities required. 
    Whenever additional sewer facilities are required to be furnished by the city before a proposed sewer unit can be placed in operation, the sewer unit charges to be collected by the city shall be levied and assessed by the city council. The city council shall make such levy and assessment by resolution and, in determining such charge, shall consider costs incurred or to be incurred by the city in providing additional sewer facilities. 
(Code 1969, § 32-14) 
Sec. 26-4-80. - Reserved. 
Sec. 26-4-81. - Report of connection of sewer units. 
    Every person who desires a sewer unit to be connected to the city sewer system shall, prior to the connection being made, report the proposed connection to the utility department. 
(Code 1969, § 32-16)

(2)  Measurement. Volume charges shall be measured by the amount of water furnished to the user by the city unless otherwise directed by the community development director. All users of the city sanitary sewer service whose total water service is not furnished by the city shall install city-approved water metering equipment to determine the proper wastewater volume charge. However, residential users who do not have a water meter may elect to pay a customer and capacity charge and a maximum volume charge based on 15,000 gallons of water usage per residential unit in lieu of meter installation. 
(3)  Base period. To ensure that wastewater service charges are equitable and reasonably related to the quantity of water billed to the customer and to ensure the quality of wastewater released by the customer into the city sewer system, the city manager shall: 
a.  Apply the volume charge specified in subsections (1) and (2) of this section for wastewater service to residential customers to the volume of water usage established during the customer's base period. The base period is defined as the average of the residential customer's water usage as shown by water billings to the residential customer for the months of December, January and February, computed effective with the first billing cycle for the month of March next following such base period billing. If customary reading of water meters is prevented by freezing conditions, accumulations of ice and snow, or similar adverse weather conditions, the city manager may, subject to disapproval by the city council, extend the base period until adequate and customary meter readings can be obtained at the termination of such adverse weather conditions, in which case the base period shall be computed to be effective at a reasonable time, not to exceed 30 days, beyond the date at which such meter reading may be accomplished. 
b.  Charge new residential customers referred to in subsections (1) and (2) of this section who have not established a base period history the sum of $18.60 per unit per month, including the capacity charge, for wastewater treatment service until a base period is established for such customer; however, the city manager may, in his discretion, establish a base period based upon two full months of water billing experience. 
c.  Make equitable adjustments to billings for commercial accounts, churches or other customers where satisfactory evidence is presented to the city manager that wastewater treatment service charges are not reasonably related to water billing of such customer. 
d.  Provide for administrative review and an appeal procedure to the board of public utility commissioners for customers who are aggrieved by the decisions of the city manager. 
(4)  Senior citizen rate. Senior citizens qualifying under the terms of section 26-4-89 shall pay the following rates for wastewater service: 
a.  The service charge shall be as follows:

(8)  Automatic adjustment. 
a.  Beginning in calendar year 2019, no later than October 15 of each year, the city manager shall: 
1.  Notify the city council that under this section, an automatic increase in wastewater service rates shall take place equal to 75 percent of the change in the Consumer Price Index (Department of Labor, Bureau of Labor Statistics, Consumer Price Index-All Urban Consumers, Water and Sewerage Maintenance (CPI) or its equivalent successor index) over the previous 12-month period ending the previous July 1 and what the proposed increase will be in the form of a percentage increase; and 
2.  Publish in a newspaper of general circulation and post in the city hall lobby and on the city's website a notice providing what the proposed increase would be and stating that the proposed increase will be effective on December 1 of that year unless the council, by affirmative action, adopts a motion canceling the proposed increase on or before November 15. 
b.  Unless the council, by affirmative action taken on or before November 15, cancels the implementation of the new proposed rates, the proposed increase based on the change in the CPI will take effect and shall be reflected on all wastewater service charges billed after December 1 of that year. 
(Code 1969, § 32-17; Ord. No. 2006-1177, § 2, 10-24-06; Ord. No. 2012-1260, § 3, 11-13-12; Ord. No. 2014-1271, §§ 2, 4, 11-11-14) 
Sec. 26-4-83. - Wastewater service rates and charges outside city limits. 
    A person who receives city sewer service outside the city limits shall be subject to this division. However, users of wastewater services shall pay for customer and capacity charges and for volume charges at 150 percent of the rates specified in section 26-4-82. 
(Code 1969, § 32-17.1) 
Sec. 26-4-84. - Standby wastewater service charge. 
(a)  As used in this section, the term "improved property" shall mean that buildings, structures or improvements have been made or placed upon such property that require connection to a public or private sewer system under this division or pursuant to the building or plumbing code. 
(b)  There is imposed a standby wastewater service charge upon all improved lots or land within the city for which wastewater service is available according to this section and which do not have a city sewer connection and city wastewater service charge. 
(c)  In order for such standby wastewater service charge to be levied, the improved property must adjoin a street, right-of-way or easement in which a city sewer line exists or shall otherwise be accessible to such and to which city sewer connections can be made to adequately service such property. 
(d)  The standby wastewater service charge shall be equivalent to the minimum customer and capacity charge per unit that could be served to such improved property based upon the improvements upon, the use made of, and the zoning of such property as determined by the city manager. Residential lots shall be charged the minimum residential unit rate specified in section 26-4-82. The appropriate commercial customer and capacity charge per month shall be based upon the actual number of apartment, commercial or industrial units upon such property as determined by the city manager. 
(e)  Charges under this section shall be imposed and billed monthly along with regular utility billing and shall become delinquent in the same manner as other wastewater utility accounts. 
(f)  The charges imposed in this section shall constitute a lien superior to all other liens, except general property taxes, upon the property so charged and shall be the personal responsibility of the owner thereof. The lien shall be enforced as provided in NMSA 1978, §§ 3-36-1-3-36-6. 
(g)  No charge shall be made pursuant to this section for service to any lot or land where, for technical or equitable reasons as determined by the city manager, wastewater service could not be reasonably used by such property. 
(h)  Any person aggrieved by a charge imposed under this section or by any determination made by the city manager may appeal to the board of public utility commissioners within 30 days after the imposition of such charge or such determination. 
(Code 1969, § 32-17.2) 
Sec. 26-4-85. - Billing; due date; delinquency. 
    Bills for sewer service shall be prepared in accordance with the rates and charges specified in this chapter and processed in accordance with the adopted rules and regulations for electric service (FEUS). Bills for sewer service shall be sent to each owner, or user, by mail, monthly. The amount of such bill shall be due and payable on the billing date specified on such bill; and if not paid on or before the 14th day after the billing date specified on the bill, the amount thereof shall thereafter be deemed delinquent and subject to the late charges and collection procedures specified in such rules and regulations and subject to the lien claim of the city as provided in section 26-4-39. 
(Code 1969, § 32-18; Ord. No. 98-1069, § 7, 2-24-1998) 
Sec. 26-4-86. - Payment of sewer connection charges. 
    Any charge to be collected by the city under the provisions of this division for connections with the city sewer system shall be due and payable at the time the connection is made, except as authorized elsewhere in this chapter for main line extension fees and impact fees. 
(Code 1969, § 32-19; Ord. No. 98-1069, § 8, 2-24-1998) 
Sec. 26-4-87. - Lien for unpaid sewer service or unit charges. 
    All unpaid sewer service or unit charges levied and collectible under this division are declared to be a lien upon the property benefited. Such lien shall not be enforceable until a declaration of the lien claim is filed with the county clerk. Such lien claim shall describe the property against which the lien is claimed, shall set forth the amount of the claim and shall state the date of connection or service. 
(Code 1969, § 32-20) 
Sec. 26-4-88. - Industrial rate schedules and cost recovery. 
(a)  The city council shall take necessary steps to establish a rate schedule for sewer service that ensures an equitable system of cost recovery. The purpose of this schedule shall be to ensure that industrial users shall pay for the costs incurred by the city in the construction, operation and maintenance of that portion of the wastewater treatment facilities which are related to industrial wastes. 
(b)  The cost recovery system shall satisfy the following conditions: 
(1)  The apportionment of costs must take into consideration the individual industrial user's contribution as related to the total waste load, taking into account the volume and strength of all discharges. 
(2)  The costs to be considered should include the following: 
a.  Amortization of the applicant's indebtedness for the cost of the treatment facilities (plant and interceptors). 
b.  Operation and maintenance of the treatment facilities. 
c.  Any additional costs necessary to ensure adequate treatment on a continuous basis. 
(3)  Substantial prepayment of the capital investment or other financial commitments will be required from each industry that contributes 30 percent or more of the total volume of strength of the waste load to be treated by the project. 
_____
(c)  The industrial charge, where the settleable solids concentration is greater than five mg/l or the COD is greater than 400, will be calculated with the following formula: 
IC = A + (K)(V)  [ 1 + a(SS - 5) 
_____
5 + b(COD - 400)

Where:
